headline: KEYCORP TO ACQUIRE MCDONALD FOR $653 MILLION
abstract: Keycorp to acquire McDonald & Co, investment banking and securities brokerage concern, for $653 million in stock (S)

headline: Philip Carret, Money Manager, Dies at 101
abstract: Philip L Carret, founder of one of country's first mutual funds, dies at age 101; photo (M)

headline: In Setback to Lockheed, Judge Delays Trial in Merger Challenge
abstract: Judge Emmet G Sullivan deals setback to Lockheed Martin Corp's proposed $12 billion acquisition of Northrop Grumman Corp, delaying trial in Government's challenge to transaction until Sept 8; says timetable means he probably will not rule until about Christmas (M)

headline: Business Travel; A subsidiary of British Airways is joining the ranks of no-frills airlines in Europe.
abstract: New subsidiary of British Airways called Go, based at Stansted Airport outside London, plans to join ranks of no-frills European airlines next month; Easyjet is so unhappy with Go's entry into no-frills field that it is taking British Airways to court, charging that parent company is 'cross-subsidizing' start-up; British Airways says there is nothing unlawful or anticompetitive about Go's operation; Seaport Hotel is set to open May 1 on Boston's waterfront across the street from World Trade Center; hotel is owned by Commonwealth Flats Development and John Drew Co; it is first new full-service luxury property in downtown Boston in more than decade; Albany International Airport is scheduled to open new $72 million passenger terminal and concourse June 1 (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: U.N. Experts Report Finding Mustard Gas in Iraqi Shells
abstract: Richard Butler, United Nations' chief arms inspector for Iraq, says experts found active mustard gas in artillery shells, raising new questions about over 500 similar shells still unaccounted for in Iraq; shells were found in 1996, but not tested until March, in face of Iraqi opposition; Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf again holds Iraq destroyed all barred weapons in 1991 (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Univision Makes Splash With a Spanish Accent
abstract: Univision stages 'upfront' presentations of its Spanish-language television programming for advertising agencies; drawing (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Palladium rises 3.7 percent on increased anxiety over export delays from Russia, leading producer; June contracts rise $10.45, to $296.55 an ounce, highest since March 1980; graph; chart (S)

headline: Signs of Shift in Senate Stance on Bank Law
abstract: Signs of shift in attitude in US Senate favor passage of bill that would remove last remaining barriers to allowing banks, securities firms and insurance companies to merge into huge financial services companies; Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, chairman of Senate Banking Committee, has scheduled committee hearings on June 17, first step toward floor consideration; D'Amato has put measure on fast track and then followed it up by having group of financial executives meet with Senate majority leader Trent Lott, who says he will set aside time for debate; House bill would make Federal Reserve the main regulator; Treas Sec Robert Rubin prefers structure that would make Comptroller of the Currency, division of Treasury, top regulator; Rubin says he will recommend Presidential veto of current measure (M)

headline: Two Makers Of Phone Gear Join Forces
abstract: Tellabs Inc is expected to announce acquisition of Ciena Corp for $7.3 billion in stock; deal illustrates that forces driving consolidation in telecommunications are affecting makers of arcanne equipment as well as companies that actually sell services to consumers; companies like Tellabs and Ciena are looking to bulk up to compete against much larger rivals (M)

headline: Arthur F. Mathews, 60, Lawyer And Expert in Securities Crime
abstract: Arthur F Mathews, lawyer and expert in securities crime, dies at age 60 (S)

headline: Questions for the President: Give and Take With China's Students
abstract: Excerpts from question-and-answer session between Pres Clinton and students at Beijing University; photos (L)

headline: Junta Shows New Name Of Brutality To Burmese
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was living under house arrest when she received Nobel Peace Prize in 1991 for advocating peaceful democratic change in Myanmar; military junta lifted her house arrest in July 1995, but has kept her cordoned off from popular support as well as from her family (M)

headline: Gold Breaks Its Promise to Miners of Lesotho
abstract: Mountain kindgom of Lesotho, where people depend on incomes from South African gold mines, has been hurt by layoffs caused by sinking price of gold; number of gold miners in South Africa has fallen, from 500,000 in mid-1980's to 300,000, and pessimists expect total to hit 250,000 by end of 1998--of which perhaps 80,000 will be from Lesotho; photo; maps (M)

headline: Prices Off Sharply on New Signs The Economy Remains Strong
abstract: US bond prices drop sharply; 30-year bond falls 18/32, to price of 104 11/32; yield rises to 5.82 percent, from 5.78 percent on June 3; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO BUY MEAD DISTRIBUTION UNIT
abstract: International Paper Co to acquire Mead Corp's Zellerbach distribution business for $263 million (S)

headline: Merging German Banks Report a Profit Rise
abstract: Bayerische Vereinsbank AG and Bayerische Hypotheken und Wechsel Bank, which are merging to form Germany's second-largest bank, report pro forma 1997 profit of 1.705 billion marks ($927 million), up 9 percent from 1.561 billion marks a year ago; merger, which will create Bayerische Hypotheken und Vereinsbank AG, is expected to be completed in September (S)

headline: Long Haymes Wins Champion Business
abstract: Champion Products division of Sara Lee Corp names Long Haymes Carr to handle creative portion of its account (S)

headline: PETERSEN COMPANIES TO BUY 2 STEREOPHILE MAGAZINES
abstract: Petersen Companies agrees to acquire two magazines, Stereophile and Stereophile Guide to Home Theatre, from Stereophile Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: BankBoston Unit Sale
abstract: BankBoston Corp is selling is document custody business to Banc One Corp to free up capital for use in other ventures (S)

headline: DAIMLER-BENZ AND CHRYSLER REVISE RATIO FOR STOCK SWAP
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG and Chrysler Corp revise ratio for their $39 billion stock swap to account for additional shares to be issued by both companies before merger is completed (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The National Association of Realtors reports on sales of existing homes in March; analysts expect an annual rate of 4.54 million, down about 180,000 from February.

headline: Italian Town Buries 90 After Mudslide
abstract: Outdoor funeral is held in Sarno, Italy, for 90 victims of mudslides caused by torrential rains; photo; map (M)

headline: Concern About Rate Rise Cuts the Size of a Dow Rally
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 36.37 points, to 9,091.52; Standard & Poor's 500 falls 1.50 points, to 1,106.64, and Nasdaq index falls 16.30 points, to 1,848.07; graph; chart (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Kathy Kayse, Midwest advertising manager at Time magazine, Chicago, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc., was named publisher at a sibling magazine, Your Company, New York, succeeding Geoff Dodge, who continues as publisher of the sibling Money magazine.

headline: 6,000 G.M. WORKERS AT MICHIGAN PLANT JOIN AUTO STRIKE
abstract: Nearly 6,000 workers go on strike at General Motors factory in Flint, Mich, joining walkout at nearby plant in increasingly bitter fight that could close down virtually all of GM's North American production within days; photos; company has already closed seven plants and laid off 18,600 workers for lack of parts from initial strike at metal-stamping plant in Flint; other plants are expected to quickly run out of spark plugs, speedometers and other parts made at site of latest walkout; issue is company's effort to shift production tasks to other factories in US and abroad; metal-stamping workers agreed two years ago to give up some of their generous benefits in exchange for new investment, which union says has not been made; company has shifted some truck parts metal-stamping equipment to Ohio after giving up plans for production in Ontario because of objections from Canadian union; GM stamping operations are very inefficient, particularly in Flint, compared with rival automakers; new pickup is key to profits: GM earns up to half of worldwide profits from North American sales of full-size pickups and sport-utility vehicles (M)

headline: Higher VW Bid for Rolls-Royce Is Seen
abstract: German newspapers report that Volkswagen AG will raise its bid for Rolls-Royce to as much as 1.7 billion marks ($950 million) now that BMW has surpassed its first offer; battle for Rolls-Royce reflects larger fight in German car industry, where BMW, VW and Daimler-Benz are all trying to expand to cover whole range of vehicles from low-priced city cars to top-luxury segment (M)

headline: 4 Colombians Pledge Change but Carry Lots of Old Baggage
abstract: Change has become byword of four candidates who hope to replace Colombian Pres Ernesto Samper in coming elections; all four have past associations that undermine their promise to transform country; candidates are Andres Pastrana, Horacio Serpa, Noemi Sanin and Harold Bedoya (M)

headline: New Chief Executive For Link Exchange
abstract: Link Exchange Inc, an Internet advertising network, names Mark Bozzini to new position of chief executive (S)

headline: France Agrees to Sale Of More of Bank's Assets
abstract: French Government, bowing to pressure from European Union, will double amount of assets that Credit Lyonnais, state-owned bank, must sell to gain approval of $16.6 million Government bailout (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Agriculture Department reports winter wheat crop is in good shape as it emerges from dormancy; wheat for July delivery falls 4.25 cents, to $3.0975 a bushel, on Chicago Board of Trade; graph; chart (S)

headline: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS: WWW.GIRLTECH.COM; Girl Tech: Smart Place To Gather
abstract: Review of Web sites for young girls, including Girl Tech; photo (S)

headline: Partners Face S.E.C. Inquiry At Andersen
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commision says Arthur Andersen LLP partners Jeffrey M Steinberg and John Geron violated securities laws when they advised Spectrum Information Technologies Inc on accounting policies over the phone that resulted in company reporting profits when it really had losses; if allegations are upheld, case would greatly increase auditors' responsibility for quarterly financial reports that companies make during the year that are not audited, but are heavily relied on by investors and analysts; Arthur Andersen spokesman says accounting firm stands behind actions of two partners; Linda Chatman Thomsen, assistant enforcement director at commission, says partners' advice was wrong and resulted in false financial information (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Attacks Microsoft In 2 Broad Antitrust Suits  The Federal Government and 20 state Attorneys General filed two broad, aggressive antitrust suits against Microsoft, in the Government's most concerted attack on a company in a generation.    The suits, announced by Attorney General Janet Reno, accuse the company, the world's largest software producer, of leveraging its monopoly in personal-computer operating systems to win control of other software, notably the browsers used for access to the World Wide Web. [Page A1.]

headline: Ethiopians and Eritreans Resume Border Battle
abstract: Heavy fighting breaks out between Ethiopian and Eritrean troops along two countries' border, dealing serious blow to diplomatic efforts to avert full-scale war between former allies; map (M)

headline: Assembly Passes Prudential Bill
abstract: New Jersey Assembly, 73-0, approves legislation that would enable Prudential Insurance Co of America to convert from mutual company, owned by policyholders, to publicly traded one; bill provides framework for compensating Prudential's 11 million policyholders in form of stock (S)

headline: Business Travel; U S Airways' low-fare Metro Jet service is an effort to beat Southwest Airlines at its own game.
abstract: US Airways' low-fare Metro Jet service is effort to beat Southwest Airlines at its own game; Metro Jet is competing with Southwest on many similar routes; Laptop Lane, new company operating office centers at airports, is preparing to open at Seattle-Tacoma Airport on June 25; nearly two-thirds of member agencies responding to recent survey by American Society of Travel Agents are charging fees for their services; in 1995 survey, number was just 25 percent; Super Shuttle, door-to-door van service that began carrying passengers last month on shared rides between Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport and LaGuardia Airport, plans to start serving Newark International Airport on June 17 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Ziff-Davis is pushing its 24-hour cable television network on computing in a three-front campaign.
abstract: Ziff Davis has introduced 24-hour cable television network focused on computing and the Internet and is counting on multimillion-dollar advertising campaign to market it; Ziff-Davis, which is 70 percent owned by Softbank Corp, introduced network, ZDTV, last month; Ziff-Davis is investing $100 million in network over two-year period, ending early next year; ad campaign was developed by Blazing Paradigm (M)

headline: Allied Signal Buys 2 Concerns
abstract: Allied Signal Inc says it will acquire Web Technologies Inc and Pharmaceutical Fine Chemicals SA; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Talks Indicate Japan's Links With Russians Are Improving
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto and Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin begin two-day meeting in effort to improve economic cooperation and work toward peace treaty that will finally mark end to territorial disputes dating from World War II; meeting takes place in Japanese resort town of Kawana (M)

headline: Looking for Compromise, South Africa Postpones Botha Trial
abstract: Trial of former South African Pres P W Botha is postponed for day while his lawyers and Truth and Reconciliation Commission negotiate to avoid embarrassing and politically divisive proceedings; 82-year-old Botha faces contempt charges for ignoring subpoenas to testify about anti-apartheid policies (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AIRGAS INC., Radnor, Pa., a distributor of industrial, medical and specialty gases, said that it would take a pretax charge of $25 million in its fourth quarter and that it expected its operating profit to fall short of analysts' estimates as it reorganizes and sells off several businesses.    COMPAQ COMPUTER CORP., Houston, bought a minority stake in the closely held Inex Corp., Toronto, a provider of Internet commerce applications software, for an undisclosed price.    BEST BUY CO., Eden Prairie, Minn., a consumer electronics retailer, will split its shares 2 for 1, payable May 26 to shareholders of record on May 11.

headline: Sneaking U.S. Jets to Iran: The Canadian Route
abstract: Joint investigation by New York Times and CBS News finds that significant portion of American-made weapons, military jets and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and Canadian Govt's decision not to support American embargo against Iran; in one such deal, Reza Akrami, Iranian living in Vancouver, tried to arrange delivery of American-made jets and military parts, including electronics to guide antiaircraft missiles; deal was arranged with a Dr Afshar, in San Francisco; deal never came off, because 'Dr Afshar' was undercover agent for United States Govt posing as arms dealer bent on evading American embargo; Akrami and an associate are arrested in Vancouver and are being held pending extradition to United States; they face charges of conspiring to smuggle sophisticated military parts to Iran; other Iranian arms deals involving Canada noted; photo of Akrami (L)

headline: BMW to Invest More In Sport Utility Area
abstract: Bayerische Motoren Werke AG will invest total of $600 million to develop new sports utility vehicle in US; BMW will hire 1,000 more workers and invest $400 million in its Spartanburg, SC, plant in next two years to meet growing US demand for sport utility vehicles (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Cinderella, Italy Preps For Euro Ball; But as Midnight Nears, Some Business Sectors Brace for Pain
abstract: President of Italian central bank warns that next few years will be 'purgatory' for Italians as economy adjusts to European demands and adapts to single new euro currency; Italian businessmen are preparing for euro in different ways; Italian companies with markets overseas welcome euro, which will lift burden of converting lira to dozen different currencies; but Italian retail trade fears that converting cash registers and consumer behavior to new money will be costly; contrasts in expectations are being felt throughout Europe, but they are starkest in Italy, as are potential gains and wrenching costs; photos; graphs; map (L)

headline: Credit Lyonnais Shares Fall Sharply
abstract: Shares in French state-owned bank Credit Lyonnais fall by their daily-allowable limit of 10 percent on Paris Stock Exchange after threat from European Union Commission that bank may be forced to repay 120 billion francs ($20 billion) in state aid; graph (S)

headline: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA STRUCTURING CHARGE IS PLANNED
abstract: Scientific-Atlanta Inc to cut 275 jobs in Oct and take structuring charge of $60 million to $75 million; does not expect expense to affect fourth-quarter operating earnings; will also record $100 million gain to adjust value of stock it owns (S)9

headline: PHYMATRIX TO EXPLORE STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES
abstract: Phymatrix Corp intends to explore strategic alternatives for the company, including possibilities of merging, selling assets or entering other business combinations; chairman-chief executive Dr Abraham D Gosman comments (S)

headline: A $276 MILLION BUYOUT OF PCA INTERNATIONAL IS PLANNED
abstract: Senior managers of portrait-photography chain PCA International Inc and investment firm Jupiter Partners LP agree to acquire between 95 percent and 97 percent of PCA for $276 million, including assumed debt (S)

headline: Pure Plays Are Hard To Find
abstract: Investing in biotechnology stocks through mutual funds discussed; only two funds invest exclusively in such stocks, but other health care funds also invest in biotech shares; table; photo (M)

headline: WET SEAL TO BUY 83 BRITCHES GREAT OUTDOOR STORES
abstract: Wet Seal Inc to purchase about 83 Britches Great Outdoor stores for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: A High-Tech Rescue For Out-of-Print Books
abstract: Lightning Print, division of Ingram, displays new high-tech system for on-demand printing of out-of-print books; charges publisher $100 to $150 to set book up in digital library and $5 a copy to print (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bank of Japan Continues Rescue Effort for the Yen  The dollar tumbled against the yen in Asian trading as the Bank of Japan sold dollars for a second day. Traders estimated that the central bank sold several billions of dollars yesterday, after selling more than $1 billion on Thursday.

headline: Publisher Moving To Geocities
abstract: Thomas R Evans, who has held top publishing titles at three magazines owned by Mortimer B Zuckerman, says he will leave to join Internet company Geocities as chief executive; he will succeed David Bohnet, founder, who will continue as chairman; Evans has been president and publisher of US News and World Report and Fast Company magazines as well as president of Atlantic Monthly (S)

headline: Microsoft Fight Will Be Waged On Wide Front
abstract: Government's antitrust case against Microsoft Corp is shaping up as high-decibel, often nasty battle to sway public opinion as well as courts; company finds itself facing unusually coherent alliance of Federal and state governments, which will use vast array of tools, including: talk-show appearances; documents that cast it as arrogant monopolist; testimonials from distinguished academics, and scarcely veiled threats of even further charges; debate over whether to try to block shipment of Windows 98, latest version of company's operating system, tested ability of Government and states to cooperate and also illustrated mixture of economic, legal and public relations considerations in landmark antitrust case; Justice Department determined, and states eventually agreed, that trying to block Windows 98 could prove to be misstep for both legal and public relations reasons; felt that since case being made in name of consumer choice there would be little justification in blocking new product that millions of consumers undoubtedly want to buy; Government and states are arguing that case against Microsoft is about nation's economic future (M)

headline: Different Problems in Kosovo
abstract: NATO faces significantly different risks and problems with the violence in Kosovo than it did in Bosnia, alliance officials say. Page A10.

headline: MEXICAN CONGLOMERATE BUYS AUTHENTIC SPECIALTY FOODS
abstract: Authentic Specialty Foods Inc to be acquired by Mexican conglomerate Desc SA for $136.4 million (S)

headline: Learning To Live With Volatility
abstract: Profiles of Kendrick Kam and Kevin Landis, co-managers of Firsthand Technology Value Fund of San Jose, Calif; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Oil prices rise 6.4 percent more after OPEC ministers say they must cut output further and United Nations inspector says Iraq had put nerve gas on warheads; August contracts rise 87 cents a barrel, to $14.52; chart; graphs (S)

headline: Treasuries Lose Early Gains As Note Auction Falls Short
abstract: US Treasury securities lose gains and end mixed; 30-year bond slips 8/32, to price of 106 22/32; yield rises to 5.66 percent, from 5.64 percent on June 23; graphs on Freddie Mac yields and 5-year Treasury notes; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Germany Pardons en Masse Thousands Persecuted by Nazis
abstract: German parliament approves mass pardon of hundreds of thousands of people punished unjustly by Nazi courts, military tribunals and medical panels; symbolic gesture offers moral rehabilitation for resistance fighters, homosexuals, deserters and others, as well as some 350,000 disabled people who were forced to undergo sterilization during Nazi era (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks End Volatile Week Lower in Waves of Selling  Stock prices fell again yesterday as Wall Street ended a wild week just the way it began: with waves of large-scale selling. Blue-chip issues were hit the hardest and pulled down the Dow Jones industrial average by 100.14 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 8,712.87. Broader stock indexes also dropped.

headline: An Unusual Window Into Vanguard
abstract: Vanguard Group, reorganizing its mutual funds into Delaware business trusts, is disclosing to shareholders holdings of senior chairman John C Bogle, chief executive John J Brennan and its outside directors in group's funds; Bogle, who touts index funds, keeps 38.4 percent of his holdings in such funds; table (M)

headline: Producer Prices Rose in May Because of Higher Drug Costs
abstract: Labor Department reports producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, matching April's increase; prices fell at annual rate of 1.6 percent during year's first five months; prescription drug prices increased by record 10.7 percent in May, almost entirely because of 600 percent price increase for 'minor tranquilizers'; Producer Price Index's core rate rose 1 percent in May, unchanged from April's increase; Commerce Department reports business inventories of unsold goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent in April, below March's increase of six-tenths of 1 percent and slowest gain in three months; business sales fell one-tenth in April; graph on producer prices (M)

headline: Japanese Move to Broaden Military Links to the U.S.
abstract: Japanese Government offers bill to broaden military ties with United States and let it offer logistical support to American forces in Japan in event of crisis; measure brings Japan step closer to playing larger security role in region; Sec State Madeleine K Albright and Min Keizo Obuchi sign related accord that underscores expanded support from Japan (M)

headline: Magazines Bowing to Demands for Star Treatment
abstract: Celebrities are gaining control over way their images are presented by magazines, which are doing their best to accommodate them; as publications have become desperate to sell their covers in intensely competitive marketplace, stars and their publicists have grown more powerful; result has been increasingly cozy, complicated relationship between two sides that publicists say is good business, but which many editors believe has spun out of control; concessions that might have been out of question few years ago are now common, and publicists say they have learned not only to divvy up access to stars, but also how to insure that articles convey right message; editors of leading magazines comment; photos (L)

headline: DIARY
abstract: TRADE  Deficit at a Record  The nation's monthly trade deficit surged to $13 billion in March, the deepest since the Commerce Department adopted its current measurement system in 1992 and considerably more than economists had expected. The deficit in February was $12.2 billion. The new figures provided clear evidence of the impact on the United States -- both good and bad -- of Asia's mounting economic woes. Growth in the American economy, which had been threatening to overheat, was restrained. But at the same time, United States exports remained weak, hurting many manufacturers and farmers, and imports surged, a trend that does not bode well for the long term.    INTEREST RATES  No Increase, for Now  The Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee declined once again to increase short-term interest rates, apparently viewing the threat of inflation as remote and believing that any American rate increase could worsen the economic situation in Asia. Underlying the benign view of inflation are a number of recent indicators, including a 2.3 percent decline in new housing starts last month, to an annual rate of 1.538 million units. Many analysts had expected a small gain. Minutes of the Fed's March 31 meeting show that it saw a risk of inflation but decided to hold rates steady because of Asia's malaise.    MARKETS  Commodity Index Skids  The Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities skidded to its lowest level in more than four years, dropping to 219.27 on Tuesday and ending the week at 219.18. Futures prices for copper, silver, oil, nickel, wheat and other commodities have been in a long-term decline that has been aggravated in recent days by Indonesia's political turmoil and -- see a pattern here? -- the Asian economic collapse. Stock and bond markets were little changed for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week at 9,144.44, up 48.44. But technology stocks were battered, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 41.77, to close at 1,805, its weakest level in more than six weeks.    TOBACCO  A Pipe Dream?  Anti-smoking legislation hit a potentially serious snag in the Senate, and further action was postponed until next month, sending President Clinton; Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and other Senate leaders who want to deter teen-agers' smoking back to the drafting table. Just as it appeared a consensus was forming to increase the Federal tax on cigarettes by $1.10 a pack while giving tobacco companies some protection against lawsuits, an unusual coalition of senators formed. Some want to kill the legislation, while others advocate the toughest possible anti-smoking measure. ''We are making a deal with the Devil,'' said Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, who opposes any limit on the companies' legal liability.    SOCIAL SECURITY  A Market-Based Proposal  The National Commission on Retirement Policy, which includes members of Congress from both parties, proposed a sweeping overhaul of the Social Security system, calling for the establishment of personal investment accounts and a gradual increase in the retirement age, to 70, to make up for a cash shortfall expected when 77 million baby boomers become eligible for Social Security benefits. ''The goal of this is to have people more involved in their own savings,'' said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, a leader of the group, which includes lawmakers, economists, pension-system experts and business executives. The report says the changes would keep Social Security solvent for at least 75 years without raising taxes. Some liberals, however, oppose any plan that does not offer guaranteed benefits.    DEALS  A Merger Epidemic  What would once have been a big deal seems today to be business as usual. Seagram, accelerating its shift from beverages and spirits into an entertainment powerhouse, agreed to buy Polygram, one of the world's largest music companies, for $10.6 billion in cash and stock; to raise money for the acquisition, Seagram is shedding its Tropicana juice business. . . . Pearson, Britain's largest publisher, and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas investment firm, agreed to buy most of Simon & Schuster's operations from Viacom for $4.6 billion in cash. . . . Office Depot said it would acquire Viking Office Products in a $3 billion stock swap. . . . Dillard's said it would acquire Mercantile Stores, a Midwest retailer, for $2.9 billion in cash. . . . Fortis, a Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance group, agreed to acquire Generale de Banque, Belgium's largest, for $11.1 billion. . . . Francois Pinault, the French investor who bought 29.1 percent of Christie's earlier this month, said he would buy the rest in a deal that values the international auction house at $1.2 billion. . . . Royal Ahold extended its reach into the American supermarket business with a $2.6 billion deal for Giant Food Inc.    VIAGRA  Worldwide Demand  Viagra, intended to help impotent men, has yet to pass clinical tests in Taiwan, but it is already selling for $59 on the black market there. In Taipei, a nurse displayed a bag of the medication. In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration reported on Friday that Pfizer Inc. had said that six patients taking the drug had died, although it was unknown if Viagra played any role in the deaths. A spokeswoman for the F.D.A. said the agency was investigating but continued to believe the drug was safe and effective and had asked Pfizer to provide more information to patients on the proper use of the drug. Pfizer's stock fell $3.69, to $105.44.

headline: Russia's 'A List' Begs Off Attending Czar's Funeral
abstract: Preparations for July burial in St Petersburg of Czar Nicholas II and his family is quietly scaled back because Pres Boris N Yeltsin, Russian Orthodox Patriarch Aleksy II and members of Czar's own Romanov family have decided not to attend; burial, which was supposed to provide moment of national reconciliation, instead reopens debates about authenticity of bones and about Czar's proper place in history; photos (M)

headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE ISRAELI ARABS: Too Israeli an Arab, and Vice Versa
abstract: Series, Israel at 50, on ethnic and cultural diversity that has evolved in half-century since founding as Jewish state; fate has left many Israeli Arabs between two worlds--in which they are second-class citizens among Israelis and Israelis among Arabs; actress Salwa Nakkara, Arab born and raised in Israel, comments (M)

headline: AT&T IS NEAR DEAL FOR NO. 2 COMPANY IN CABLE TV IN U.S.
abstract: AT&T Corp nears deal on acquiring Telecommunications Inc, nation's second-largest cable television operator, in deal that could sharply expand AT&T's ability to provide Internet access and local phone service; seeks to acquire only TCI's cable properties, not its programming unit, Liberty Media, which already trades as separate stock; deal would give AT&T direct access to homes for first time since it spun off local phone operations in 1984 (M)

headline: RADIO UNICA ADDING TO SPANISH-LANGUAGE STATIONS
abstract: Radio Unica Corp to buy Los Angeles radio station KBLA-AM from Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc for $21 million (S)

headline: For Financial Advisers, A Pledge on Payments
abstract: National Association of Personal Financial Advisors, group of some 600 fee-only advisers, seeks to popularize client-protection pledge that would make clear source of adviser's compensation and reveal any conflicts of interest; oath includes promise that adviser does not get compensation from another party for referring clients; oath may rankle other advisers, whose income comes from sales commissions, other sources (M)

headline: Patents; An inventor looks back on pleasures and on lessons learned.
abstract: Jacob Rabinow receives Lifetime Achievement Award for invention from Lemelson-MIT Awards Program; Rabinow received 120 United States patents over course of his 88 years; many models for Rabinow's inventions are on display at National Institute of Standards and Technology, where he worked for many years; Lemelson-MIT Awards Program also announces recipient of its $500,000 annual award, which goes to Prof Robert S Langer for his pioneering work in tissue engineering and drug delivery; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHARMERICA INC., Tampa, Fla., agreed to acquire National Institutional Pharmaceutical Services Inc., Owings Mills, Md., a unit of Integrated Health Services Inc., for undisclosed terms.

headline: Compressed Data; Web Imitator Displeases Maker of Etch a Sketch
abstract: Ohio Art Co, maker of Etch a Sketch, battles alleged trademark infringement by Web-A-Sketch Web site, developed by Alan Watts, which lets would-be artists make geometric drawings in cyberspace; drawing (S)

headline: Chief Guard Is Killed in Vatican Along With Wife and a 2d Man
abstract: Commander of Vatican's Swiss Guards, his wife and younger Swiss guard are shot and killed in Vatican just hours after he was appointed to post; Vatican suspects murder-suicide; says Col Alois Estermann, wife Gladys Meza Romero and Vice Cpl Cedrich Tornay were shot in Estermann's apartment in Guards' barracks with firearm, which was found under Tornay's body; slayings are first in Vatican in decades, and its motives remain unknown; Vatican launches probe; Estermann's tenure at Vatican for past 18 years noted; was near Pope John Paul II during assassination attempt in 1981, and has made more than 30 trips abroad with Pontiff as part of security detail; photo; map (M)

headline: 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money
abstract: EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers.    To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age.

headline: Some Black Americans Find Only a Chill in South Africa
abstract: Many black Americans who moved to South Africa with missionary zeal to contribute in building prosperous black nation after collapse of apartheid have been greeted with resentment from black South Africans, and are discovering that, with exception of skin color, they share little by way of language, culture or background; black South Africans say Americans are patronizing, overbearing and clannish, believe they are owed something because of efforts to support anti-apartheid boycotts, and are taking their jobs away; say Americans have no real stake in success of country and should leave it alone to decide its future; some black Americans say they have been lied to, misled and abused by South Africans, ostensibly out of jealousy and ignorance; estimated 1,000 currently work in South Africa, many as representatives of 300 companies that have established footholds there; others work for nonprofit groups as freelancers; photos (M)

headline: Rome Journal; 3-Step Justice System: Conviction, Appeal, Escape
abstract: Italy's notoriously inefficient, slow judicial system is target of new ridicule following escape of Mafia boss convicted of drug trafficking; Pasquale Cuntrera was released on technicality and managed to evade police monitors and escape in his wheelchair; photo; fax on release lay on prosecutor's desk for five days, depriving authorities of chance to re-arrest Cuntrera, who is now being sough as far away as South America; in second recent case, 79-year-old Licio Gelli disappeared from Tuscan villa just before sentencing in bank fraud case (Rome Journal) (S)

headline: Integrated Electrical Deals
abstract: Integrated Electrical Services Inc agrees to acquire nine electrical contracting and maintenance companies with combined 1997 revenues of $140 million (S)

headline: Jacob Katz, 93, Social Historian of the Jews
abstract: Jacob Katz, internationally known authority on history of Jewish people, dies at age 93 (M)

headline: I.M.F.'s Latest Aid Plan for Indonesia Calls for Billions More
abstract: The International Monetary Fund reached an agreement today that paves the way for resuming aid to Indonesia for the first time since President Suharto resigned last month, but it warned that economic conditions have worsened so quickly that the country will need billions more in emergency aid.    In announcing an economic reform plan today, the fourth since Indonesia's economic crisis began in October, fund officials predicted that the country's economy would shrink more than 10 percent this year. Independent economists expect the recession to be much worse, and the World Bank predicted earlier this week that by the end of the year 40 percent of the population would fall below the poverty line, a huge setback for a nation that a year ago seemed to be a model for developing nations.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Franklin Electronics Publishers to DiMassimo Inc to handle advertising for Rex PC Companion, which had been handled by Della Femina/Jeary & Partners; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Schwab on Line in Britain
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp says its Charles Schwab Europe unit has begun on-line investing service in Britain (S)

headline: COKE EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER BEVERAGE SALES TO RISE 10%
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it expected sales of its beverages to rise as much as 10 percent in the second quarter. Coca-Cola, which is based in Atlanta, said second-quarter case volume, an important measure of the company's underlying growth, was expected to rise up to 8 percent in the United States, up to 11 percent in both Latin America and Europe, up to 17 percent in Africa and as much as 8 percent in the Middle and Far East. Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, had 1997 revenue of $18.86 billion. Its stock rose 75 cents, to $84.875.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Europe Takes To the Road In a Small Way; Despite Hefty Price Tags, Micro-Cars Gain a Toehold
abstract: European's love of small cars has given rise to new type of vehicle, the micro-car; these cars have only one forward gear, seat two people but can cost as much as conventional cars--upwards of $9,000; so far few have been made, but they are starting to crop up throughout Europe; top manufacturers like Microcar and Aixam, both of France, expect sales to double by 2000 for voiturettes, which get about 68 miles a gallon; European manufacturers of conventional cars, like Renault in France and Volkswagen in Germany and Fiat in Italy, have poured billions of dollars into small-car development in recent years, paying little note to voiturettes; Mercedes-Benz, unit of Daimler-Benz, has become first large auto maker to enter two-seater market with fully equipped model called Smart Car, which it developed with Swiss conglomerate SMH; chart; photo (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises sharply against dollar; graphs; table (S)

headline: War Is the Wrong Model
abstract: Miriam Singer Breyer letter opposes May 24 article on corporate team-building program run by former Army Rangers (S)

headline: Ulster's Fire-and-Brimstone Loyalist Preaches 'No!'
abstract: Article profiles Rev Ian Paisley, Northern Ireland's fire-and-brimstone Protestant loyalist, who sternly opposes peace agreement aimed at ending sectarisn violence in British province; he is embodiment of generations of resentments and resistance to compromise that have galvanized opposing sides as people of Northern Ireland and Irish Republic prepare to vote on accord on May 22; photo (M)

headline: Real Proposal, But Bent Knee Was Virtual
abstract: Mark Saperstein proposes to Sandy McElroy with a job posting on the Internet for a 'Lawfully Wedded Wife'; she accepts via voice mail (M)

headline: Macedonia's Albanians Are Restive
abstract: Nationalism is spilling with alarming speed into civil life of Macedonian capital of Skopje, where Albanian and nationalist militants are threat to Government; Macedonia, one of most tolerant of five states carved out of former Yugoslavia, has been unable to stanch ideological mutations that lead to ethnic conflict; state, while incorporating its ethnic Albanian minority into Government, has also sought to bolster its legitimacy by mythologizing Macedonian culture; Government has claimed, despite dubious historical evidence, that Alexander the Great is forefather of modern nation and has turned Macedonian Orthodox Church into official creed; ethnic Albanians, who are mostly Muslims, feel they can never be full members of state; map; photo (M)

headline: Consumer Debt Up Again
abstract: Federal Reserve reports US consumer borrowing rose $5.5 billion in April, to $1.250 trillion (S)

headline: Media Talk; Men's Journal Encounters Problems on Mount Rainier
abstract: Latest issue of Men's Journal, with article touting minimal risks involved in climbing Mount Rainier, hit newsstands days before death of climber in avalanche and stranding of two climbers in whiteout; editor David Willey defends article; Mount Rainer National Park superintendent John Krambrink cites risks; photo (S)

headline: With Orders Slowing, Chip Maker Will Cut Jobs
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp, facing slowdown in computer chip orders, will cut 1,400 jobs worldwide, or about 10 percent of its employees, through combination of layoffs and attrition; National says cuts will center primarily on company's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES GROUP INC., Fort Worth, said it might sell some assets, including its natural gas gathering and processing operations, to reduce debt from its $3.5 billion acquisition of Norcen Energy Resources Ltd.    ALLIANCE IMAGING INC., Anaheim, Calif., a provider of outsourced radiology services, agreed to buy U.S. Diagnostic Inc.'s Medical Diagnostics unit for $29.6 million in cash and $6 million in assumed debt.

headline: How Windsor II Saw A Treasure in Chrysler
abstract: Article on how James B Barrows, manager of Vanguard Windsor II and collector of vintage automobiles, made a killing for the fund by accumulating shares of Chrysler Corp prior to merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler; Barrows comments; graph (M)

headline: Irish Feel Fierce Crosswinds as Fateful Vote Nears
abstract: Irish rock group U2 and its leader, Bono, stage concert in Belfast, Northern Ireland, in support of peace agreement which faces referendum on May 22; bring together for first time longtime adversaries, Catholic leader John Hume and Protestant leader David Trimble; proponents of agreement press efforts to explain it to voters, while opponents play on voters' fears and suspicions by portraying referendum as moral decision that strikes at very soul of their religious, political and class identities; photo (L)

headline: Siemens Profit News Puts Outlook in Doubt
abstract: German electronics giant Siemens AG posts weaker-than-expected profit growth in first half of its fiscal year, startling analysts; Siemens says net income rose 10 percent, to 1.19 billion marks ($665.1 million)--well below forecasts of 1.28 billion marks; sales rose 17 percent, to 52.1 billion marks ($29.1 million) (S)

headline: Bill Sale Is Only Item on Treasury Schedule
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.02 percent and a six-month bill was 5.15 percent.

headline: Best Habitat For a Mouse
abstract: Q.  I teach in a children's computer lab with 20 Macintoshes. Hard-surfaced mouse pads show lots of dirt and grease; with cloth-covered ones, it seems that the mice operate smoothly longer and collect less debris. Is the rougher surface better?    A.  Rough, but not too rough, is best for the mouse. Good pads have a slight texture so the mouse ball can grip the surface and track smoothly. If the surface is too smooth, the mouse ball slides; if it's too rough, the ball sticks, causing skipping on the screen.

headline: Brazil Power Asset Sale Attracts Few Bidders
abstract: Brazil sells its largest power distributor, Metropolitana, for $1.78 billion (US), but fails to sell second distributor as demand for electric assets being sold proves weaker than expected; group led by Brazil's Light Servicos de Eletricidade SA makes sole bid for Metropolitana (S)

headline: APPLIED CELLULAR SEEKS PLAN TO INCREASE STOCK PRICE
abstract: Applied Cellular Technology Inc plans to hire investment banker to help it explore ways to increase its share price, including mergers and joint ventures (S)

headline: CENDANT IN TALKS TO BUY BRITISH ROADSIDE SERVICES UNIT
abstract: Cendant Corp says it is in talks to buy Royal Automobile Club Ltd's RAC Motoring Services business for about $750 million in cash (S)

headline: TELECOMMUNICATIONS BUSINESS FILES FOR INITIAL OFFERING
abstract: Time Warner Inc will seek to raise as much as $175 million by selling shares of its local telephone business, Time Warner Telecom Inc, to the public (S)

headline: AUTO PARTS MAKER SEEKS STAKE IN BRAZILIAN COMPANY
abstract: Dana Corp, auto and truck parts manufacturer based in Toledo, Ohio, offers to buy controlling stake in Nakata SA, producer of drive shafts and shock absorbers; would gain Nakata factories in Sao Paulo, Brazil, where company is based, and in Buenos Aires (S)

headline: BBDO Offices Win At Clio Awards
abstract: Clio Awards ceremonies are held for advertising; offices of BBDO Worldwide win most honors, 28 Clios in all (S)

headline: Record for Exchange Seat
abstract: A record $225,000 has been paid for a seat on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the exchange said yesterday. The New York-based exchange said the sale beat the previous record set on May 13 of $200,000, which tied with the last high price set in 1996. The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange is in the process of merging with the New York Cotton Exchange.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  Ethics rules say accountants can't own clients' stock. So when two giant firms merge, there is a lot of portfolio purging. By Anne Tergesen.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Shareholder Value: Sorting Out the Voices
abstract: Monsanto Co former chairman and chief executive Richard J Mahoney article on how financing research and product development can conflict with stock analysts' demands for immediate results; cites importance of screening validity of advice of voices that purport to speak for shareowners; drawing (M)

headline: Liberty Life Ends Talks With Standard Bank
abstract: Liberty Life Assn of Africa Ltd and Standard Bank Investment Corp end merger talks after failing to agree on price (S)

headline: Patents; A restraint to hold, or sometimes free, riders when their horses come to a sudden stop.
abstract: Kimberly Kojima receives patent for seatbelt-like device that binds rider to his horse if animal stops in its tracks, to prevent kind of accident that paralyzed actor Christopher Reeve three years ago; Frederick Lee receives patent for surveillance and recording system that uses battery of video cameras to monitor what happens to plane in flight; unlike black boxes, images from Lee's camera system will not go down with plane if it crashes; instead, radio on plane transmits signals from cameras to satellite that relays them to ground station; June Ekman and Laurence Wilson receive patent for ergonomic chair they believe suits any individual because its seat is made from large inflated ball (M)

headline: South Africa Takes Notice of a Multiracial Party
abstract: Multiracial United Democratic Movement, headed by black politician who defied South Africa's former white-supremacist Government white Afrikaner regarded as key figure in apartheid era, is succeeding in efforts to build multiracial party to challenge Pres Nelson Mandela's largely black-supported African National Congress; is headed by Bantu Holomisa and Roelf Meyer (M)

headline: PHELPS DODGE AGREES TO $220 MILLION DEAL IN BRAZIL
abstract: Phelps Dodge Corp agrees to pay $220 million for Brazilian carbon-black manufacturing business of Minorco SA, European-based arm of South Africa's Anglo American Corp (S)

headline: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL SEEKS 20TH CENTURY
abstract: American International Group Inc says it plans to raise its stake in 20th Century Industries to over 50 percent; 20th Century spurns unsolicited offer (S)

headline: In Latin America, New Wealth Shakes Out Old Family Habits
abstract: NEW YORK—  As their Asian and Middle Eastern clients retrench, private bankers are turning to Latin America, where stable economies and rapidly growing markets are encouraging investors to shed some of their conservatism.

headline: Pakistan Test Leaves U.S. Out of Ideas and Angered
abstract: US reacts with anger and sense of frustration to Pakistan's nuclear test, as Clinton Administration officials say they have few ideas about how to stop arms race in South Asia; Pres Clinton condemns new tests in statement, saying, 'Pakistan and India are contributing to a self-defeating cycle of escalation'; he calls on both to 'renounce further nuclear and missile testing immediately and take decisive steps to reverse this dangerous arms race' (M)

headline: Some Restrictions on Baby Bells Are Upheld
abstract: A Federal appeals court, ruling in a closely watched case, today upheld regulations that restrict the nation's regional Bell companies from entering the electronic publishing business.     The case was brought by the BellSouth Corporation, the Atlanta-based regional phone company, which argued that the Federal Communications Commission restrictions were  unconstitutional because they singled out the Bells by name. BellSouth also argued that the rules violated First Amendment rights of free expression.

headline: Cellular Service Cheaper In East, a Survey Says
abstract: International Data Corp reports that cellular phone serve appears to be least expensive in the East and most expensive in California (S)

headline: Quirky PC Games Try to Find Market Niche in a Virtual Pet Cemetery
abstract: Profile of Lava Mind, home-based company in San Francisco that was started by Steven Hoffman and Naomi Kokubo; Lava Mind is best known for series of zany CD-ROM business simulation games for personal computers; games are popular among college professors and children; company operates Virtual Pet Cemetery as Web site to attract computer users to their products; photo (M)

headline: Mexican Charges Filed Over I.B.M. Contract
abstract: Authorities in Mexico City have charged 3 executives of IBM de Mexico and 22 current and former Mexico City officials with conspiracy in connection with acquisition without competitive bidding of $28 million computer system that city says has never worked (S)/

headline: Bias Said to Hurt Independent Mexican Unions
abstract: Mexican Labor Ministry, responding to US Labor Dept report that found favoritism toward unions aligned with Mexico's ruling party in labor elections, criticizes US for going beyond terms of North American Free Trade Agreement (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  The glare of competition was too much last year for Oakley, the maker of high-tech sunglasses. Many analysts say things now look brighter. By James Sterngold.

headline: Turning Desktops Into Theme Parks
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on growing popularity of desktop theme programs; new iteration on screen savers take various components of computer desktop, wallpaper, screen saver, fonts, icons and sounds, and repackage them around single theme; drawing (M)

headline: Big Sludge Spill Poisons Land in Southern Spain
abstract: Break in reservoir of zinc mine in southern Spain releases about 150 million cubic feet of acidic sludge into Guadimar River near Aznalcollar, contaminating croplands and Donana wildlife reserve and causing serious environmental disasters; photo; map; makeshift dikes stop toxic waste from swamping reserve, but poisonous flow has cut through northern part of vital buffer zone around park; heavy-metal pollution will immediately enter food chain during crucial breeding season for many species; Donana Park is on main route for Europe's migratory birds and home to many mammals but farms and tourism have been encroaching on fertile region; environmentalists have warned of danger from Los Frailes Mine thirty miles away; large open-pit mine is owned by Toronto-based Boliden Ltd (M)

headline: COMPUTER HORIZONS SEEKS SPARGO CONSULTING OF LONDON
abstract: Computer Horizons Corp offers to buy Spargo Consulting PLC for stock valued around $67.4 million (S)

headline: Kalisz Journal; Playground Has Plenty of Ghosts to Go Around
abstract: Rabbi Hertz Frankel of World Council of Orthodox Jewish Communities and Jewish leaders in Poland are pressing for removal of school playground, and possibly school itself, from site of former Jewish cemetery, Kalisz, Poland; seek to restore sanctity of cemetery, where famed 17th-century rabbi is buried; restoration of more than 1,000 Jewish cemeteries in Poland has been matter of friction and cooperation between Jewish communities abroad and Polish authorities since fall of Communism; non-Jews in some small towns have spruced up Jewish cemeteries; map; photos (M)

headline: In Ulster, a Feeling That Peace Has a Chance
abstract: Protestants and Catholics who voted on May 22 for new peace agreement are cautiously adjusting to idea of lasting peace in Northern Ireland; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Pound weakens after Financial Times reports Bank of England's policy-making committee voted 5 to 3 in favorof keeping rates on hold; graph (S)

headline: Riney Executive To Be Carat Chief
abstract: David Verklin, top media executive at Hal Riney & Partners, will leave after 11 years to join Carat North America in new position of chief executive (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURANCE GROUP INC., Miami, an insurance holding company, agreed to acquire MS Diversified Corp., of Jackson, Miss., a seller of extended automobile warranties, for $54.6 million in cash.    PMT SERVICES INC., Nashville, a provider of credit-card authorization and payment services to small businesses, said it would acquire the closely held MBN National Inc. of Los Angeles for an undisclosed price.    AFC ENTERPRISES INC., Atlanta, agreed to buy the Paradise Bakery and Cafe, a fresh-food bakery operator, from Paradise Holdings Inc., for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.

headline: Treaty Was Violated, He Asserts : Bundesbank Aide Derides 'Lazy' Deal
abstract: FRANKFURT—  A senior Bundesbank official on Monday denounced as a "lazy compromise" the agreement over the leadership of Europe's central bank, saying it violated the European Union's Maastricht treaty.

headline: Seoul Won't Seek Japan Funds for War's Brothel Women
abstract: South Korea says it will end effort to win Japanese compensation for South Korean women forced into Japanese military brothels in World War II; will pay each of 152 registered 'comfort women' $22,700, supplemented by $4,700 each from victims' rights groups; Pres Kim Dae Jung pledges to continue to seek apology from Japan; says Government will not interfere with continued demands by women and nongovernment organizations for Japanese compensation (M)

headline: A Bond Sale, Not an Indonesian Turnaround
abstract: Analysis of import of Asia Pulp and Paper's successful $500 million bond offering to Indonesia's economic future; Asia Pulp and Paper is first Indonesian company to enter market since financial crisis devastated economy; most analysts say Asia Pulp and Paper has unique strengths that make it one of Indonesia's most attractive prospects for foreign investors, and should not be seen as bellwether for Indonesia; they say that although Indonesia has begun fulfilling some provisions of its latest agreement with International Monetary Fund, country still has suffocating foreign debt and insolvent banking system (M)

headline: SECURITY CAPITAL TO BUY BELGIAN PARKING COMPANY
abstract: Security Capital Group Inc to buy Bernheim-Comofi of Belgium, parking garage company, for $225 million (US) (S)

headline: The Ghoul Pool: Morbid, Tasteless and Popular
abstract: THE all-media wake for Frank Sinatra and the countdown that preceded it took me back to April 1984, when I first dipped my toe into the ghoul pool.    As a novice floor clerk in the cacophonous options trading pit of the American Stock Exchange, I was still learning hand signals when one of the traders tore off his Walkman earphones and yelled: ''I'm losing my shirt! What a long shot!''

headline: A Pot of Gold For Publishers Of Textbooks
abstract: Publishers of textbooks and instructional materials registered strongest gains in sales last year in any category of $21 billion US book market, with purchases of elementary school books increasing by 13 percent, to $3 billion, and college texts rising by 7.4 percent, to $2.7 billion; many states have increased spending for textbook purchases for schools and libraries; recent mergers in the industry, including Pearson PLC's $3.6 billion acquisition of Simon & Schuster's education division, discussed; chart (L)

headline: Buckets of Details, From Auto Shops to Zoos
abstract: Article evaluates several CD-ROM trip planners; photos (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank Shares Rise on Merger Rumor
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG shares rise on speculation that bank, Germany's largest, could merge with Chase Manhattan Corp (S)

headline: Girl Zone for Hip Girls
abstract: Mary Jo Reale letter on May 21 article on Web sites for girls notes omission of Girl Zone, popular Web zine

headline: Technology; 'Baby Softs'? Envisioning A Breakup Of Microsoft
abstract: Now that Justice Dept and Attorneys General of 20 states have filed long-threatened antitrust suits against Microsoft Corp, question remains why most obvious, and perhaps cleanest, solution has yet to be put on bargaining table: breakup of Microsoft into its component businesses; challenges to Microsoft's monopoly do not address more fundamental issue of how to insure a truly competitive environment in which software code is currency upon which a new digital economy is increasingly based; Microsoft's iron-fisted control of market for operating-system software is keystone of its continuing efforts to dominate applications programs, new media and other businesses--a degree of control that has prompted speculation about breakup for years; SRI International, Silicon Valley research institute, offers hypothetical model in whic Microsoft eventually becomes five separately owned and operated companies, which SRI calls 'Baby Softs'; business functions of new Baby Softs described (M)

headline: A Vice Chairman of Salomon Leaves to Manage His Money
abstract: Robert H Lessin resigns as vice chairman of Salomon Smith Barney to devote his time to venture capital investing and managing his own money (S)

headline: West Bank Arabs Scrape By as They Lose Housing
abstract: Demolitions of Arab houses in West Bank and East Jerusalem have sharply increased in recent weeks, leaving scores of people homeless because their dwelling lack building permits; policy seems aimed at consolidating Israel's hold on East Jerusalem and on West Bank areas Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's Government seeks to keep; Clinton Administration reportedly presses for suspension of further demolitions as part of deal to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace talks; map (M)

headline: Cruise the Internet and Download Your Own Zamboni?
abstract: Zamboni Model 100 ice rink resurfacing machine will soon be offered on the Web for $9,995 at Sportsite.com; photo (S)

headline: Larry King Signs CNN Accord Totaling $7 Million a Year
abstract: Cable News Network has signed its talk show host, Larry King, to new contract that will bring his salary close to parity with leading news anchors on broadcast networks; CNN executives will not comment on terms, but King says that under the deal, a five-year contract, he will receive compensation package totaling close to $7 million a year (M)

headline: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS TO DROP WHOLESALE BUSINESS
abstract: Consolidated Natural Gas Co will drop its money-losing gas marketing and trading business, resulting in pretax first-quarter charge of up to $75 million; company will dismiss all 125 employees of division, or about 2 percent of its work force; Consolidated will focus on selling gas to residential and small business customers, as well as its natural gas and oil exploration and gas pipeline operations (S)

headline: News Corporation Creates a New Unit
abstract: News Corp forms worldwide integrated media and marketing division, News Corp One, to offer marketers new ways to affiliate with company's more than 35 advertising-supported businesses; Kayne Lanahan is named to head News Corp One in New York as senior vice president and director (S)

headline: SECURITY CAPITAL ATLANTIC BUYS NINE PROPERTIES
abstract: Security Capital Atlantic Inc says it bought 9 apartment complexes in North and South Carolina for $161.5 million from Charter Properties Inc, increasing its holdings by about 9 percent (S)

headline: Europe Approves MCI-Worldcom Merger Deal
abstract: European Union approves Worldcom Inc's proposed $43.7 billion purchase of MCI Communications Corp after MCI says it will sell its Internet business; European Commission will issue its formal approval of deal on July 8 (S)

headline: Intuit Is Backing Away From Quicken for Macs
abstract: Intuit, maker of popular Quicken 98 personal finance program, says it will not release new version for Apple Macintosh computers, citing declining Mac sales; news is bitter blow for Apple (S)

headline: Times Mirror Weighs a By-the-Numbers Approach to Expanding Coverage of Minorities
abstract: Mark H Willes, chief executive of Times Mirror Co and publisher of Los Angeles Times, is devising unorthodox plan to give more coverage and sell more newspapers to women, African-American, Asian and Hispanic readers; he has ordered meeting of senior editors to discuss new quantitative models to establish baseline of how well their coverage reflects community demographics; most journalists queried do not object to his goal but very few are comfortable with his approach (M)

headline: A Big Investor Stands to Get A Huge Payoff
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, who was mocked for his 1990 investment in Chrysler Corp, when company was still recovering from years of poor sales, could realize enormous profit if talks between Chrysler and Daimler-Benz AG result in merger; Kerkorian purchased total of 100 million shares over last 8 years, for total of $1.4 billion; he sold back 11 million shares in wake of 1996 standstill agreement with Chrysler management in which he agreed not to acquire more than 13.75 percent of company; if merger is completed, his remaining stake of 89 million shares would be worth nearly $5 billion, more than triple his original investment; aside from Kerkorian, Chrysler's largest shareholders are Capital Research and Management, with 5.85 percent of Chrysler stock, and State Street Bank and Trust, with 2.97 percent stake; photo; graph (M)

headline: Experts Dispute Iraq's Claim It Ended Germ War Effort
abstract: Team of independent experts who reviewed Iraq's progress in eliminating biological weapons at Baghdad's request has rejected Pres Saddam Hussein's contention that he no longer has germ warfare program; experts' report, issued on April 9, calls Iraqi disclosures 'incomplete and inadequate' and says Baghdad has failed to convince them that biological weapons or ingredients to make them have been eliminated; says Iraqi claims that missile warheads containing biological weapons had been destroyed 'cannot be reconciled with physical evidence' (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes and assignments noted (S)

headline: The Daily News tries to stem a tide of watery ink in new color presses as costs mount.
abstract: The Daily News is seeking to stem tide of red ink linked to problems with its new state-of-the-art Goss Newsliner presses at The News' printing plant in Jersey City; 18 months after News spent hundreds of millions of dollars installing presses, full-color images are nowhere in sight in The Daily News, except on Sundays; issue of waterlogged inks in presses is only latest in series of glitches that have dogged the presses since they were installed; photo (M)

headline: Atlas Plugged: Choosing A World View
abstract: Article evaluates several CD-ROM atlases (S)

headline: Israel Also Has the Bomb, and Its Neighbors Are Angry and Envious
abstract: Onset of nuclear arms race in Southeast Asia rekindles sense of deep frustration among Arabs over their own countries' impotence in face of Israel's nuclear arsenal; even though Areab leaders have condemned tit-for-tat tests that have established India and Pakistan as undisputed nuclear powers, they have insisted too that attention be focused on what they see as danger of Israel's nuclear might; many leaders are bitter over fact that West has seemed to acquiesce in nuclear imbalance in Middle East by omitting Israel from calls to halt spread of weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.55   5.42        3-month T-bills   4.96   4.97   4.91        6-month T-bills   5.11   5.10   5.15        10-yr. T-infl.   3.71   3.70   3.52        10-yr. T-note   5.57   5.58   6.48        30-yr. T-bond   5.78   5.82   6.77        Telephone bd.   7.05   7.05   7.82        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.25   5.67          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: Northeast Utilities Rejects a Bid for a Unit
abstract: Northeast Utilities's Public Service of New Hampshire unit again rejects New Hampshire Electric Cooperative's $1.4 billion cash bid for its transmission and distribution business (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHASE MANHANTTAN CORP., New York, the nation's largest banking company, acquired Marine Midland Bank's Continental Airlines One Pass credit card portfolio, for undisclosed terms.    W. W. GRAINGER INC., Chicago, a distributor of maintenance and repair supplies, will split its stock 2 for 1 and buy back up to 5 million shares, or about 10 percent of the 48.8 million common shares outstanding.

headline: Dollar Falls Against Yen as Bank of Japan Acts
abstract: Dollar tumbles against yen in Asian trading as Bank of Japan again sells dollars to prop up Japanese currency (S)

headline: $62 BILLION DEAL TO SHIFT BALANCE IN PHONE INDUSTRY
abstract: SBC Communication Inc's planned acquisition of Ameritech Corp in $62 billion deal will significantly shift balance of power in US telecommunications industry; will create nation's largest local telephone company and threaten remaining regional Bells with specter of having to compete eventually with wealthy, aggressive leviathan that will control about third of nation's local phone lines; new company will dominate local phone markets in swath through middle of nation from Detroit to El Paso, as well as in California and Connecticut; will be nation's No.2 carrier, behind AT&T; if approved by state and Federal regulators, merger will leave AT&T and other large phone companies defending their turf from company that has demonstrated enormous appetite for growth and acquisition; photo; charts (M)

headline: AES TO GET HANWA ENERGY'S POWER BUSINESS
abstract: AES Corp to acquire power plant business of Hanwha Energy Co of South Korea; AES will inject $370 million of cash into business within two weeks and will also invest about $230 million to complete construction of unfinished power plant; AES may also assume $270 million of debt (S)

headline: A Fashionable Place to Be: A Supermodel's Site On Line
abstract: Supermodel Niki Taylor plans own Web site offering fashion and style advice; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Report Calls Iran No. 1 Terror Sponsor, Despite New Leader
abstract: United States State Dept, in its annual report on international terrorism, contends that Iran remains 'most active state sponsor of terrorism' despite last year's election of a more moderate President, Mohammad Khatami, and 'more conciliatory' rhetoric adopted by Khatami and his deputies; report, required by Congress, finds that Teheran Govt was responsible for at least 13 assassinations last year, most of them in northern Iraq against members of Iran's main opposition groups; number of casualties from international terrorism dropped last year: 221 people died in terrorist acts in 1997, compared with 314 in 1996; more than third of 304 acts of international terrorism took place in Colombia; deadliest terrorist attack took place in Egypt, when 58 foreign tourists and 4 Egyptians were killed in attack by Muslim extremists at temple near Luxor; State Dept singles out seven state sponsors of terorism: Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, Sudan and Syria (M)

headline: A commercial code revision tries to take on the task of legislating the Internet.
abstract: Critics complain proposed revision of Uniform Commercial Code dealing with sale of all kinds of copyrighted digital data is so overbroad and complex it threatens to bury electronic commerce industry in legalese; revision is built around legally questionable premise that consumers do not buy software, but merely license to use software in limited ways; drawing (M)

headline: Ah, the Hiss of Yesteryear: Audio Buffs Look Back
abstract: Musicians, audio buffs and trendy youth are creating demand for audio retro-technology, such as analog synthesizers that defined sounds of the 1970's and 1980's; photo (M)

headline: SOUTHERN TO BUY 9 POWER PLANTS IN MASSACHUSETTS
abstract: Southern Co agrees to buy 9 power plants from Commonwealth Energy System and Eastern Utilities Associates for $537 million to bolster its electricity-trading operations in Northeast; plants are in Massachusetts (S)

headline: Allies Upset as U.S. Eases Stance on Kosovo
abstract: America's closest European allies are upset that Washington has changed tack yet again on issue of Kosovo, pushing to ease pressure on Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic despite his intensified repression in province (M)

headline: On Far Right, A Soft Voice Undermines French Center
abstract: Interview with Bruno Megret, soft voice of France's far right who is regarded as brain behind political strategy that has convulsed French politics by undermining country's political center (M)

headline: Cable Modems' Other Side
abstract: Dan Woog letter on May 21 article hails cable modems but deplores poor service by cable companies (S)

headline: International Paper And Volvo in Deals
abstract: Volvo Car Corp signs worldwide television deal with CNN unit of Time Warner Inc; three-year, multimillion-dollar programming partnership will introduce World Beat, weekly music show to begin in June on various CNN networks; International Paper Co signs $3 million agreement with National Geographic Society and its National Geographic magazine to co-sponsor society's Geography Awareness Week in November and Teacher Summer Institute, program to promote geographical education; International Paper also agrees to minimum two-year ad program with National Geographic (S)

headline: To Many, Out of Sight . . .
abstract: BIOLOGISTS and the public see the world differently in regard to environmental threats, recent polls show.    Biologists overwhelmingly view the loss of biodiversity -- that is, the loss of different species of plants and animals and their habitats -- as the most serious environmental problem, but the public is mostly unfamiliar with the concept of biodiversity and considers pollution the biggest threat.

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.37   5.56        3-month T-bills   4.93   4.93   5.13        6-month T-bills   5.03   5.03   5.38        10-yr. headline: The Economics Of Intervention; A Prominent but Impolitic Theorist Questions the Worship of Free Markets
abstract: Profile of World Bank chief economist Joseph E Stiglitz, who uses post and Asian crisis to re-fight battles he lost as adviser to Pres Clinton; he opposes austerity measures for Asia favored by Clinton Adminstration and International Monetary Fund, relying on widely taught theories that bear his stamp; he comments, interview; diagram; table of biographical data; photos (M)l

headline: By Any Measure, Europe's New Monetary Union Is a Historic Exploit
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Starting from the Declaration of Independence, it took the United States nearly 90 years to establish a fully fledged common currency, and a further 50 years to set up the Federal Reserve system in 1913.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.60   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.97   4.96   4.96        6-month T-bills   5.10   5.08   5.17        10-yr. headline: Fox Sports Network Names New Agency
abstract: Cliff Freeman & Partners is named agency of record for Fox Sports Network, division of Fox Broadcasting unit of News Corp (S)

headline: Weary Hands At the Throttle
abstract: Union Pacific Railroad's 1996 merger with Southern Pacific to form nation's largest railroad caused what regulators call unprecedented breakdown in rail traffic through heart of America that has lasted more than 10 months; economists say losses for nation total billions of dollars, and some customers are suing railroad; Richard K Davidson, Union Pacific's chairman, resists most demands from rail customers, unions and members of Congress for renewed Government oversights; he disputes Federal investigators who list management and worker fatigue among prime causes of crashes that killed nine workes last year; engineers and conductors say railroad's managers tried to squeeze merger for every possible economy and efficiency, leaving far too few supervisors, locomotives or crews when brisk economy kept freight traffic rising; Union Pacific has responded to safety and service complaints by agreeing to recruit thousands of new workers, but veterans say inexperience of new hires will present new risks; photos; charts; graphs (L)

headline: Korean Bank Closings Prompt a Big Yawn
abstract: Economists view South Korea's decision to close five small weak banks and merge them into larger, healthier competitors as symbolic but largely ineffective start to fixing nation's ailing financial system; five hold only 7.2 percent of banking system's bad debts; move gives seven other shaky banks reprieve and foists new problems on banks forced to swallow weak banks; Financial Supervisory Commission plans to spend 17.5 trillion won ($12.65 billion) to buy nonperforming loans from five banks, add capital to acquiring banks and set up reserve fund to buy unforeseen problem debts that arise in six months after mergers; photo (M)

headline: Picnics and a Quarrel Mark Israel's 50th Anniversary
abstract: Israel marks its 50th birthday with uniquely Israeli blend of smoky barbecues, military fly-overs, fireworks and controversies; centerpiece of jubilee, three-hour outdoor gala tracing country's history in song and dance, at which Vice Pres Al Gore is guest of honor, is also focus of day-long dispute after ultra-Orthodox Jews protest scene with scantily dressed dancers; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Deficit in March Lower Than Forecast
abstract: US posted smaller than expected budget deficit in March; US Treasury figures show deficit totaled $13.813 billion, compared with deficit of $21.3 billion in March 1997; revenue rose 9.1 percent, to $117.93 billion, from year earlier; spending rose 1.8 percent from year earlier, to $131.743 billion (S)

headline: New Yorker's Top Executive Is Replaced
abstract: Conde Nast Publications president, Steven T Florio, names David Carey, Conde Nast House & Garden publisher, to succeed his brother, Thomas A Florio, as president of New Yorker magazine; says his brother will return to previous post as publisher of Conde Nast Traveler, directing magazine's overseas expansion and assuming added title of vice president; move comes as Conde Nast begins to fold money-losing New Yorker into operations of its other 15 publications; merger will cut back-office costs and let magazine offer advertisers bulk corporate rates; Conde Nast Traveler publisher Lisa Hughes will move to House & Garden as publisher; photos (M)

headline: Demand Off, Boeing to Stop Making MD-11
abstract: Boeing Co says it will stop producing MD-11 wide-body jet late next year and lay off some workers because of slumping demand for aircraft (M)

headline: Costs Mounting As Plants Close In G.M. Strike
