abstract: Strike by 3,400 UAW workers at General Motors Corp metal stamping factory in Flint, Mich, has closed seven assembly plants from Kansas to Canada and part of three other plants, idling more than 18,000 workers by GM's count; 5,000 workers at second parts-making factory in Flint are expected to decide whether to strike over what they call unmet job security demands; auto analysts say strike in Flint, Mich, will ripple across North America within days, quickly shutting most of 22 assembly plants not yet affected by metal-stamping plant strike, causing hundreds of temporary layoffs at independent parts supply companies and depleting dealer inventories of cars and trucks; economists say combined work stoppage could trim nation's production of goods and services by $6 billion, on yearly basis, if settlement is not reached before end of month; chart; photo (M)

headline: OWENS CORNING SELLING GLASS-FIBER AND SPECIALTY UNIT
abstract: Owens Corning to sell glass-fiber yarns and specialty materials division of its Composites Systems business (S)

headline: Argentina Arrests 8 Iranians and Ousts 7 in Anti-Jewish Bombings
abstract: Argentine Government, stating it is near breakthrough in investigation of two bombings of Jewish centers in recent years, arrests eight Iranian residents and orders expulsion of seven of Iran's eight embassy employees in Buenos Aires; is reportedly close to breaking diplomatic relations with Iran; senior officials acknowledge American and Israeli intelligence have been correct in asserting that Iran played direct role in 1992 bombing of Israeli Embassy and 1994 bombing of Argentine Israeli Mutual Assn, in which total of 114 people died (M)

headline: Clinton Starts Visit to China By Answering Critics in U.S.
abstract: With the pageantry of thundering drums and clanging gongs, President Clinton was welcomed to China tonight, the first American President to visit this country in nearly a decade, and he mildly rebuked critics in Washington who have attacked his policy of engagement with Beijing.     ''There may be those here and back in America who wonder whether closer ties and deeper friendship between America and China are good,'' the President said, speaking as much to his audience at home as to the throngs of Chinese who poured into the streets of Xian today to give Mr. Clinton a tumultuous welcome.

headline: A Disk Too Dear
abstract: Kenneth Likier letter, responding to May 17 article on removable computer storage products, scores high price of Imation's Superdisks (S)

headline: 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money
abstract: EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers.    To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age.

headline: Sometimes 3 Managers Are Better Than One
abstract: ONE hot industry trend -- some would say fad -- is the concentrated fund: an offering that holds 30 or so stocks instead of the typical 100 or more. Another is the so-called all-star fund, in which several high-profile managers each run a slice of a portfolio.    Combine the two and -- bingo -- you start another trend, funds in which two or more star managers run a concentrated portfolio. Sun America Asset Management and Prudential Securities just unveiled two such funds.

headline: Ruling on Microsoft Shows a Fault Line In Antitrust Theory
abstract: Antitrust experts say appeals court ruling that Microsoft Corp can bundle internet browser with its operating system software is both big victory for company and reflection of wider debate over how antitrust doctrine should apply to high-technology industries; say majority ruling echoes hand-off approach championed by Microsoft, while dissent mirrors Justice Department's philosophy; ruling spurs sharp rise in Microsoft stock; Justice Department and state attorneys general, pursuing broader antitrust suit against company, cite reasons why ruling's impact might be limited (M)

headline: German Output Rises Faster Than France's
abstract: German Federal Statistics Office says nation's gross domestic product expanded 1 percent last quarter, well above rate in fourth quarter of 1997 of only three-tenths of 1 percent; annual output grew 3.8 percent from a year earlier; French Government says output rose six-tenths of 1 percent in first quarter from previous three months, below fourth quarter's gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent and slowest gain in a year; on an annual basis, growth accelerated to 3.5 percent from 3.2 percent in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Tracking the Flow of Cash Abroad
abstract: CALLING this year's overseas markets volatile is a bit like saying India and Pakistan are having a neighborhood cook-off.    How have fund investors reacted to the spinning markets? By piling into hot European funds, bailing out of plummeting Latin American stock funds and -- surprisingly -- plowing enormous amounts of cash into the debt of emerging markets.

headline: Stock Market In Indonesia Reflects Hope
abstract: Indonesian stocks rise at opening of stock market, lifted by hopes that resignation of Pres Suharto will allow new Cabinet to push ahead with reforms (S)

headline: Railtrack Gets Go-Ahead For a High-Speed Link
abstract: British Government will hand over construction of troubled project for fast-train link from London to Channel Tunnel to Railtrack Group PLC, while group that includes British Airways PLC will help run Eurostar high-speed trains traveling through the tunnel; new plan will see British track operator Railtrack build $8.8 billion link in two stages; it will be completed in 2007; Government steps in after losses at Eurostar nearly forced collapse of London and Continental Railways, eight-member group picked in 1996 to run British end of Eurostar and to build high-speed line (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises to 3-month high after Denmark increases key interest rate, which resurrects speculation that Bundesbank will soon raise rates; in New York the dollar costs 1.7669 marks, down from 1.7803; graph; chart (S)

headline: Intel and Microsoft Face Differing Antitrust Paths
abstract: Lawyers for Intel Corp should be well acquainted with antitrust inquiries by Federal Trade Commission--process different from one followed in Justice Department antitrust cases--because commission has been investigating Intel throughout this decade; FTC and Intel are about to enter administrative and legal process far different from Justice Department's case against Microsoft Corp; suit against Intel will never reach Federal District Court; initial judicial proceedings will take place at administrative level (M)

headline: Buyer to Revive 2 Popular On-Line Magazines
abstract: Zapata Corp, food processing business owned by Avram A Glazer, will acquire two on-line magazines as first step in major strategic initiative to acquire Internet and electronic-commerce companies; will also change its name to Zap; magazines being acquired, Word and Charged, were shut down by Icon CMT Corp in March; Glazer says he will rehire employees of both magazines (M)

headline: Yeltsin Appoints Ex-Aide to Negotiate Fund Loan
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin names ex-Deputy Prime Min Anatoly B Chubais as his special representative to negotiate with International Monetary Fund on possible new multibillion-dollar loan to help stabilize Russia's financial markets; Russia cancels sale of 182-day Treasury bills at first of three planned auctions because investors demand too high a yield (S)

headline: Seth R. Thomas, 56, Clockmaker's Scion
abstract: Seth R Thomas, clockmaker, dies at age 56 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AGCO CORP., Duluth, Ga., a farm machinery company, agreed to acquire the Spra-Coupe line of crop sprayers from the Ingersoll-Rand Co. for an undisclosed amount.    BRADLEY REAL ESTATE INC., Northbrook, Ill., a real estate investment trust, agreed to sell a Chicago office building for $84.5 million to two affiliates of Goldman, Sachs & Company.    MASCO CORP., Taylor, Mich., a maker of building, home improvement and consumer products, agreed to be bought for an undisclosed price by Bosch-Siemens Hausgerate G.m.b.H., a joint venture of Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. and Siemens A.G. that is Germany's largest maker of major household appliances.

headline: Euro Deal Adds to Kohl's Political Woes
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is up for re-election and is already in trouble over country's economic problems, is being severely criticized for compromising with France over selection of president of new European Central Bank, which will decide monetary policy for all 11 countries that adopt euro as currency; is being accused of sloppiness and of selling out to France; German candidate, Wim F Duisenberg, will be appointed president for eight-year term--but has agreed to voluntarily retire halfway through term to make way for French candidate, Jean-Claude Trichet (M)

headline: DuPont Shifts Focus To Sciences Unit
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co will reorganize to focus on its fast-growing agricultural, biotechnology and pharmaceutical businesses (S)

headline: CISCO SYSTEMS PLANS SILICON VALLEY LAND PURCHASES
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc to buy 230 acres in Milpitas and San Jose in California's Silicon Valley for use for future growth; has no immediate construction plans (S)

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARD COVER    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH

headline: From TV To Web, Buyout By Buyout
abstract: Bert Ellis, chairman and chief executive of Atlanta-based iXL Holding Inc, wants to build world's largest Internet solutions company; Ellis's company, through numerous acquisitions, has become budding interactive communications conglomerate, luring top industry talent like Lara Stein, formerly of Microsoft Corp and now president of iXL; photos (L)

headline: President Promoted At Unit of Omnicom
abstract: Thomas L Harrison, president of Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom Group, is being promoted to chairman and chief executive; John Wren will relinquish those duties and continue as chairman and chief executive of Omnicom (S)

headline: Banks Let Indonesia Postpone Repayment
abstract: Thirteen foreign banks agreed on a framework to allow Indonesia to delay repayment of nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt that was a  barrier to restarting the economy.    While the agreement is simply a framework for renegotiating the debt on a case-by-case basis, the unexpectedly quick action by the banks gives Indonesia the best economic news in months. It is also a boost to the new Government of President B. J. Habibie, who is struggling to assert his legitimacy.

headline: Alexander Papamarkou, 68, An International Financier
abstract: Alexander Papamarkou, investment banker and philanthropist who made major contributions to New York institutions, dies at age 68; photo (S)

headline: U S West Selects DDB Needham
abstract: U S West Inc names DDB Needham Worldwide to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by N W Ayer & Partners (S)

headline: DRAKE'S, THE MAKER OF YODELS AND RING DINGS, TO BE SOLD
abstract: Interstate Bakeries Corp to acquire Drake's, maker of Yodels and Ring Dings, from Culinar Inc for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Berger Manages a Welter of Crises in the Post-Cold-War White House
abstract: Article profiles Samuel R Berger, Clinton Administration's national security adviser who is struggling to manage welter of international crises, latest being India's decision to carry out string of underground nuclear tests; photo (M)

headline: KULICKE SEES LOSS AFTER INTEL HALTS ORDER
abstract: Shares of Kulicke & Soffa Industries fall 12.6 percent after company, a semiconductor-equipment maker, warns of third-quarter loss because Intel Corp has canceled estimated $30 million order (S)

headline: Real Pain, Not Virtual
abstract: D R Newman Sr letter on Apr 23 article on dissemblers who join Internet support groups (S)

headline: L. L. Bean Puts Account in Review
abstract: L L Bean Inc places its advertising account in review; account has been handled for five years by Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston; billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million (S)

headline: Martin H. Schrader, 73, Magazine Publisher
abstract: Martin H Schrader, former Hearst magazines publisher, dies at age 73 (S)

headline: Taiwan Chip Makers Face Dumping Penalty
abstract: US trde panel finds that dumping practices by computer memory-chip makers from Taiwan hurt American makers, opening way for penalty tariffs on Taiwan products; panel says underpricing of static random access memory semiconductors, or S-RAM computer chips, by South Korean companies, Hyundai Electronics Industries and LG Semicon, did not injure American chip makers, and companies are cleared from additional duties (S)

headline: AGREEMENT IS SET ON CLASS-ACTION LITIGATION
abstract: Philip Morris agrees to settle shareholder securities class-action litigation against company and several former officers (S)

headline: Real Change or Empty Promises?
abstract: Analysis of whether Japan, in making pledges on economic program to strengthen its economy, really committed itself to far-reaching change; questions whether currency intervention by US and Japan will be overwhelmed within a few days by market forces, leading to ever-cheaper yen and to greater economic turmoil around the world; says at stake is a firmer yen and Asian economic stability (M)

headline: Industrial Bank of Japan Reduces Three Stakes
abstract: Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd sells significant portion of shares it holds in Nomura Securities Co, Nikko Securities Co and Daiwa Securities Co (S)

headline: Just Why Do We Buy?
abstract: Architectural historian Heli Meltsner letter, responding to May 3 article on spending habits of middle class, says assumption that aluminum siding is 'practical' purchase that adds value to a residence is highly questionable (S)

headline: Lewis H. Young, 73, Former Editor in Chief of Business Week
abstract: Lewis H Young, former editor in chief of Business Week who expanded the horizons of business reporting, dies at age 73; photo (M)

headline: PACKARD BELL TO USE CYRIX CHIPS FOR FIRST TIME
abstract: Packard Bell NEC Inc will use processors from National Semiconductor Corp's Cyrix unit in some of its computers, ending its exclusive use of chips from Intel Corp (S)

headline: CBS SELLING SECURITY SYSTEMS BUSINESS TO HONEYWELL
abstract: Honeywell Inc agrees to buy Westinghouse Security Electronics Inc, subsidiary of CBS Corp, for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Market Hits an 11-Year Low As a Strike Begins in Korea
abstract: South Korea's economic crisis worsens with beginning of nationwide strike and deepening weakness in stock market to 11-year low; Korean Confederation of Trade Unions goes ahead with two-day strike to press its demands that Government take better care of workers whose job security is at risk from nation's economic problems; stock market's main index drops 19.91 points, or 6 percent, to 311.99, lowest level since February 1987 (M)

headline: Editors Debate Realism vs. Retreat in Newsroom Diversity
abstract: Top officials of American Society of Newspaper Editors ignite debate in organization with proposal to scale back goal of having nation's newsrooms reflect country's ethnic mix by year 2000, which was projected at 15 percent when goal was set in 1978; say goal is unrealistic in view of rise in nation's minority population, nearly 26 percent in 1994; about 11.4 percent of nation's newspaper reporters, photographers and editors are now members of minority groups; ASNE officials suggest new goal of lifting minority representation in newsrooms by seven-tenths of 1 percentage point annually, bringing it to 20 percent by year 2010; group of dissenting editors plans to look for a more ambitious set of goals, while minority journalists' groups express dismay (M)

headline: Daimler-Benz Takes Over Chrysler as VW Acquires Rolls-Royce: Fast Lane for German Firms
abstract: LONDON—  German automakers moved boldly Thursday to extend their global influence as Daimler-Benz AG said it would acquire Chrysler Corp., and as Volkswagen AG won a come-from-behind bidding contest to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd., the luxury British carmaker.

headline: What the Biggest Cities Can Learn From the Upstarts
abstract: Viewpoint commentary by Joel Kotkin on concern in cities nationwide about role of business leaders in their communities; many of nation's biggest cities are facing new problems rallying strong civic leadership from executives in era of mergers, shareholder pressure and economic globalization; while engaged busines elites have weakened in cities like Los Angeles and New York, new ones are flourishing in upstart places like Seattle, Atlanta, Irvine, Calif, and Research Triangle of North Carolina; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., announced plans to provide the turbines for a $1.5 billion thermal power plant to be built in China by a joint U.S.-Chinese venture.    INTERNATIONAL PAPER, Purchase, N.Y., agreed to acquire a majority interest in OAO Svetogorsk, a Russian pulp and paper business, from a Swedish packaging material concern, Tetra Laval. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Limited Reports Rise in Earnings
abstract: Limited Inc says fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 34 percent; profit before charges and gains rose $25.8 million from $19.3 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 10 percent, to $2 billion from $1.83 billion; Limited announces plans to sell its 84 percent stake in Abercrombie & Fitch Co to Limited shareholders (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark weakens against dollar on concerns about weakness in Russia; graphs (S)9

headline: KEYCORP TO ACQUIRE MCDONALD FOR $653 MILLION
abstract: Keycorp to acquire McDonald & Co, investment banking and securities brokerage concern, for $653 million in stock (S)

headline: Philip Carret, Money Manager, Dies at 101
abstract: Philip L Carret, founder of one of country's first mutual funds, dies at age 101; photo (M)

headline: In Setback to Lockheed, Judge Delays Trial in Merger Challenge
abstract: Judge Emmet G Sullivan deals setback to Lockheed Martin Corp's proposed $12 billion acquisition of Northrop Grumman Corp, delaying trial in Government's challenge to transaction until Sept 8; says timetable means he probably will not rule until about Christmas (M)

headline: Business Travel; A subsidiary of British Airways is joining the ranks of no-frills airlines in Europe.
abstract: New subsidiary of British Airways called Go, based at Stansted Airport outside London, plans to join ranks of no-frills European airlines next month; Easyjet is so unhappy with Go's entry into no-frills field that it is taking British Airways to court, charging that parent company is 'cross-subsidizing' start-up; British Airways says there is nothing unlawful or anticompetitive about Go's operation; Seaport Hotel is set to open May 1 on Boston's waterfront across the street from World Trade Center; hotel is owned by Commonwealth Flats Development and John Drew Co; it is first new full-service luxury property in downtown Boston in more than decade; Albany International Airport is scheduled to open new $72 million passenger terminal and concourse June 1 (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: U.N. Experts Report Finding Mustard Gas in Iraqi Shells
abstract: Richard Butler, United Nations' chief arms inspector for Iraq, says experts found active mustard gas in artillery shells, raising new questions about over 500 similar shells still unaccounted for in Iraq; shells were found in 1996, but not tested until March, in face of Iraqi opposition; Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf again holds Iraq destroyed all barred weapons in 1991 (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Univision Makes Splash With a Spanish Accent
abstract: Univision stages 'upfront' presentations of its Spanish-language television programming for advertising agencies; drawing (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Palladium rises 3.7 percent on increased anxiety over export delays from Russia, leading producer; June contracts rise $10.45, to $296.55 an ounce, highest since March 1980; graph; chart (S)

headline: Signs of Shift in Senate Stance on Bank Law
abstract: Signs of shift in attitude in US Senate favor passage of bill that would remove last remaining barriers to allowing banks, securities firms and insurance companies to merge into huge financial services companies; Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, chairman of Senate Banking Committee, has scheduled committee hearings on June 17, first step toward floor consideration; D'Amato has put measure on fast track and then followed it up by having group of financial executives meet with Senate majority leader Trent Lott, who says he will set aside time for debate; House bill would make Federal Reserve the main regulator; Treas Sec Robert Rubin prefers structure that would make Comptroller of the Currency, division of Treasury, top regulator; Rubin says he will recommend Presidential veto of current measure (M)

headline: Two Makers Of Phone Gear Join Forces
abstract: Tellabs Inc is expected to announce acquisition of Ciena Corp for $7.3 billion in stock; deal illustrates that forces driving consolidation in telecommunications are affecting makers of arcanne equipment as well as companies that actually sell services to consumers; companies like Tellabs and Ciena are looking to bulk up to compete against much larger rivals (M)

headline: Arthur F. Mathews, 60, Lawyer And Expert in Securities Crime
abstract: Arthur F Mathews, lawyer and expert in securities crime, dies at age 60 (S)

headline: Swiss Central Bank to Fight Holocaust Claims
abstract: Swiss National Bank bluntly states that it will fight class-action lawsuit in US that accuses it of accepting looted assets from Germany during Nazi era; also disputes jurisdiction of American courts; Michael Hausfeld, attorney for plaintiffs, comments (M)

headline: 13 States Plan Antitrust Move Over Microsoft
abstract: Attorneys General from 13 states, apparently intent on blocking imminent release of Microsoft Corp's next version of its Windows software, are in final stages of preparing joint antitrust action against company; several Attorneys General say they would rather act in conjunction with Justice Dept, which has been pressing its own antitrust suit against Microsoft; say they want to prevent Microsoft from using its dominance in personal-computer operating systems to promote sale of other software products (M)

headline: Counting Sheep, And Dollar Signs
abstract: Many consumers are buying expensive bedding in pursuit of sounder sleep; price of high-end bedding is escalating as result of technological innovations, improved designs and more expensive materials; drawing (M)

headline: An irreverent agency creates a campaign to help a fledgling Episcopal church expand its reach.
abstract: Advertising column on unconventional and somewhat irreverent advertising campaign for fledgling Episcopal church in Maryland; aim is to attract younger people who currently do not attend services; 1998 survey by Barna Research Group found 20-somethings are half as likely as older adults to attend church; most churches remain wary of using commercials (M)

headline: Keeping Up With the Gateses?
abstract: Juliet B Schor, economist at Harvard University, says majority of Americans are intent on 'competitive consumption,' trying to acquire trappings of rich by accumulating most, and latest, toys; says many Americans seek to emulate life styles of wealthiest 20 percent in nation rather than those in their general earnings category, or even those one rung above; result is that millions of Americans are participants in national culture of upscale spending; finds television is big driver of consumer aspirations; Schor is author of book, The Overspent American; photo (M)

headline: What Florida Needs
abstract: Andrew Dier letter on Apr 12 article holds Florida panhandle has enough suburban vacation developments and could use more parks (S)

headline: Business Travel; Three more airlines to eliminate advance boarding passes, which could mean longer lines.
abstract: AMR's American Airlines, Trans World Airlines and UAL's United Airlines are eliminating all advance boarding passes this month, which could mean longer check-in times for business travelers at airports; BAA PLC, which owns seven British airports, will offer express train service between Heathrow and Padding Station in downtown London starting June 23; five London hotels owned by Millennium Hotels and Resorts, subsidiary of CDL Hotels, are cutting their rates by 30 to 40 percent from July 6 through Sept 6 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Apple Denies Patent-Infringement Claim
abstract: Apple Computer Inc denies claims by Imatec Ltd that its Color Sync systems infringe patents held by Imatec and issued to Imatec chairman Hanoch Shalit; says it will vigorously defend itself against firm's $1.1 billion suit; seeks to invalidate patents (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Brian S. Posner; Warburg Pincus Growth and Income Fund
abstract: Brian S Posner, partner and portfolio manager at Warburg Pincus Asset Management, discusses his favorite stocks; says that as stock prices climb, he has more difficulty finding stocks he likes; photo; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Decline on Fears Of Higher Interest Rates  A four-day rally in stocks ended amid renewed fears that robust economic growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. As a result, the Dow Jones industrial average, Standard & Poor's index and Nasdaq composite all declined.    Investors are also waiting for Friday's employment data for April and a clearer indication of just how much American corporations will be affected by the economic turmoil in Asia. [Page D10.]

headline: Transportation Board Ponders Planned Conrail Takeover
abstract: Federal Surface Transportation Board will hold hearings on plans by Norfolk Southern and CSX to take over Conrail, only major freight carrier serving Northeast; while approval is expected, the board, striving to make amends for Union Pacific debacle two years ago when Union Pacific acquired Southern Pacific, has already attached tougher conditions and oversight to Conrail's acquisition (M)

headline: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro
abstract: Analysis of Pres Jacques Chirac's successful drive to deny full eight-year term to Wim F Duisenberg as head of new European central bank; he has forced Duisenberg, backed by all other European Union leaders and all 15 EU central bankers, to agree to retire early; economists hold move will weaken common currency; photo (M)

headline: An Imperfect Market, But Beware the 'Cure'
abstract: Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions director Thomas O'Brien letter disputes Joseph E Stiglitz's May 31 article on government intervention in failing companies (S)

headline: Bank of Thailand Sees Weak Currency as Aid
abstract: Bank of Thailand governor Chatumongkol Sonakul says central bank will accept weaker baht to increase exports but will raise interest rates to limit currency's fluctuations; photo (S)

headline: GEC Alsthom to Acquire A Division from Alcatel
abstract: GEC Alsthom NV, joint venture of General Electric Co PLC of Britain and Alcatel Alsthom of France, agree to acquire Cegelec, Alcatel's engineering and systems division; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: 'People Power' Unrest on Indonesian Campuses
abstract: Democracy drive is growing on university campuses across Indonesia; students seem unsure whether movement will end with bloody crackdown or people's revolution, but are increasingly willing to confront police; are gaining support among middle class, which blames Pres Suharto for economic crisis, by denouncing corruption and rising prices; protests are eroding Suharto's aura of authority and omnipotence and creating new confusion about where nation is heading; map; photos (M)

headline: Articles to Include Cosmetic Samples
abstract: Allure and Glamour magazines will feature cosmetic samples with some of their articles; cosmetics companies will supply samples for free, with publisher Conde Nast paying cost of inserting samples; photo (M)

headline: A.I.G. Forms Alliance With Insurer in Taiwan
abstract: American International Group, largest publicly held insurer in US, has formed alliance with Fubon Insurance Co, Taiwan's largest property and casualty insurer; AIG already owns at least 1.8 percent of Fubon and operates one of Taiwan's largest life insurers, Nan Shan Life Insurance Co; Fubon alliance involves American International Underwriters, AIG's overseas property and casualty unit (S)

headline: Disney Joins Rush to Build Web Gateways
abstract: Walt Disney Co announces complex deal valued at about $900 million in which it will buy 43 percent of Infoseek, a service that helps guide users on World Wide Web; Disney and other companies are following trail blazed by America Online and Yahoo, which are rushing to construct gateways to the Internet, known as 'portals,' that are starting points for most computer searches; these services are most attractive to on-line advertisers; Disney's intention is to create new Internet service that combines Infoseek with its existing offerings, which include Web sites for ABC television, ABC News, ESPN sports network, Disney's movies and site of original Disney entertainment for children; Disney will receive 43 percent of Infoseek in return for $70 million in cash and relinquishing ownership of Starwave, a company that creates elaborate Web sites; chart shows largest companies that have access to Internet (M)

headline: Long a Hot Stock, Is Fannie Mae Settling Down?
abstract: Article on prospects for Fannie Mae stock, which has slowed its advance in recent weeks; says Fannie Mae's run as great growth investment may be ending if analysts predictions that housing market is near or past its peak are correct; graphs (M)

headline: Ivo John Lederer, a Scholar of Eastern Europe, Is Dead at 68
abstract: Ivo John Lederer, refugee in only group of European Jews given special passage to US by Pres Roosevelt during World War II, and who went on to became Russian and Eastern European scholar, dies at age 68; photo (S)

headline: Wireless Unit Spinoff Called Near at Sprint
abstract: Sprint Corp is close to agreement to spin off its wireless telephone business, Sprint Spectrum LP, as publicly traded company, allowing its cable television partners to escape a venture that never reached its lofty goals; new company could have market value of as high as $9 billion; Tele-Communications Inc owns 30 percent of venture, while Comcast Corp and Cox Communications Inc each own 15 percent (M)

headline: Mitchell Feared the Killing of a Leader
abstract: Interview with former US Sen George J Mitchell, Northern Ireland peace negotiator, who says he accelerated pace of negotiations that led to agreement after threat by unidentified paramilitary group to murder high-profile person associated with talks (M)

headline: Albright to See Netanyahu And Arafat In London
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat will travel to London on May 4 for separate meetings with Sec of State Madeleine K Albright aimed at reviving stalled peace talks; announcement is made by British Prime Min Tony Blair after meeting with Arafat in Gaza while on Middle East tour; US State Department says meetings will be held to determine whether American proposals on further Israeli withdrawals from West Bank and other issues can provide basis for breakthrough and lead to talks on permanent peace settlement; photo (M)

headline: Pilots Stage Strike At All Nippon Airways
abstract: Pilots at All Nippon Airways Co, Japan's second-largest airline, go on strike to oppose cut in pay (S)

headline: Dark Underside of Polish Family Life: Violence
abstract: Domestic violence is becoming a public issue in Poland, nation where sanctity of the family is of almost mythical importance and where most homes are organized along strict patriarchal; often quoted Polish proverb says 'If a man does not beat his wife, her liver rots'; women's groups are now discussing issue of domestic violence, holding 'tribunals' where women tell their stories and seminars to sensitize police and prosecutors, who have often dismissed their complaints; a national billboard campaign alerts Poles to idea that brutality is more than just a family spat; one poster shows badly beaten woman, and says, simply, 'Because the soup was too salty'; statistics are notoriously hard to pin down in Poland, but in 1995 the courts recorded 33 percent rise in number of domestic vilence cases, suggesting that more women are reporting such incidents; photos; map (L)

headline: Taliban Lets Food Reach Region On Front Lines With Shiite Foes
abstract: Taliban Government in Afghanistan allows critical UN food shipment to be made to front-line region that has been cut off for nearly one year because of Taliban fighting with local Shiite force (S)

headline: Rally in Treasury Market Ends As Price of 30-Year Bond Slips
abstract: Treasury securities prices fall; 30-year bond falls 2/32, to 103 17/32, to yield 5.87 percent (S)

headline: Two Settle Insider Charges
abstract: Julia P Mobley and Rosamond S Brown agree to pay total of $58,123 to settle charges they made illegal profits by trading stock of MidSouth Corp based on insider knowledge of company's pending acquisition by Kansas City Southern Industries; women were friends of lobbyist for Kansas City Southern, who tipped Mobley about merger negotiations (S)

headline: Cable Modems: For a Few, Real Speed
abstract: Small but growing number of people have switched home Internet access from fast dial-up connection to cable modem; until recently, such access was limited to corporations, universities and those with T-1 phone line at home; photo (M)

headline: Hooking Up The Nation
abstract: Analysis of AT&T's bid to redefine communications landscape with planned acquisition of cable television giant Tele-Communications Inc; scramble to provide high-speed Internet access seen key to deal; AT&T hopes to offer customers complete package of local, long-distance and wireless phone service along with cable television and Internet access; table of deals by which telecommunications businesses have tried to increase their reach (M)

headline: U.S. Cites Japan Aid in Limiting Privacy
abstract: White House will announce that Japan has endorsed its unregulated, tax-free approach to electronic commerce, including its stance against strict privacy regulations planned by European Union; Ira C Magaziner, Pres Clinton's adviser on electronic commerce and Internet, welcomes fact that Japanese are taking market-oriented approach (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * MDC Communications Corp., Toronto, agreed to acquire 75 percent of Cybersight, an interactive agency with offices in Santa Monica, Calif., and Portland, Ore. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Web Site Designed to Let Free Speech Ring Out
abstract: Digital Freedom Network, proponent of free speech that is working with numerous international human rights groups, has established Internet Web site (www.dfn.org) that includes collected writings from more than dozen countries where free expression has been supressed (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Raising cigarette taxes will surely punish tobacco's victims.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says economists and legal scholars wonder whether tax-based fix for tobacco is good public policy; new cigarette taxes will drive up retail price of tobacco and wind up punishing the victims; bulk of tax will be on people making less than $30,000 a year; most costs of smoking-related illneses are offset by reduced Social Security payments to smokers who die young; Government could better deter teen-age smoking by insisting that stores not sell tobacco to minors; drawing (M)

headline: BOEING TO TAKE ADDITIONAL $350 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Boeing Co, which has already cited production problems for $2.6 billion in charges, says it will take additional pretax charge of $350 million in first quarter for its 737 jetliner and that it might have to take further charges for it later (S)

headline: East Timor Separatist Accepts Parts of Jakarta Autonomy Offer
abstract: East Timorese independence leader, Jose Ramos-Horta, says he will accept offer of limited autonomy within Indonesia now and five-year delay on referendum on territory's permanent status, but will not agree to recognition of Indonesian sovereignty in meantime (S)

headline: It's a Mall . . . It's an Airport; . . . It's Both: The Latest Trend in Terminals
abstract: Number of airports are turning their concourses into shopping malls; Pittsburgh International, major hub for US Airways, was one of first airport to emphasize shopping; it gives merchants access to around 60,000 passengers a day and has about 100 retailers; airport stores can be profitable: sales per square foot are often three or four times as high as those in other locations, even though prices are same as at malls; airports from Heathrow, outside London, to LaGuardia in New York to National in Washington, DC, have undergone major renovations in recent years in which addition of new stores has played key role; others, like Chicago's O'Hare, are following suit; graph; photos (M)

headline: Liz Claiborne Wins Case In Trademark Infringement
abstract: Liz Claiborne Inc wins trademark infringement case against Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc, a Brooklyn sweater factory that is involved in tangle of litigation with Claiborne and Unite, garment workers' union; Federal Judge Robert W Sweet rules that Mademoiselle repeatedly violated Claiborne's trademarks in 1995 by selling thousands of sweaters made exclusively for Claiborne through other outlets; Mademoiselle is ordered to pay damages of $582,000, its estimated profits on illegal sales; ruling is important victory for Claiborne, which once boasted of dealing with Mademoiselle's showcase unionized factory; as Claiborne sent more of its manufacturing abroad, it tried to reduce its dealings with Mademoiselle, but was blocked by union arbitrator in 1996; second arbitration case was pending when Claiborne and Unite settled arbitration claims last spring; in separate suit, Mademoiselle has accused Claiborne of conspiring with Unite to drop arbitration claims in exchange for payment of $13 million in 'liquidated damages'; Mademoiselle is operating under federal bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: G.M. Chief Gets Larger Bonus
abstract: General Motors Corp chairman-chief executive John F Smith Jr received bonus of nearly $2.5 million in 1997, up 53 percent from 1996 bonus of $1.6 million (S)

headline: We, the People Of the Internet; Cybercitizens Debate How to Form On-Line Union, Perfect or Otherwise
abstract: United States Government's plan to hand over control of registering Internet addresses to as-yet-unformed nonprofit international group spurs heated debate over group's makeup; representatives from Government and industry and libertarian technologists who have historically supervised Internet have competing goals, but share belief in free-flowing communication and in value of electronic commerce; effort to supervise Internet addresses has become first test of self-governance movement; Prof David Farber, one of Internet's founding fathers, warns governments will seize control if Net establishment fails to reach accord, interview; photos (M)

headline: I.B.M. Reports That Its Net Fell 13% in First Quarter
abstract: IBM says earnings fell 13 percent in first quarter; attributes decline to price wars in personal computer business; company earned $1.036 billion, down from $1.195 billion; sales edged up 1.8 percent, to $17.6 billion; chart (L)

headline: Clash of Technologies in Merger
abstract: Analysis of Citicorp-Travelers Group Inc merger holds it will likely take better part of a decade, at best, before computer and data base systems of combined company can be fully integrated; says technology experts point out that Citicorp itself has been trying for 10 years to merge computers that run its banks in 100 countries into one happy family and that work is far from done; holds computers in Travelers insurance company are barely on speaking terms with machines in its Salomon Smith Barney brokerage or its Commercial Credit finance company (L)

headline: 'Bye, Mom; Hello to a Higher Fee
abstract: Article on doubling of escort fees charged by Northwest and Delta airlines for unaccompanied children; it is likely that competitors will follow suit; drawing; chart (M)

headline: Homes for Elderly Replacing Family Care as China Grays
abstract: Dramatic sign of China's demographic aging is boom in old-age homes, shift away from traditional practice in which parents remain with children; graying of world's largest population, although still in initial stage, is already affecting everything from family living traditions to urban attitudes about merits of sons versus daughters; rising proportion of elderly reflects longer life expectancies and effects of China's stringent family planning policies; country must scramble to create Western-style pension and social security programs on vast scale, since rising share of elderly retirees coincides with collapse of Communist system of cradle-to-grave welfare; situation in cities such as Guangzhou, which are expanding homes for elderly, discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: ING Is Selling U.S. Units for $1.15 Billion
abstract: ING Groep N.V. said today that it was selling its United States property and casualty insurance business to Guardian Royal Exchange P.L.C. for $1.15 billion.    ING, the second-biggest financial services company in the Netherlands, said that it in turn would buy Guardian's Canadian property and casualty insurance business for $375 million. Guardian, Britain's fourth-largest general insurer by market capitalization, will pay the $775 million balance for the United States businesses in cash.

headline: Challenges Inside and Out Confront OPEC
abstract: Lowest oil prices in 12 years have created severe crisis for oil-producing countries both inside and outside of OPEC, and they have been struggling to reverse the decline; OPEC has found itself increasingly impotent in oil market, and as its 11 member nations prepare to meet in Vienna, a new, loosely structured coalition has emerged, led by such big OPEC members as Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, as well as non-OPEC giants like Mexico and Norway; whether such a coalition can turn prices around remains much open to question; graph (M)

headline: Fiat and Renault Set To Pool Bus Units
abstract: Fiat SpA says it will pool its bus-making operations with Renault SA in 50-50 joint venture that will become second-largest bus maker in Europe, with annual sales of about $1 billion, producing 4,500 buses and 1,500 mini-buses a year; largest bus maker is Daimler-Benz (S)

headline: Another Way to Fly
abstract: Letter from Carl J Selbo on enjoying Apr 16 article on flight simulation software (S)

headline: Market Falls Again, Ending Worst Month Since October
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 70.25 points, to 8,899.95; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 6.78 points, to 1,090.82; Nasdaq composite index drops 15.75 points, to 1,778.87; graph of Dow Jones average; tables of hot and cold stocks and of favorite stocks (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: DuPont to Buy Out Merck In Joint Drug Venture  DuPont will pay Merck $2.6 billion for its half of DuPont Merck Pharmaceutical, the joint venture they formed in 1991.    Analysts were surprised. They had been speculating about what DuPont would do with the $5 billion it is expected to receive from selling 20 percent of its oil unit, Conoco, in a deal announced last week. [Page D5.]

headline: London Journal; Britons Prick Up Their Ears: Blair's a Li'l Peculiar
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair surprises accent-conscious Britain by adopting hybrid accent called Estuary English, dropping t's and h's in his appearence on television talk show; accent is generally used by modestly accented people trying to appear more upscale and by people with upscale accents, particularly teen-agers in expensive schools, trying to sound more streetwise; Blair spokeswoman denies he puts on new accent; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls to lowest point since August 1991, extending its drop from May 18, on worries over effect of Indonesia's instability on Asia; in New York, dollar rises to 136.44 yen from 136.25; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Pentagon Report Now Belittles the Menace Posed by Cuba
abstract: Pentagon intelligence report concludes that collapse of Soviet bloc in 1991 gravely eroded size and power of Cuba's military, leaving it barely able to support itself, let alone attack its neighbors; House Speaker Newt Gingrich, in protest to Pentagon, says Fidel Castro remains 'dangerous and unstable tyrant' (M)

headline: Accountants Want Lawyers' Secrecy Rights
abstract: Accountants are using public's frustration with Internal Revenue Service to push bill that would give them same privileges that lawyers have in keeping tax advice confidential; measure, approved by House and by Senate committee as part of broad IRS overhaul bill, would give tax accountants boost in their battle for business with tax lawyers; lawyers complain it would move accounting firms closer to being able to practice corporate law (M)

headline: Iwerks Plan For Showscan Is Overruled
abstract: Shareholders of Iwerks Entertainment Inc overrules company's management, voting down plan to acquire rival Showscan Entertainment Inc (M)

headline: Where Nothing Lasts Forever; Subtle Reminders for Consumers on Replacing Products
abstract: Manufacturers of wide variety of products, including some nonperishable goods, are using 'freshness dates' and other strategies to prod consumers to use more of their products faster and replace them more frequently; this adds up to increased sales for producers; products with suggested expiration dates include razors, toothbrushes, batteries, even beer, which in fact can last for years; ability to influence people's behavior has been proved to work; car dealers trained millions of drivers to change their oil every 3,000 miles instead of 3,300 miles, and when working women stopped baking cakes in 1970's, maker of Arm & Hammer baking soda sold them on idea of pouring product down drain to insure fresh-smelling sinks; photos (M)

headline: CLINTON IN CHINA: REACTION -- Surprising Exchange on Rights on Chinese Television; Clinton's Harsh Words On '89 Massacre Seep Into Beijing's Alleys
abstract: Pres Clinton, in nationally televised news conference from Beijing, says Chinese Government's use of military force to suppress 1989 Tiananmen demonstrations was tragic and wrong; there was no advance warning by Chinese news organizations about broadcast, and Clinton's frankest comments are omitted from later news accounts; still, word gets out and residents of Beijing express surprise that authorities allowed Clinton's remarks to be broadcast on air; state-run news organizations uniformly support 'resolute measures' taken in crackdown, in which hundreds of civilians are believed to have been killed; Government's decision to allow broadcast of Clinton's comments seems to reflect situation where policy is catching up with reality already out on street; people in Beijing speak quite freely about politics, and many say without hesitation that they agree with Clinton's assessment; photo (M)

headline: Article 1998042200000601969 -- No Title
abstract: ENRON CORP., Houston, said it planned to sell 15 million new shares, in a move that could raise more than $770 million, to repay debt and pay for expansion of its retail electricity business.    SYSCO CORP., Houston, a food service and distribution company, agreed to buy the food service distribution business of the closely held Jordan's Meats Inc., for undisclosed terms.

headline: ARMSTRONG WORLD SEEKS GERMAN FLOORING CONCERN
abstract: Armstrong World Industries will make $275-million tender offer for DIW AG, German flooring maker (S)

headline: Cephalon Falls as F.D.A. Meeting Is Canceled
abstract: Shares in Cephalon Inc drop 21 percent after company says Food and Drug Administration has canceled advisory panel meeting to reviews its drug Myotrophin for Lou Gehrig's disease; shares in Gilead Sciences Inc gain about 20 percent after company publishes better-than-expected results from clinical trials of potential new AIDS drug called Preveon (S)

headline: G.M. Chief Urges Strike's End as 23d Plant Is Shut
abstract: General Motors Corp chairman John F Smith calls for speedy resolution of two-week strike that has shut down virtually all of car maker's North American assembly plants and has idled more than 100,000 workers; Pres Clinton urges GM and United Automobile Workers to work out their differences (M)

headline: U.S. Theme Can Make a Film a Tough Sell Abroad
abstract: Mutual Film International pools money from its French, German and Japanese partners to buy American films for distribution around world; it is tricky business, because world is made up of hundreds of different markets with different cultures and tastes, and movie that is great hit within United States may be flop elsewhere; photo; chart (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.36   5.46        3-month T-bills   4.87   4.93   4.96        6-month T-bills   5.07   5.11   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.72   3.70   3.64        10-yr. T-note   5.46   5.44   6.44        30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.64   6.73        Telephone bd.   7.09   7.09   7.77        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.21   5.65          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls sharply, erasing gains from a day earlier, on renewed concern about oversupply after Norway hints it will not go along with OPEC output cuts; June contracts fall 42 cents, to $15.32 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Novartis Plans To Research Disease Genes
abstract: Novartis AG of Switzerland, in largest commitment yet by major pharmaceutical company to field of genomics, to announce it will invest $250 million in proprietary research institute to be build in La Jolla, Calif; establishment of institute could give Novartis a major competitive advantage as drug discovery moves into new era based on knowledge of how diseases progress at molecular and genetic level (L)

headline: CABOT TO TAKE A $54 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Cabot Corp will take charge of about $54 million in third quarter (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VIAD CORP., Phoenix, said its Travelers Express Co. unit began a $17-a-share cash tender offer for Moneygram Payment Systems Inc., of Englewood, Colo.    WESTERN ATLAS INC., Houston, completed its cash tender offer for 3-D Geophysical Inc. for $114.8 million after it settled a lawsuit by a 3-D shareholder who said the price was too low.

headline: Japanese Yen Weakens a Bit Against Dollar, but Stocks Rise
abstract: Financial markets in Asia react cautiously on June 22 to political and diplomatic efforts to stabilize Japanese yen and other Asia currencies; yen dips modestly against dollar in early trading, to 137.35 from 136.10 on June 19, erasing slight gains brought on by US intervention; Japanese stocks are stable, with Nikkei average up 12.34 points, to 15,280.32 in early trading (M)

headline: Japan's Lack of Leadership Pushes ASEAN Toward Cooperation With China
abstract: SINGAPORE—  China has used its strong economy and apparent immunity to Asia's financial turmoil to gain significant diplomatic favor with its previously suspicious neighbors at the expense of Japan, which has failed to meet regional expectations of leadership, officials and analysts say.

headline: Nations Endorse Moves to Eradicate the Plague of Small Arms
abstract: Representatives from African and Western nations endorse measures to control spread of light weapons; action comes at two-day meeting in Oslo, Norway, called to advance proposed moratorium on export, import and manufacture of light weapons in West Africa, and to consider how that moratorium can be model for other regions of world; meeting is convened by Norwegian Initiative on Small Arms Tranfers and United Nations Development Program (M)

headline: Rural Indonesia Projects Win 225 Million From World Bank
abstract: World Bank approves $225 million loan to Indonesia; money will go directly to accounts set up by community leaders in rural areas and be used to build roads and schools and improve water supply (M)

headline: G.M.'s Plant in Brazil Raises Fears Closer to Home
abstract: Strike now crippling General Motors, while partly about short-term job security and workplace safety disputes, reflects larger struggle over GM effort to adopt at home manufacturing techniques it introduces at plants in Brazil and elsewhere abroad; GM's use of pre-assembled parts, trend sweeping auto industry, has allowed it to cut number of workers needed for each vehicle produced; Brazilian unions have accepted cut because GM has been hiring as it builds more plants in nation's expanding market; effort to cut employment more quickly at remaining factories in United States, where GM loses market share, alarms United Auto Workers members (M)

headline: Nasdaq Fines Morgan Stanley $1 Million
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers fines Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co $1 million, contending that firm and its traders manipulated Nasdaq 100-stock index by setting false, high prices for some of underlying shares; Morgan Stanley plans to appeal decision (M)

headline: Foreigners Buy Korea Stock but Not Companies
abstract: Foreigners have been buying South Korean bonds and pouring cash into country's resurgent stock market but direct foreign investment in Korean companies remains sluggish; while foreign investors complain about sketchy accounting and legal barriers, many of negotiations are bogged down over issue of price; even acutely troubled Korean companies are expensive, their ability to survive bolstered by easy availability of capital; South Korean banks are finding ways to prop up favored corporations that are technically insolvent, and the result, in eyes of many foreign investors, is that valuations are unrealistically high (L)

headline: Patriarch of a New, Uncelebrated Family
abstract: Interview with Mark P Hurley, founder of Undiscovered Managers, family of mutual funds whose portfolios are run by hodgepodge of obscure money management firms; Hurley says what sets his mutual funds apart is that they are run by small independent outfits not yet discoverd by the masses; photo (M)

headline: The Web Reflects a Wider World
abstract: Dominance of English in cyberspace is being challenged, and speakers with a first language other than English have become the fastest-growing group of new Internet users; on-line multilingualism could have profound implications for how the Internet is used and developed and presage a truly global mass medium; one result of the shift could be a crack in American hegemony over Internet culture; photos of web users in San Jaun, PR, and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; chart of languages on the Web (M)

headline: Half-Year Profit Slid 91%, NEC Says
abstract: NEC Corp says earnings fell 91 percent in second half of year ended on March 31; net income for second half of fiscal year dropped to 5.539 billion yen ($40.4 million) from 60.370 billion yen a year earlier; revenue declined 6.6 percent, to 2.53 trillion yen from 2.71 trillion yen (S)

headline: Unilever Profit Beats Analysts' Expectations
abstract: Unilever PLC reports first-quarter pretax profit jumped 56 percent, to 754 million pounds ($1.25 billion), up from 482 million pounds a year ago; graph (S)9

headline: The One-Stop Financial Mall: Is It What Peoria Longs For?
abstract: Citicorp-Travelers Group merger proposal, while praised on Wall Street, is inspired more by corporate view that consumers who have abandoned Main Street shops for giant malls are now eager to see their insurance agencies, bank branches and securities brokers as financial supermarkets; analysts like Charlene Stern caution that new behemoth, Citigroup, will have to learn from best retailers, not from each other, about how to sell each of their products effectively; company still must negotiate thicket of regulatory issues, as well as public concern about financial concentration (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           April 3   Mar 27   April 4       1998   1998   1997       Gasoline production, daily   8.0   8.0   7.7       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.4   3.4       Gasoline stocks   213.0   215.0   196.0       Distillate stocks   122.9   123.4   98.4       Crude imports, daily   8.1   8.8   8.3       Product imports, daily   2.2   1.7   2.1       Crude stocks   328.5   328.9   308.4       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   94.3   94.1   94.3          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: In Estate Planning, A Roth I.R.A. Shines
abstract: Article describes advantages of Roth individual retirement accounts to older investors who are planning estate disbursement (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Oil prices snap two-day rally and tumble 6.6 percent on lack of domestic storage space because of excess supply, forcing traders to sell; July delivery contract falls 83 cents, to $11.77 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies column; yen retreats on market disappointment with details of Japan's $128 billion package to invigorate economy; graph (S)

headline: Circulation Of Papers Rises Slightly, Audit Says
abstract: Audit Bureau of Circulations releases figures showing that newspaper circulation, battered by decade of declines, is showing limited improvement for second time in year; finds increases at New York metropolitan area dailies and at USA Today helped push overall daily circulation up by seven-tenths of 1 percent; Sunday newspaper circulation declined by 1.7 percent; perennial circulation leader, Wall Street Journal, lost nine-tenths of 1 percent of its average weekday circulation; Washington Post saw weekday circulation decline 1.1 percent; USA Today's weekday average circulation grew by 3.2 percent; second-strongest circulation gainer was Los Angeles Times, up 2.45 percent (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP., New York, named Thomas Miglis head of global systems, to manage the company's year 2000 software fixes, preparing for European monetary union and other projects.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  NONE REPORTED

headline: Ex-Bosnian Serb Chief Maneuvers
abstract: Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, charged with war crimes in connection with 43-month siege of Sarajevo and massacre of several thousand Bosnian Muslims in Srebrenica area in 1995, reportedly contacts several rival Bosnian Serb leaders to explore whether any alternatives to trial in the Hague are acceptable; in recent months, Bosnian Serb Government led by his rivals and supported by West, has stripped him of much of his influence and access to money (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about the exposure of two Dreyfus Corporation mutual funds to sudden shifts in the value of small-company stocks misstated the percentage of shares of Atlantic Pharmaceuticals Inc. that are held by Dreyfus funds. It is 8 percent, not 23 percent.    The article also characterized the financial results of Atlantic Pharmaceuticals incorrectly. While the company had no sales through the first quarter of 1998, it received a $2.5 million license fee in May.

headline: Summit Talks Shift Focus To Atom Tests By New Delhi
abstract: Underground nuclear tests by India shifts focus of economic summit of eight leading industrial nations in Birmingham, England; Pres Clinton steps up criticisms of India in hopes of dissuading Pakistan from following suit; has so far had little success in persuading allies to follow US lead by imposing economic sanctions on India (M)

headline: WASTE MANAGEMENT SET TO CUT ITS DIVIDEND
abstract: Waste Management Inc. said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to conserve cash and take a second-quarter pretax charge of $70 million to $90 million for costs related to the year 2000 software bug. The trash company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., cut its dividend to a penny a share from 17 cents, payable on July 2 to shareholders of record on June 17. It said it would license USA Waste Services Inc.'s plan to eliminate the 2000 problem from its computer systems and discontinue its own plan. The moves come two months after the beleaguered company agreed to be bought by its rival, USA Waste, for $21.8 billion. Waste Management shares fell 43.75 cents yesterday, to $33.125.

headline: Hong Kong's Latin Competitor; Panama's 'Den of Pirates' Tries to Upgrade Its Image
abstract: ''A den of pirates,'' one American Government official snorted when asked about the warren of shops, warehouses and banks just off the Caribbean entrance to the Panama Canal. In recent books, the spy novelist John Le Carre has portrayed the 1.5-square-mile walled compound as a steamy, seedy nest of intrigue where, for the right price and with the right contacts, just about anything goes.    That much isn't fiction. The free-trade zone here is the largest in the world outside Hong Kong, selling more than $6.2 billion in goods in 1997 to customers from all over Latin America and the Caribbean.

headline: GLIMCHER REALTY TRUST BUYING 5 MALLS FOR $375 MILLION
abstract: Glimcher Realty Trust says it agreed to buy five shopping malls for total of $375 million from various sellers in privately negotiated deals; malls are in Alabama, California, Minnesota, North Carolina and Oregon (S)

headline: For Lee Iacocca, a New Game of Chicken
abstract: Outlook for Koo Koo Roo restaurant chain discussed in light of appointment of Lee A Iacocca as acting chairman, move that greatly boosted company stock; company has increased revenue rapidly, but never made profits because of rising costs; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Barnes & Noble Adds Software To Expand On-Line Bookstore
abstract: Barnes & Noble, as part of major overhaul of its on-line bookstore, adds software superstore with 1,000 titles (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  Please release me? That's not the tune that captive REIT's are singing. The current crop may outperform an earlier generation of trusts. By Sana Siwolop.

headline: Boeing Falls Short on Plane Deliveries
abstract: Boeing Co says it has delivered 108 planes in first quarter, two short of its previous estimate, as company tries to clear up production bottlenecks (S)

headline: UNOVA BUYS AMTECH RADIO FREQUENCY IDENTIFICATION UNIT
abstract: Unova Inc acquires Amtech Corp's high-frequency radio frequency identification unit, Transportation Systems Group, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Simplicity Limits Options
abstract: Harold Goldberg, owner of Web design firm, reviews World Wide Web-site development product offered by Microsoft Corp for novice designers; photo (M)

headline: For Nigeria's Leader, Offense Is the Best Defense
abstract: New Nigerian ruler Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar apparently brings sense of urgency to transition to civilin rule, acting decisively without waiting to consolidate power; his best hope seems to be working with jailed civilian leader Moshood K O Abiola; photo (M)

headline: The consolidation trend reaches the industry's second tier as Lois/USA acquires a smaller rival.
abstract: Lois/USA Inc is making its second acquisition since December, buying Scaros & Casselman, a Stamford, Conn, agency that opened in 1993; all-cash price is undisclosed (M)

headline: U.S. Gives Netanyahu a Reprieve On Pullout Decision for 2 Weeks
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu wins two-week reprieve in battle over 13 percent withdrawal from West Bank that US has set as threshold for resuming peace negotiations with Palestinians; American officials insist that, despite retreat, Pres Clinton still intends to compel Netanyahu by end of May to make difficult choice of making substantive withdrawal in West Bank and ending 14 months of deadlock in negotiations, or rejecting US plan and forcing crisis with Americans and Palestinians; Netanyahu's upcoming five-day visit to US, in which he is expected to intensify campaign against Clinton Administration's pressures, discussed (M)

headline: AHL SERVICES TO BUY MINNESOTA MARKETING COMPANY
abstract: AHL Services Inc to purchase marketing-product distribution business of Gage Marketing Group for $81.1 million (S)

headline: U.N. Panel Defeats U.S. Move to Censure Cuba on Human Rights
abstract: United Nations Human Rights Commission, 19-16, rejects United States-led effort to censure Cuba for its human rights practices; defeat apparently reflects growing view, particularly among Europeans and Latin Americans, that Cuba cannot be isolated forever and that Cuba is trying to meet international human rights obligations; commission strongly condemns human rights violations in Iraq, 32-0 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls to 6 1/2-year low after Moody's Investors Service Inc warns it might downgrade Japan's credit rating; dollar hits 135.42 yen, strongest since September 1991, before settling at 135.10 yen, up from 133.50; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Dash Past Rush?
abstract: Talkers magazine says Dr Laura Schlessinger and Howard Stern have eclipsed Rush Limbaugh as most listened-to radio talk-show hosts; experts say ascent of Dr Schlessinger and Stern over Limbaugh reflects broader shift away from political talk radio as strong economy and weariness with scandal dull public's interest in Washington, DC; photos (L)

headline: Joint Efforts to Prop Up Yen Cause a Selloff in Treasuries
abstract: Sharp selloff of US Treasury securities linked to efforts by US and Japan to prop up Japanese yen; 30-year Treasury bond falls 1 9/32, to 105 17/32; yield rises to 5.73 percent, from 5.65 percent on June 16; graph shows average for Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Compaq to Shift A Key Assignment
abstract: Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of Interpublic Group of Companies will soon lose crucial ad assignment from Compaq Computer Corp to DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group (S)

headline: Lyondell Petrochemical to Buy ARCO Chemical
abstract: Lyondell Petrochemical Co to buy ARCO Chemical Co from Atlantic Richfield Co for $5.6 billion in cash, a deal that would triple Lyondell's size and make it a major provider of chemicals; Lyondell will also assume $870 million of ARCO Chemical's debt (M)

headline: Baker Hughes Likely to Buy Western Atlas
abstract: Baker Hughes reportedly is close to accord on buying Western Atlas Inc for about $5 billion in stock (M)

headline: Soaring at 4,500 Feet, Steps From the Fridge
abstract: Computer flight simulations are among the most popular software sold; FAA even approves some desktop simulations for training under certain conditions; some pilots still regard simulations as a waste of time or even counterproductive; assessment of simulation software from Microsoft, Sierra and Eidos Interactive/Looking Glass; photo (L)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Why Microsoft Should Be Left Alone
abstract: Bhaskar Chakravorti, senior member of global consulting practice of Monitor Co, scores antitrust actions against Microsoft Corp; says basic lesson is that technology markets, properly understood, require no more regulatory intervention than other markets; holds regulators need only increase speed of competitive dynamic by helping to establish technological standards and by insuring flow of innovation through enforcement of intellectual property rights (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Germany's currency initially rises on speculation that interest rates will be increased in preparation for the euro, but it ends weaker as speculation wanes; in New York, the dollar rises to 1.7962 marks from 1.7925; graph; chart (S)

headline: David Schneider, 77; Led Fight for the Concorde
abstract: David Schneider, airline executive who led British Airways campaign to bring supersonic Concorde to New York, dies at age 77 (S)

headline: Compressed Data; I.R.S. Redesigns Form On Tax-Exempt Status
abstract: Internal Revenue Service plans to require organizations seeking tax-exempt status to provide their Web addresses; will check their Web sites to help determine whether they are really commercial enterprises (S)

headline: Sub's Goal Infiltration, Seoul Says
abstract: South Korean Army officers said today that they had found evidence that the North Korean submarine caught this week in a fishing net had been engaged in an infiltration mission and had just picked up or dropped off spies or commandos.    A search of the submarine found the bodies of nine North Koreans, four of whom were grouped together and had died of single gunshot wounds to the head.

headline: The Silicon Valley Gang; An Influential Industry With Lots of Money Is Getting Its Way on Capitol Hill
abstract: Computer industry with lots of money is getting its way in Congress; number 1 issue on computer industry's agenda is Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act, bill approved today by finance subcommittee of House Commerce Committee; identical legislation has already passed in the Senate; bill would prevent investors and their lawyers from filing class-action securities fraud cases in state courts; instead, these suits would have to be brought in Federal court under strict rules imposed by Congress in 1995 to discourage 'meritless' lawsuits; partly through Technology Network, coalition of 140 California companies, computer industry has provided substantial campaign contributions to politicians; in 1995 and 1996, industry gave $4 million to Congressional candidates; computer companies and their executives have given more than $1.2 million in last 18 months; leading recipients of such contributions are Sens Alfonse M D'Amato and Christopher J Dodd; chart; photos (M)

headline: This Time, Things Really Are Different
abstract: Floyd Norris's last Market Watch column on the stock market (Norris is leaving business section to join editorial board; Gretchen Morgenson will take over column); focuses on some week's events, including charges of fraud lodged against penny-stock brokerage firm Biltmore Securities, rapid rise in K-tel stock, Goldman Sach's prospects of underwriting securities that would let investors bet on rainfall or cold weather and risks of derivatives; graph (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Conference Takes On Internet Privacy Again
abstract: Commerce Department yo hold summit meeting on Internet privacy amid continuing dispute between industry, which holds it acts to protect privacy, and other groups complaining industry self-regulation is inadequate; drawing (M)

headline: Computer and Me, And Baby Makes 3
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (User's Guide) column on computer software for very young children touted as intelligence-enhancing discusses experience of introducing her 9-month-old to Jump Start Baby CD-ROM; photo (M)

headline: Netscape Signs Web Directories
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp signs agreements with Internet directory companies including Lycos Inc and Infoseek Corp to feature them on World Wide Web (S)

headline: Kellogg, in Slump, Names New President
abstract: Kellogg Co names Carlos Gutierrez as its president and chief operating officer, positioning him to take over world's largest cereal company; Gutierrez is seen as heir apparent to chairman and chief executive Arnold Langbo; he fills position that has been vacant since 1992 (S)

headline: Sunken Treasure's Sinking Fortunes; 'X' No Longer Marks the Spot For Governments or Investors
abstract: Environmental, cultural and historical forces are merging to alter practice of shipwreck salvage; new rules along United States coastline are placing wrecks off limits or making them tough to retrieve; United Nations is set to begin debating treaty to protect wrecks worldwide; shift is hurting treasure hunter Mel Fisher, who also battles state suspicion that he sold fake coins; table; map; photos (M)

headline: Trusts Cast Off Fusty Image
abstract: MANCHESTER—  If the mention of trusts and trust funds conjures up images of old money and bespoke private banking arrangements for the truly wealthy, think again. Trusts can be a useful and cost-effective financial planning tool for individuals with modest fortunes who wish to preserve family assets and ease the settling of their financial affairs after death.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Little Change Is Expected From F.T.C. Move on Intel  Intel, which has about 90 percent of the microprocessing market for personal computers, is facing its greatest level of competition in more than a decade. Yet, the Federal Trade Commission is preparing to file an antitrust lawsuit against Intel, accusing the company of abusing its position as the monopoly manufacturer of microprocessors and bullying some computer manufacturers.

headline: Microsoft Case Gets September Trial Date
abstract: Sept 8 date set for antitrust trial of Microsoft

headline: Experts Dispute Iraq On Germ Weapons
abstract: Independent experts who reviewed Iraq's progress in eliminating biological weapons at Baghdad's request have rejected President Saddam Hussein's contention that he no longer has a germ warfare program.    Their report called Iraqi disclosures ''incomplete and inadequate,'' and said Baghdad had failed to convince them that biological weapons have been eliminated.

headline: G.M. Closes More Plants; Talks Falter
abstract: General Motors' North American operations move closer to being shut down completely, as strikes at two Michigan parts factories force company to idle 13,000 more workers and partly close host of other parts and assembly plants; combined work stoppages have sent 63,100 workers home and closed more than 40 assembly and parts factories in US, Mexico and Canada (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Werner Michel, a longtime executive at Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of True North Communications, is retiring after more than 50 years in the agency and media industries. He was most recently senior partner for national broadcast programming at BJK&E Media.

headline: Foreign Banks Pulled Out Of Asia Late, A Report Says
abstract: Report released by Bank for International Settlements says international banks began pulling their money out of Asia during last half of 1997, with South Korea and Thailand bearing brunt of withdrawals; lending to Indonesia remained stable between June and December 1997, but figures do not reflect recent political and social upheaval in the country (M)

headline: First Lady Visits Center For Women And the Law
abstract: First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton and Sec of State Madeleine Albright travel to outskirts of Beijing to visit women's legal aid center that operates on leading edge of China's developing legal system, tackling wide range of issues affecting women; Clinton praises center's work as 'ground-breaking;' Albright praises it for innovative and courageous work (M)

headline: 13 Shopping Centers Sold
abstract: Malan Realty Investors Inc will buy 13 shopping cents in six Midwestern states from Sandor Development Co for $33.7 million (S)

headline: Intel Seeks New Information in U.S. Suit
abstract: Intel Corp, in its first formal response to Government's antitrust suit filed earlier this month, says it cannot respond to complaint unless Federal Trade Commission provides more specific information on who has been harmed by company's action; Intel argues that companies cited in complaint--Compaq Computer Corp, Digital Equipment Corp and Intergrah Corp--are customers, not competitors, and therefore are not subject to harm under Federal antitrust laws (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Motley Fool to Produce A Weekly Radio Show
abstract: David and Tom Gardner, founders of Motley Fool on-line investment sites, to produce weekly radio show in partnership with Cox Radio Inc (S)

headline: Restrictions on Iraq Will Stay in Force, U.N. Council Rules
abstract: Security Council decides to extend sanctions against Iraq, ignoring threats from Baghdad that it will disrupt future arms inspections if sanctions are not lifted; Bill Richardson, US representative, says United Nations weapons inspectors have found that Iraq still has long way to go in accounting for all of its weapons of mass destruction; Council, in gesture to Iraqis, who have recently allowed greater access to arms inspectors, does not limit future sanctions reviews to six-month intervals but reverts to system of permitting reviews every 60 days; US has vowed to veto any lifting of sanctions until Iraq has met number of requirements, including verifiable disarmament and return of prisoners and property seized in invasion of Kuwait (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Who gets information first on auto sales figures can be critically important, and controversial.
abstract: Market Place column on controversy surrounding issuance of monthly auto sales figures; says investors, stock analysts and even Federal Reserve officials eagerly await release each month of sales for signs of condition of individual companies and health of economy as a whole; notes some people, though, wait longer than others; Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt Jr and others criticize selective disclosure of sales figures (L)

headline: Acquisition In Kentucky By Ohio Bank
abstract: Star Banc Corp to acquire Trans Financial Inc for $696 million in stock (S)

headline: Saving for College: Why Bother?
abstract: Letter from Helga Olsson says people are frittering their money away and then seeking help from Government to fund their children's college education (S)

headline: Bold Step for Citigroup On Shaky Asian Ground
