abstract: Merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc could reshape financial industry in Asia; Citicorp chairman John S Reed, who first realized his vision of Citibank as financial supermarket for emerging global middle class in Asia during 1980's, is betting that Asia's middle-class consumers are ready to buy even broader array of financial services from single company; it is bold bet--all more risky because economic crisis in Asia has sapped finances of very customers enlarged company would try to reach (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COLLAGEN CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., a medical technology company, plans to sell its Lipomatrix Inc. breast implant unit to improve its profits and focus on treatments for human tissue.    UNICORP ENERGY CORP., Toronto, an investment company, agreed to sell its indirect interests in three residential properties held through SPY Properties Ltd.

headline: Big Board Seat Price Dips
abstract: Seat on New York Stock Exchange sells for $1.4 million, down from recent sale of $1.6 million on April 3 (S)

headline: ZENITH DOUBLES LAYOFF AT ILLINOIS PICTURE TUBE PLANT
abstract: Zenith Electronics Corp doubles to 800 number of jobs it will cut at Melrose Park, Ill, color picture tube plant (S)

headline: Morocco Finds Fundamentalism Benign but Scary
abstract: Militant Islamic groups have been mobilizing and expanding in Morocco; they have gained followers in shantytowns in Casablanca and other cities by assisting sick and unemployed, and are recruiting high school teachers and university students; photo (M)

headline: SENATORS REJECT BID TO LIMIT COSTS OF ENLARGING NATO
abstract: Senate rejects measure to limit United States share of cost of the weapons Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic will need to join NATO; amendment, proposed by Sen Tom Harkin, would limit US military subsidies to prospective members to 25 percent of total NATO aid to nations; Senate debate on NATO expansion focuses on range of issues; photo (M)

headline: JAPAN'S ECONOMY APPEARS BLEAKER
abstract: Japan, painting bleaker-than-expected economic picture, reports its output shrank at stunning annual rate of 5.3% in first quarter; reports output for fiscal year ended Mar 31 fell 0.7%; confirms output fell for two consecutive quarters, meeting generally accepted definition of recession; Treasury Sec Robert Rubin again urges Japan to fundamentally change its financial structure and vigorously spur economy; Japanese officials again warn yen, which has fallen 3 percent against dollar this week, is falling too far and too fast; Chinese Amb Li Zhaoxing urges Group of Seven industrialized nations to bolster yen; graph; photo (M)

headline: Advisers and Lawyers Stand To Get Richer in Auto Deal
abstract: Several investment bankers and lawyers say investment bankers who advised two auto companies--Credit Suisse First Boston for Chrysler Corp and Goldman, Sachs & Co and Deutsche Bank for Daimler-Benz--could make combined total of $60 million to $80 million for their work on proposed $39 million merger deal; figure could reach $100 million; those fees do not include army of lawyers who get their cut, which could tally more than $10 million; Chrysler's chief executive Robert J Eaton could get extra $47.95 million (M)

headline: Rome Journal; Lunch With a Lesson: Pasta a la Linda McCartney
abstract: Linda McCartney Day is observed in Rome, Italy, schools--a meatless homage to former Beatle Paul McCartney's wife, who promoted vegetarianism; some Italian parents are appalled, believing that their children need to eat the eternal pasta with meat sauce as part of healthy diet; photos (M)

headline: Albright Gets New Mission: Patch Rift With Israel
abstract: Pres Clinton, risking more signs of friction in his Mideast policy, orders Sec of State Madeleine Albright to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Washington on May 13 to resolve latest impasse in peace talks; move, also aimed at easing US-Israeli tensions, follows failure of talks in London to seal agreement with Netanyahu on scope of further pullbacks from West Bank in return for stronger Palestinian moves against Muslim militants; photo (M)

headline: Elan Plans to Acquire Neurex In a $700 Million Stock Swap
abstract: Elan Corp, pharmaceuticals company based in Dublin, to acquire Neurex Corp, biotechnology company based in Menlo Park, Calif, in stock swap valued at about $700 million (M)

headline: Q & A / Joseph Estrada : Philippine Election Victor Pledges to 'Unite' Country
abstract: MANILA—  With 80 percent of the ballots counted, the vice president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, has emerged as the clear-cut winner in the presidential election of May 11. Mr. Estrada, who will be inaugurated on June 30 as the successor to President Fidel Ramos, was interviewed Sunday at his residence in the Manila suburb of San Juan by Don Kirk for the International Herald Tribune:

headline: Seoul Ready to Close Two Securities Firms
abstract: South Korean Government is poised to shut Dongsuh Securities Co and Coryo Investment & Securities Co to underscore its determination to bolster foreign investors' confidence in nation's debt-ridden financial industry (S)

headline: Nguyen Co Thach, Hanoi Foreign Minister, 75
abstract: Former Foreign Min Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam, urbane diplomat who struggled but failed to normalize relations with United States in 1980's, dies at 75; career reviewed; photo (M)

headline: Even in a Game, a Formula One Course Can Test Courage
abstract: Joesph Siano, editor at The Times who covered auto racing for the paper from 1988 to 1997, evaluates CD-ROM game F1 Racing Simulation, from UBI Software; photos (M)

headline: Secretary-General Foresees a Growing Activist Role in Crises : A NATO No Longer Just for Defense
abstract: BRUSSELS—  "What kind of world are we living in when people are demonstrating outside my windows at headquarters with placards saying 'NATO, save us'?" Secretary-General Javier Solana asked a visitor.

headline: The First Pets Get Their Own Book
abstract: Simon & Schuster will publish book, Dear Socks, Dear Buddy, devoted to Clinton family pets; book will include introduction by Hillary Rodham Clinton, photos of pets and samples of fan letters from children; Mrs Clinton to donate proceeds to National Park Foundation; photo (M)

headline: DISNEY BUYS REMAINING TWO-THIRDS OF STARWAVE
abstract: Walt Disney Co says it bought remaining two-thirds stake in Starwave Corp that it does not already own; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Hillenbrand to Sell Unit
abstract: Hillenbrand Industries agrees to sell its Medeco Security Locks Inc unit to Assa Abloy AB of Sweden for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Keeping Computer Printers in Ink
abstract: Computer printers have become ubiquitous in offices and homes, and growing number of companies, including Xerox Corp, are recognizing there are billions of dollars to be made in keeping them inked up; Xerox's product is discount-priced replacement toner cartridge for use on Hewlett-Packard Co's laser printers; research firm estimates that almost $5 billion worth of replacement toner cartridges and $6.5 billion of ink-jet cartridges will be sold this year; printer makers, who formerly tolerated interlopers, are now cutting prices, filing lawsuits, even tinkering with their products to make them hard to refill; photo; chart (M)

headline: APARTMENT INVESTMENT OF DENVER ADDING TO HOLDINGS
abstract: Apartment Investment and Management Co completes purchase of Ambassador Apartments Inc for $646 million (S)

headline: China's Leading University Celebrates and Ponders
abstract: Excitement over anticancer drugs angiostatin and endostatin shifts from laboratory to public after reports that tests eradicated tumors in mice with no side effects; many cancer institutes, doctors and cancer support groups report surge of phone calls from those desperate or merely curious; drug manufacturer, Entremed Inc, says it will be 12 to 18 months before first stages of trials on humans begin, and maybe several years before drugs are available on market, if at all; cancer experts say trials could be especially complicated, given that angiostatin and endostatin work unlike other treatments by attacking blood vessels that feed tumors, starving them of blood they need to grow; some warn against putting too much faith in treatment that has not been proved on anything but mice, noting that medicines that often work on mice do not help humans; comments by prominent New York City oncologist Dr Larry Norton noted; Entremed stock soars in trading on May 4, rising by $39.75 per share (M)

headline: Judge Rejects Proposed Pact in Sex Harassment Case
abstract: Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley unexpectedly rejects proposed settlement of sex discrimination case against Smith Barney Inc, criticizing it for vagueness and questioning whether it will have sufficient financial backing; decision does not mean Snith Barney and female plaintiffs must start over, and both sides say they believe judge's criticisms can be swiftly addressed; proposed settlement had been widely expected to win court's approval (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A networking stock vaults on a takeover story, quickly denied.
abstract: Market Place column on expected mergers of telecommunications equipment companies and data-networking equipment companies; notes that news report that Bay Networks Inc (data-networking company) rejected takeover offer from Northern Telecom (telecommunications equipment company) sent Bay's shares up 16 percent on expectation that Bay has another, more generous suitor in wings (M)

headline: Harsh Verdict In Coup Trial Puts Nigeria In a New Bind
abstract: One day after Nigerian military tribunal sentenced Lieut Gen Donaldson Oladipo Diya and five others to death in connection with coup plot, reactions in both Nigeria and abroad suggest that far from clearing his path of perceived enemies, verdict has narrowed maneuvering space of already badly isolated head of state, Gen Sani Abacha (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Plans More Job Cuts in Asia
abstract: Deutsche Bank will dismiss at least 100 more employees in Asia as it continues global reorganization (S)

headline: U.S.-SAUDI INQUIRY INTO 1996 BOMBING IS FALLING APART
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say probe of 1996 terrorist bombing that killed 19 American airman in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, has collapsed over disagreements with Saudis; Administration's insistence that it remains committed to case is at odds with signs that probe has dissolved in muddle of inconclusive evidence and ill-feeling between United States and Saudi Arabia; Federal Bureau of Investigation Dir Louis J Freeh has pulled out dozens of investigators initially sent to bombing scene, leaving only one agent; evidence suggesting Iran sponsored attack has further complicated probe because US and Saudis have recently sought to improve ties with Iran's new Government; families of American victims are beginning to complain openly; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Knotty Issue for Belfast: Fate of Royal Ulster Police
abstract: Polls show warring Protestant and Catholic communities of Northern Ireland, who will vote on peace agreement on May 22, are preoccupied about fate of Royal Ulster Constabulary, most heavily armed police force in Europe that Catholics accuse of enforcing Protestant domination of their community; Catholics are demanding that force be disbanded and replaced entirely, but Protestants object; Protestant leaders make ringing assertions for its record at fighting terrorism, its tradition of loyalty and discipline and gallantry represented by more than 300 of its members killed in action and thousands wounded and disabled; say it should be hailed, not assailed; photo (M)

headline: Bankers' Credo: Bigger Is Better
abstract: Some of biggest names in banking have joined trend toward gargantuan institutions; chart (M)

headline: A New Tactic for Kosovo Rebels: Attacks on Isolated Serb Civilians
abstract: Ethnic Albanian rebels change tactics in recent days and begin attacking and kidnapping Serbian civilians in apparent effort to drive them out of their villages in overwhelmingly Albanian province of Kosovo, Serbia; Kosovo Liberation Army previously avoided attacking civilians, despite deaths of scores of ethnic Albanian civilians in counterinsurgency sweeps by Serbs; take five Serbian villages and many small hamlets and farms around Klina after gun battles with residents; map; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: LENNAR ADDING TO HOLDINGS IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
abstract: Lennar Corp agrees to buy home builders Colrich Communities, Polygon Communities and Communities Southwest for $370 million in cash and stock, continuing its expansion into booming West Coast market (S)

headline: Sony to Rethink Earnings Reports
abstract: Sony Corp says it will report earnings in greater detail, to give shareholders more accurate idea of how each business is performing; Sony reports earnings for year ended March 31 on May 7 (S)

headline: Guidelines Are Sought for Internet Privacy
abstract: Civil liberties advocates and children's groups urge Clinton Administration to abandon its hands-off stance to Internet privacy regulation after Federal Trade Commission report painted dismal picture of effectiveness of companies' self-regulation, especially in regard to children (M)

headline: Jiang Held His Cards Till Final Moment
abstract: American officials say live television access to Chinese audience during Pres Clinton's meeting with Pres Jiang Zemin in Beijing represented breakthrough, but are unsure as to why Jiang allowed wide disemmination of Clinton's views; two-day meeting was fruit of risky decision in November 1996 to conduct summit meetings in Washington and Beijing without conditions, and thus no guarantee of success (M)

headline: Old Idea, New Tools
abstract: John L Hoh Jr letter comments on June 11 article on digital cameras

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen jumps 2 percent on views that central bank is trying to raise its value by buying yen and selling dollars; dollar falls to 143.47 yen from eight-year high of 146.15 on June 15 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen rises against dollar for first time in week on survey suggesting Japan's economy is not as weak as believed; graphs; table (S)

headline: Toll Reaches 96 as Hunt for German Crash Victims Nears End
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung of South Korea looks forward to nine-day visit to US; will resist temptation while in Washington to rub it in to all the officials in the Reagan Administration who wanted nothing to do with him when he was an exiled dissident there; relishes his new leadership role in Asia and says Korea hopes to use its current economic crisis to push through economic reforms and make its democracy stronger so that it will be a model for Asian region; photo (M)

headline: Evercore Makes a Bid For Court TV
abstract: New York investment firm Evercore Partners Inc has made bid to buy majority financial interest in Court TV and wants to transform channel into one that features law-related entertainment shows and documentaries, as well as its current coverage of trials and legal news; Evercore is also negotiating to persuade NBC's top cable executive, Thomas S Rogers, to become partner in Court TV venture; cable industry executives say Evercore is offering to invest more than $300 million for Court TV, which is owned equally by NBC, Time Warner and Liberty Media, and that three current owners will each retain minority interest if deal is completed (L)

headline: Ranks of Albanian Rebels Increase in Kosovo
abstract: Albanian rebel groups in Kosovo, Serbia, have swelled in numbers in recent weeks--in part by infusion of new troops and weapons smuggled over border from Albania; there are indications guerrillas have been joined by mercenaries; rapid and startling growth of insurgency has prompted fears that unrest in province could explode into next Balkan war; map (M)

headline: Petersen Acquires Inside Sports Magazine
abstract: Petersen Companies acquires magazine Inside Sports from Century Publishing Co and plans to merge it with its 51-year-old title Sport magazine; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Novelty for China: Owning a Home
abstract: Chinese Govt formally spells out its radical new housing policy, under which hallowed right of workers to virtually cost-free apartments will end this year; under new guidelines, most urban residents will have to either buy their homes or pay much higher rents (M)

headline: Credit Mutuel to Acquire Paris's Stake in Insurer
abstract: Credit Mutuel will buy French Government's 67 percent stake in Cie Financiere de CIC SA for $2.2 billion; CIC's sale clears the way for disposal of its parent company, state-owned insurer Groupe des Assurances Nationales, by the Government (S)

headline: Amid Chaos at Airport, Air France to Miss Start of Cup
abstract: PARIS—  With only two days to go before the opening of the World Cup soccer tournament, for which it is the official carrier, the strike-bound state-owned airline Air France stood no chance Sunday of getting back to normal before the world's largest sporting event gets under way.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * British Airways, New York, to Miller/Huber Relationship Marketing, San Francisco, to develop business travel direct marketing programs in the United States. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $25 million to $30 million. Miller/Huber will work with M & C Saatchi, New York, the airline's lead advertising agency, and Carlson Marketing Group, Minneapolis, which handles consumer direct marketing.

headline: 2 Advertisers Select Agencies
abstract: 3DO names Hal Riney & Partners as its ad agency; Crown Books names Richards Group to handle its account (S)

headline: As the bride and groom walk down the aisle, companies hope to brand them for life.
abstract: Major consumer-products companies, which formerly shunned bridal market, are buying ad pages in magazines that carter to the about-to-be-married (L)

headline: Citing 'Constructive Engagement,' He Acts to Counter Critics in Congress : Clinton Widens Defense of China Visit
abstract: WASHINGTON—  President Bill Clinton issued an impassioned defense of his policy of "constructive engagement" with China on Thursday, clearly hoping to prevent congressional criticism from overshadowing the first trip by a U.S. president to China in this decade.

headline: Irish Island Unites, in Commerce, Even Before an Accord
abstract: While Northern Ireland's politicians have been taking forced first steps to bring two parts of Irish island closer together, province's business people have been virtually razing long-disputed border; members of predominantly Protestant commercial establishment have set aside sectarian tensions that have arrested Ulster's development in other areas and boldly struck deals with their counterpats in predominantly Catholic Republic of Ireland (M)

headline: Manavi Journal; Georgia's Celestial Wine: Is the World Ready?
abstract: Wine has been part of life in Georgian Republic for over 5,000 years, and for much of that time Manavi and other villages in Kakheti district have been wine heartland; nearly every family has known nothing but wine business for many generations; each village produces distinct variety, and it is all but impossible to find anyone who does not swear that his or her village makes very finest; map; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Seeks To Overturn Land Mine Moratorium
abstract: Pres Clinton scrambles to repeal law he signed in Feb 1996 to impose one-year moratorium on use of antipersonnel land mines starting in Feb 1999; Defense Department opposes law, warning of serious threats to American troops around world, although it has no current plans to use mines; Clinton stand angers highly organized and vocal critics of land mines; national security adviser Samuel R Berger has appealed to law's sponsor, Sen Patrick J Leahy, to push for its reversal (M)

headline: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL IN DEAL WITH LINCOLN PROPERTY
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust to acquire 25 multifamily residential properties in four states from Lincoln Property Co for $465 million in cash and operating partnership units; deal includes assumed debt (S)

headline: In Brazil Tobacco Country, Conglomerates Rule
abstract: Most of small tobacco companies in Brazil have been acquired by conglomerates that decide tobacco prices and punish growers if they decide to sell elsewhere; officials in Santa Cruz Do Sul estimate that 35 percent of tobacco growers will end harvest owing more money than they earn; map; photo (M)

headline: JOINT VENTURE WITH REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES IS PLANNED
abstract: The Ford Motor Company took a big step yesterday into the car dealership business, announcing that it would set up a joint venture with Republic Industries  and Ford dealers in Rochester that would own all of the Ford dealerships in the city. Republic has become the nation's largest retailer of cars by buying nearly 300 dealerships over the last year and a half. The transaction calls for the creation of a new company that would own all eight Ford dealerships in Rochester plus one of the city's three Lincoln-Mercury dealerships. The new company would be owned by the dealerships' current owners plus Ford and Republic.

headline: America Online In a Settlement
abstract: America Online Inc agrees to pay $2.6 million to 44 states to settle complaints that it misled consumers about fees and phone rates (S)

headline: Deal of the Day
abstract: Broadcom Corp shares, offered to public at $24, twice original target price, rise to $53.625; graph (S)

headline: Albright Finds Unalloyed Love in a Newly Minted Democracy
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright visits Mongolia, basking in attention of nation's plucky young democratic reformers; meets with Prime Min Tsahiagiyn Elbegdorj, who says Monglia implements both political and economic changes, while cherishing human rights; photo (M)

headline: BBDO Executive To Leave Company
abstract: Arnie Semsky, longtime media executive at BBDO Worldwide, says he will leave agency at end of year; BBDO has no plans to name successor (S)

headline: Debating the Merit of a Social Security Cap
abstract: Congress and Clinton Administration are considering proposals to assure Social Security's long-term health, including eliminating earning caps for benefit recipients ages 62 to 69; earnings limits have long come under fire from older Americans and their advocates; they claim earnings test discourages sixty-somethings from working during still-productive life stage; Social Security Administration estimates 329,000 Americans lost part of their benefits last year because of earnings caps; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Help for North Korea on Fuel
abstract: US urgently presses Japan, South Korea and other countries for money to supplement North Korea's energy supplies, key part of deal that got North Korea to stop developing nuclear weapons; US is guarantor of promise of 500,000 tons of fuel oil a year, but Clinton Administration has had trouble obtaining money from Republican Congress; US officials with Sec Madeleine Albright in South Korea underscore problem of funding Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization; Pres Kim Dae June says South Korea will keep commmitment despite economic crisis; photo of South Korean demonstrating in Seoul during May Day observances (S)

headline: BOWNE MAKES BID FOR DONNELLEY ENTERPRISES
abstract: Bowne & Co offers to buy Donnelley Enterprise Solutions Inc for $21 a share, or about $105 million (S)

headline: In the Headlights: P.D.A.'s and Virtual Pets
abstract: New trends in video and computer games are revealed at recent Electronic Entertainment Expo, Atlanta; photo (M)

headline: Putting All the Eggs In One Basket
abstract: Market Watch column gives advice on whether or not to invest after AT&T merges with Tele-Communications Inc (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCDONALD'S CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., the restaurant chain, plans to invest more than $400 million to open 400 restaurants in Central Europe in the next three years.    BELL ATLANTIC CORP., New York, said it expected a second-quarter pretax charge of $40 million to $60 million for costs of 300 to 400 more employees who are taking advantage of its retirement-incentive program.

headline: The Man Reshaping Prime Time; Television News Magazines Keep Spreading. Here's Why.
abstract: Success of Dateline NBC, which will control five hours a week of NBC's schedule, is remaking landscape of prime time; show, under executive producer Neal Shapiro, has rewritten rules of news magazine program, adding new touches to format; entertainment executives, who once saw news magazine as news division nuisance, increasingly view format as highly useful, multinight franchise that can ease pressure to fill prime time with more expensive entertainment shows; show has been target of frequent critical attacks for focusing on ratings and tabloid-style stories and for opening door to influence from entertainment division; graph of rise in number of such shows; photo (M)

headline: French Official Investigated In Military Contract Scandal
abstract: Roland Dumas, high-ranking French official, is placed one step short of indictment in inquiry about multimillion-dollar payments made to Christine Deviers-Joncour, lobbyist promoting sale of warships to Taiwan in 1991; Dumas has been placed under investigation for alleged embezzlement and complicity in misappropriation of funds (M)

headline: Metronet Acquiring Phone Unit from Rogers
abstract: Metronet Communications Corp acquires Rogers Telecom unit of Rogers Communications Inc for $1.08 billion (Canadian) or $745 million (US) in cash and stock; merged company, to be called Metronet Communications, will have more than 800 employees (S)

headline: Korean Trade Surplus Set Record in April
abstract: South Korea reports posting record trade surplus of $3.93 billion, Apr, compared with year-earlier deficit of $1.41 billion; exports rose 7 percent, while imports plunged 35.5 percent (S)

headline: Joy and Anger Erupt at Main Symbol of Government
abstract: Students occupying Indonesian Parliament building, Jakarta, hail Pres Suharto's resignation; call on Parliament to replace Suharto's chosen successor, Vice Pres B J Habibie (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A paging company faces problems in the heavens and on earth.
abstract: Market Place column on Paging Network Inc, which has more than one-fifth of US paging market; focuses on company's efforts to cut costs and seek new opportunities as information provider; chief executive John P Frazee Jr's revamping plan discussed; photo (L)

headline: BERTUCCI'S, PIZZA CHAIN, IS SOUGHT BY NE RESTAURANT
abstract: Bertucci's Inc says NE Restaurant Corp has offered to buy pizza chain for $10.50 a share, or about $93.5 million, topping previous bid of $8 a share from Bertucci's management group (S)

headline: But It's Friday, Isn't It?
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on who wears what on casual Friday in your office; photo

headline: The Options Parade
abstract: Letter from Corey Rosen disputes reasons given for bestowing such huge stock option awards on many of America's top executives (M)

headline: Mellon Sues Bank of New York to Stop Bid
abstract: Mellon Bank Corp sues Bank of New York Co, contending that it used confidential information gleaned from previous merger talks when it offered to buy Mellon for $23.7 billion on Apr 22; Bank of New York never signed confidentiality agreement during previous merger discussions; Bank of New York is thought to be in weak position to pursue anything other than friendly merger with Mellon, which has strong anti-takeover laws on its side; analysts say Mellon's directors might reconsider if Bank of New York raised its current bid of $90 per share (M)

headline: Britons Fear Child-Sex Convicts in Their Communities
abstract: Britain grapples with issue of how to handle people convicted of sex crimes against children after they complete prison terms; new community-notification laws and efforts to impose stiffer sentences and increase authorities' ability to monitor offenders have failed to assuage doubts of local groups; raucous, occasionally violent demonstrations outside police stations thought to shelter released felon Sidney Cooke cited (M)

headline: For Some In Republic: The Vote? What Vote?
abstract: Irish radio shows highlight news unrelated to peace agreement, even as voters in north and south go to polls (S)

headline: HORIZON BANCORP HIRES FIRM TO HELP IT WEIGH OPTIONS
abstract: Horizon Bancorp says it hired Baxter Fentriss & Co, investment bank, to look into possible mergers (S)

headline: Boeing to Cut Production Of 747 Jumbo Jets in 1999
abstract: Boeing Co says it will probably cut production of its 747 jumbo jet next year because of weakening demand from Asian airlines; company says it still faces difficulties meeting demand for new version of its popular 737 narrow-body jet; company recently began producing 737's at pace of 14 a month, up from 7 a month (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     Elcor

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: FRONTIER CORP., Rochester, the fifth-largest United States long-distance phone company, named an AT&T Corporation executive, Rolla Huff, as chief financial officer to replace Louis Massaro, who retired in February.

headline: Upsurge in Extremist Attacks After Lull Touches Off a Scramble to Find Causes : Germans Ponder Violence
abstract: MAGDEBURG, Germany—  - At 7:25 P.M. on a recent Tuesday night, two young toughs broke into a Palestinian's apartment in a public housing project on the fringe of this city.

headline: London Journal; Jeers Across the Channel From the Rowdy Press
abstract: British tabloids are fanning old-style prejudice against French and Germans as Britain moves closer to rest of Europe through European Union; Lord Wakeham, who heads Press Complaint Commission, body that holds press to voluntary code of conduct, is losing patience with headlines he fears could spur attacks by Britain's notoriously violent football hooligans on French people during World Cup soccer tournament; photo (M)

headline: Her Mother Isn't Pleased As Daughter Rips Gates
abstract: Jennifer Edstrom, co-author of book Barbarians Led by Bill Gates: Microsoft From the Inside, which is critical of Gates, comments on strains publication of book has created with her mother, who is exec of public relations firm that represents Microsoft Corp; book recounts internal politics and office intrigues at Microsoft, presenting unflattering portrait of Gates; photo (S)

headline: Short-Sellers of Compaq Increased Their Position
abstract: Short-sellers increased their bet against the Compaq Computer Corporation last month. Compaq, the leading personal computer maker, had warned last month that profits would suffer as it cut prices sharply to reduce bloated inventories.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jefferson Smurfit Acquiring Stone for $2 Billion in Stock  Jefferson Smurfit has agreed to acquire Stone Container for $2 billion in stock to create one of the world's largest manufacturers of paperboard and paper-based packaging products. It will also assume $4.35 billion in debt. Smurfit-Stone Container will have annual sales of more than $8 billion.

headline: LABOR V. LABOR: A special report.; Garment Union Battles Its Own Workers
abstract: Special report, Labor v Labor, on suit by workers at bankrupt Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc's Brooklyn plant charging Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees betrayed them by accepting small payment for workers and large payment for union in settling arbitration claim against Liz Claiborne, which shifted its sweater manufacturing abroad; suit is first serious challenge to decades-old system that lets unions penalize garment makers who ship jobs abroad; critics hold system gives garment makers way to cut labor costs without risking strikes and gives unions money as membership dues dwindle; photo (L)

headline: Bigger, Faster, More 3-D
abstract: Personal computers coming onto the market this year and next will offer speeds up to 500 megahertz, bigger monitors, more memory and variety of special features including new 3-D graphics cards and 3-D sound; photo (M)

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Why Gouge the Taxpayers?
abstract: On Wednesday, a day after reporting that Guinness, the brewer, would sponsor the Old Royal Observatory in Greenwich, and that, as a result, official time in Britain would be known as Guinness Mean Time, rather than Greenwich Mean Time, The Financial Times published a correction.     The release upon which it relied ''was apparently intended as part of an April 1 spoof,'' the newspaper said, adding that there was a sponsorship deal, but no Guinness Mean Time.

headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE SECULAR JEWS: Beauty Is Truth. That Is All the Stylish Need to Know.
abstract: Series, Israel at 50, on ethnic and cultural diversity that has evolved in half-century since founding as Jewish state; interview with Ilan and Aviva Pivko, affluent secular Jews, who defend their hedonism as necessary embellishment that creates environment that looks and feels better, and who regard Israeli-Arab conflict and violence it has spawned as backgound noise; photo (M)

headline: DDB Needham Gets Pep Boys Account
abstract: Pep Boys assigns national advertising account to DDB Needham, unit of Omnicom Group (S)

headline: Dow Ends Over 9,100 Despite Mediocre Earning Reports
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 97.20 points, or 1.1 percent, to record9,110.20; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbs 6.06 points, to 1,115.75; Nasdaq index climbs 18.08 points, or 1 percent, to 1,843.03; graph; chart (L)

headline: China Voices 'Regret,' but Still Faults India
abstract: China, Pakistan's oldest and most powerful Asian ally, expresses 'deep regret' over Pakistan's decision to conduct nuclear tests, but officials reiterate opinion that India touched off crisis with its earlier tests (S)

headline: Japanese Auto Makers Tell U.S. What It Wants to Hear
abstract: Japanese auto makers are all but promising not to increase already high exports to United States over next year despite weakening yen that enables them to charge lower prices in dollars, dampened demand at home and collapse of Asian market; key factor in keeping down exports is probably Japanese industry's shift of production to America (M)

headline: NORTHERN CALIFORNIA MALL IS SOLD FOR $130 MILLION
abstract: Colony Capital Inc and developer Michael Swerdlow acquire Great Mall of the Bay Area, largest shopping mall in Northern California, for $130 million (S)

headline: Boeing Earnings Tumbled By 91% in First Quarter
abstract: Boeing Co says earings plunged 91 percent in first quarter, falling below estimates of Wall Street analysts; revenue rose 24 percent, to $12.9 billion, from $10.4 billion in year-earlier quarter (M)

headline: The Other German in U.S. Books
abstract: Michael Naumann, German publisher named to head Henry Holt & Co thee years ago, has sought to raise Holt's profile with pricey contracts with prominent authors like Salman Rushdie and through his own blunt candor; some rival American book publishers and former employees complain that Naumann does not understand his adopted culture given his spending levels and sales history; Holt has been losing money, and Naumann estimates that his 136-person staff has turned over by 75 percent; Naumann is revered among many authors and agents for his charm and knowledge about dizzying range of issues, but he has not endeared himself to other publishers of parent Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck by vying for same authors and hiring away some prized editors; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AUTOCAM CORP.,  Kentwood, Mich., an automotive-  and computer-parts maker, plans to acquire an unidentified European manufacturer for about  $70 million, including assumed debt.    MCG CREDIT CORP.,  Arlington, Va., a specialty finance company, completed a management buyout of MCG from First Union Corp. and formed a new unit that will make loans to media companies.

headline: American Topics : Mansion — or Jailhouse?
abstract: The doorman at the Missouri governor's mansion, dressed in tuxedo and white gloves, is quick with a smile as he opens the heavy doors. Inside, another formally dressed servant graciously takes a visitor's coat.

headline: People
abstract: * Mark MacDonald was named to the new position of group publisher at Individual Investor Group, New York, overseeing Individual Investor and Ticker magazines as well as Individual Investor Online and Special Situation Reports. He had been president of the Association of Independent Business Owners, Westfield, N.J.; before that, he served as group publisher at Men's Journal, New York, owned by Wenner Media.

headline: Graft Charge Hurts Nation, Ex-President Of Iran Says
abstract: Former Iranian Pres Hashemi Rafsanjani says corruption charges against Teheran Mayor Gholahossein Karabaschi poison political environment and threaten nation's health, speech, Teheran; holds Ayatollah Ali Khamenei averted further turmoil by ordering Karabaschi released from prison; warning is directed at conservatives who pressed to jail Karabaschi (M)

headline: With Estrada's Victory Certain, Everybody's in His Parade
abstract: MANILA—  Suddenly, shining new stickers bearing the word "Erap" or "Estrada" are appearing on the bumpers of the big vans and limousines that carry the elite of Metro Manila from their rambling homes in walled "villages" to the high-rise office buildings of Makati, the central business and financial district.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture caption with May 24 article on battle for Marvel Entertainment Group, which misidentified Marvel Comics character

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 7/  Investors may rue a knee-jerk interest in stocks being repurchased by their companies. The buybacks may never happen, and the shares may not go up. By Ingrid Eisenstadter.

headline: Nguyen Van Linh, Vietnam's Ex-Party Chief, Dies at 82
abstract: Nguyen Van Linh, former Vietcong guerrilla who directed 1968 Tet offensive and then revitalized Vietnam's economy as nation's Communist Party leader, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices fall 6.7 percent because of warmer weather and 24 percent increase in supplies compared with levels of year earlier; May contracts fall 17.8 cents, to $2.479 for every thousand cubic feet; graph; chart (S)

headline: Germans Find Possible Crash Links and Inspect 60 Trains
abstract: German authorities, acting day after nation's worst rail crash in more than 50 years, pull scores of express trains out of service after discovery of broken wheel and track damage possibly linked to disaster; withdrawal of 60 Inter City Express trains deepens speculation that accident, in which at least 93 people died, was caused by mechanical failure; photo of train being removed from crash site (M)

headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE PIONEERS: Cultivators of a Nation's Strength Hoped for a Harvest of Generosity
abstract: Series, Israel at 50, on ethnic and cultural diversity that has evolved in half-century since founding as Jewish state; interview with Marga and Uri Goren, original settlers who spent lifetime building and defending Israel who say they did not expect country to become so big and successful, and that it has failed to take advantage of its strength to be generous to Arabs; photo (M)

headline: On TV, a Defiant Gates Faults Tactics by U.S.
abstract: Defiant William H Gates takes to television studio on Microsoft Corp's campus to defend his company's business practices and to assert that by filing broad antitrust lawsuits against his company, the Government and group of state Attorneys General are threatening pace of technological innovation in personal computer industry (L)

headline: 3M to Trail Forecasts, and Its Shares Fall
abstract: Stock of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co drops $5.8125, or 6.7 percent, to $81 in active trading, after company says its second-quarter earnings will be below estimates (S)

headline: GIAT of France to Cut 3,000 to 4,000 Jobs
abstract: GIAT Industries, French loss-ridden state-owned arms maker, will eliminate 3,000 to 4,000 jobs, or as much as 38 percent of its work force; Defense Min Alain Richard says cuts are part of reorganization plan to be announced at beginning of July that will include closing of several GIAT manufacturing sites (S)

headline: Patents; A new technology allows pain medication to be inhaled for easier administration.
abstract: Aradigm Corp patents technology it says will make pain medication much easier to administer; has developed inhalable form of morphine, pain-treatment drug that now must be administered intravenously, and is developing hand-held electronic inhaler; is developing system in partnership with SmithKline Beecham; Scott Alpert, drug test administrator, patents software system for use in detecting drug abuse by evaluating person's eyes; has started Drugensic to develop product; Catherine Young of Cy Young Industries patents popcorn holder that permanently attaches to stadium or theater seats (M)

headline: Swissair's Parent To Reduce Costs
abstract: SAir Group Inc, owner of airline Swissair, says it aims to cut $678 million (US) in costs over next three years to stay competitive in increasingly open European airline market (S)

headline: EX-CHINESE LEADER CONFRONTS BEIJING ON 1989 MASSACRE
abstract: Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as Communist Party chief at time of 1989 Tiananmen Square, Beijing, crackdown, challenges China's leaders to admit incident was both wrong and immense political blunder, letter to party's Central Committee; holds Pres Clinton's visit offers chance to reverse official verdict on massacre; has been under house arrest for nine years and risks further punishment with bid to spur debate; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Oil declines again on fear of protracted global glut and insufficient OPEC cuts; July contracts fall 73 cents, or 5.4 percent, to $12.75 a barrel, weakest since October 1988; graph; chart (S)

headline: Only Disconnect (For a While, Anyway)
abstract: Connectivity has become a seeming necessity of modern life but some heavy users of e-mail and cellular phones are finding that taking breaks to unplug from the intrusiveness of electronic communication helps them relax, focus, and renew their creativity; photos (M)

headline: Saving for College: Why Bother?
abstract: Letter from Charles Di Maggio disputes claim in Mar 8 article that parents are in denial over future costs of their children's higher education; says that topic dominates discussions among his peers (M)

headline: Law to Repeal Pakistani Arms Ban Is Proposed
abstract: United States Sens Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, and Tom Harkin, Iowa Democrat, with tacit blessing of Clinton Adm, propose repealing a law that has prohibited American military assistance to Pakistan since 1990 as incentive to Pakistan's Govt not to conduct an underground nuclear test; legislation surfaces as delegation dispatched by Pres Clinton heads for Pakistan to appeal for restraint following India's nuclear tests this week (S)

headline: Mexican Shootout Leaves Bullet Holes and Bitterness
abstract: Shootout in El Charco between army troops and guerrillas, whom Mexican authorities identify as members of Popular Revolutionary Army (EPR), leaves at least 11 civilians dead; local officials and Mixtec Indians of the village, which is in Guerrero state on southern Pacific coast, accuse army of using excessive force; unlike Zapatista Indian rebels in Chiapas, the EPR, which is descended from some of the most radical leftist groups of the 1980's, has little support from mainstream Mexicans; but the guerrillas are often welcomed in hamlets like El Charco, where Indians live on the low end of subsistence and expect Government to treat them at best with neglect and at worst with racist violence; map; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about companies' regrouping after the deaths of their top executives in an airplane crash misstated the titles of two executives who assumed new roles. Peter S. Janson is chief executive of ABB Inc., as well as being its president. Howard Pierce is executive vice president for the Americas of ABB's parent company, ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd., not chairman, chief executive and group executive vice president for the Americas.

headline: Inspectors Tell How Iraq Concealed Programs
abstract: United Nations arms inspectors, using spy-plane and satellite photographs never before shown to diplomats, give Security Council daylong display of evidence that they have gathered in attempt to counter Iraq's contentions that it has disarmed and deserves to have sanctions lifted (M)

headline: CBS Names Heir Apparent for the Chairman's Position
abstract: CBS puts new top management team in place for its long-term future when it announces promotion of Mel Karmazin and Leslie Moonves to newly created positions under Michael Jordan, chairman and chief executive; Karmazin, who had been chairman of CBS station group, is named president and chief operating officer of CBS; Moonves, president of CBS Television, has designation of chief executive officer added to his title, and will oversee all CBS's programming divisions; Karmazin's elevation to formal second-in-command status under Jordan is interpreted as announcement of line-of-management succession (L)

headline: South Korea May Look For Tobacco Investors
abstract: South Korea says it might sell 25 percent stake in its $3 billion cigarette monopoly to foreign investors, possibility that is drawing interest from Rothmans UK Holdings PLC of Britain and from other tobacco companies; Government owns 37.3 percent of Korea Tobacco and Ginseng Co (S)

headline: 'You'll Be Hearing From Us Soon'
abstract: youll be hearing from us soon**Job seekers are invited to tell their stories about their encounters with job interviewers who showed odd behavior (S)

headline: Closed-End Fund Investors Gain Clout
abstract: Little-noticed decision by Securities and Exchange Commission has given investors in closed-end funds enormous power, handing them the right to oust investment managers by vote; ruling clears the way for shareholders of eight funds to vote on pending proposals to dismiss their advisers; chart lists closed-end funds in which investors have filed proposals to end management advisory contracts (M)

headline: New Mac Gets an A For Offbeat Cuteness
abstract: Some people who have seen the iMac, new Apple computer that is scheduled to be in stores in August, describe it in terms of its offbeat cutness; machine is brightly colored, roly-poly computer--a one-piece unit with monitor and central processor in one box; photo (S)

headline: Tbilisi Journal; The 'Man of the Year,' Just 29 and Via Manhattan
abstract: Mikheil Saakashvili, 29, is among most prominent of several dozen bright young people who are playing important roles in building new post-Communist order in Georgia; Saakashvili, former Manhattan lawyer, was elected to Georgian Parliament in 1995; he often rates as second most popular person in Georgia in public opinion polls, trailing only Pres Eduard A Shevardnadze; photo; map (M)

headline: Founder to Resign At Think New Ideas
abstract: Think New Ideas Inc, Internet marketing and technology company, announces that Scott Mednick, its founder, chairman and chief executive, will leave to pursue career in philanthropy; company also says it has dismissed its outside auditor, BDO Seidman; board of Think New Ideas is expected to name Ron Bloom, president and chief operating officer, to succeed Mednick as chairman and chief executive (S)

headline: Kremlin Soft-Pedals Its Rebuke to India, and Opposes Sanctions
abstract: Min Yevgeny M Primakov reaffirms Russia's refusal to join other countries in economic sanctions to punish India for resuming nuclear tests; Russia'a complaints against testing have been muted, reflecting its close commercial ties with India and view of India as counterweight to China (M)

headline: Leica Selling Unit That Makes Microscopes
abstract: Leica AG of Switzerland says it has sold its microscope division to group of international investors for total of $500 million; Schroders Ventures heads group that is buying Leica Microsystems GmbH (S)

headline: Despite Countless Critics, Hashimoto Has No Rival
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto, facing popular discontent over his handling of Japan's economic problems, has no strong rival within his ruling Liberal Democratic Party; opposition leader, Naoto Kan, currently most popular politician in Japan, seeks to build large-scale coalition to challenge Liberal Democrats in next election; photo (M)

headline: SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE CONSIDERS A TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: Spaghetti Warehouse Inc weighs takeover bid of $47 million in cash from Conquest Partners; says total value of acquisition would come to $58 million including debt refinancing and transaction costs (S)

headline: Harry Harding, 94, Advertising Executive
abstract: Harry Harding, who was executive vice president of Young & Rubicam advertising agency in early 1960's and then senior executive for Time Inc, dies at age 94 (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Denies New Rwanda Charges
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan dismisses renewed accusations that he is among those at UN headquarters who did nothing after warning in early 1994 that campaign of genocide would occur in Rwanda (S)
