headline: The Technophile Shakers
abstract: Stuart Semmel letter says April 9 article wrongly described the Shakers as being averse to technology (S)

headline: Albright Nudges Suharto to Resign : 'An Opportunity For Statesmanship'
abstract: WASHINGTON—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED MAY 22, 1998

headline: Equity and Convertible Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Wolf Group to Acquire Partners & Shevack
abstract: Wolf Group Integrated Communications Ltd acquires Partners & Shevack from Mickelberry Communications Inc (M)

headline: Chairman of Eli Lilly Announces Retirement
abstract: Randall L Tobias, chairman and chief executive of Eli Lilly & Co, announces that he will retire at end of 1998; Sidney Taurel, president and chief operating officer, will succeed Tobias as chief executive July 1 and as chairman Dec 31; Taurel will retain title of president; it is unclear why Tobias, who is 56, chose to retire now; company's stock rose 90.8 percent last year (M)

headline: Sunbeam Shopping And Consolidating
abstract: Sunbeam Corp is searching for advertising agency to handle its worldwide consolidated advertising and promotional account, with billings estimated at $160 million; majority of account has been handled by Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Fall to 3-Month Low On Growing Asian Concerns  The turmoil in Asia has sent United States stock markets tumbling, wiping out the gains of the last three months for the Dow Jones industrial average. Yesterday, the Dow fell 207 points, or 2.3 percent. Some other market gauges have fallen even more, suggesting what Wall Street calls a market correction -- a drop of 10 percent or more -- is under way.    Investors are increasingly concerned that the economic crisis in Asia has yet to reach bottom. Japan, which many hoped would be the region's savior, announced last week that its economy shrank sharply in the first quarter, amounting to its steepest decline since World War II. [Page A1.]

headline: Hewlett-Packard Quarterly Profit Falls 13%
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported a 13 percent decline in quarterly earnings today after having warned two days earlier that its results would show unexpected weakness, largely because of lower prices for personal computers.    But in a conference call this morning with securities analysts, Hewlett-Packard executives also attributed the earnings decline to Asia's economic crisis, acquisition-related expenses and an unexpected acceleration in the company's internal costs.

headline: Telefonica of Spain Reports Jump in Net
abstract: Telefonica SA says its first-quarter net income jumped 17.8 percent to $217 million (S)

headline: Media Talk; Renegade of Magazine World Rejoins the Establishment
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines president and chief executive David J Pecker has rejoined Magazine Publishers of America, which he quit in 1993; move is triumph for trade group, which has been courting Hachette; photo (S)

headline: Perhaps No Better Time To Add Computer Memory
abstract: Prices for latest generation of memory chips have plunged in recent months because of glut in supply; analysts expect prices to drift lower until summer, when they may stabilize or begin to rise (S)

headline: Public and Private Debt Issues Expected for Offering This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.97 percent and a six-month bill was 5.08 percent.

headline: V-Chip and Ratings Are Close to Giving Parents New Power
abstract: Television manufacturers are racing to meet new Federal Communications Commission mandate to include V-chip technology in all sets bigger than 13 inches by January 2000; viewers will also soon be able to purchase set-top boxes to retrofit existing televisions; V-chips decode ratings for sex, violence and profanity transmitted by TV networks and can be set to black out undesired programming; photos (M)

headline: Dow Jones Decides to Buy Back Shares
abstract: Dow Jones & Company plans to buy back as much as $300 million of its shares and take a $98 million second-quarter charge as it completes the sale of its financial information unit to Bridge Information Systems Inc.    The charge is to cover costs related to the $510 million sale, and it follows a $922.5 million fourth-quarter charge to write down the value of its initial $1.6 billion purchase of the unit, which was once known as Telerate.

headline: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS EXTENDS FIBER OPTICS NETWORK
abstract: Qwest Communications International to announce that it has activated five new segments of its transcontinental fiber optic communications network with combined length of 3,051 miles (S)

headline: Chinese in U.S. Tie Harassment To Clinton Trip
abstract: Human rights advocates say China is harassing Chinese residents of United States who return home for visits, apparently in effort to discourage expatriates from organizing protests against Pres Clinton's planned visit; interviews with eight Chinese students and scholars who returned recently to US from China indicate visiting Chinese are detained, sometimes for days, and questioned intensely about their involvement, real or imagined, in dissident movement in US; photo (M)

headline: Seeking Dramatic Footage No Matter What the Cost; Competing for Images From Trouble Spots, TV Crews Can Put Lives, and Ethics, at Risk
abstract: Competitive pressures among three leading video news agencies may be making it increasingly tempting for them to ignore ethical distinctions; in one recent incident, Red Cross workers taken hostage in Somalia claim cameraman ignored requests that there be no filming and pushed armed guard toward one hostage, sparking tense moments caught on film; camera crew was from APTV, arm of Associated Press, that has made its mark with combination of high-quality video and prices initially intended to undercut Worldwide Television News and Reuters; photojournalists, who are inviting targets encumbered by their equipment, risk their own lives as well in danger spots around world to bring back dramatic pictures; four AP photographers have died in last 5 years; photos (M)

headline: U S West Faces Suit Over Long-Distance Venture
abstract: AT&T Corp, MCI Communications Corp and four other organizations file suit seeking to block U S West Communications Group's plan to market long-distance phone service in its region; Denver-based U S West announced plans to jointly market its local phone service with long-distance service of Qwest Communications International Inc; U S West has not complied with requirement of 1996 Telecommunications Act that it open its local phone markets to competition (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: METROPOLITAN LIFE INSURANCE CO., New York, named Jon F. Danski senior vice president and corporate controller, succeeding Fred Hauser, who retired last year. Mr. Danski will run Met Life's corporate controller's department in Tampa, Fla., dividing time between Tampa and New York. He will report to Stewart G. Nagler, the chief financial officer.

headline: Fuji and Kodak turn to Madison Avenue in the latest round of their battle over the photo market.
abstract: Fuji Photo Film Co and Eastman Kodak Co increase marketing and advertising budgets; both are touting products instead of overall good-bad guy idea; both are stressing what marketing trade calls 'presence marketing,' an attempt to associate their names and products with cultural icons (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Copyright Treaty Raises Concerns on Research
abstract: Some computer security experts oppose provision of House bill that would ratify two treaties intended to strengthen international copyrights in cyberspace; say bill would make it illegal for them to test computer security by barring attempts to break security safeguards used to prevent unauthorized copying of creative work published on line (S)

headline: South Korea Is Testing Appetite for Asian Debt
abstract: South Korea is expected to bring its first-ever offering of soverign debt to market on April 7 or 8, a $3 billion test of investors' appetite for exposure to Asia as region attempts to rebound from crisis (M)

headline: Patents; A wedding-dress kit that lets the bride-to-be custom-design her gown at off-the-rack costs.
abstract: Patents column notes number of inventors have come up with wedding-inspired patents, seeking slice of profits in lucrative wedding business; Janie Paine, inventor who owned bridal shop for several years, devises and patents wedding-dress kit that enables bride to custom-design her dress at about same cost as off-the-rack gown; some other wedding-related patents noted (M)

headline: UNICAPITAL IN DEALS TO BUY 7 SMALLER LEASING COMPANIES
abstract: Unicapital Corp to acquire seven leasing companies for about $162.5 million; companies are US Turbine Engine Corp, Jumbo Jet, Lease Corp of America, Madison Leasing Co, Saddleback Financial Corp, HLC Financial Inc and Myerson Companies (S)

headline: Stock Offerings During the Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline drops on news of unexpected increase in inventories and high refining rate, suggesting ample supplies for summer; May contract falls 2.07 cents to settle at 50.61 cents a gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: U.S. JOBLESS RATE PLUNGES TO 4.3%, LOWEST SINCE 1970
abstract: Labor Department reports United States unemployment rate fell to 4.3 percent, Apr, lowest level since Feb 1970, down from 4.7 percent in Mar; rapid pace of hiring is leading to shortages of certain kinds of workers; wages are rising faster than prices; graphs (M)

headline: Uncertainty Leaves Publishers Holding the Books
abstract: Computer book publishers and booksellers who see introduction of Windows 98 as event of year for them are concerned that Justice Dept suit against Microsoft will delay introduction of new software; no fewer than 66 new how-to books on Windows 98 are expected to be in stores on June 25; if Windows 98 fails to show, or if its code is substantially modified under court order, publishers and booksellers could be in serious bind; given large costs publishers have already incurred, delay of 60 days would cause significant cash-flow problems (M)

headline: When Overtime Doesn't Feel So Fine
abstract: Overtime and uncompensated work have emerged as key labor issue in wake of staff cuts at many companies; increasingly robust job market is making employees feel secure enough to sue employers and and leave jobs they see as exploitive; photo (M)

headline: AT&T to Offer New Nationwide Cut-Rate Wireless Service
abstract: AT&T Corp moves to shake up wireless telephone industry with new service that offers calls from almost anywhere in US to anywhere in nation for flat rates of as little as 11 cents a minute; company also says it has short-term exclusive rights to distribute new wireless phone by Nokia of Finland that can be left on for more than a week at a time--much longer than most wireless phones (L)

headline: True North Reports Agency Merger
abstract: True North Communications says Modem Media Inc and Poppe Tyson would be merged to form Modem Media.Poppe Tyson (S)

headline: Pressed by U.S., China Frees Catholic Bishop Loyal to Vatican
abstract: Chinese authorities have released, six months early, one of their most prominent religious prisoners, elderly Roman Catholic Bishop Zeng Jingmu who was jailed for refusing to submit to authority Government-sponsored church; release, which has been sought by American officials, is clearly timed to soften American concerns about human rights before Pres Clinton visits China in late June; Bishop Zeng was arrested in November 1995 and sentenced, without trial, to three years of 're-education through labor' for holding unauthorized religious services in a home; he has already spent 23 years in prison since 1950's for openly proclaiming his allegiance to the Vatican (M)

headline: Ravaged by War and Massacre, Rwanda Faces Scourge of AIDS
abstract: AIDS epidemic is sweeping through rural Rwanda, fanned by decade of ethnic war and upheaval; health officials say that even if it is arrested now, epidemic will take life of 1 person out of 10 in next decade; Government survey of 4,750 people suggests that Rwanda's epidemic is one of worst in East Africa, with overall infection rate even higher than in Uganda; survey shows that about 11 percent of Rwandans are HIV positive; United Nations officials estimate that about two-thirds of 30 million people worldwide who are infected with virus live in sub-Saharan Africa; graph; map; photo (M)

headline: Frenchman Seeks the Rest Of Christie's
abstract: Francois Pinault, French takeover investor and art collector who bought 29.1 percent of Christie's for $243.2 million two weeks ago, announces that he intends to buy rest of it in deal that values entire company at $1.2 billion; acquisition will pass ownership of eminently British company to a Frenchman for first time in its 232-year history (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Accounts
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc awards its corporate brand agency, Foote, Cone & Belding, added duties for disk drive and tape drive products; account had been handled by van Bronkhorst Group; Mastercard International Inc awards its Internet advertising account to GSD&M; account had been handled by Thunderhouse (S)

headline: U.S. Businesses Press For an Asian Bailout
abstract: American businesses are furiously lobbying Congress to approve $18 billion for the International Monetary Fund so the Asian bailout can continue.

headline: Earnings Climb 27% at Fidelity Investments
abstract: Fidelity Investments says earnings increased 27 percent in 1997; reports earnings of $535.6 million, up from $423.1 million in 1996; revenue rose almost 17 percent, to $5.88 billion from $5.05 billion in 1996 (S)

headline: Renault Says Sales Rose 24% in First Period
abstract: Renault SA says first-quarter sales rose 24 percent; sales reached 58.63 billion French francs ($9.77 billion), up from 47.20 billion francs last year (S)

headline: Motorola Drops Plan for Its Own Data Satellites
abstract: Motorola Inc agrees to scrap its $12.9 billion plan to build satellite network capable of delivering high-speed data communications and instead joins rival but equally ambitious project to build an 'Internet in the sky'; Motorola will invest about $750 million in exchange for 26 percent of project, Teledesic LLC, which was founded by Microsoft Corp's chairman William H Gates and Craig O McCaw, cellular phone pioneer who sold his company to AT&T in 1993 for $12.6 billion; Motorola rejects Boeing Co to become Teledesic's prime contractor; Teledesic says Boeing will remain important participant in project but it is clear that Motorola has become its main partner; Matra Marconi Space, joint venture of General Electric Co of Britain and Groupe Lagardere of France, also agrees to take part in project (M)

headline: Tracing Family Trees
abstract: Peter Stockschlaeder letter on genealogy-releated CD-ROM's (June 18 article) suggests Reunion 5.0 from Leister Productions

headline: Vickers Says It Accepts BMW Offer for Rolls
abstract: Vickers PLC formally accepts $566 million takeover offer for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars from BMW, but rival suitor, Volkswagen AG, immediately promises sweeter price for luxury-car maker, reportedly $800 million in cash; Volkswagen also reportedly offers to buy Cosworth, Vickers motor subsidiary; photo (L)

headline: Iridium Wireless Link Is Near Completion
abstract: Iridium LLC says that it will complete its 66-satellite global wireless communications network with final satellite launching on April 26, making it first company to complete such a system; $5 billion network, known as Iridium system, will allow subscribers to communicate using hand-held telephones and pagers virtually anywhere in world (S)

headline: Powergen Plans To Buy Utility For $1.4 Billion
abstract: Powergen PLC to buy East Midlands Electricity for $1.4 billion in cash from Dominion Resources Inc; will assume $1.8 billion in debt (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Bob Pearson was named to the new position of executive vice president and managing director for the North American health practice at GCI Group, New York, part of Grey Advertising. He had been vice president for sales and marketing at Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, Philadelphia.

headline: With the Euro en Route, Time to Pick a Manager
abstract: Selection of president for Europe's new central bank is contest between Germany and France, harkening back to centuries of nationalism and rivalry for dominance on continent; every country that will adopt euro currency, except for France, supports Wim F Duisenberg, president of Dutch central bank; France supports its own central banker, Jean-Claude Trichet (S)

headline: New Currency, New Opportunities
abstract: FROM his vantage point as the chief investment officer of Deutsche Bank, Hanspeter Ackermann sees expanding opportunities for investors in a unifying Europe. As portfolio manager of the bank's closed-end New Germany fund, a $665 million growth fund invested primarily in midsize German companies, Mr. Ackermann is deploying money to pursue some of those opportunities. And as a Swiss citizen, he sees firsthand the significance of being inside or outside the euro club.   SHARON R. KING    Q. How will investing in Europe change as a result of the creation of the single European currency?   A. The top-down style of selecting stocks, where you analyze country, industry and then go down to the stock level, probably becomes irrelevant. The opposite of that is a bottom-up manager, which basically is our style. We really don't look at macro themes, but much more company-specific data.     The concept of the country fund itself at some point will probably have to be wider. I can imagine that some funds might consider changing to a more European-based fund.   Q. How should American investors be thinking about the part of their portfolio that they will invest in a changing Europe?   A. Before, you had different countries, like Germany and France, individually fighting for market share. They all looked insignificant relative to a large country like the United States. Now this is changing. You have a major competitor -- let's just call it Europe. It has a much more powerful industrial base. It will not be inhibited by any cross-border taxation or inefficiencies.     What we're going to see here is a major structural change, much higher efficiency. I think that there will probably be more money allocated to Europe than in the past.   Q. What about countries that remain outside the monetary union?   A. For a country like Britain, it's probably less of an issue to be in or out, because it's a much larger economy with much less dependence on Europe. The U.K. has had more cross-border alliances with the United States than with Europe, so it will be easier for the U.K. to stand outside and to remain outside.    In the case of Switzerland, I see difficulties for that country to stay out and to compete with the border restrictions.    I'm not sure how much the financial sector will be affected, but you could see some impact mainly from the currency translation on other manufacturing sectors.    Right now the Swiss franc is relatively strong, and that's obviously damaging the export industry. But currency fluctuations may make it difficult for corporations to plan ahead. For the smaller European countries, sooner or later they're going to be forced into the same situation, where there will be an overwhelming economic case for joining the European Monetary Union. So, my guess will be they're all going to join over time.   Q. Will companies in countries outside of the monetary union have growth problems?   A. Yes. Distribution will be a problem.    I'm from Switzerland. When I walk through customs in Europe, they treat me like any other passport holder. But if you are part of the union, they basically just wave you through.    The same effect will probably occur on any distribution or licensing agreement. You would rather give the members of the union preferential treatment. So obviously there's an advantage to being part of the union.   Q. From an investment standpoint, will countries outside of the monetary union be riskier?   A. They should be. You're dealing with higher currency risk; then you have the economic risk of not gaining access to the same markets. There's even a risk of size, which means a liquidity risk.   Q. How do you pick stocks for the bank's funds?   A. There are five criteria. The most important is earnings momentum, to which we allocate roughly one-third of the investment decision-making.     Another third would be management. We look at the track record and the commitment to enhance the company's value. The final third is split between the financial strength of the company and its overall value versus the industry, the stock's history and the market itself.    Q. What are some stocks you own that fit your criteria?   A. One of our biggest holdings is Adidas. We have 8.6 percent of the fund in that company. They have acquired Salomon, the ski producer. When we look at other companies like Nike, or Puma in Europe, most of them have lost market share to Adidas-Salomon. And this is one of the few true growth stories in Germany, in our belief.    This company has excellent management. We see roughly 20 to 25 percent earnings growth consistently into the year 2000.     What's not included in that figure yet is the effects of the Salomon acquisition. Salomon has had its strength mainly in France, and Adidas has had its strength mostly in Germany. But now there should be a massive benefit from synergies.    We also like Continental A.G. We have about 4.3 percent of the fund in that. Continental has had compound earnings growth of about 25 percent for three years, and I think it has been overlooked by the market.     What's interesting is that they're really a leader in technology. There's huge free cash flow, and 1998 should be a turnaround year for the company as margins increase.    In Europe there are two other major tire companies, Pirelli and Michelin. In our view, there's no room for three major companies in Europe, so at some point you're going to see a merger or an alliance.    In Wella A.G., the beauty products company, we've seen a management turnaround. In the past, Wella's management has not been very open, and they came to a point in 1995 where the management disappointed and earnings fell by about 50 percent. That obviously shocked the market.    The perception was: We cannot trust that firm anymore. But the company did make changes within the management to come back and regain the confidence. I think we were one of the first to recognize that they are pursuing a much more shareholder-friendly attitude.

headline: Credit Lyonnais Facing Pressure on Asset Sales
abstract: European Commission says France has month to propose sales of Credit Lyonnais assets or bank may be forced to repay part of state aid received in 100-billion-franc ($16.2 billion) bailout (S)

headline: Buyout Funds Exploring Bid For Polygram
abstract: Forstmann Little & Co and Thomas H Lee Co, two of nation's largest leveraged buyout funds, weigh bid for Polygram NV; team's investment banker, Allen & Co, has sent letters to both supervisory board of Polygram and its parent, Royal Philips Electronics NV, giant Dutch electronics company that owns 75 percent of Polygram, saying they are interested in exploring a bid; Seagram Co has been in talks over possible acquisition of Polygram; Seagram and Philips are believed to have set deadline of May 17 to reach a deal (L)

headline: Sanyo Shares Jump On a Buyback Plan
abstract: Stock of Sanyo Electric Co jumps after company says it will buy back up to 35 billion yen ($263 million) worth of its own shares (S)

headline: UNITRODE BALKS AT BID FOR BENCHMARQ MICROELECTRONICS
abstract: Shares of Unitrode Corp and Benchmarq Microelectronics Inc move in opposite directions after Unitrode's board withdraws recommendation that shareholders approve $135 million aquisition of Benchmarq (S)

headline: Heller Financial Initial Offering
abstract: Heller Financial, factoring company owned by Fuji Bank of Japan, sells minority interest in itself for $1.04 billion, producing largest initial public offering by United States company in nearly two years; Fuji will continue to control Heller (S)

headline: Treasuries Dip on Fed Inaction
abstract: US Treasury prices end slightly lower; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 5/32, to 102 22/32; yield eduges up to 5.93 percent, from 5.92 percent on May 18; chart (M)

headline: $34 Billion Merger Expected By Norwest and Wells Fargo
abstract: Norwest Corp of Minneapolis and Wells Fargo & Co of San Francisco plan to join forces and may announce $34 billion deal on June 8 (M)

headline: Ladbroke Acquisition Under Antitrust Review
abstract: British Government refers Ladbroke PLC's planned $628 million (US) purchase of Coral betting shop chain from Bass PLC to Monopolies and Mergers Commission because of competition concerns (S)

headline: Indonesia to Sign 3d I.M.F. Rescue Pact
abstract: Indonesia is within days of signing new accord with International Monetary Fund to try to rescue its collapsing economy, and fund's leadership is fending off criticism that it is giving in too much to demands of Pres Suharto; new accord delays imposition of earlier requirements that Indonesia end its subsidies on electricity, gasoline and number of basic food items; Indonesian officials say fund's attempt to terminate subsidies are stoking anti-Government protests across country (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Inside Intel, Latest Setbacks Provoke Worries
abstract: Market Place column on Intel Corp's impending antitrust problems, as result of its dominance of chip business; Federal Trade Commission is expected to file suit against company; antitrust action will have little impact on Intel's business at first; over longer term, being embroiled in battle with Government could take its toll; FTC investigated Intel previously, but took no action; this leads analysts to suspect Government must have great confidence in its case now or it would not contemplate taking action that might result in failure; Intel could suffer greatly if Government suit results in guidelines on company's technological advancements; even without FTC pressure, Intel faces increased competition and a computer market that is becoming saturated; graph (M)

headline: Pager Service Is Disrupted By a Glitch With Satellite
abstract: Millions of nation's paging customers lose service after failure by Galaxy 4 satellite operated by Panamsat Corp, which is owned by Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors Corp; failure also disrupts television networks including CBS, though problem does not affect network's on-air operations; Paging Network Inc says 80 percent to 90 percent of all US paging customers lost service; Pagemart Wireless Inc calls interruption unprecedented and lashes out at Panamsat (L)

headline: NUCLEAR ANXIETY
abstract: AFTERMATH -- Experts say they fear an India-Pakistan war and a new arms race. News analysis, page A9.

headline: World News Briefs; U.N. Aid Agency Seeks Access in North Korea
abstract: UN World Food Program warns North Korea food relief supplies will be scaled back if large areas of country are not open to international aid workers; more than 40 provinces, with population of 400,000, have been off limits to relief agencies (S)

headline: Tottenham Journal; The Cross They Carry Is the Red Cross's Blunder
abstract: Thousands of Canadians received tainted blood from Canadian Red Cross in 1980's, and now red cross has become symbol of disillusionment, painful reminder of how badly their faith in the compassion of Canada has become; late last year an independent commission reported that Canada's blood system has failed to protect sick Canadians who received blood in 1980's; commission concluded that Govt had not adequately supervised Red Cross; agency has been stripped of its responsibility for blood system, and compensation was offered to about 1,000 people with AIDS; but some 42,000 Canadians contracted hepatitis C, which attacks liver and can be fatal; worried about setting too wide a precedent for compensation, federal and provincial authorities jointly set up compensation fund worth about $750 million; but fund was for benefit only of those who contracted diseasee between 1986 and 1990, when screening test was used in United States, but ignored in Canada; compensation package has become huge moral and political issue; photo (L)

headline: Bishop's Death Shakes Hopes for Guatemala Peace
abstract: Recent beating death of Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi has shaken Guatemalans' confidence that long civil war is really over and plunged Pres Alvaro Arzu's Government into crisis; human rights and civic groups hold murder, three days after Gerardi made public exhaustive Roman Catholic Church probe of human rights abuses during civil war, was intended to thwart action against abusers by frightening survivors, witnesses and Government; reject Government stand that he was likely crime victim; map; photo (M)

headline: Shares Up Broadly as Second Quarter Starts With a Bang
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 68.51 points, at 8,868.32; Nasdaq composite closes up 11.98 at 1,847.66; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 6.40, to 1,108.15; graph; chart (L)

headline: Researchers Crack Code In Cell Phones
abstract: Group computer researchers at University of California at Berkeley successfully crack widely used encryption method designed to prevent cloning of digital cellular phones, and they believe they have stumbled across evidence that system was deliberately weakened to permit Government surveillance; method that was cracked is known as GSM, for Groupe Speciale Mobile standard; GSM, world's most widely used encryption system for cellular phones, is employed in about 80 million of devices worldwide and by as many as two million phones in US; 20 American cellular phone companies, including Pacific Bell, unit of SBC Communications Inc, and Omnipoint Corp, use GSM standard (M)

headline: Simon D. Strauss, 86, Expert On Mining and Metals Market
abstract: Simon D Strauss, expert on metals markets, dies at age 86 (S)

headline: Amid Asian Crisis, Mahathir Holds On
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  East Asia's upheaval has already toppled governments in Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia, and the question now being asked with increasing frequency in Malaysia is whether Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad will also have to take responsibility for a looming recession and hand over power.

headline: Province Healthcare Deal
abstract: Province Healthcare Corp agrees to buy Havasu Samaritan Regional Hospital in Lake Havasu City, Ariz, from Samaritan Health System, for $105.5 million, adding to 8 hospitals in 4 states it now owns or leases (S)

headline: Pow! The Punches That Left Marvel Reeling
abstract: Article on Marvel Entertainment Group focuses on events that led to bankruptcy of company and delisting of Marvel on New York Stock Exchange; says fighting between financiers Ronald O Perelman and Carl C Icahn for control of company has left behind little of lasting value for investors, employees or comic book fans to show for their time in control of company; holds their original stakes in Marvel--about $10 million for Perelman, about $40 million for Icahn--represented pocket change to these billionaires; chart; drawings; photos (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls to its weakest level against dollar since Jan 8, hurt by permission about Japan's economy and weak stock market; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Friendly $3.6 Billion Bid Could End Brawl for Echlin  Dana made a friendly $3.6 billion stock offer to acquire Echlin, a smaller rival in the auto parts industry and the target of a hostile $3.1 billion bid of cash and stock from SPX. Echlin shares rose 8.4 percent and Dana fell 5.2 percent. The bid could end a takeover battle that began nearly three months ago.    Echlin would, in effect, become a seventh business unit at Dana. Echlin's chairman and president, Larry W. McCurdy, would be named president of the Echlin Strategic Business division and would lead Dana's entry into the aftermarket, where Dana has little presence. [Page D2.]

headline: Fallon McElligott hires a new chief creative officer.
abstract: David Lubars, who has been president, chief executive and chief creative officer at BBDO West unit of BBDO Worldwide, will leave to become creative director at Fallon McElligott; his appointment is effective on June 15; will assume creative responsibilities from Bill Westbrook, who will continue as president; photo (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: International Banks Pulled Money From Asia in 1997  International banks began pulling their money out of Asia during the last half of 1997, with South Korea and Thailand bearing the brunt of the withdrawals, according to a report released by the Bank for International Settlements. [Page D9.]    Dollar Climbs Above 137 Yen  The dollar rose above 137 yen for the first time in almost seven years amid expectations that neither the United States nor Japan would be willing to stem the yen's decline. The dollar also gained against the mark. [D9.]

headline: Fine Host Discloses S.E.C. Investigation
abstract: Fine Host Corp says it is subject of formal investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission; SEC has been informally reviewing company since Jan 29, after a week in December when Fine Host's shares plunged 64 percent with no explanation from the company (S)

headline: SAMSONITE PLANS REPURCHASE OF UP TO 59% OF SHARES
abstract: Samsonite Corp says it wil buy as many as 12 million shares at $40 a share; buyback, representing 59 percent of company's shares outstanding, is part of new recapitalization plan and replaces planned special dividend announced in Mar (S)

headline: Nissan to License Technology to Daimler
abstract: Nissan Motor Co says it will license pickup truck manufacturing technology to Daimler-Benz AG (S)

headline: Travel Services Adds Reservation Unit
abstract: Travel Services International Inc acquires Lexington Services Associates for $37.5 million (S)

headline: SYLVAN LEARNING SYSTEMS ADDING LANGUAGE INSTRUCTOR
abstract: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc acquires Aspect, closely held provider of English as a second language programs, for $65 million in stock (S)

headline: British Aerospace Soars on Hopes Company Might Buy Dasa
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG's merger with Chrysler Corp could lead to sale of Daimler's military aerospace arm, Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG, to British Aerospace PLC; British Aerospace has $1.3 billion in cash, and is considered to be company best positioned to lead consolidation in Europe's fragmented weapons industry (S)

headline: M.I.T. Re-engineers Magazine to Attract New Readers and Ads
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology re-engineers Technology Review, its money-losing magazine; magazine's new team and its supporters say that catalyst for shift was financial, but that its focus on policy implications of technology had made magazine predictable and crotchety; new focus will be on innovation and how it is done; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Sunbeam is facing a bleak outlook in the wake of the dismissal of its combative chief executive.
abstract: HOW much worse can it get for the Sunbeam Corporation?    Since the board of directors dismissed Albert J. Dunlap as chairman and chief executive nearly two weeks ago, the stock has continued to plummet. By all accounts, the financial outlook for the rest of the year looks bleak. Suggesting the situation is even more dire, the company said yesterday that there were unanswered questions about its 1997 financial results and confirmed that the Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating its accounting practices.

headline: Silver Is Down 3% on Rumor Buffett Sold Some of Holdings
abstract: Silver falls 3.1 percent, hurt by speculation that billionaire investor Warren E Buffett has sold about a third of his silver holdings since amassing sizable stockpile early this year; graph (M)

headline: Texaco Plans to Sell Unit
abstract: Texaco Inc is seeking buyers for its British gas marketing division, Texaco Natural Gas; company is also looking to sell its 50 percent stake in retail gas-marketing company Calortex (S)

headline: Times Guide to Entertainment Opens on the Internet Today
abstract: New York Times Co will introduce Internet service about entertainment, restaurants and shopping in New York City and its suburbs; site, called New York Today, will be available, starting Jan 16, at www.nytoday.com; service will compete with New York Sidewalk from Microsoft, Digital Cities New York from America Online and Citysearch New York from Citysearch; Daniel J Donaghy, general manager of New York Today, and Martin A Nisenholtz, president of New York Times Electronic Media Co, comment (M)

headline: Nissan to Cut U.S. Production Sharply
abstract: Nissan Motor Co will reduce vehicle output by 25 percent, sharpest cut since it opened plant in Smnyrna, Tenn, in 1983; Nissan does not plan any job costs and workers will be given time off with pay (S)

headline: Morgan Earnings Fall but Exceed Forecasts
abstract: J P Morgan & Co says earnings weakened in first quarter; large regional banking companies such as First Union Corp and Norwest Corp report double-digit gains for quarter; PNC Bank and State Street Corp post strong results; J P Morgan earned $237 million in quarter, down 44 percent from $424 million a year earlier; revenue rose 9 percent, to $2 billion; First Union says earnings rose 16 percent, to $587 million; Norwest says net income rose to $367.7 million from $321.9 million in year-earlier quarter; PNC Bank says earnings increased 1.1 percent; earnings grew to $269.3 million from $266.3 million; State Street says earnings rose 22 percent; net income rose to $105.7 million from $86.4 million; chart (L)

headline: Attempted Killing Links Turkish Army, the Kurds and Politics
abstract: Turkey's most prominent rights advocate, Akin Birdal, is released from hospital, but questions remain about who was behind May 12 attempt to kill him; police have arrested six men in connection with shooting; Birdal has identified two of them as gunmen who shot him in chest, arm and legs; Turkish military officers assert that Birdal and his Human Rights Association maintain ties with Kurdish guerrillas (M)

headline: Halting Loans Isn't Enough, Both Parties Tell Clinton
abstract: Republicans and Democrats in Senate score Clinton Administration's unwillingness to call on Indonesian Pres Suharto to resign; score stress on economic stability over democratic change; United States and its allies, in policy shift, suspend $43 billion economic bailout, halting total of $2.7 billion of loans from Asian Development Bank and World Bank; cite chaos that makes it impossible to track spending (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for April. Analysts expect an increase of 0.3 percent.  The National Association of Purchasing Management issues its index for May.

headline: Israelis, Proud and Worried, Now Ask, What Is Our State?
abstract: Article in series Israel at 50 notes that it has been fashion among Israelis on 50th anniversary of their state to feign indifference to jubilee; Israeli commentators explain it as reaction to difficulty of celebrating when driving into shopping mall still requires security check, when unemployment is high and when most bitter conflicts are no longer with Arabs, but among Jews; they note that after 50 years, there is still no peace; not surprisingly, this tangle of problems and passions is reflected in variety of events and demonstrations for Independence Day, which begins on April 29 with fireworks, rock concerts and parties around country; photos (M)

headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE SEPHARDIM: A Sense of Grievance Over a Life Spent 'on Standby'
abstract: Series, Israel at 50, on ethnic and cultural diversity that has evolved in half-century since founding as Jewish state; Sephardic Jews, immigrants or descendants of immigrants from North Africa and Middle East who make up 48 percent of Israel's population, carry keen sense of grievance for what they consider discrimination because of Sephardic background; level of their schooling and unemployment rate has been below that of European, or Ashkenazic Jews; residents of Netivot Sephardic community comment; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Jury Rejects Keyboard Injury Claims
abstract: Jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn rejects claims by nine people that they suffered injuries from using computer keyboard made by Digital Equipment Corp; decision reverses in part a 1996 verdict that was seen at the time as significant setback for computer maker; one of plaintiffs, Patricia Geressy, won judge of $5.3 million from jury in December 1996 for her claims of wrist injuries using Digital keyboard; but judgment was thrown out of court in May 1997 (M)

headline: Britain to Spend $520 Million to Pep Up Ulster
abstract: Britain proposes $520 million aid package for Northern Ireland as part of effort to win voter approval of peace accord (S)

headline: Bonn Sniffs for Russian Moles, Worrying C.I.A.
abstract: Exoneration of Volker Foertsch, German intelligence officer accused of spying for Russia, has not put end to controversy surrounding matter in either Germany or US, where case has raised troubling new questions at Central Intelligence Agency about possible betrayal of US secrets; CIA officials are concerned that German intelligence, which was often compromised by Communist agents during cold war, is again being infiltrated by Moscow; say Russia has never stopped spying on US and European countries despite collapse of Communism, and may be rebuilding its spy network for post-cold-war period (M)

headline: GENESIS HEALTH TO ACQUIRE VITALINK FOR $600 MILLION
abstract: Genesis Health Ventures Inc agrees to acquire Vitalink Pharmacy Services Inc for $600 million in cash or securities plus $90 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Stake in Nikko To Be Bought By Salomon
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney, Travelers Group Inc unit, reportedly plans to buy minority stake in Nikko Securities Co, Japan's third-largest brokerage firm (M)

headline: GTECH MAY GO PRIVATE THROUGH A LEVERAGED BUYOUT
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp says it might go private through leveraged buyout, in effort to increase its shareholder value (S)

headline: Dealer in U.S. Debt Is Ending Operations
abstract: Eastbridge Capital Inc, one of 36 primary dealers that deal directly with Federal Reserve's securities trading desk, is closing down operations; is unit of Nippon Credit Bank Ltd, which is closing all overseas units and affiliates to cut costs (S)

headline: South Asian Arms Race: Reviving Dormant Fears of Nuclear War
abstract: News analysis of nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan that has now burst into open view; particular danger seen because two arch-enemies, unlike US and Russia during cold war, have not held serious negotiations over outstanding problems for decades, or concluded agreements limiting weapons; photo; nuclear war could erupt over Kashmir, which has been in dispute since independence in 1947, and few countries have much leverage with either side; analyst Stephen P Cohen observes that Pakistan, which feels profoundly insecure and surrounded by enemies, was not offered any real incentives not to test, and has been deprived of much of its conventional military capability by cutoff of US equipment, whereas India is better armed by any measure (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY; An on-line grocer bets against bananas and meat, instead pushing low prices and national delivery.
abstract: Technology column by Evan I Schwartz on New York start-up called Netgrocer Inc, which offers 4,000 grocery itmes from its Web site; unlike more-established competitors that have their own delivery fleets, Netgrocer subcontracts package delivery to company that specializes in such things: FDX Corp, which delivers orders within two to three days; Netgrocer president Daniel Nissan says on-line shoppers want convenience of having nonperishable pantry items delivered at low cost, while buying their perishable foods in person at local specialty shops; says Netgrocer offers prices that are same as grocery store in Midwest, but well below going rates in New York; photos (M)

headline: Volvo Subsidiary to Buy Korean Equipment Unit
abstract: Samsung Heavy Industries says it expects to sell its construction-equipment division to Volvo Construction Equipment Corp of Sweden in deal worth $765 million; sale would be largest ever by South Korean company to foreign interests (S)

headline: Eye Catching: How New Media Are Racing to Become the Mass Media; The Search Services Want Your Eyes to Find No Reason to Wander
abstract: Yahoo and other search services, which attract million of visitors a day, are emerging as potential Internet profit centers, stirring interest among advertisers and on-line retailers; seek to keep visitors at their sites with variety of added services, redefining themselves as 'portals' to Web rather than as mere search engines; table; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Armstrong World  BankAmerica  Consol Papers  Highwoods Pptys  Kennametal  Noble Affil  Protective Life  Regency Rlty  Sthrn Calif Wtr

headline: Of Microsoft and Market Forces
abstract: ''Why Microsoft Should Be Left Alone'' (Viewpoint, May 24), by Bhaskar Chakravorti, drew varied responses from readers. Mr. Chakravorti, a senior member of the global consulting practice of the Monitor Company in Cambridge, Mass., argued that technology markets require no more regulatory intervention than other markets -- and that Microsoft has endured not by crushing competition but by finding ways to make challengers' products its own. Some readers essentially agreed; some saw other issues at work in Microsoft's fight with the Government.    To the Editor:

headline: Travelers to Get 25% Stake in Japanese Brokerage House
abstract: The Travelers Group and the Nikko Securities Company formally announced an agreement today that will give the Wall Street powerhouse a 25 percent stake in Japan's third-largest securities brokerage firm for $1.6 billion. The deal immediately raised questions about how quickly the Japanese financial industry would consolidate.     The Travelers-Nikko alliance, which had been expected since reports of it first appeared here on Friday, came as Japan is undergoing a broad-based financial restructuring aimed at making its markets as flexible as those in New York and London by 2001. Japanese and foreign companies are exploring possible combinations that will help them better compete in this new arena, and in markets around the world.

headline: Hilton Gambling Split-Off Seen, Then Merger With Grand Casinos
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp reportedly plans to split its hotel and gambling operations into separate companies and merge gaming unit with Mississippi gambling operations to be spun off by Grand Casinos; deal will free profitable hotel business from troubled gambling business and create gambling giant (M)

headline: USA Networks Chief Quits In Wake of Its Acquisition
abstract: Kay Koplovitz, founder, chairman and chief executive of USA Networks Inc, says she is leaving cable television company; Barry Diller, whose HSN Inc agreed to acquire USA Networks last October, is expected to assume direct control (M)

headline: In Death, Indignity for Despised Killer
abstract: Thai officers poke and prod body of former Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot, Sahook, Cambodia, taking fingerprints and other evidence to prove that man responsible for over million deaths is dead; examination falls short of full autopsy; foreign journalists view body; his widow, Mea Son, says he died in his sleep; Cambodian troops and Khmer Rouge defectors pursue last group of guerrilla holdouts, led by Ta Mok; map; photo (M)

headline: Russia Announces Intent to Ask I.M.F. for 10 to 15 Billion More
abstract: Russian Govt announces that it will seek $10 billion to $15 billion in additional assistance from International Monetary Fund (S)

headline: Prudential Bill Raises Concern For Consumers
abstract: New Jersey lawmakers are poised to adopt legislation governing reorganization of Prudential Insurance Co of America that consumer advocates say contains troubling loopholes that could shortchange nearly 11 million policyholders; legislation provides framework for distributing stock to policyholders as Prudential shifts to publicly traded company; at issue is how to determine each policyholder's share of company's worth; traditionally, when insurers have switched to public ownership they have used their accumulated profits as starting point in that calculation, in Prudential's case, that is $20 billion; Prudential says it is unclear what dollar amount will be used as benchmark (M)

headline: U.S. Offers China Incentive on Sanctions
abstract: United States, spurred by release of noted dissident Wang Dan, is offering to lift some sanctions it imposed on China after 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown if China makes added concessions on human rights, trade and exporting of dangerous technologies before Pres Clinton's visit; expects added prisoner rleases closer to visit; is pressing for further Chinese moves to open markets and cut tariffs to help China's bid to join World Trade Organization; photo (M)

headline: Chase Manhattan Picks Foote, Cone
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp selects Foote, Cone & Belding in New York to handle its consolidated corporate branding, worldwide consumer and business-to-business advertising account; billings estimated at $75 million (S)

headline: Target Practice in Geneva on the Global Trade Body
abstract: The World Trade Organization has come under attack recently from critics who say it ignores environmental and social issues in settling trade disputes.     At the center of the issue is a ruling against the United States last month, favoring a challenge from developing countries to the United States law that protects sea turtles from shrimpers' nets. Interest groups are accusing the three-year-old trade organization of being responsible for gutting environmental laws in the name of unfettered trade.

headline: As Strife Grips Indonesia, U.S. Asks Citizens to Leave and Delays Aid Payment
abstract: United States urges most of nearly 11,000 Americans living in Indonesia to leave country immediately, citing worst political violence there in more than three decades; Clinton Adm also joins European nations in delaying $1.4 billion emergency aid payment and orders evacuation of all nonessential employees of United States Embassy in Jakarta; it also calls off planned mission to Indonesia by high-ranking American military delegation (M)

headline: TEXAS UTILITIES WINS CLEARANCE ON ENERGY GROUP BID
abstract: Texas Utilities Co wins British Government clearance for its 6.3 billion pound ($10.4 billion) bid for Energy Group PLC, putting pressure on rival Pacificorp to top bid (S)

headline: Behind Headlines on Study, a Couple Married to Their Work
abstract: Profile of Donna Hoffman and Thomas Novak, co-authors of controversial article in journal Science demonstrating that lower-income black Americans are far less likely to have Internet access than whites of similar economic status; Hoffman reports receiving hate messages via E-mail since publication of report; Gary Chapman, who has worked to bring computer access to low-income communities, says import of Hoffman-Novak study is that it points out what is lacking on Internet; says content on Internet is not compelling enough to African-American community; photo (M)

headline: Americans, Flouting U.N. Embargo, Organize Relief for Iraqis
abstract: Americans are beginning to react against policy of continued sanctions against Iraq by organizing their own relief projects for Iraqi people; Americares, private relief organization based in New Canaan, Conn, says it will carry out first American airlift of over 75,000 pounds of medicines and hospital supplies to Baghdad, where nearly eight years of sanctions have crippled civilian medical system (M)

headline: Sudanese And Rebels Call for Vote In the South
abstract: Peace talks between Sudanese Government and southern rebels end in Nairobi, Kenya, on note of progress, as both sides agree to accept internationally supervised vote on self-determination for southern half of nation (M)

headline: Italy Agrees to Sell 12% of Energy Company
abstract: Italy's Government approves selling about 12 percent of its shares in energy company ENI SpA, which would lower its ownership stake to about 40 percent; sale is valued at $6.8 billion at current market prices; Government says it plans to retain control of ENI, Italy's biggest oil and gas company, even after the sale, a concession to Communists (S)

headline: Bank of New York Bids $23.7 Billion for Mellon
abstract: Bank of New York Co announces unsolicited $23.7 billion takeover offer for Mellon Bank Corp of Pittsburgh; Mellon spurns offer, setting up possibility that Bank of New York may mount hostile takeover for Mellon; hostile takeover is highly unusual step in banking industry and signal that huge mergers that are transforming nation's financial landscape threaten to get nasty; charts (L)

headline: Serious Tool For Searches
abstract: Family tree CD-ROM products serve not only as tool to draw family trees but also as place to record family events, history, and stories; Palladium Interactive's Ultimate Family Tree, Mindscape's Family Heritage Deluxe, Sierra Home's Generations Deluxe and Broderbund's Family Tree Maker Deluxe evaluated; photos (M)

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY HAVAS TRAVEL BUSINESS
abstract: American Express Co to buy Havas Voyages, France's biggest travel agency, for about 1 billion French francs ($166 million) from Havas SA (S)

headline: Lowe & Partners Takes Most Addys
abstract: Lowe & Partners/SMS takes top honors at annual presentation of Best of New York American Advertising Awards, known as the Addys, which are sponsored by Advertising Women of New York; North American offices of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising wins most Effie Awards, which are sponsored by New York chapter of American Marketing Association (S)

headline: 'Titanic' Lifts Profit At News Corporation
abstract: News Corp says its third-quarter profit, better than expected, rose 10 percent, led by its hit movie Titanic and higher advertising revenue at its television stations and Fox TV network; profit from operations rose $319 million from $291 million a year earlier; revenue rose 11 percent, to $3.22 billion (S)

headline: Correction: A Map of Jerusalem
abstract: Corrected map of Jerusalem; map with June 22 article on plan to expand city located parts of 1949-67 Israeli-Jordanian border incorrectly

headline: A Clean Bill For the Iraqis On A-Arms? Experts Upset
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency is moving close to declaring Iraq free of nuclear weapons, and some US experts are raising alarms and charging agency with complacency; they say Iraq's record of deception and its wealth of talented scientists point to both intention and ability to recreate atomic program quickly (M)

headline: 4 Airlines Set 2 Alliances For Marketing
abstract: Nation's four largest airlines to form two competing alliances that could portend dramatic shift in industry's landscape; American Airlines and US Airways just announced their new marketing alliance, and Delta Air Lines and United Airlines will soon make their announcement; these follow on heels of Northwest Airlines' recent agreement with Continental Airlines; deals are expected to allow partners to market and sell tickets on each others' flights in practice known as code-sharing; analyst says consumers will not see lower fares because there will be no increase in supply; such alliances do not require Government approval because no equity changes hands; Government may object anyway, claiming it is anti-competitive for three alliances to control 80 percent of market (M)

headline: Ex-Clinton Aide To Berkeley Post
abstract: Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the former chief economic adviser to President Clinton, has been named dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.    Ms. Tyson, who in 1993 became the first woman to lead the White House Council of Economic Advisers, will be the only woman dean of a major American business school.

headline: Treasury Sets Auction of Bills and Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and the auction of a 30-year inflation-indexed note on Wednesday. By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent; on the six-month bill, it was 4.94 percent. The inflation-indexed note was priced to yield 3.64 percent.    The following issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Posts Earnings of $49 Million
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi PLC earned 29.7 million pounds, or $49 million, on revenue of 407 million pounds in 1997; Cordiant reports earnings of 24 million pounds, or $40 million, on revenue of 319.1 million pounds (S)

headline: Swiss Banks Make Offer On Nazi Loot
abstract: Switzerland's three largest commercial banks offer $600 million to settle claims from Holocaust victims who charged that their families' assets were stolen; leaders of Jewish groups immediately reject offer as 'humiliating,' and say negotiations have broken down; banks hint that their offer is final; Swiss Government is opposed to large settlement because it knows that next target of suits will be Swiss central bank, which received more than 80 percent of Nazi Germany's stolen gold (M)

headline: Nissan Is in Talks With Daimler-Benz
abstract: Nissan Motor Co and Diamler-Benz AG of Germany are in discussions about potential business tie-up between Daimler and Nissan's heavy-truck manufacturing unit (S)

headline: Conair Buys Waring Unit
abstract: CTS Corp agrees to sell its Waring Products division to Conair Corp; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Taiwan Steelmaker Cuts Its Prices
abstract: China Steel Corp, Taiwan's biggest steelmaker, makes first unscheduled price cut in its 27-year history as cheaper imports from Korean rivals threaten its domestic market; China Steel cuts prices for hot-rolled steel by 5.3 percent and prices for cold-rolled steel price by 2.8 percent (S)

headline: VALLEY NATIONAL AGREES TO ADD WAYNE BANCORP
abstract: Valley National Bancorp to acquire Wayne Bancorp Inc for over $69 million in stock (S)

headline: Reluctant Threat: West's Kosovo Policy Hinges on the Use of Force
abstract: United States and its allies reportedly remain reluctant to use force against the Yugoslav Army, despite NATO's decision to put on a display of air power in countries bordering Serbian province of Kosovo; but Western policy, as it is being formulated on the run, hinges on the credible threat of force in order to prompt a negotiated solution between Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic and the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo; Clinton Administation and NATO officials are counting on Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin to help persuade Milosevic to halt the violence and start negotiating seriously (M)

headline: As U.S. Spars With Microsoft, Federal Offices Use Its Systems
abstract: Government is becoming increasingly dependent on Microsoft software, even as it steps up its antitrust pursuit of company that produces it; industry analysts estimate that in current fiscal year, Microsoft's Government sales will be about $380 million, up nearly 40 percent from previous year; part of push toward Microsoft involves company's office productivity and communications programs like its Word for word processing and its Excel spreadsheet, which in many Federal offices is replacing software from Wordperfect and Lotus; biggest move involves sales of Microsoft's industrial-strength operating system, Windows NT, which is becoming more and more popular in corporate America; Justice Dept insists that its antitrust confrontation with Microsoft is not meant to hobble company but to protect competition and innovation in software industry; says if Microsoft succeeds not through unfair advantages but by offering best product for best price, then modern antitrust policy is working as it should (M)

headline: True Delbert Morse, 102, an Eisenhower Official
abstract: True Delbert Morse, former Agriculture Department Under Secretary and an architect of agricultural price support policy, dies at age 102 (M)

headline: As Unemployment Worsens, Hong Kong Stocks Fall 5.7%
abstract: Unemployment in Hong Kong reached 4.2 percent from March through May, highest rate in 15 years; stock market plunges 5.7 percent to its lowest closing level since Jan 30, 1995; Hang Seng drops 452.94 points, to 7,462.50; Jan Lee, chief economist at Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, predicts unemployment will rise to 5.5 percent by end of 1998; says overall economy, which shrank at 2 percent annual rate in first quarter, will probably finish 1998 with 1 percent decline--first full year of recession since Hong Kong began tracking its growth in 1961; graph (M)

headline: Wolf Announces Shifts at Meldrum
abstract: Wolf Group announces changes at its Cleveland agency, Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ABIGAIL ADAMS NATIONAL BANCORP, Washington, the holding company for Adams National Bank, named Jeanne Delany Hubbard chief executive and chairwoman of the bank after the ouster of Barbara Davis Blum. The bank is one of the few United States banks owned and run by women.     AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, named James Cracchiolo president of its international division, TRS International, succeeding Thomas Ryder.

headline: For the repetitively stressed and those otherwise challenged, a computer mouse operated by foot.
abstract: James Loop receives patent for foot mouse designed to be manipulated with floor pedals, for computer users who suffer from repetitive stress injuries; David Burrello receives patent for single-use toothbrush (S)

headline: Alternative doorways to the Internet are popping up in the spirit of free-flowing information.
abstract: Technology column by Tom Watson on grand designs of many Web-search companies; says they are no longer content to direct user to Web sites, but seek to create 'portals' to Internet, complete with dial-in service, free E-mail and personal Web pages, paging and messaging, customized news, local weather and stock tracking; says it is radical departure from original business model of catching customer's eye on way to other sites; drawing (M)

headline: Angelus N. Cotsidas, 96, Pastry Executive
abstract: Angelus N Cotsidas, founder and chairman of Table Talk Pastry Company, dies at age 96 (S)

headline: Sharon Won't Join Netanyahu in Meeting Albright
abstract: Min Ariel Sharon, who is considered key to Israeli Government approval of any peace deal, says he will not join Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu in his meeting with State Sec Madeleine K Albright; protests Netanyahu's unauthorized 'promises'; stand will stiffen Netanyahu's resistance to United States pressure for further withdrawal from West Bank (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.36   5.34        3-month T-bills   4.98   4.90   5.21        6-month T-bills   5.06   5.04   5.38        10-yr. T-infl.   3.74   3.74   3.62        10-yr. T-note   5.63   5.58   6.86        30-yr. T-bond   5.92   5.87   7.09        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.08   8.11        Municipal bds.   5.30   5.28   5.96          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: U.N. Chief Pays a Visit To Tribunal For Rwanda
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan visits International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda during trial of Col Anatole Nsengiumva, who is charged with inciting Hutu mobs to kill Tutsi during 1994 civil war; says there has been extensive improvements in tribunal over past six months; his suspension of its top administrative officers little over year ago for mismanagement and questionable financial transactions recalled (M)

headline: Analysts Are Stars of This Investing Universe
abstract: Analyst-driven funds are gaining recognition on Wall Street as having credible money mangement strategy with solid returns; Galileo fund is one of handful of mutual funds in which analysts make buy-and-sell decisions (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/  The perils of investing in illiquid stocks, as seen in two small-cap mutual funds from Dreyfus. By Gretchen Morgenson.    INVESTING IT /Page 4/  They were ready for him to retire, but would their investments sustain their expensive life style? Fresh Start, by Dawn Gilbertson.

headline: Fed Report Indicates Growth Free of Inflation
abstract: Federal Reserve's latest reading on economy points to inflation-free growth as some manufacturers contend with weaker demand from Asia for electronics and other products; Fed's latest regional economic outlook states that expansion is occurring in nearly all districts; Commerce Dept says new orders for manufactured goods rose three-tenths of percent, to seasonally adjusted $336.23 billion; orders fell revised seven-tenths of percent in February, slightly less than perviously reported drop of nine-tenths of percent; map; graph (M)

headline: Marcos Family Big Winners in Philippine Elections
abstract: MANILA—  For the family of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, election day has emerged as a turning point in its drive for renewed power and respectability in the Philippines, and aides are now openly talking of a possible presidential pardon for his widow, Imelda.

headline: Countdown Starts for New Money : Adoption of Single Currency Marks Triumph of Political Will
abstract: BRUSSELS—  A decades-long vision becomes reality Saturday with the formal nomination of 11 countries to join Europe's monetary union embracing 290 million Europeans in a single market with the same money, the euro.

headline: 5 Attractions for Summer Joy Riding
abstract: Verne G Kopytoff reviews Riddler's Revenge, new roller coaster at Six Flags Magic Mountain in Valencia, Calif (S)

headline: Ancient Machines For Making Text
abstract: Collectors of typewriters find the Internet to pursue their low-tech passion; Dr Richard Polt comments; photo (M)

headline: Asia's Crisis Upsets Rising Effort To Confront Blight of Sweatshops
abstract: Asia's financial crisis spawns desperation to extent that more people than ever seem willing to take grim or dangerous jobs in factories, even as pressure grows in West against sweatshops; scholars and labor organizers say trend toward improved working conditions in Third World, where economic misery and differing labor standards have long made sweatshops more prevalent than in West, has been sharply reversed; say financial crisis has forced many workers to compete for jobs that year ago they would have scorned, and that increasing numbers of desperate workers are lining up to take precisely kinds of jobs that are being roundly condemned in West; in slums and in Indonesia and Thailand, many workers even speak of sweatshop jobs as their greatest aspiration; photo (M)

headline: Murphy's Law of the Podium
abstract: On the Job column offers series of points for executives and managers on importance of being prepared when giving presentations or speeches; drawing (M)

headline: NATO Action in Kosovo Would Face New Pitfalls
abstract: NATO forces, which bombarded Bosnian Serbs into peace-making, face different situation with Serb attacks in Kosovo province; Yugoslav army is much better organized and equipped than Bosnian Serbs ever were, Kosovo campaign lacks clearly-defined lines, and NATO attack would not likely cut off supply lines from central Serbia; hope is that threat of force will persuade Pres Slobodan 1 Milosevic to ease suppression of ethnic Albanians (S)

headline: As Crowds Vent Their Rage, Rwanda Publicly Executes 22
abstract: Tens of thousands of Rwandans gather in Kigali and other towns to watch and cheer execution of 22 people convicted of mass murder, and to vent their rage at slaughter of Hutus by Tutsis in 1994; Froduald Karamira, one of those executed, was prominent businessman and prime ideologue behind Hutu Power movement; his daily hate broadcasts encouraged Hutus to murder; photo of defendants at trial last year; map; human rights advocates charge many of Rwandan trials failed to meet 'international standards of justice,' but Government is under pressure from survivors, and seeks to send message to Hutu guerrillas who continue to kill large numbers of Tutsi in countryside; UN tribunal in Tanzania, by contast, has yet to convicted anyone (S)

headline: Hindu Nationalists Move to Rule India's Atom Era
abstract: As India adjusts to new status as nuclear weapons state, many Indians are wondering whether they should prepare for new era of dominance by Hindu nationalist leaders who ordered five underground nuclear tests, which have forced country to reset political and philosophical compass; many Indians feel widespread condemnation abroad, including economic sanctions by US, could be matched by similarly far-reaching political effects at home; feel approval of tests by Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee and approval by 90 percent of Indians in public opinion polls have struck powerful blow against opposition parties, rearranging political landscape in nationalists' favor (M)

headline: Clinton Is 'Encouraged' by Iraqi Progress on Arms Inspections
abstract: Pres Clinton says that he is encouraged by Iraqi cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors and that he expects to reduce number of American troops who are now deployed in Persian Gulf region to keep watch on Iraq (M)

headline: Times Makes Appointments in Circulation
abstract: John Daly, executive who spearheaded New York Times's move to broaden its reach by making distribution agreements with 123 newspaper distributorships, is named vice president for national circulation at newspaper; Lauretta Prestera, vice president for advertising for last four months, is returning to circulation department as vice president of New York circulation (S)

headline: INTEGRATED HEALTH SELLS 5 NURSING HOMES TO OMEGA
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc sells five nursing homes to real estate investment trust Omega Healthcare Investors Inc for $50 million to pay down debt; nursing homes are being leased for 13 years to closely held joint venture Lyric Healthcare LLC, which hired Integrated Health to operate them (S)

headline: Investors Seek Sale Of Nuveen
abstract: Little-known analyst Mario Cibelli is pressing John Nuveen Co, giant mutual fund group, to put itself up for sale; has won backing of some other minority shareholders disappointed by group's poor performance; St Paul Cos, which owns majority stake, and Nuveen board oppose sale (M)

headline: Ethiopia and Eritrea Seem Ready to Do Battle
abstract: Ethiopia and Eritrea appear to be on verge of war over 250 square miles of disputed land known as Yigra triangle; both sides, formerly staunch allies, have massed troops in area and accused other of invading zone; crisis has worsened despite efforts of United States Asst State Sec Susan E Rice to ease tensions; Ethiopia demands Eritrean withdrawal; Eritrea denies its forces are on Ethiopian soil; map (M)

headline: France and Germany Report Output Gains
abstract: French manufacturers increased output in March by 1.2 percent, a three-month high, while German output rose eight-tenths of a percent in the month; Germany's exports boomed in same month, while its money supply, key inflation indicator, fell in April; reports suggest expansion will continue in coming months (S)

headline: As Colombia Picks New Chief, Rebels Voice Their View
abstract: Colombia's two main rebel groups have issued stinging attacks on Horacio Serpa, who has campaigned as presidential candidate best able to negotiate end to civil conflict; biggest rebel group blames him for 1992 breakdown in peace talks and holds talks with representative of rival candidate, Andres Pastrana; surprising turnaround is latest in series of strange election twists; photo (M)

headline: At Cremation Of Pol Pot, No Tears Shed
abstract: Body of Pol Pot, one of century's great mass killers, is cremated near Cambodian-Thai border; only dozen people witness cremation, including small group of photographers who are invited to record event (M)

headline: Profits More Robust Than Expected at UAL and US Airways
abstract: UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, and US Airways Group report first-quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street analysts' estimates; Trans World Airlines reports loss slightly greater than estimates; UAL earned $61 million, down 42 percent from $105 million in year-earlier quarter; US Airways Group says first-quarter earnings fell 36 percent, to $98.3 million from $152.7 million in quarter a year earlier; company says it has postponed plan to begin serving Gatwick Airport in London from its hub in Charlotte, NC, bowing to British Government in dispute over landing rights; Trans World Airlines reports loss of $55.5 million, compared with loss of $71.6 million in 1997 quarter (M)

headline: PSA Peugeot Citroen Sales Rise by 24%
abstract: PSA Peugeot Citroen, France's largest car maker, says sales soared 24 percent in first quarter; sales reached 57.8 billion French francs ($9.63 billion), up from 46.5 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: When One Operating System Just Can't Satisfy a Customer
abstract: V Communications, whose System Commander permits computer users to have more than one operating system on single computer, will soon offer System Commander Special Edition for Windows 98 (S)

headline: Germans to Mourn Mark, The Symbol of Revival
abstract: Germans are expected to mourn 50th anniversary of German mark on June 20, 1948 in light of Europe's decision to go with single currency, the euro, on Jan 1, 1999; anyone seeking to understand why Germans will mourn need look only at tumultuous days when mark was born--not simply new coinage of fallen realm, but infant emblem of Germany's regeneration as postwar Europe's economic colossus (L)

headline: When to Retire? Planners and Workers Are on Opposite Paths
abstract: More Americans over last three decades, despite proposal to push back Social Security retirement age, are taking early retirement; early retirees comment; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen's rebound fades on expectations of weaker Japanese economy; in New York the dollar costs 129.60 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFIC TO BUY METALLURG FOR $300 MILLION
abstract: Metallurg Inc to be bought by investor group led by Safeguard International Fund LP for about $300 million in cash (S)

headline: Magnetic Mania; In This Merged, Merged World, Anything Goes
abstract: Another day, another dozen deals.    On a single day last month, Office Depot, an eye on expanding abroad, agreed to buy Viking Office Products in a $3 billion stock swap; Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company announced a $1.59 billion hostile tender offer for Allied Group, an Iowa car and home insurer; Dillard's, the Midwestern retailer, bought the Mercantile Stores Company for $2.9 billion, and Cardinal Health, hoping to become a one-stop service provider for pharmaceutical companies, paid $2.2 billion in stock for R. P. Scherer.    And those were just the biggest fish. In all, 11 proposed deals with a total value of about $17 billion were announced on May 18. It was a pace almost unheard of -- or would have been last year or the year before. In 1998, though, it wasn't so unusual. The growing conviction by corporations worldwide that bigger is better in the global marketplace has generated a merger wave that has dwarfed anything that preceded it.
