headline: Colombian President's Accuser Handily Wins Presidency
abstract: Colombians vote resounding end to scandal-ridden presidency of Ernesto Samper, electing as his successor Andres Pastrana, Conservative former Mayor of Bogota who first accused Samper of accepting money from drug dealers; his election over Horacio Serpa, Interior Minister and Samper's most loyal advocate, opens new chapter in Colombia's relations with US, which have boiled over with suspicion and bitterness during Samper's four years in power; photo (M)

headline: Bringing Financial Respectability to a Drug Maker
abstract: Article on Milan Panic, former Prime Minister of Yugoslavia who heads ICN Pharmaceuticals and is credited with bringing financial respectability to beleaguered and oft-maligned drug company; Panic is subject of Securities and Exchange Commission probe into his sale of ICN stock in 1994 before company announced that ICN drug ribavirin would be not be approved by Food and Drug Administration; staff of SEC has recommended to full commission that Panic be banned from being officer or director of any publicly traded company in US; graph; photo (M)

headline: In the Words of Albright: A Crisis of Partnership
abstract: Excerpts from Sec Madeleine K Albright's speech to National Press Club (M)

headline: U.S. LIQUIDS BUYING 13 COMPANIES TO REACH NEW MARKETS
abstract: US Liquids Inc, processor of nonhazardous waste, plans to buy 13 companies with combined 1997 revenue of $97.6 million to expand into new businesses and geographical markets (S)

headline: North Korea Plans to Continue Developing and Selling Missiles
abstract: North Korea, rejecting United States suggestions that it curb missile program, says it will continue to develop and deploy missiles and sell them abroad; hints it might freeze program if US first lifted economic embargo (M)

headline: Big Bank Overcomes Its Scandals
abstract: Bankers Trust Corp has overcome financial scandals and is refashioning itself as investment banker to nation's smaller, fast-growing companies; earnings have rebounded, but it remains to be seen whether this strategy will give New York bank heft it needs to go it alone on Wall Street and avoid becoming takeover bait; chief executive Frank N Newman says Bankers Trust has no intention of trying to compete with larger rivals (M)

headline: In Seattle, Bill Gates Is Still a Hometown Hero
abstract: Employees and former employees of Microsoft Corp in Seattle suburb of Redmond, site of Microsoft headquarters, feel no immediate threat from Justice Department's antitrust suit against Microsoft; dominant view is that Microsoft will fight department because fighting--and winning--is what Microsoft does best; Microsoft has produced half-dozen billionaires and more than 2,000 millionaires; some Redmond residents comment; photo (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Ranch 1, New York, to Posnick & Kolker, New York, as the first agency to create campaigns for the fast-food chain. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: In California, Enron Curbs Power Sales
abstract: Enron Corp has temporarily stopped trying to sell electricity to residential customers in California, demonstrating difficulties that many power marketers face in trying to attract business; although about 10 million customers in California are able to choose their electricity suppliers, fewer than 1 percent have so far decided to switch from their local power companies; Enron has been able to persuade only about 30,000 customers to switch; Enron chairman-chief executive Lou Pai comments (M)

headline: EUROPEANS ACCEPT A SINGLE CURRENCY DESPITE LATE SNAG
abstract: European Union plan to begin common currency among 11 countries in 1999 gets underway after leaders of 15 member nations, meeting, Brussels, resolve dispute between France and Germany over who should run new European central bank; leaders name Wim F Duisenberg of Netherlands, German-backed candidate, to eight-year term after he says he plans to retire by mid-2002; France had sought written agreement that he would leave after four years to make way for French candidate, Jean-Claude Trichet; photo (L)

headline: Still Tough in New York, but Getting Better
abstract: Finding a summer job is far harder for teen-agers in New York City than it is for their peers in most of the nation for reasons ranging from a shortage of lawns to mow to competition from recent immigrants.    They are not alone, of course. Teen-agers in Los Angeles, Miami and other cities also have a much tougher time finding employment.

headline: Newspapers Join On-Line Network
abstract: Gannett Co, Central Newspapers Inc and McClatchy Co to join Classified Ventures on-line network, which links on-line classified listings, advertising and other local information posted on newspapers' Web sites (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Cent Vt Pub Svc

headline: Computers: Hard to Use?
abstract: Dr Jakob Nielsen letter on May 28 article holds computers do not have to be hard to use

headline: Pepsi-Cola, with cola sales lagging, replaces its top marketer with a three-man committee.
abstract: Advertising column explores Pepsi-Cola Co's decision to restructure leadership of its marketing for all its soft-drink brands; company has announced departure of Brian Swette, its chief global marketing officer, and instead of replacing him, company is creating marketing council composed of its top three executives; company has been stung by lagging performance of its flagship Pepsi-Cola brand (M)

headline: An anti-award ceremony that seeks to bury Madison Avenue, not praise it.
abstract: Awards called the Schmios, presented by critics who contend that advertising fosters unfortunate consumerist culture among Americans, are presented; awards are timed to precede presentations of Clio Awards for creativity in advertising; sponsors listed (L)

headline: The Party Is Great, But Not All Are Invited
abstract: Floyd Norris article on sharp first-quarter rise in Nasdaq composite average; notes most of gain came in top 100 stocks of thousands in average; sees investors moving money out of companies with disappointing earnings into other stocks, keeping ever more concentrated list of stocks riding high on sea of liquidity; graph (M)

headline: German Jobless Rate Is Unchanged at 11.5%
abstract: Germany's unemployment rate was unchanged at 11.5 percent in March (S)

headline: Rapp Collins Forms Alliance
abstract: Rapp Collins Worldwide forms alliance with Customer Management Group; Customer Management will continue to operate under present management (S)

headline: Clinton Argues For 'Flexibility' Over Sanctions
abstract: Pres Clinton, in remarks to about 60 evangelical Christian leaders at White House, criticizes laws that automatically impose sanctions on countries for behavior that Americans find unacceptable; says such legislation puts pressure on executive branch to overlook violations so that it will not have to carry out sanctions; asks group to withdraw its support for pending legislation that aims to reduce religious persecution overseas by imposing trade and aid sanctions on repressive regimes (M)

headline: CLINTON IN CHINA
abstract: DETAINING DISSIDENTS -- The U.S. expressed concern over reports of arrests during the President's visit. Page A9.

headline: ABC stays with old yellow, but it's in an 'evolved' form.
abstract: ABC network is bringing back for second season an irreverent, yellow-tinted campaign that satirically salutes those intermingled twinges of guilt and pleasure felt by most Americans as they watch television; updated campaign for 1998-99 prime-time season developed by TBWA Chiat/Day detailed; photo (M)

headline: Bank Purchase in Nevada
abstract: Alabama-based Colonial Bancgroup to acquire Interwest Bancorp for undisclosed amount in stock (S)

headline: Kin Earned Riches, Says New Leader Of Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian economists and political activists begin to document sprawling business holdings of Pres B J Habibie's family amid growing concern that he used public office to amass private fortune, though on lesser scale than ex-Pres Suharto; he defends family wealth and denies nepotism (M)

headline: Korean President Sees a Western Cure for Economic Ills
abstract: South Korea's Pres Kim Dae Jung tells New York business leaders that his country's once-prized economic miracle is nothing but a 'house of cards' and that his people need American help to rebuild economy in a more Western image, speech to Council on Foreign Relations; Kim lashes out at his predecessors for creating economy characterized by collusion and corruption; says South Korea has turned decisively to democracy and it has opened its borders to foreign investment and trade; photo (M)

headline: With Nigeria's Military Ruler Dead, Concern Is Voiced for the Fate of His Jailed Foe
abstract: Hafsat Abiola, daughter of Moshood K O Abiola, Nigerian opposition leader jailed after being elected President in 1993, calls for military to step aside in wake of death of military ruler, Gen Sani Abacha, and for father's immediate release, phone interview; expresses concern about father's welfare; other Nigerian opposition leaders call for Abiola to be installed as President of transitional Government; photos (M)

headline: Riots Break Out in Jakarta After Shooting of Students
abstract: Riots explode near Jakarta's central business district in response to Indonesia police shootings of student protesters; looting continues into night, with crowds targeting ethnic Chinese shopkeepers; Pres Suharto cuts short visit to Egypt; appeals for calm in statement delivered by Vice Pres B J Habibie; riots close major roads, leaving city paralyzed, and further damage already devastated economy; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn drops 1.7 percent on forecasts of mostly dry weekend weather for rain-soaked Midwest, which has prevented some farms from planting; July contracts fall 4.5 cents a bushel, to $2.5575; graph; chart (S)

headline: A G.E.-Mexico Locomotive Deal
abstract: General Electric Co says TFM SA de CV, Mexican railroad operator, ordered 75 locomotives with maintenance contracts in transaction valued at several hundred million dollars as Mexico makes its railroads private (S)

headline: BAY VIEW CAPITAL TO BUY PSB LENDING FOR $153 MILLION
abstract: Bay View Capital Corp to acquire PSB Lending Corp for $153 million in stock and cash plus as much as $147 million from future profits (S)

headline: Spy Agencies Under Attack for Providing No Warning : Clinton Vows to Punish India
abstract: WASHINGTON—  President Bill Clinton vowed Tuesday to apply U.S. laws imposing strong sanctions against India after its underground nuclear tests, and he implored other countries in the region not to follow India "down the path of a dangerous arms race."

headline: Leak Caused NATO to Drop Bosnia Effort On Fugitives
abstract: Senior US officials say plans for capturing people indicted on war-crimes charges in Bosnia, including fugitive Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, went awry last year after US military officers learned that French Army Maj Herve Gourmelon had been meeting secretly with Karadzic (M)

headline: TIME WARNER TO ADD 9.6 MILLION SHARES TO BUYBACK PLAN
abstract: Time Warner Inc will increase its existing stock buyback program by 9.6 million shares; increase raises size of company's buyback program to maximum 53.7 million shares, or about 9 percent of company's outstanding shares (S)

headline: UNEASY ALLIES: A special report.; Bogota Aid: To Fight Drugs or Rebels?
abstract: Concerned about the growing power of leftist rebels in Colombia, the Clinton Administration is expanding its support for Government forces fighting in the hemisphere's longest-running guerrilla war.    United States officials say the aid is aimed at stanching the flow of illegal drugs from Colombia, and will only go after the insurgents where they protect the production of heroin and cocaine. The officials say they have no intention of getting mired in Colombia's internal conflict.

headline: People
abstract: Myron Lyskanycz is named managing director at Leo Burnett Co, succeeding Brian William, who left agency (S)

headline: Keeping It All in the Gabelli Family
abstract: Funds Watch column on Gabelli Global Opportunity fund, which started on May 11 and is managed by Mario Gabelli's 30-year-old son, Marc; photo (M)

headline: Warning Issued About Viagra
abstract: Pfizer Inc says it is warning paramedics and emergency room physicians not to administer nitroglycerin to patients taking Pfizer's impotence drug Viagra; Viagra label already has warning that it should not be used by those taking organic nitrates like nitroglycerin, which is primarily used to treat angina--chest pain caused by clogged arteries (S)

headline: Israeli Drug Company Pursues European Deal
abstract: Jerusalem-based Teva Pharmaceutical Industries is in talks to acquire unidentified European pharmaceutical company with annual sales of $100 million (S)

headline: South Korea in Accord With Monetary Fund
abstract: South Korea and International Monetary Fund agree on new targets for country's economy, including forecast of first recession since 1980; they agree that economy will shrink 1 percent this year, down from their projection of 1 percent growth made in February; they also agree to let Government run larger budget deficit than earlier planned (S)

headline: Sales of Chrysler Vehicles Jumped 27% in May to a Record
abstract: Chrysler Corp says sales of cars and trucks in US rose 27 percent in May, making it best sales month ever for Chrysler; car sales rose 4.7 percent, to 73,452 vehicles, from May 1997; truck sales rose 39 percent, to 176,579; total of 250,031 vehicles, beat previous record of 245,289 in May 1996; Honda Motor Co and Toyota Motor Corp also post gains (M)

headline: Venice Journal; A Gondola (as It Were) Built for 2,600, Plus Crew
abstract: Grand Princess, largest cruise ship in world, sails into Venice on its maiden voyage; cruise ship cost $450 million and is most expensive one ever built; it was built by Italian shipbuilding company Fincantieri and its parent company is Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co of Britain; diagram; map shows route of maiden voyage (M)

headline: Planners Ease Travel, but Would Jack Kerouac Have Used One?
abstract: AAA MAP 'N' GO 3.0  (DeLorme; $39.95; Windows 95 and 3.1.)    TRIP PLANNER 98 Version 6.0  (Microsoft Expedia; $39.95; Windows 95.)    TRIPMAKER DELUXE 1998  (Rand McNally; $44.95; Windows 95 and NT.)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Yen Slides, U.S. Renews Pressure on Japan
abstract: American authorities step up pressure on Japanese Government to make good on its promises of economic reform and avoid another decline in yen's value, one week after Clinton Administration signed off on multibillion-dollar intervention in currency markets to support Japanese yen; investors seem to have been unimpressed with speed of Japan's efforts to clean up $600 billion in bad bank debts, spur the economy and accelerate deregulation of its financial markets; Deputy Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers comments to Congress suggest that Clinton Administration will not intervene again any time soon; photo; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: HOSPITALITY IN BUY-AND-LEASE DEAL WITH CANDLEWOOD
abstract: Hospitality Properties Trust agrees to buy and lease back 16 hotels in 12 states from Candlewood Hotel Co for about $135 million in second such agreement between the two companies (S)

headline: At Least 80 Die in German Train Crash
abstract: At least 80 people are killed and hundreds injured when high-speed passenger train hits concrete pillar of road overpass at 125 miles an hour near Eschede, Germany; officials call it worst crash in Germany in at least 50 years and say final toll will probably exceed 100; crash stuns Germany, which prides itself on safety and speed of its train sytem; map; photos (M)

headline: 8 World Leaders Urge Suharto to Show Restraint in Handling Indonesian Turmoil
abstract: Leaders of seven largest industrial democracies and Russia, at Group of Seven economic summit meeting, Birmingham, Eng, call on Pres Suharto to show restraint in responding to growing unrest in Indonesia; call for political and economic changes; Pres Clinton scrambles to assemble united front to protest India's nuclear tests, winning accord on toughly worded statement, but only vague promises of concrete action; seeks formula to convince Pakistan not move ahead with own nuclear tests (M)

headline: An environmental campaign is 'Back by popular neglect.'
abstract: One of best-known, most-honored commercials ever--public service announcement in which American Indian, Iron Eyes Cody, sheds tear at sight of littered landscape--is being revived; Indian is being presented not as living man but 'as an icon'; familiar 'crying Indian' character, introduced on Earth Day 1971, is coming back in commercial that will be shown publicly for first time on Earth Day 1998; new spot promotes Keep America Beautiful Inc; commercial was created on pro bono basis by North Castle Partners; photo (L)

headline: Patents; Bluepoints, an aquaculture company, finds a way to clean the world's polluted shrimp ponds.
abstract: Bluepoints Co patents a way to keep shrimp ponds clean so they never have to be abandoned by shrimp farmers; LaTina D McCoy patents new type of nipple guard for breast-feeding women that she says will help women with sore breasts or those who have premature infants who are not strong enough to latch on properly; Intellectual Property Owners Association releases its ranking of top 10 recipients of US patents for 1997 (M)

headline: South Koreans Protest Spread Of Layoffs In I.M.F. Plan
abstract: Tens of thousands of South Korean workers walk off their jobs and stage polite protests against layoffs and increasing use of temporary workers; workers express anger at conglomerates, whose owners seem to be escaping hardships suffered by average Koreans, and at Government, which passed law in Feb making it easier to lay off workers as part of effort to prod conglomerates to restructure; sentiment is also running against International Monetary Fund, which made increased 'labor flexibility' condition of its $58 billion bailout (M)

headline: Apartheid's Architects Losing White Votes in South Africa
abstract: Loss of Parliamentary seats by National Party in three recent local elections is seen as first sign of possible big swing away from party that ruled South Africa from 1947 to 1994; loss is first tangible evidence that support for builder of apartheid is being lost to Democratic Party--heir to white liberal anti-apartheid parties of 1970's and 1980's (M)

headline: EQUITY OFFICE TO BUY 13 PROPERTIES FOR $394 MILLION
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust agrees to acquire 13 buildings totaling about 2.7 million square feet from affiliates of Miller Global Properties LLC and Anschutz Properties Co, for about $394 million (S)

headline: COMMUNICATIONS GIANT: THE SHAREHOLDERS -- A Hitch in the AT&T-TCI Hitch; For Shareholders, a New Type of Stock to Behold
abstract: Millions of AT&T Corp shareholders will receive so-called tracking stock as part of merger between AT&T and Tele-Communications Inc; tracking stock is a security typically issued by large conglomerate with interests in wide variety of businesses; because security is designed to track narrow segment of company's far-flung operations, issuing it is good way for a company to put discrete market value on those operations alone; in most cases, ownership of tracking shares does not represent direct ownership of business's underlying assets, as common stock ownership does; underlying assets are still owned by issuing company, but in tracking stock the issuing company agrees to parcel out economics of business, as it were, giving its shareholders stake in entire operation while its tracking stockholders can concentrate their bet; chart shows breakdowns of AT&T's and Tele-Communications' various operations; photo (M)

headline: 4-Day Rally Comes to Halt On Fear of Rate Increases
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 45.09 points, to 9,147.57; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 6.57 points, to 1,115.50; Nasdaq composite index falls 13.95 points, to 1,864.91; graph; chart (L)

headline: Training Wheels, Out of Control
abstract: Summertime, and the interns are eager. Or difficult. Or clueless. Many companies hire summer interns, and with much success. But sometimes the work doesn't fit the interns' talents -- or overcome their desire to go to the beach. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.ob, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: For Long-Distance Discounts, More Numbers to Dial
abstract: Dial-around long-distance companies, largest of which is MCI Communications, are changing ad campaigns to accommodate government's new 7-digit dialing requirements; photo (M)

headline: Campbell Drops Special Meals
abstract: Campbell Soup Co drops its effort to market frozen foods to people with high blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes (S)

headline: Next-Door Neighbor Demands That World Powers Shun India
abstract: Pakistani leaders demand United States and other world powers act decisively to isolate India after its five nuclear tests; strongly hint that strength of international response will shape their decision on whether to detonate own nuclear bombs; Min Gohar Ayub Khan holds invoking of mandatory sanctions under US law is not effective response (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: FORD MOTOR CO., Dearborn, Mich., moved the head of its Ford division, Ross Roberts, to a new position directing the auto maker's efforts to restructure its dealer organization and reduce distribution costs. Jim O'Connor, 55, vice president of the company's Lincoln-Mercury division, will succeed Mr. Roberts, 60, as head of the Ford division. Mark Hutchins, 52, vice president for Latin American operations, will succeed Mr. O'Connor at Lincoln-Mercury.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Beneficial and Household Merging in $9 Billion Deal  Beneficial and Household International, which have competed with each other to provide consumer loans for most of this century, will merge in a stock swap valued at nearly $9 billion.    Though dwarfed by the Citicorp-Travelers merger announced a day earlier, the Beneficial-Household merger would be one of the biggest in the business of consumer finance. Shares of Household fell 4.1 percent on the merger announcement, while Beneficial shares rose 5.7 percent. [Page D2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Government Plans to Sell Shares in Uranium Business  The Government will try to privatize its uranium enrichment business by selling stock to the public, with proceeds expected to be $1.36 billion to $1.65 billion.     The entity to be sold, the United States Enrichment Corporation, operates aging factories in Piketon, Ohio, and Paducah, Ky., and had sales of $1.6 billion last year. It is also developing a laser-based enrichment system at laboratories of the Energy Department, of which it was once a part. [Page A1.]

headline: FPA MEDICAL MANAGEMENT SHARES LOSE HALF THEIR VALUE
abstract: Shares of FPA Medical Management Inc. lost nearly half their value yesterday after the company said it planned to take pretax charges of $200 million in the second quarter, ending on June 30. FPA Medical, based in San Diego, operates a network of 7,700 physicians that treat 1.2 million people nationwide under contracts with health maintenance organizations. In the quarter ended March 31, it lost $9.1 million on revenue of $392 million. Shares of FPA lost $5.50 to close at $6 on the Nasdaq stock market. The company said the charges included $125 million for good will impairment, a $40 million write-down of shared risk and other receivables, and $35 million for severance payments, office consolidation and other expenses.

headline: Information Highway Maps Speed Traps
abstract: Web site called WWW Speedtrap Registry lists regular speed patrols in every state, town by town; separate pages list foreign speed traps, updates on state laws and information about police radar; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup: Plaudits Aren't Universal
abstract: Diana B Henriques column on outlook for universal banking in United States in light of planned Citicorp merger with Travelers Group; notes banks abroad that offer 'universal' range of financial services have not been as profitable as US banks and have been plagued by some awesome frauds and blunders; graph (M)

headline: Cellular License Is Sold by Brazil
abstract: Group led by DDI Corp of Japan and Suzano de Papel e Celulose SA of Brazil buys license to offer mobile phone service in Brazil's southern states for at least $802 million (S)

headline: VICOR TO BUY 2 CONCERNS OWNED BY JAPAN TOBACCO
abstract: Vicor Corp to acquire two money-losing power suppply businesses owned by Japan Tobacco Inc (S)

headline: Intel Confirms Flaw in a Chip, and Delay
abstract: The Intel Corporation confirmed today that a bug would delay shipments of its 450NX chip set, which is to be used with its new Xeon microprocessor in high-powered servers.    Xeon will sell for $1,100 to $2,800, depending on the level of memory included with the chip. The Xeon is Intel's first entry into the area of high-performance computing, which has been dominated by chips like the Sun Microsystems Sparc, the Hewlett-Packard PA-RISC and the Silicon Graphics MIPS.

headline: CHIRON COMPLETES PURCHASE OF HOECHST VACCINE UNIT
abstract: Chiron Corp pays $115.5 million to acquire 51 percent stake in Chiron Behring GmbH & Co held by Hoechst AG of Germany (S)

headline: FAMILY RESTAURANTS TO ACQUIRE IACOCCA'S KOO KOO ROO
abstract: Koo Koo Roo Inc, chicken restaurant chain headed by Lee A Iacocca, to be bought by Family Restaurants Inc in stock swap valued at about $143 million (S)

headline: U.S. Is Planning A Move to Seize Pol Pot for Trial
abstract: Pres Clinton has ordered Departments of Defense, State and Justice to devise plans for arrest and trial of Pol Pot, Khmer Rouge leader responsible for death of perhaps a million Cambodians in 1970's; Administration officials and Western diplomats say that Khmer Rouge appears to be near collapse as result of mass defections and internal fighting; Pol Pot and other Khmer Rouge leaders are said to be in hiding in Cambodian jungle only few miles across border with Thailand; diplomats say Thai Government is willing to take Pol Pot into custody as long as US agrees to take him out of Thailand within hours of his capture; senior US military officers say that intelligence reports show that Thai military had actually taken Pol Pot into custody but then freed him (M)

headline: Rubin Defends I.M.F. Policies and Continues His Asian Tour
abstract: US Treas Sec Robert E Rubin, after whirlwind visit to Malaysia where he defended International Monetary Fund's harsh prescriptions for healing Asia's economies, arrives in Thailand; says he had good meeting with Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, who has been vituperative critic of West (M)

headline: India Cuts Key Rate In Move to Ease Lending
abstract: India's central bank cuts its key interest rate to 9 percent from 10 percent and eases other restrictions on lending to stimulate economy and reduce cost of financing India's growing fiscal deficit; central bank will also allow foreign institutional investors to trade treasury bills for first time (S)

headline: Just Keep Those Letters Coming
abstract: Article by novelist Benjamin Cheever on his initial enthusiasm for electronic mail, which was dampened by flood of commercial communications that he could not separate from personal messages; photo (M)

headline: Proxy Peace; Prosperity and Hushed Deals Quiet the Annual Meeting
abstract: Corporate annual meeting, once fraught with management tension and investor anger, has turned into something of love fest; credit for some of prevailing peacefulness goes to tremendous runup in stock prices, making shareholders more accepting of status quo; another factor is increasing power of pension funds and other big institutional investors; because they own much larger share of public companies, as opposed to individual holders, management is quicker to capitulate to their wishes; increasingly, shareholder complaints about investment issues are being heard behind scenes, and many disputes are resolved in what amounts to back-room deals, well out of earshot of other investors; so little of consequence is being decided at annual meetings that some well-known regulars no longer attend; photos; graph (M)

headline: Cohen Orders Inquiry Into U.S. Nerve Gas Charges
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen orders probe into charges United States Special Forces used nerve gas sarin against Laotian village believe to harbor American defectors during Vietnam War; stresses Defense Department has no evidence to substantiate charges, raised by Cable News Network and Time magazine (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Doses of Bad News Push Stock Market Down  Stocks dropped sharply, reversing two days of strong gains, on a selloff in drug and technology shares, a new whiff of weakness in Asia and ripple effects of a crash in Cendant stock after the leading franchiser disclosed possible accounting abuses.

headline: Fans Flock to Vinyl In the Era of CD's
abstract: Vinyl records are back in vogue; odd alliance of musicians, alternative rockers, rap fans, dance club disk jockeys, recording engineers and audiophiles have helped revive and strengthen format; sales of new vinyl have grown as more LP's have become available; photo (M)1

headline: NATIONWIDE FINANCIAL BUYING MORLEY FOR $32 MILLION
abstract: Nationwide Financial Services Inc agrees to buy Morley Financial Services Inc for $32.1 million (S)

headline: Managers Shuffled At Two Agencies
abstract: Two agencies have reorganized top management.    At Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of Havas Advertising, Gary Epstein, 37, managing partner and new business development director, was promoted to president. Mary Baglivo, 40, who was president, was named chief executive. Ms. Baglivo succeeds Ralph Rydholm, who stepped down in March and is now a consultant to the agency. Bob Welke continues as chairman and chief creative officer. Mr. Epstein will still oversee new business activities for the time being.

headline: For Long-Term AT&T Investors Stock Has Skyrocketed Since '84
abstract: AT&T Corp investors who have held their shares since 1984 breakup of American Telephone and Telegraph Co have earned returns of 1,128 percent; that gain includes values created by stock splits, reinvested dividends, spinoffs and mergers; shares that closed at $61.50 on Dec 30, 1983 are worth $755 today (M)

headline: Jolting Its Citizens, Indonesia Sharply Raises Energy Cost
abstract: Indonesia Govt announces plans to raise prices of fuel and electricity by 70 percent, hours before International Monetary Fund unanimously approved restoring financial aid; announcement, fulfilling commitments to IMF that Government has long resisted, leaves many Indonesians shocked; Government also announces plans to dismantle its vast monopoly in certain industries; areas; photo (M)

headline: Movie Before Clinton Visit Stars Jiang as a Statesman
abstract: Chinese Government documentary on Pres Jian Zemin's 1997 visit to US, called Across the Pacific, opens in Chinese theaters 10 days before state visit by Pres Clinton; portrays Jiang the way he wants to be seen, as jovial Renaissance man who is relaxed witty statesman of top rank, and the course of Chinese-American relations the way China wishes it to be, as on smooth track to partnership (M)

headline: Oxford Health Plans Posts A Deficit of $45.3 Million
abstract: Oxford Health Plans reports loss of $45.3 million on sales of $1.2 billion for first quarter of 1998; Oxford is preparing offering of high-yield bonds; chart (L)

headline: Tripping Over Translations
abstract: Scott Bennett letter on Apr 30 article on shortcomings of computer translations (S)

headline: Small Gannett Paper Won't Print Gay Weekly
abstract: Small daily newspaper in Georgia reverses its earlier decision to print largest gay newspaper in South after group of 47 ministers meets and encourages parishioners to cancel subscriptions and advertising; Chris Jensen, publisher of The Times in Gainesville, Ga, says he told publisher of The Southern Voice, 10-year-old gay newspaper with editorial offices in Atlanta, that scheduling press time had become too complicated; Times is owned by Gannett Co; photo of Chris Cain, publisher of Southern Voice (S)

headline: Choose Some 'Good Old Days' And See How They Really Were
abstract: Variety of World Wide Web sites enable users to review events of particular day or time period; photo (M)

headline: COVENTRY TO BUY COMMUNICARE P.E.O. INSTEAD OF KIWI
abstract: Coventry Industries Corp to acquire Communicare PEO for more than $50 million to expand its employee staffing services; Coventry also terminates its letter of intent to acquire Kiwi International Holdings Inc (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Canandaigua Wine Co., Canandaigua, N.Y., to Trone Advertising, Greensboro, N.C., to handle advertising and promotion for a new wine brand, Arbor Mist. Billings were estimated at more than $6.5 million for the first six months. Trone handles other Canandaigua brands like Mystic Cliffs wine, Paul Masson brandy and Cook's champagne.

headline: U.S. Bars Japanese Who Admits War Crime
abstract: Two years ago, when the Department of Justice created a list of suspected Japanese war criminals who would be prohibited from entering the United States, veterans and Asian-American groups were delighted. Finally, they said, people who had raped, butchered or experimented on civilians and prisoners during World War II would be treated like the ex-Nazis who faced similar prohibitions.    But this week, when American officials used that watch list for the first time to bar a Japanese man from entering the country, those same groups were enraged. The reason was simple: The man, Yoshio Shinozuka, was their guest.

headline: Paths of 2 Executives In a Proposed Merger
abstract: Article on SBC Communications' proposed $62 billion acquisition of Ameritech Corp focuses on SBC Communications chairman-chief executive Edward E Whitacre Jr and Ameritech chairman-chief executive Richard C Notebaert; says Whitacre will stay on as chairman and chief executive of combined company; Notebaert will retain his job and titles at Ameritech, but he is widely expected to leave after yet-to-be-determined transition (L)

headline: Five Countries Seize Islamic Terror Suspects
abstract: Police in France, Belgium, Italy, Germany and Switzerland raid homes of suspected Islamic militants in coordinated effort to bar terrorism by Armed Islamic Group of Algeria during World Cup soccer tournament in France; detain at least 88 people; French Min Jean-Pierre Chevenement says police have evidence of planned attacks (M)

headline: U.S. Welcomes Resignation But Is Cool to the Successor
abstract: US steps up calls for transition to democracy in Indonesia; welcomes Pres Suharto's resignation, but is cool to B J Habibie; senior officials express hope that Habibie's tenure will be short; Pres Clinton comments (S)

headline: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES TO BUY 25 JETS FROM EMBRAER
abstract: Continental Airlines Inc says it will buy at least 25 new 37-seat jets from Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA, also known as Embraer, for $315 million, making Continental largest customer of Brazilian company's regional jets; Continental takes option to buy additional 50 aircraft (S)

headline: Living With the Palestinian 'Catastrophe'
abstract: Ethan Bronner article in series Israel at 50 focuses on plight of Ibrahim Shikaki, 70-year-old scion of respected Arab family who is eking out living as day laborer in Jewish state; maintains that in many ways his story and that of his eight children is that of Palestinian people, saga of humiliation and fury but also one of emerging accommodation and rebirth; notes that one of his sons Fathi Shikaki, who was assassinated in 1995, founded militant anti-Israel movement Islamic Holy War; says another son, Abdul-Aziz, is part of consortium of pharmacists and doctors who are establishing first pharmaceutical factory in Gaza Strip; map; photo (M)

headline: Strong Dollar and Woes Abroad Drop Long Bond Yield to 5.82%
abstract: US Treasury securities rise; benchmark 30-year bond rises 11/32, to price of 104 9/32; yield drops to 5.82 percent from 5.84 percent, lowest since April 6; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Compaq Discloses Management Team
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp discloses management team that will lead company after its $9 billion acquisition of Digital Equipment Corp; says Digital's chairman and chief executive Robert B Palmer will leave at end of July; John J Rando, head of Digital's service business, will become senior vice president and will still oversee services; Enrico Pesatori, who had been number 2 at Digital before he was ousted in 1996, is promoted to senior vice president of worldwide marketing at Compaq; Bruce L Claflin, who was Digital's senior vice president of worldwide sales and marketing, will leave company; William D Strecker of Digital will replace Compaq's Bob Stearns as head of technology and corporate development; Thomas C Siekman, Digital's corporate counsel, will assume that position in combined company (S)

headline: David Hicks, 69, Interior Design Star of the 60's, Is Dead
abstract: David Hicks, interior design star of 1960's, dies at age 69; photo (L)

headline: Kazakhs Raise Curtain on Remote New Capital, but Many Ask Why
abstract: ASTANA, Kazakhstan—  Free hands were hard to find in Kazakhstan's new capital on Wednesday, in the hours before it was officially offered to the nation by President Nursultan Nazarbayev.

headline: Too Many Hats
abstract: Charles F Mansfield Jr letter discusses March 1 article on Vernon Jordan (S)

headline: Netherlands Investment Group Seeks Weiss, Peck & Greer
abstract: Robeco Group, a Netherlands investment group, is buying Weiss, Peck & Greer LLC for about $400 million; it will also make further payments of up to $200 million over next five years depending on future profits of Weiss, Peck (M)

headline: Lucent Value Tops Ex-Parent AT&T's
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc surpasses its former parent, AT&T Corp, in market value; Lucent's market capitalization climbs to $98.52 billion, thanks to increase of $1.8125 in its shares, to $74.1875; Lucent has surged more than fivefold since the initial public offering, while AT&T shares have climbed 36 percent in the same period (S)

headline: CORNERSTONE TO BUY OWNER OF BUILDINGS IN WEST
abstract: Real estate investment trust Cornerstone Properties Inc agrees to acquire William Wilson & Associates for $990 million in cash and stock; it will also assume debt of about $780 million (S)

headline: Jewish Groups Go to Capitol Squabbling Among Themselves
abstract: Letters signed by 81 senators and 150 House members urging Pres Clinton to confront Israel publicly with American proposal to break deadlocked peace talks with Palestinians leads to squabbling between conservative American Israel Public Affairs Committee and more liberal Conference of Mayors of Major Jewish Organizations over Clinton Administration's attempt to revive troubled peace effort; both groups send letters praising Pres Clinton and urge him to continue difficult work of peacemaking (M)

headline: COMPUTER NETWORK MAKER PLANS COST-CUTTING MOVES
abstract: Shiva Corp, maker of remote-access computer networks in Bedford, Mass, will cut 125 jobs and close its plant in Scotland in effort to save $10 million to $15 million a year; company will move Edinburgh plant's technical support staff to Wokingham, England (S)

headline: A New President Is Named at Wells Fargo
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co names Rod Jacobs, who is currently its chief financial officer, as president, filling post vacated by departure last year of William Zuendt; Ross Kari, executive vice president, will replace Jacobs as chief financial officer (S)

headline: Broadcast and Cable Interests Debate Rules for Digital TV
abstract: Presidents of largest companies in television industry spar at Congressional hearing over question of whether cable television companies will be required to carry digital television programs that broadcasters will begin putting on air this fall; cable executives contend 'must carry' rule would force them to push popular cable programs off their systems to make room for new digital shows at time when few people have expensive digital sets; broadcasters respond that two-thirds of nation's homes subscribe to cable and transition to digital television will fail unless cable transmits new digital signals, particularly high-definition signals, to these customers (M)

headline: PREMIERE TECHNOLOGIES BUYS TELECONFERENCE BUSINESS
abstract: Premiere Technologies Inc says it acquired American Teleconferencing Services Ltd for $30 million in cash and $22 million in stock (S)

headline: Suharto Finds Friends Are Few Now That He's Just an Ex-V.I.P.
abstract: Former Indonesian Pres Suharto marks 77th birthday in isolation and disrepute, Jakarta; former accolytes shun him as autocratic political system he created disintegrates and his financial empire begins to crumble (M)

headline: An Even Smaller Phone With Even More Stuff
abstract: Ericsson AB, Swedish-based telephone company, to introduce in United States later this year its smallest mobile telephone, which includes such things as voice mail and caller ID device; phone is 4 inches tall and weighs 4.7 ounces; photo (S)

headline: 2 Speedster Chips Joining a Clunker
abstract: Intel Corp unveils several new Pentium II microprocessors; two of them are rated at 350 MHz and 400 MHz and will most likely be used initially in server computers; another is known as Celeron, lacks a performance-enhancing feature of regular Pentium chips and is intended for computers costing less than $1,000 (S)

headline: MIDLAND, A CANADIAN BROKER, IS NEARING TAKEOVER
abstract: The stock of Midland Walwyn Inc. rose yesterday for a fourth day on renewed speculation that the concern, Canada's last major independent brokerage firm, is close to accepting a takeover offer. Midland's stock rose $1.25 (Canadian), to $27.25, in Toronto trading. The stock has risen 19 percent in the last four days, giving the company a market value of about $1 billion (Canadian). Analysts said Merrill Lynch was the most likely buyer for Midland, which has 170 branches and 1,800 employees.

headline: Cleaning Up Municipal Markets
abstract: Analysis of $400 million settlement between Merrill Lynch & Co Inc and Orange County, Calif; says settlement is another significant milestone in efforts, now years in the making, to clean up questionable practices in $1.3 trillion municipal finance market; cites remedial actions taken in this area (M)

headline: When E-Mail Words Pall, A Program Can Add Pizazz
abstract: Novita Communications offers software that can make electronic mail multimedia; program lets users add range of colors and fonts to E-mail, along with recorded voice clips, animated images, personal photographs and even playable games (S)

headline: Risky Business; A Set Fee for Each Patient Gives Doctors More Control and More of a Financial Stake
abstract: Many doctors and hospitals in New York City and number of other big cities are embracing form of managed care known as capitation, in which they get lump sum per enrollee; capitation gives care providers more control and carries more financial risk; gives doctors financial stake in holding down costs; new Government-financed study finds patients covered under such plans are less satisfied with care than people in health maintenance organizations whose doctors are paid for each service; table; graph; photo (M)

headline: But You Said 'Casual'
abstract: New York Times is looking for stories on who wears what on casual day in the office; photo (S)

headline: Senate Rejects Bid to Create a NATO Unit to Resolve Conflicts
abstract: Senate rejects attempt to create tribunal within NATO to help resolve conflicts that might affect alliance before they erupt into full-blown hostilities; votes 62 to 37 to reject proposed amendment to plan to add Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic to military alliance (M)

headline: FONOROLA BOARD RECOMMENDS REJECTION OF CALL-NET BID
abstract: Fonorola Inc advises shareholders to reject Call-Net Enterprises' offer to buy company at $41 (US) a share, for total of $1.1 billion; Fonorola board says offer does not reflect value of company (S)

headline: Astra to Buy Out Merck in Venture
abstract: Astra AB announces that it will buy Merck & Co's half of their American joint venture; parting of two companies will take at least 10 years (S)

headline: Internet Phone Calls, No Computer Necessary
abstract: Telecommunications industry is being shaken by companies that offer phone-to-phone long-distance service over the Internet without a computer and with sound quality that is close to that offered by standard telephone; 'telephony' calls are cheaper partly because their transmission is broken up into bits, which diminishes sound quality, but primary because until now Internet carriers have not had to pay the fees mandated by national and international regulation; FCC has taken first step to level playing field, but Internet's regulatory advantage remains strong for international calls because Internet companies are often able to avoid or reduce settlement rates that some countries levy against calls to or from other nations (M)

headline: COINMACH LAUNDRY PLANS TO ACQUIRE GORDON & THOMAS
abstract: Coinmach Laundry Corp agrees to buy Gordon & Thomas Companies for about $58 million in cash plus assumption of $2 million in liabilities (S)

headline: FOUNDATION HEALTH TO SELL UNIT FOR $290 MILLION
abstract: Foundation Health Systems Inc sells it workers' compensation unit to Superior National Insurance Group Inc, a unit of Superior National Corp, for about $290 million in cash (S)

headline: Critics Assail PBS Over Plan For Toys Aimed at Toddlers
abstract: Children's advocates criticize merchandising schemes for Teletubbies, four popular British puppets that have become part of Public Broadcasting System's programming aimed at toddlers; child advocates fear this could nurture consumer mentality in children not yet able to speak properly; critics worry that programmers are being influenced by how much money PBS can make from toys and other products tied to program; with public television's chronic financial need, such windfalls could be tempting enough to sway judgments about program's suitability--notion that PBS rejects; photo (M)

headline: Feuds Rack Albania, Loosed From Communism
abstract: Blood feuds, which follow precepts laid down in medieval canon, is again part of Albanian society in which it lay superficially submerged during 50 years of Communist rule; since early 1990's revenge killings have spread among clans in village of Old Tropoje; weapons have become valued as much as human life, such that man who kills another and takes his weapon can be avenged with taking of two lives; map; photo (M)

headline: MCI to Sell Wholesale Internet Unit to Cable and Wireless
abstract: MCI Communications Corp agrees to sell its wholesale Internet business to Cable and Wireless PLC for $625 million in cash; sale is widely perceived as attempt to placate antitrust regulators who are reviewing planned $37 billion acquisition of MCI by Worldcom Inc; it is also reflection of just how testy relations between MCI and Justice Department have become (M)

headline: ING Says Profit Rises 86.5% in Quarter
abstract: ING Groep NV says profit rose 86.5 percent in first quarter, to 1.94 billion Dutch guilders ($966 million) from adjusted 1.04 billion in period a year earlier (S)

headline: Samsung Curbing Output of Chips to Cut Back Inventories
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co of South Korea, one of largest semiconductor manufacturers, says it will suspend all production of memory chips and much of production of nonmemory chips for a week to reduce inventory and strengthen prices; cuts could hurt South Korea because semiconductors are one of country's largest exports and one of biggest sources of badly needed hard currency (S)

headline: The threat of a strike by actors remains despite a tentative labor agreement.
abstract: Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers reaches tentative contract agreement with Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Radio and Television Artists, but situation remains delicate and volatile; agreement, which is subject to approval by a board representing both groups and their members, calls for joint study on key issue of foreign and cable television 'residuals,' the share of revenues that actors earn when their films are shown abroad or on cable (M)

headline: Blunt Ex-General Wins Siberia Governorship
abstract: Aleksandr I Lebed, former aide to Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin who was dismissed reportedly because of political ambitions, wins sweeping victory in runoff gubernatorial election in Siberian region of Krasnoyarsk, assuring himself foothold in Russian presidential race in 2000; victory returns him to national limelight, most specifically with seat on Federation Council or Upper House of Parliament (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.53   5.42        3-month T-bills   4.98   5.01   5.05        6-month T-bills   5.15   5.17   5.31        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.75   3.58        10-yr. T-note   5.71   5.76   6.71        30-yr. T-bond   5.97   6.03   6.92        Telephone bd.   7.16   7.19   8.03        Municipal bds.   5.33   5.36   5.82          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: MATTEL AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF AMERICAN GIRL DOLLS
abstract: Mattel Inc to acquire Pleasant Co, maker of American Girl line of dolls, for $700 million (S)

headline: MOSCOW ATTEMPTS DRASTIC MEASURES TO SAVE ECONOMY
abstract: Russia mounts drastic effort to preserve value of its currency and stem exodus of foreign investors as its financial markets teeter on brink of collapse; officials triple interest rates, announce that they will be willing to accept lower price for selloff of Russia's last big oil company, Rosneft, and appeal for support from International Monetary Fund; Moscow's financial markets have been under siege as fears have mounted among investors and US officials that economic turmoil in Asia will spread to Russia; Moscow stock market is world's worst performing market, off more than 50 percent this year; swoon in market has turned into profound political crisis and has become major worry for US policymakers who have thrown their support behind Pres Boris N Yeltsin's Government; graph shows plunge in Russian stock market and rise in interest rates (M)

headline: An Imperfect Market, But Beware the 'Cure'
abstract: Economist John T Bennett letter disputes Joseph E Stiglitz's May 31 article on government intervention in failing companies (S)

headline: Ford Has 15% Gain in Profits for Quarter
abstract: Ford Motor Co reports 15.1 percent gain in first-quarter operating profits; profit was $1.69 billion, up from $1.47 billion in year-earlier period; revenue fell 2 percent, to $36.58 billion; chart (L)

headline: Even Pessimists Erred on Cendant
abstract: Anyone holding short positions on Cendant Corp shares would have profited greatly when stock plunged 46 percent in single day; but short position represented only 4 percent of outstanding shares, even smaller than that of month earlier; it seems shorts were caught just as flat-footed by Cendant's troubles as other stockholders (M)

headline: Sunbeam's Board, in Revolt, Ousts Job-Cutting Chairman
abstract: Sunbeam Corp dismisses chairman, Albert J Dunlap, who earned nickname Chain Saw Al for wholesale sacking of factory workers and managers alike, both at Sunbeam and elsewhere; board of directors says it no longer believes he has skills to revive ailing consumer appliance maker, which lost $44.6 million during first-quarter 1998 and will post worse-than-expected results for rest of 1998; he will be replaced by a director, Peter A Langerman; is owed severance package of salary, stock, and options that could be worth more than $35 million; photos; graph (M)

headline: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
abstract: Letter from Joanne Tobey on April 2 article on declining use of Apple computers says she loves her Mac (S)

headline: Fruit, Cars and Now Funds: How a Portfolio Joins a Lemon List
abstract: Many formulas offer advice to investors about how to assess performance of their mutual funds, but simple formulas rarely provide fodder necessary for complicated investment decisions; biggest problem with almost every rating system is reliance on historical information; in today's fast-changing global markets, it is precisely because fund has underperformed recently that it might well outperform going forward (M)

headline: Credit Lyonnais Bailout Is Given Approval
abstract: European Commission clears 125-billion-franc ($21 billion) bailout of Credit Lyonnais SA after France agrees to sell state-controlled bank next year and shed a fifth of its assets before then (S)

headline: Heavy Buying in Blue Chips Sends Dow Up 66.76 Points
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 66.76 points, or about eight-tenths of a percent, to close at 8,870.56; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 1.1 percent, to close at 1,094.83 and Nasdaq composite soars 1.6 percent, to 1,769.95; graph; chart (M)

headline: Japan Waits As 2 Banks Weigh Merger
abstract: Long-Term Credit Bank, one of Japan's biggest and weakest banks, discusses merger with smaller, stronger rival, Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co, move that could ease concerns that troubles at Long-Term could spread and endanger Japan's financial stability; Liberal Democratic Party secretary general, Koichi Kato, hails talks; denies party leaders helped broker deal, which would give Government chance to put into practice its blueprint for tackling $600 billion in bad debt held by banks; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto orders detailed plan for establishment of bridge bank to assume loans and clients of failed institution (M)

headline: Oxford Health Is Trying to Sell Bonds
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc seeks to sell $200 million in high-yield bnds in private placement as part of $700 million financing package (S)

headline: This Year in Argentina, Two Brothers Build an Empire; Outsiders, They Bet on Future of a Global Breadbasket
abstract: Alejandro Elsztain and his brother, Eduardo, are quietly building Latin America's newest real estate empire; doubled their rural land holdings to 1.1 million acres in last year--a vault that suddenly made their farm company, Cresud, Agrentina's largest landowner and biggest producer of beef and grain; their separate real estate company, IRSA, headed by Eduardo Elsztain, is remaking skyline of Buenos Aires and pushing city's development south and west; graphs; photos (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Workers at a Second Plant Go On Strike Against G.M.  Nearly 6,000 members of the United Automobile Workers union went on strike last night at a General Motors spark plug and speedometer factory in Flint, Mich., joining strikers at a nearby G.M. plant in a bitter fight that could close all of the company's North American assembly plants within days.

headline: People
abstract: Daniel J Osheyack, associate publisher at Entertainment Weekly, is named associate publisher for marketing at People magazine; he succeeds Vanessa Reed, who left to take similar position at Glamour magazine; Madeleine Miller is named to new position of senior partner and worldwide account planning director at J Walter Thompson; Lori Isola is named to new position of senior partner and group broadcast director (S)

headline: United Health To Acquire Humana Inc.
abstract: United Healthcare Corp, one of nation's largest health insurers, agrees to acquire Humana Inc for $5.5 billion, further shrinking number of competitors in industry and narrowing choices of managed-care plans for consumers; chart (M)

headline: Gojko Susak, Defense Minister of Croatia, Is Dead at 53
abstract: Gojko Susak, Croatia's Defense Minister, dies at age 53 from lung cancer; photo (M)

headline: CABLE MICHIGAN AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY AVALON CABLE
abstract: Avalon Cable of New England to acquire Cable Michigan Inc for $435 million (S)

headline: EXERCISE FINDS U.S. UNABLE TO HANDLE GERM WAR THREAT
abstract: Forty officials from over dozen Federal agencies in March participated in secret exercise near White House to determine what would happen if terrorists attacked US with devastating new type of germ weapon; exercise, known as table top, is civilian version of military war game; under scenario, terrorists spread virus along Mexico-US border, primarily in California and southwest; results were not encouraging; officials were quickly overwhelmed by panicked population, and began quarreling among themselves and with Washington over how to stem epidemic; outcome of exercise illustrates that US is still unprepared to respond to biological terror weapons; Pres Clinton is expected to approve plan that would enhance country's ability to deter and limit damage from such attack; photo (M)

headline: 2 BELL COMPANIES ARE SET TO REJOIN IN $60 BILLION DEAL
abstract: SBC Communications Inc, dominant local telephone company across Western US, will reportedly acquire Ameritech Corp for approximately $60 billion, recreating much of old Bell system; merged entity will become by far biggest local telephone company in US, exceeding Bell Atlantic; SBC will reportedly pay 25 percent premium over Ameritech's closing stock price of $43.875 on New York Stock Exchange on May 8, with Ameritech stockholders receiving $55.76 per share; SBC'c acquisition of Pacific Telesis in 1997 and planned acquisition of Southern New England Communications, former Baby Bells, noted; diagrams (M)

headline: Power to Fascinate Intact, Turin Shroud Is Unfurled
abstract: Shroud of Turin is put on public display on April 18 for first time in 20 years; over three million pilgrims and tourists are expected to travel to Turin, Italy, to see shroud, which will be on view in Turin Cathedral until mid-June; decades of scientific testing and historical scholarship have not resolved debate about whether it is burial cloth of Jesus; relic's remarkable history is chronicled and debated on over 30 Shroud of Turin websites, including webpage of Turin Fire Dept, which proudly recounts how firefighter, Mario Trematore, managed to rescue shroud during accidental fire on April 11, 1997 that destroyed much of chapel built to house it; photos (M)

headline: The New Salomon: A Smaller Fish in a Bigger Pond
abstract: Salomon Brothers will soon be relatively small brand within huge monolith as result of two breathtaking mergers; first, Salomon merged with Travelers Group's Smith Barney brokerage firm to become Salomon Smith Barney; now Travelers will merge with Citicorp; some Salomon veterans lament firm's immersion into ever-bigger financial companies (M)

headline: BEHIND THE BATTLE FOR RUSSIAN POST, ECONOMIC CONTROL
abstract: Internal battle over future of Russian Government bursts into open as fight for control of economic policy between small group of big business owners who have amassed huge fortunes and Government economic reformers; newspaper owned by Boris Berezovsky, Russia's richest and most ruthless tycoon, announces that pitched battle over Pres Boris Yeltsin's nomination of Sergei N Kiriyenko as Prime Minister can only be avoided if Yeltsin abandons market reformers trying to better regulate sale of state property; Berezovsky is believed to be acting with other leading tycoons and has forged key alliances; ex-Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin echoes his call that reformer Anatoly B Chubais be denied post as head of electrical power monopoly; photos (M)

headline: U.S. BUSINESS ROLE IN POLICY ON CHINA IS UNDER QUESTION
abstract: Clinton Administration handling of satellite technology exports to China by key Clinton supporters illustrates competing forces that buffet President on China policy; classified Pentagon report in May 1997 concluded that scientists from Hughes Electronics and Loral Space and Communications had turned over expertise that significantly improved reliability of China's nuclear missiles, even though companies were ordered to keep tight rein on such sophisticated technology sought by Chinese military; criminal probe of companies was reportedly undermined when Clinton approved Loral's exports to China; White House denied any political interference in issue, but Chinese reportedly concluded that Administration policy on issues like spread of weapons and human rights abuses could be reversed by corporations; Loral is headed by largest personal donor to Democratic Party last year; Administration's China policy has come under intense Congressional scrutiny in last year; at issue is influence American contributors have on China policy (M)

headline: MORRISON RESTAURANTS IN TALKS ON POSSIBLE SALE
abstract: Morrison Restaurants Inc holds talks with several undisclosed companies about its possible sale; posts loss of $90,000 in fiscal third quarter ending Feb 28, compared with year-earlier profit of $701 million (S)

headline: Russia Takes Steps To Assure Investors Economy Will Hold
abstract: Russia tries to assure anxious investors that it will not follow path of Indonesia and faltering Asian economies; Pres Boris Yeltsin summons leading bankers and industrialists to unusual Kremlin meeting on ways to end financial crisis, while new Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, tells foreign investors that Government will not allow downturn in Asia to infect economy; assurances come amid questions over whether Government can maintain stability of ruble and avoid panic among investors and ordinary Russians; follow series of economic blows, including decline in oil prices, tough talks with International Monetary Fund and labor unrest, all of which have landed while Kiriyenko has been trying to assemble Government; graph; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buffett May Face Scrutiny From Institutional Holders  The acquisition of General Re by Berkshire Hathaway, which was announced late Friday, means Wall Street professionals will become holders of 15 percent of the shares of Berkshire Hathaway, Warren E. Buffett's far-flung corporate empire.    For years, Mr. Buffett has enjoyed a luxury unknown to most other corporate chiefs -- he has answered almost exclusively to individual investors. But now the professionals who manage portfolios for mutual funds, college endowments and big corporations will be asking questions. Market Place. [Page D6.]

headline: NEWS WATCH; In a Boston Museum, Fish Don't Need Any Water to Swim
abstract: Computer Museum, Boston, will open giant virtual aquarium that let visitors create and program their own fish and then watch them interact; exhibit, developed with Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Nearlife and financed by National Science Foundation, Sun Microsystems and others, will show how patterns arise through simple interactions and rules; drawing (S)

headline: Investors Cheer as Philips Considers Sale of Polygram
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV says it might sell its 75 percent stake in Polygram NV, music company; possibility that Polygram might be on market prompts hopes among Polygram investors that Seagram Co would drop its interest in rival EMI Group PLC and become more interested in buying Polygram; Seagram has reportedly had serious talks Polygram; it is unclear what other companies might bid for Polygram (M)

headline: On-Line Advertising Spending Triples
abstract: Internet Advertising Bureau of New York reports spending for on-line advertising more than tripled last year compared with 1996; marketers spent $906.5 million in 1997 compared with $266.9 million in 1996 (S)

headline: Fed Chief Calls the Economy One of the Best He Has Seen
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan tells Joint Economic Committee of Congress that economy is in extraordinarily good shape and that he sees no immediate need to strike against inflation by raising interest rates; says combination of low unemployment and strong growth could eventually force central bank to raise rates; says price presssures are subdued and Asia's financial crisis is already working to take some of steam out of US economy; Greenspan photo (M)

headline: Argentina Says Israel Can Have Croat Who Headed Camp
abstract: Pres Carlos Saul Menem says that, if asked, Argentina would extradite to Israel, Dinko Sakic, elderly Croatian man who headed camp where tens of thousands of Jews, Serbs and Gypsies were killed in World War II; photos (M)

headline: Talks Seen on Sale of a Texas Instruments Business
abstract: Texas Instruments is reported in talks to sell memory-chip operations to Micron Technology (S)

headline: Killing of Arab in Jerusalem Is Called Revenge
abstract: Israeli police say fatal stabbing of Palestinian man on his way to work in Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Jerusalem was apparently act of revenge for recent fatal stabbing of Jewish student (M)

headline: NATIONWIDE MUTUAL REACHES $1.7 BILLION DEAL FOR ALLIED
abstract: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Co agrees to buy Allied Group Inc and its affiliates for $1.7 billion (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Confederate Motorcycles Inc to Needleman Pilla Advertising, as first ad agency to handle its account; billings estimated at $3 million; Nike Inc to Good Fast Creative, to handle retail display advertising; Guinness Bass Import Co to Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano, to introduce Caffrey's Irish Ale in US; billings undisclosed; Nobody Beats the Wiz to Lord Group, to handle its account, which had been handled by Bozell Retail; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: 2 Associations To Join Operations
abstract: Internet Advertising Bureau and Internet Local Advertising and Commerce Association will combine operations under bureau name; bureau will also form Local Advertising Committee to be headed by Jim D'Arcangelo; bureau releases figures for Internet ad revenue, showing that revenue in first quarter of 1998 totaled $351.3 million, up more than twofold from $129.5 million in corresponding period of 1997; bureau presents first annual Marketer of the Year Award, which goes to Intel Corp (S)

headline: CVS to Split Stock, 2 for 1
abstract: CVS Corp says it will split its shares 2 for 1 and increase its dividend (S)

headline: Windows 98? Microsoft Set To Start Sales On June 25
abstract: Microsoft Corp will begin selling long-awaited version of its Windows 98 operating system on June 25 (S)

headline: Scouting a Path For Home Networks
abstract: Michelle Slatalla article on how households with multiple computers can create a home network; notes predictions that demand for home networks could spawn a $1 billion market within five years; drawing (M)

headline: Pieces of Advice for Japan
abstract: Article, turning table on 1980s advice from Japan on how to improve America, offers tongue-in-cheek suggestions for reviving Japan's economy; drawings (L)

headline: Avoiding That Sinking Feeling
abstract: Investing in stocks of companies that can raise their prices to consumers discussed as defensive strategy in face of shrinking corporate profits; graph of drop in manufacturers' pricing power (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Will Japan try to inflate its way out of its economic morass?
abstract: Economic Scene column on prospects of Japan 'inflating' its way out of economic recession and declining yen; says inflating its economy might backfire for its ailing Asian trade partners; drawing (M)

headline: People
abstract: Siboney USA names Max Lefeld to new post of creative director; Neal Vitale resigns as Petersen Cos president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: Memo From Belfast; Gerry Adams Blunders, and Peace Drive Stumbles
abstract: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams has stirred Protestant fears in advance of vote on Northern Ireland peace plan with appearance at party convention, Dublin, of Irish Republican Army guerrillas freed from prison to attend event; accord supporters struggle to overcome damage; gaffe underscores tensions in fragile coalition backing accord; Adam concedes error, interview; British and Irish officials privately say they erred by allowing temporary release of seven prominent IRA prisoners; photo (M)

headline: Jiggling Livers, and Advertising, in a Lively Screen Saver
abstract: Road Island Soft Systems, Woonsocket, RI, to offer new series of free screen savers that can be downloaded from www.risoftsystem s.com/liverdance.asp; saver features spoof of Irish stepdancer Michael Flately and his internationally acclaimed Lord of the Dance performance; photo of screen saver image (S)

headline: Business Travel: Road Warriors Losing Options; Corporate Ire Rises Along With Business Air Fares
abstract: Corporate America has grown increasingly irritated by steadily rising business air fares, especially to smaller cities; in response, companies are giving more of their employees less choice and flexibility in making travel arrangements; many companies dictate not only what airlines employees can fly on but also what hotels and rental car companies they must use; and video conferences are more often pushed as alternative to a trip; many companies are negotiating special deals at prearranged rates; graph; photo (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: As the Chinese See It, Taiwan Remains Most Important Issue
abstract: From China's point of view the most explosive issue in its relationship with the United States is Taiwan. Chinese officials consistently argue that the level of American arms sales to the island violates Washington's pledge to reduce and, ultimately, phase out such sales.    To press its point, Beijing contends that its help to Pakistan and Iran's military and missile programs, which Washington is trying to limit, is comparable to Washington's military assistance to Taiwan. In negotiations, Beijing has suggested trading off its missile cooperation in the Middle East for American commitments to cut arms sales sharply to Taiwan,  a possibility criticized by American Republicans like the former American Ambassador to China and representative to Taiwan, James R. Lilley.

headline: Life Insurance Loses Ground As Investment Options Grow
abstract: Millions of Americans are starting to either do without life insurance or buy less; they have been pouring money into investments like mutual funds and variable annuities, which they hope will take them comfortably through their golden years; shift in attitudes, which has been building gradually for years, has sent life insurance sales into something of free fall and radically changed how insurance companies do business; many young people have also gotten caught up in what financial specialists call 'wealth accumulation,' pumping spare money into 401(k) and other retirement plans; Americans bought 17.7 million new life insurance policies 15 years ago; they bought 11.1 million last year, 37 percent drop; graph (M)

headline: The Mix-It, Match-It Theory of Management
abstract: Item suggests combination of buzzwords or buzz-phrases that could be used as title for management self-help book; photo (M)

headline: New York Fails to Capture Lead : London Still Reigns As King of Art World
abstract: LONDON—  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED APRIL 21, 1998

headline: Deeper Asia Slump Hurts U.S. Exporters
abstract: Asia's financial crisis is hurting the American economy more than expected, new trade statistics released by the Government show.

headline: OLSTEN EXPECTING A LOSS ON HOME-HEALTH BUSINESS
abstract: Olsten Corp expects to close 60 offices and report $34 million second-quarter loss because of charges for cutting back its home-health business (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Issues Extend Selloff, Weakening Market  The stock market fell yesterday for the fourth time this week, hurt by drops in Dell and other technology shares on further worries about the impact of Asian economic problems. Losses among drug stocks also led the market down.

headline: Holocaust Exhibits Now Accessible to a Larger Audience
abstract: Officials of Simon Wiesenthal Center's Museum of Tolerance say they hope to make their collection of Jewish Holocaust documents, photographs and artifacts available to people on Internet; style and content of site are based on museum's Multimedia Learning Center; photo (M)

headline: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
abstract: Letter from Bill Wagstaff on April 2 article on declining use of Apple computers says his Mac is wonderful (S)

headline: BELCO TO GET 80% STAKE IN CANADIAN ENERGY COMPANY
abstract: Belco Oil and Gas Corp says it agreed to acquire 80 percent interest in Big Bear Exploration Ltd for $141 million (S)

headline: Diplomacy Buffs Image Of Cardinal In Austria
abstract: Christoph Cardinal Schonborn, 53, theologically conservative leader of deeply divided Roman Catholic Church in Austria, is being cited as possible successor to Pope John Paul II; Pope's visit to Austria is giving his entourage and Vatican press corps closer look at Schonborn, who has handled deep scandal with deft diplomacy, acknowledging and apologizing for sexual misdeeds of predecessor, Hans Hermann Cardinal Groer; photo (M)

headline: CARNIVAL IN $500 MILLION DEAL TO BUY CUNARD
abstract: Carnival Corp says it and group of investors will buy Cunard cruise ship line from Norwegian shipbuilder Kvaerner ASA for $500 million, creating world's largest luxury cruise line; Carnival will merge Cunard with Seabourn Cruise Line, which it owns in partnership with Atle Brynestad, a Norwegian businessman; Carnival will have two-thirds interest in combined company; Cunard ships include Queen Elizabeth 2 and Sea Goddess I and II (S)

headline: Gates Describes the Road Ahead as Noisy
abstract: Microsoft chairman Bill Gates adresses annual Windows Hardware Engineering Conference, extolling Microsoft's plans for a consumer version of its Windows NT operating system; also predicts that voice, rather than mouse or keyboard, will eventually become the primary user interface for computers (S)

headline: Sovereign Vatican Can Investigate Its Own Crime
abstract: Article notes Vatican is sovereign city-state that has right to prosecute any crimes, including homicide, that occur within its 108.7-acre borders (M)

headline: Samsung to Cut Output At Korean Chip Plants
abstract: Samsung Electronics Co, world's largest memory-chip manufacturer, says its Korean plants will probably shut down for a week in July in addition to week already set for June; cut in production is intended to increase price of company's mainstay 16-megabit dynamic random access memory chips (S)0

headline: State Department Warns of 'Critical Levels' of Crime in Mexico
abstract: US State Department toughens its advice for Americans traveling to Mexico, responding to surge in violent crimes against tourists in Mexico and mounting complaints from Americans that they were not adequately warned by their Govt about dangers; revised Consular Information Sheet says for first time that crime rate in Mexico City 'has reached critical levels'; it warns of 'marked increase in the level of the violence of the crimes committed, including what appears to be a significant incidence of sexual assaults in crimes committed against women'; some recent crimes against visitors to Mexico noted (M)

headline: Dow Chemical's Profit Falls 10%
abstract: Dow Chemical Co says first-quarter profit fell 10 percent before gains and charges, to $405 million, from year earlier; says revenue fell 3.3 percent, to $4.83 billion (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: U.S. ECONOMY  Whoa, Big Fella!  Two economic indicators released early last week suggested that the economy was throttling back from the heated pace it reached earlier this year. Sales of previously owned homes fell in April, while consumer confidence edged lower this month. Existing-home sales in the United States declined 2.5 percent last month, to an annual rate of 4.77 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. And the Conference Board said its measure of consumer confidence declined to 135.2 in May, from 137.2 a month ago. A few days later, however, the Commerce Department reported that the economy in the first quarter was even stronger than initially reported. The gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 4.8 percent, up from the earlier estimate of 4.2 percent. Not to be outdone by upbeat assessments, President Clinton said he now expected the budget surplus for 1998 to hit $39 billion.

headline: A Small Card Maker Finds Itself Atop the Web
abstract: Web site run by Blue Mountain Arts, greeting card company, is among most visited sites on World Wide Web; enables users to send electronic personalized greeting cards; other greeting card Web sites discussed; photo (M)

headline: The Eagle Hasn't Lost Its Wings
abstract: Gold's prolonged depression has created boom in gold coins, as investors worry about how much higher stock market can go; rather than viewing gold as anachronistic hedge against inflation, many see it as bargain; part of appeal of gold bullion coins is their size and relative affordability; unlike gold bricks or bars, they are easily stored, can be mailed to one's home and have commonly recognized value; photo (M)

headline: PRIMUS TELECOMMUNICATIONS INCREASES TRESCOM BID
abstract: Primus Telecommunications Group Inc raises its bid for Trescom International Inc to $155 million from $122 million; Primus, in exchange for higher bid, will get stock options from Warburg Pincus Investors LP and certain Trescom officers allowing it to buy more than 50 percent of Trescom if merger is not completed (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, a bank holding company, said its shareholders had approved a 2-for-1 split of its common stock. The new shares will be payable June 12 to shareholders of record as of today.    ORION CAPITAL CORP., Farmington, Conn., a provider of specialty property and casualty insurance, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire United Grocers Inc.'s Grocers Insurance Group unit for $36.25 million in cash.

headline: Opportunity Now Comes With Numbers Included
