abstract: Syntroleum's planned merger with SLH Corp will provide investors with numbers needed to evaluate developer of technology to convert natural gas into liquid products (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Recent survey by NPD Group of 15,000 on-line users in the United States finds 51 percent of them are expected to curb their on-line searches for period of time tonight in order to watch the on-air series finale of Seinfeld television series (S)

headline: Ex-Argentine Junta Leader Held in 70's Kidnappings
abstract: Jorge Rafael Videla, Argentina's former president, who was jailed in 1987 and pardoned in 1990 for human rights abuses during his dictatorship, is detained and could faces new charges of ordering children kidnapped and illegally adopted by military families during 'dirty war'; surprise move promises to expand long-running battle between human rights officials and Government of Pres Carol Saul Menem; several of children involved apparently were born in secret prisons; photo (M)

headline: China Tells U.S. It Won't Devalue Currency
abstract: Chinese officials assure Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin that they do not plan to devalue nation's currency, the yuan; persuading China to maintain a stable yuan has become a top priority of Clinton Administration, which fears a devaluation could spark another wave of copycat devaluations across Far East; Rubin praises China as an 'island of stability'; photo (M)

headline: Agency.com Buys Rest of Online Magic
abstract: Agency.com acquires shares of Online Magic that it does not already own; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: For Many Blue-Collar Fathers, Child Care Is Shift Work, Too
abstract: Lower-paid, blue-collar men are leading trend toward more-involved fatherhood; they are spending more time with their children by working split shifts with their wives; economic forces are not the only reason: some two-income families do not believe in outside child care, and some men simply see their work at home as part of being a father; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Arms Inspector Firm on Iraq Nerve Gas but Accepts New Tests
abstract: United Nations arms inspector Richard Butler tells Security Council that tests at United States Army laboratory left no doubt that Iraq loaded deadly VX nerve gas into missile warheads; accedes to Council decision to call for further tests in Switzerland and France because of Iraq's stand that US lab was biased; says findings show Iraq lied in denying it used VX in weapons; Council extends sanctions against Iraq for another 60 days; United States protests letter Iraqi Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf sent to Security Council disparaging Asst State Sec Martin Indyk as Jew and Zionist (M)

headline: Hope Over Ulster Rises as Leaders Warm Up
abstract: Prime Ministers of Irish Republic and Britain and Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders in Northern Ireland press efforts to reach historic agreement to end sectarian violence as April 9 deadline approaches; photo (M)

headline: Monitors Picked Up Only 1 of 5 India Blasts
abstract: Only one of five nuclear tests that India announced this week was detected by the thousands of seismometers around world set up to track earthquakes and atomic blasts, renewing debate among experts about how effectively a test ban treaty can be monitored; drawings, graphs show how scientists detect underground nuclear blasts and earthquakes (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Big Sales Gain for Sunbeam Proves Costly to Investors
abstract: Market Place column describes two investor lawsuits filed against Sunbeam Corp, charging company used off-season promotion for barbecue grills last winter to artificially inflate its results for 1997, in order to more easily obtain financing to acquire three companies; investor lawsuits call this early-buy promotion deliberately misleading; products remained in retailers' inventory until weather warmed; now, in what should be good period for grill sales, Sunbeam has fewer orders than it would otherwise because of its 'early buy' program; Sunbeam has issued warnings twice this year about slowing sales, causing its stock to plummet, and is expected to report loss for first quarter (M)

headline: New Netscape Browser Will Enter the Fray
abstract: Netscape Communications announces that its Communicator 4.5 Internet browser will be available in a beta version next month, and the final version will be shipped in the fall (S)

headline: A Nonmanufacturing Index Shows Growth
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management's new nonmanufacturing activity index shows activity rose at nonmanfacturing companies in May from April; index was at 64 in May, first official month of the survey; that is up from 63 in April, according to previously unreleased data; association has been conducting pilot surveys for new index since July 1997, when index was 57.5 (S)

headline: International Briefs; Pakhoed Cancels Plan For Van Ommeren Deal
abstract: Royal Pakhoed N.V. said yesterday that it had canceled plans to buy Royal Van Ommeren N.V. in an effort to create the world's largest oil-  and chemical-shipping company, after European Union antitrust regulators demanded nearly twice the cuts in oil-storage capacity the companies had offered. Both companies' shares plunged after the the 1.35-billion-guilder ($665 million) stock-swap agreement was called off. Pakhoed fell 7 percent lower, at 70 guilders, and Van Ommeren sank 6 percent, to 85.6 guilders.

headline: E. N. Hoffman, 79, Ad Executive And Avid Jazz Fan and Promoter
abstract: Edward N Hoffman, advertising executive for 50 years who never retired, dies at age of 79 (M)

headline: U.S. Hopes Iran Won't Misread Treatment of Visiting Wrestlers
abstract: Clinton Administration says it hopes Iran did not misinterpret short detention of Iranian wrestlers by immigration authorities when athletes entered US at O'Hare International Airport to participate in tournament; says it hopes no offense was taken over long-standing procedures, in which members of team were photographed and fingerprinted (S)

headline: Dollar's Rise Against Yen Helps to Lift Treasuries
abstract: Treasury prices end higher for first time this week, lifted in part by dollar's rally against yen (S)

headline: L.A. Cellular Selects Deutsch for Account
abstract: LA Cellular names Deutsch Inc to handle its account, with billings at $20 million (S)

headline: C.I.A. Study Details Failures; Scouring of System Is Urged
abstract: Adm David E Jeremiah says his probe for Central Intelligence Agency of failure of United States intelligence services to forsee India's May 11 nuclear tests found structural weaknesses in US intelligence that go far beyond India question; calls for overhaul from top down; holds CIA had few or no spies in India, CIA's ability to use people rather than machines to gather data is weak worldwide, satellites produce far too much data for overworked and undertrained intelligence analysts to handle and satellites and analysts alike failed to focus on India's test site; holds senior policy makers and intelligence officials held to fixed belief that India would not test nuclear arms in face of open and repeated vows by newly elected Hindu nationalist leaders to deploy bomb (M)

headline: Learning Company to Acquire Broderbund in a Stock Swap
abstract: Learning Company agrees to acquire Broderbund Software Inc, rival producer of educational software, in stock swap valued at $420 million; deal is latest and largest in new wave of consolidation in educational and consumer software market (M)

headline: Netscape Breaks Even With Unexpectedly Strong Revenue
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp earned $8,000 in its second fiscal quarter ended April 30, down sharply from $7.3 million in quarter ended March 1997; revenue rose 5 percent, to $127.2 million; second-quarter earnings for 1998 include one-time gain of $8.3 milion from sale of securities; Netscape registers loss of $54.2 million on revenue of $8.3 million for month of January because of change in its reporting year (M)

headline: Hard-Pressed, Suharto Plans To Shuffle His Cabinet
abstract: Indonesia's Pres Suharto retreats in face of mounting protests and says he will shuffle unpopular Cabinet, which is packed with relatives and cronies, just two months after appointing it in defiance of public calls for change; spokesman suggests move is in response to complaints of citizens, which were conveyed to him by leaders of Parliament; Indonesian and foreign analysts say Suharto must make deeper cuts in autocratic rule if he is to remain in office; military puts death toll in rioting at almost 500; says most of victims were looters trapped in shoppping centers set ablaze by other looters; though sporadic outbreaks of looting and arson continue through capital of Jakarta, city is mostly peaceful; foreigners continue to flee; photo (M)

headline: FIRSTENERGY SERVICES PURCHASING COLONIAL MECHANICAL
abstract: FirstEnergy Services Corp, FirstEnergy Corp unit, to acquire Colonial Mechanical Corp (S)

headline: A Little Something 'For Good Luck'
abstract: Some residents of Seattle, Wash, comment on their monetary gift-giving practices (S)

headline: U.S. to Ask for a U.N. Tribunal to Prosecute the Khmer Rouge
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say US will ask United Nations Security Council to form tribunal to bring genocide charges against surviving leaders of Khmer Rouge, guerrilla group responsible for deaths of more than million Cambodians in 1970's (M)

headline: Shelves of Snooping Aids Make Privacy Hard to Buy
abstract: Electronics analysts say telephone tapping is bigger than ever, and easier; court-authorized government wiretaps reached record two million private conversations last year; although all states ban unauthorized third-party wiretaps, private investigators say they are being bombarded with clients' requests for illegal wiretaps; many new telephone answering machines have button that will begin taping conversations without informing other party; this is legal in most states; photo (M)

headline: A Personal Computer Is Not Always a PC
abstract: Q. Are all desktop computers considered PC's? Are Apple computers PC's?    A.  A PC, defined in the dictionary as a personal computer, is designed for an individual to use it to process and store data electronically, so many devices can be considered PC's. Not counting the models constructed from hobby kits, PC's have been around only since 1977, when Apple Computer, Commodore and Radio Shack began to sell machines that you could buy in stores.

headline: U.S. v. MICROSOFT; The Kitchen Sink Operating System
abstract: Chronology of some of more significant steps in evolution of Microsoft Corp's operating system, 1981-98; chart (L)

headline: Investors Show Faith In Korean Rebound
abstract: South Korea, financially destitute just four months ago, won an enormous vote of confidence from investors around the world yesterday with the successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds.    It was the first time South Korea had attempted to sell i.o.u.'s to foreign investors since the worst of its economic crisis in December, when the Government's largest state-owned bank had to scrap a bond sale because of investor resistance.

headline: Sulzberger Family Sells Some Times Co. Shares
abstract: Four members of Sulzberger family, including two directors of The New York Times Co, say they sold more than one million shares of stock in company, taking in more than $76 million; sellers are Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Dr Judith P Sulzberger, Marian S Heiskell and Ruth S Holmberg (S)

headline: New Novel to Be Acid Test for Booksellers
abstract: Tom Wolfe appears at independent bookstore convention in Chicago to plug his novel, A Man in Full, his first book in 11 years; his publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, is betting it will be best seller, and is printing largest first run in its half-century history, 1.2 million copies; elaborate preparations under way for book's September debut underscore how much commerce in literature has changed; publishers find themselves in frantic high-volume, low-margin business; membership in American Booksellers Assn has dropped by 45 percent since 1991, reflection of exodus of owners who could not compete with price-cutting superstore chains and discount warehouses; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Agree Rlty  Harnischfeger  Total Sys Svcs

headline: Cola Upstart Bubbles Over From Britain
abstract: Virgin Cola, upstart British soft-drink company started three years ago by music industry and airline executive Richard Branson, plans to enter crowded and hostile American beverage market on May 12; move coincides with one of more intense moments in cola war history; last week, Pepsico Inc sued Coca-Cola Co, contending Coke illegally manipulated food-service distributors; Branson comments; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Falls, Nasdaq Climbs As Investors Still See Value  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up by about 50 points during the day, slipped 1.74 point, to 8,711.13. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index jumped 24.52 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,805.82, with shares of Intel, Microsoft, Dell Computer and Cisco Systems climbing.     The Dow had been up as much as 50 points, before retreating sharply in the last half-hour of trading. Analysts largely attributed the late turnaround to a computer-generated sell program. [Page D10.]

headline: A 1995 Executive Pay Plan Led to Big Bonus This Week
abstract: Computer Associates chief executive Charles B Wang, president Sanjay Kumar and executive vice president Russell M Artzt earn total of 20.25 million company shares worth $1.1 billion as company stock attains price goal set under their 1995 pay plan; restrictions on shares will lapse over seven years (M)

headline: Kraft Joins Frierson & Mee
abstract: Neil Kraft joins Frierson & Mee as partner and creative director (S)

headline: The Net's Real Riches
abstract: Eric S Nylund letter expresses hope that popularity of Internet leads to establishment of information infrastructure of high-speed fiber optic lines (S)

headline: COLD TRAIL: A special report.; Congo Not Alone in Ending Massacre Inquiry
abstract: Howard W French special report on failure of United Nations investigation to establish facts in one of most troubling mysteries of Congo's seven-month civil war: disappearance and presumed killings of tens of thousands of Hutu refugees; refugees disappeared as they were being driven clear across Africa's third-largest country by rebel army of Laurent Kabila in his successful effort to overthrow dictator Mobutu Sese Seko; UN puts toll at 180,000 people; failure of inquiry was fault of many--not just Congolese; though Kabila pledged to cooperate, Congolese used every tactic to frustrate inquiry; UN made crucial concessions to Kabila's Government that weakened inquiry; Congo's neighbors, particularly Rwanda and Uganda, that sponsored Kabila's rebellion were hostile to any investigation that might disclose details of their involvement; Western nations, led by US, were eager to cement their ties to new authorities in Kinshasa and pressed UN to give in to Congolese demands; map; photo (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Japan's Auto Makers Go It Alone; Tradition Creates Resistance to Industry's Consolidation
abstract: Japanese automakers believe merger between Chrysler Corp and Daimler-Benz AG will not immediately affect Japan; Japanese cars are still well designed and relatively affordable, and Japan has not cornered more than half of market for cars in Asia, still expected to be growing market in long run; Toyota Motor Corp and Honda Motor Co make some of most competitive cars and their worldwide sales are still expected to be brisk; Japanese car producers are reluctant to diverge from strategy of independence; workers at Nissan Motors plants are worried that foreign joint ventures could lead to cost-cutting and changes in company's welfare programs; photo (M)

headline: A Homecoming At Fannie Mae; Franklin Raines Takes Charge Of a Most Political Company
abstract: Profile of Franklin D Raines, outgoing budget chief for Clinton Administration, who will become chief executive of Federal National Mortgage Assn, or Fannie Mae, at end of the year; focuses on challenges that await Raines; photos (M)

headline: SOWING DEATH: A special report.; How Japan Germ Terror Alerted World
abstract: Court testimony by member of Japan's Aum Shinrikyo religious cult shows it carried out repeated germ attacks in early 1990's to kill millions of people throughout Tokyo and at nearby American bases where thousands of service people and their families live; group sprayed pestilential microbes and germ toxins from rooftops and convoys of trucks, hoping to ignite apocalyptic war; its targets included Japanese Diet, Imperial Palace, surrounding city and American base at Yokohama, which is headquarters of Seventh Fleet; at least nine attacks failed, largely because group never possessed germs of sufficient virulence, despite great effort; cult sought lethal bacteria from local sources and traveled on microbe-hunting trips to a northern Japanese isle as well as to Africa, apparently eager to obtain deaded Ebola virus; burst into headlines in 1995 when it released nerve gas into Tokyo subways, killing dozen people; its biological work, meant to be thousand times more devastating, was mentioned only in passing, in scattered reports; photos; map (L)

headline: Time Warner Results Flip To Net Loss in the Quarter
abstract: Time Warner Inc reports net loss of $62 million compared with profit of $35 million; loss linked to weak performance of its music division and continued losses at WB television network; revenues rose to $3.1 billion from $3 billion; chart (L)

headline: Raytheon Chooses The Heir Apparent
abstract: Raytheon Co ends almost yearlong search for successor to its chairman, Dennis J Picard, by naming Allied Signal Inc's Daniel P Burnham as president; Burnham will join Raytheon on July 1 as president and chief operating officer before becoming chief executive on Dec 1; Allied Signal names Frederic M Poses to newly created position of president and chief operating officer after Burnham resigns (S)

headline: An Empire Imperiled : Jakarta Sets Out on Road to Reform
abstract: JAKARTA—  The new government made its first move on Monday to review, and possibly dismantle, parts of the enormous business empire and cartels built up by former President Suharto and his family during his 32-year rule.

headline: G.M. to Develop Pickup Truck With Isuzu
abstract: General Motors Corp will develop pickup truck with Isuzu Motors Ltd of Japan for sale in US, Europe and Brazil (S)

headline: Deal for Cataract Surgery
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc says it signed licensing agreement with Optex Ophthalmologics Inc and its parent company, Atlantic Pharmaceuticals Inc. to complete development of Catarex, cataract-removal technology invented by Optex (S)

headline: LOOPHOLE ON GUNS FEARED IN EUROPE
abstract: Clinton Administration has discovered that despite US laws intended to curb international trafficking in firearms, it has virtually no control over where American weapons end up once they are shipped to Europe; law enforcement officials in Europe and US say thousands of high-powered and semi-automatic American pistols and rifles sold to Europe in last few years have ended up fueling violent conflicts in several countries, and in hands of street criminals and organized crime syndicates; there are also indications that American firearms have found their way to Iran and Iraq; State Dept, as first step to address problem, is on verge of revoking all outstanding licenses for firearms exports to British companies (M)

headline: Patents; Those needing transplants may someday be able to grow organs from cells inserted in the body.
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Children's Hospital of Boston researchers have recently won three patents scientists hope will someday mean patient in need of transplant can grow own healthy new organs; Advanced Tissue Sciences, which licensed patents, plans clinical trials using technology to grow tissues like muscle; technology involves seeding human cells on bio-degradable scaffolding in laboratory and implanting structure where replacement tissue is needed (M)

headline: Minority Journalists Reconsider Seattle
abstract: Four organizations representing journalists who are members of minority groups are expected to gather in Seattle in July 1999 for joint meeting; some members question selection of Seattle, given fact that Washington voters may pass measure on November ballot that would end most, if not all, affirmative action programs in state (S)

headline: Ketchum Expands Ethnic Operations
abstract: Ketchum Public Relations Worldwide expands its ethnic communications operations by forming unit in Atlanta to specialize in public relations campaigns aimed at black consumers; unit will be called African-American Markets Group; Betsy Helgager is named to head new unit and is promoted to vice president (S)

headline: Hearst Magazines Quits Trade Group in a Dispute With Its Longtime Rival, Conde Nast
abstract: Hearst Magazines, Hearst Corp unit, has resigned from Publishers Information Bureau, trade group that tracks magazines' advertising pages; protests bureau's decision to count ad pages in personal finance supplement Conde Nast sent with its 15 magazines in ad count of each individual magazine; Hearst aide K Robert Brink has resigned as chairman of bureau's council; dispute adds fuel to long rivalry between Hearst and Advance Publications Inc' s Conde Nast unit and spurs bureau to rethink policies (M)

headline: Paris Journal; Barricades of '68 Are Down, and the Boutiques Are Raised
abstract: Daniel Cohn-Bendit, still red-headed but upholstered by middle age, recalls student demonstrations in Paris in 1968, when he was famous, or infamous, as Danny the Red; interview; photos then and now (Paris Journal) (S)

headline: SPENDING IT; 5 Attractions for Summer Joy Riding
abstract: Megan O'Matz rates Great Bear, new roller coaster at Hersheypark in Pennsylvania (S)

headline: Stocks Gain Slightly as Wary Buyers Return to Blue Chips
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 33.63 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to close at 8,970.20; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 5.37 points, to close at 1,097.60; graph; charts (M)

headline: CONFERENCE OPENS ON CREATING COURT TO TRY WAR CRIMES
abstract: UN will convene conference in Rome, Italy, on June 15 to thrash out rules for international court to prosecute war criminals in ambitious effort to extend rule of international law; envisions permanent court where individuals accused of atrocities and genocide can be tried and punished, even though most basic issues of jurisdiction and accountability remain deeply contested; US, China, France and Russia want UN Security Council to decide which cases should be proseecuted; Clinton Administration, and particularly Pentagon, fear that unless court is in some way answerable to world's leading democracies, American soldiers could be hauled before international judges on politically motivated charges; at least 42 other nations are battling for independent court, arguing that unless its prosecutors are free from interference from Security Council, its authority will be toothless (M)

headline: A British Phone Company Looks to America
abstract: Cable & Wireless PLC's plan to buy MCI Communications's Internet business is threatened by antitrust issues being raised about Worldcom's planned acquisition of MCI; company could end up with more of MCI than expected or lose deal entirely; is racing to build bulk in belief that global communications market will end up being dominated by few international giants; tables and graphs of company financial data; diagram; photo (M)

headline: Awash in U.S. Aid. Could Float Fine Without It.
abstract: Israel's new-found economic success leads many Israelis and Americans to question size of United States aid package; Israel, largest beneficiary of US aid, has been getting $3 billion in American economic and military aid for last several years, even as overall foreign aid budget has fallen; has proposed phasing out economic aid and increasing military aid, for eventual overall cut of 20 percent; Congressional members who favor larger cuts fear offending American Jews or Israel's powerful lobby (M)

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP TO SELL COOKIE UNIT TO UNITED BISCUITS
abstract: Campbell Soup Co to sell its European premium cookie unit, Delacre, to United Biscuits Holdings PLC of Britain for $125 million (S)

headline: As Print Revenue Ebbs, www.juneplaymate.com?
abstract: Playboy reports minuscule earnings last quarter, 30 percent decline in newsstand revenue and 11 percent drop in advertising revenue, compared with year earlier quarter; but its World Wide Web site showed 84 percent growth, to $1.42 million (S)

headline: Clinton, in Beijing Square, May Tread on the Ghosts
abstract: Pres Clinton's appearance in Tiananmen Square, symbolic center of Communist China, has been nonnegotiable point with Chinese officials since Pres Clinton first agreed to visit country; June 1989 massacre that ended pro-democracy demonstrations in square did not take place in square itself; armed forces approaching square from west began shooting indiscriminately at unarmed civilians when they were three miles away from square and ceased shooting by the time they reached the edge of square; plan of square (M)

headline: Logitech Gains Immersion Stake
abstract: Logitech International SA, world's biggest computer-mouse maker, acquires 10 percent stake in software company Immersion Corp to speed development of new mice and joysticks (S)

headline: Lawmakers' Letter Urges Clinton Not to Press the Israelis Publicly
abstract: Three-quarters of Senate and one-quarter of House urge Pres Clinton not to present Middle East peace proposal in public that Israeli Government opposes; say public proposal leaves Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat with very little incentive to negotiate (M)

headline: STATOIL OF NORWAY INVESTS IN NEW YORK POWER STATIONS
abstract: Statoil of Norway's American unit buys 50 percent stakes in power stations at Kennedy International Airport and State University of New York from Community Energy Alternatives for $70 million; unit changes name from Eastern Group to Statoil Energy (S)

headline: A Step Ahead of the Government
abstract: Analysis of Lockheed Martin Corp's minor legal victories so far in defending itself against Government's effort to block its proposed $8.3 billion takeover of Northrop Grumman Corp; says most antitrust experts say Lockheed faces at best a slim chance of prevailing in largest antitrust case brought by Government (L)

headline: GO2NET BUYS SILICON INVESTOR FOR $35 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Go2net Inc acquires Silicon Investor, a Web site for small investors, for $35 million in stock (S)

headline: LUCENT ACQUIRING SDX, A BRITISH TELEPHONE CONCERN
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc to acquire British business telephone company SDX Business Systems PLC for $202 million (US) (S)

headline: Ulster Peace Accord Wins Backing of Protestant Party
abstract: Northern Ireland's largest political party, Ulster Unionists, beats back growing internal opposition and votes to support week-old peace agreement aimed at settling decades of violent struggle between Protestants and Catholics; Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises for second day against US dollar after Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto hints that Japan will cut income taxes to help economy; in New York the dollar costs 133.35 yen, down from 134.80; graph; chart (S)

headline: Suharto Fostered Rapid Economic Growth, and Staggering Graft
abstract: Indonesia's Pres Suharto was reforming autocrat who clung to power so long that he undermined his legacy and considerable accomplishments; Asian economic crisis was catalyst that pushed Suharto out after 32 years, but his family's unrestrained corruption and staggering graft of family and associates alienated military and business class; Suharto brought stability, economic development, family planning and widespread literacy, and made country self-sufficient in rice; he moved Indonesia into anti-Communist orbit after overthrowing Sukarno, helped found ASEAN and promoted capitalism, but at home cracked down ruthlessly on dissent and allowed his six children to become unimaginably rich; photo with Sukarno in 1967 (M)

headline: Some on Wall St. See Buffett's Hand in Bond Sales
abstract: Bond traders on Wall Street are questioning whether Warren Buffett is selling part or all of his huge position in zero-coupon Treasury bonds as huge sell orders pour in on same long-term Treasury issues that Buffett owns; one trader reports that Buffett's people say they are not selling any of roughly $20 billion in zero-coupon bonds purchased last year by Berkshire Hathaway Inc, Buffett's investment company; in last couple of weeks, some $5 billion face value of 2020 and 2021 maturities that Buffett owns have been sold; photo (M)

headline: First Union Merges Direct Marketing
abstract: First Union Corp consolidates its direct marketing account at two shops: Hill, Holliday Direct in Boston and Earle Palmer Brown Direct in Philadelphia; account, with billings estimated at $30 million, had been divided among several agencies (S)

headline: FIRSTAR IN DEAL TO BUY UNIT OF CARGILL
abstract: Firstar Corp will buy Cargill Leasing Corp (S)

headline: A Family Links Up, But United We Fall
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (User's Guide) column discusses her family's use of an on-line mailing list as way to stay in touch with each other; says on-line mailing lists harness power of E-mail and amplify it by sending identical messages to everyone on the list; notes two programs that run most of world's mailing lists, called listserv and majordomo, are complex software programs developed from series of small programs designed to accomplish single goal of managing mailing list; says such lists are now within reach of average person through small cadre of campanies that charge monthly fee to act as hosts for mailing lists on their servers; says she uses L-Soft, Maryland company (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Antitrust Suit Against Intel Prepared by Regulators  The Federal Trade Commission is readying a major antitrust suit against Intel, charging the company with abusing its position as the dominant manufacturer of microprocessor chips for personal computers and bullying some computer makers, lawyers said.    The suit marks the second front in the Federal Government's antitrust assault on Wintel, as the computer juggernaut built around Microsoft's Windows operating system and Intel's microprocessors is known. Microsoft was sued last week. [Page A1.]

headline: A Long Way From Simplicity
abstract: Stephen Weller letter on May 28 article holds Microsoft routinely sabotages computer simplicity through overprogramming (S)

headline: Milan Journal; 'The Black Widow' Goes on Trial in Gucci Slaying
abstract: Trial of Patrizia Reggiani, wealthy socialite accused of ordering 1995 killing of her ex-husband and Gucci heir, Maurizio Gucci, begins in Milan; co-defendants, Benedetto Ceraulo and Orazio Cicala, are locked in iron cage in courtroom; photos (M)

headline: Bank Merger Fever Spreads To Canada
abstract: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Toronto-Dominion Bank set $15.9 billion (US) merger, move that would leave Canada's already highly concentrated financial services industry with just four large national banks; new bank, to be named CIBC, would be Canada's second largest and one of 10 largest in North America; Finance Min Paul Martin says Government will not let any merger proceed until task force on financial services sector's future issues its report in Sept; cites need for strong domestic competition; graph (M)

headline: Media Convergence
abstract: News analysis of AT&T's acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc, nation's second-largest cable television company, and of rising wave of mergers in telecommunications, cable television and media companies that have become increasingly dependent on digital technology of computing; business logic underscoring trend is that companies face once-in-a-corporate lifetime choice of getting in early to become leaders in new markets of information age or be relegated to also-ran status; graph (M)

headline: A Courtroom Disciplinarian Who's Unintimidated by Technology
abstract: Article on US District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who will supervise sweeping antitrust cases brought by Justice Department, 20 states and District of Columbia against Microsoft Corp (L)

headline: Hard Truth of the Mideast
abstract: News analysis of decision by Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to travel to Washington for further Middle East peace talks, after rejecting US ultimatum demanding that Israel withdraw from 13 percent of West Bank; Clinton is sticking to course of trying to push Israel to accept proposed agreement, even though he has so far failed to influence Netanyahu; photo (M)

headline: Cable Industry Ready to Fight to Offer Internet Access
abstract: Cable and telephone companies are massing their forces for protracted war over which group will provide high-speed Internet access to people's homes; cable industry will introduce organization to promote its own modem technology, called Cable Broadband Forum; latest technology for getting access to Internet over cable television systems comes from telephone company (M)

headline: David Ayalon, 84, Israeli Scholar Of Muslim History and Arabic
abstract: David Ayalon, scholar of Muslim history and Arabic language, dies at age 84 (S)

headline: 5 Nations See World Cup Threat : European Police Detain Algerians
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Police in five European countries on Tuesday raided the homes of people suspected of supporting an Islamic extremist group in Algeria. Officials said the coordinated operation — in Belgium, France, Germany, Italy and Switzerland — was aimed at forestalling the threat of terrorist violence during the World Cup soccer tournament, which opens in France next month.

headline: Popular Target: Family Trees
abstract: Internet is an obvious destination for the genealogically inclined, and its popularity among family tree makers is underscored by survey which found that nearly a third of AT&T Worldnet Service subscribers have used the Internet to seek family roots (S)

headline: A Mobile-Phone Software Venture
abstract: Psion PLC, British palmtop computer company, is joining with Nokia of Finland, Ericsson of Sweden and Motorola to develop software for mobile phones that behave more like computers; venture, called Symbian, is intended to surpass Microsoft Inc's Windows CE, now used in many palmtop computers, to become standard operating software for mobile communication devices (S)

headline: Futures Merger Approved by Regulators
abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission approves merger of New York Cotton Exchange and Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to form second-largest United States agricultural exchange; combined exchange to be called Board of Trade of the City of New York (S)

headline: Red Army Faction Disbands, Saying Its Cause Is 'Now History'
abstract: Last remaining urban guerrillas of Red Army Faction announce that they have dissolved their organization because they and their cause are 'now history' (M)

headline: KOREAN BANK AND BANKERS TRUST IN INVESTMENT TALKS
abstract: Seoulbank of South Korea and Bankers Trust New York Corp reach accord for Bankers Trust to advise Seoulbank on restructuring to attract new investment; deal may include mutual minority equity investment (S)

headline: Iran's Tension Underscored In Celebrating Its President
abstract: A year after an election that changed the face of Iranian politics, students and ordinary Iranians rallied by the tens of thousands here today to revel in the openness instilled by the new President, Mohammad Khatami.    The anniversary gathering was the most raucous and uninhibited political demonstration seen in Iran in many years. But it came against a backdrop of sharpening tensions between the kinds of moderate Iranians who came out to celebrate Mr. Khatami's landslide victory and conservatives who view his popularity as a real threat to their long-time grip on power.

headline: Musicians Tap Rich Lode of Sheet Music, Sold and Shared
abstract: Internet sites featuring sheet music or guitar chords offer immediacy that is exclusive to Internet; within hours of death of Tammy Wynette, sheet music of her hit Stand By Your Man was on line; photo (M)

headline: BANKAMERICA PLACES ITS MUTUAL FUNDS UNIT ON SALE
abstract: BankAmerica Corp puts its Robertson Stephens Investment Management mutual funds unit up for sale as parent company prepares to merge with Nationsbank Corp (S)

headline: Intel Case Gives Antitrust Law a New Twist
abstract: Analysis of Federal Trade Commission's antitrust suit against Intel Corp; says odd feature of complaint is that it accuses Intel of victimizing putative rivals that are also customers; holds in separate instances involving Intergraph Corp, Compaq Computer and Digital Equipment Corp, Intel Corp is accused of withhholding technical data about its processors from companies that were designing computers around Intel chips; says what will make Government's case difficult is that only one of those companies--Digital--ever seriously competed with Intel; adds information that Intel freely acknowledges it withheld from those companies may have had no direct bearing on competition in chip industry (M)

headline: Saving for College: Why Bother?
abstract: Letter from Gregory L Waters says parents having trouble financing their children's higher education should consider state colleges and universities, which are far less expensive than private institutions and many of which offer good educations (S)

headline: In a Suharto Fief, 'Hang Suharto!'
abstract: Thousands of Indonesia college students stage anti-Suharto demonstration outside Parliament, Jakarta; military lets students from dozens of schools enter building to air their grievances in meetings with Government representatives; photo (M)

headline: Guernica Journal; Fascism's Prey: Now Healing and a Quest for Truth
abstract: Survivors recall destruction of Guernica, Spain, in 1937 by German warplanes, which aided Gen Francisco Franco during Spanish Civil War; recent apology by German Parliament has been well received, but anger remains over fact that neither Government in Madrid nor military has ever recanted Franco's official lie, that town was destroyed by leftist Basque radicals; Guernica, which inspired famous painting by Pablo Picasso, has been symbol of fascist brutality during civil war; map; photos (M)

headline: Indonesian Riot Police Open Fire At Protests, Killing Six Students
abstract: Indonesian security forces fire on demonstration that spilled from college campus in Jakarta onto major highway; kill six students and wound at least a dozen; students, who are from an elite school attended by children of many senior Government and military aides, were calling for Pres Suharto's resignation; violence began when they refused to return to campus after day of peaceful protest; photos (M)

headline: New Breed of College All-Star; Columbia Pays Top Dollar for Economics Heavy Hitter
abstract: Columbia University has agreed to pay nearly $300,000 a year to lure Robert J Barro, one of nation's most distinguished economists, away from Harvard University; market for top economists resembles big-time deals in sports and Hollywood; focus on money has moved into upper-most tier of schools, which have traditionally counted mostly on their reputations to lure talent; other economists being courted by major schools include Drew Fundenberg, Alvin E Roth, Paul Krugman, Thomas J Sargent and Paul Romer; charts; photos (L)

headline: HEALTH INSURERS SEEK BIG INCREASES IN THEIR PREMIUMS
abstract: Many employers, for first time since 1992, are facing double-digit increases in cost of their health insurance next year--highest inflation rate since majority of employees moved into managed care; insurers are seeking increases for 1999 that are far above this year's, when most premiums rose in single digits after four years of stability; critics of managed care say magnitude of increases undercuts basic appeal behind managed care: savings from lower costs; 85 percent of American employees were enrolled in managed-care plans in 1997; benefits consultants estimate that increases will average about 7 percent nationally, or five times current 1.4 percent consumer inflation rate; Kaiser Permanente is seeking 12 percent increase from large employers in California (M)

headline: HALL OF HARD QUESTIONS
abstract: Like, where to fit it all? The creation of the American Museum of Natural History's new biodiversity exhibit was an adventure in itself. Page 4.

headline: ASPEN TECHNOLOGY TO BUY CHESAPEAKE DECISION
abstract: Aspen Technology Inc agrees to acquire Chesapeake Decision Sciences Inc for more than $135 million (S)

headline: Dropping an Internet Hot Potato
abstract: Analysis of Commerce Department proposal to turn management of Internet domain names, and thus management of Internet itself, over to private not-for-profit international corporation that would represent various Internet interests; proposal disappoints people hoping for more immediate action to ease impending logjam (M)

headline: Clinton Rejects Pleas to Avoid Tiananmen Ceremony
abstract: President Clinton rejects appeals that he avoid welcoming rite in Tiananmen Square, Beijing, when he visits China this month, news conference with South Korea's Pres Kim Dae Jung; holds appearing at site of deadly 1989 crackdown on democratic protesters does not signal he endorses suppression of dissent; calls his now-controversial approval of China's launching American satellite over Justice Department objections 'pretty routine decision' made on recommendation of other agencies; rebuffs gentle pressure from Kim to ease American economic sanctions against North Korea; cites improved conditions for workers in South Korea in announcing resumption of Overseas Private Investment Corp loan guarantees for American companies doing business there; hails Kim as human rights pioneer; photo (M)

headline: U.S. SET TO BACK $1 BILLION OUTLAY TO AID INDONESIA
abstract: United States is preparing to back $1 billion payment in international emergency aid to Indonesia, despite evidence that Pres Suharto's family and friends are continuing to undermine efforts to break up multibillion-dollar monopolies they control; Treasury officials acknowledge that Indonesia has failed to meet some of most important conditions that were imposed by International Monetary Fund in return for $40 billion bailout package; say, nevertheless, that United States expects to vote in favor of gradual resumption of aid when monetary fund's board meets next week; Clinton Adm says it is satisfied that Indonesia is making 'adequate progress' toward meeting IMF demands (M)

headline: William Hewitt, 83, Responsible For Overseas Expansion of Deere
abstract: William A Hewitt, who transformed Deere & Co from midsized Midwestern tractor company to world's largest producer of agricultural equipment, dies at 83 (S)

headline: Murphy's Law Can Trip Up Even Systems That Sing
abstract: Article and diagram explain computer system havoc created by introduction of new software by comparing it to hotel with a new doorman on the job (S)

headline: Albright Says She Will Add Day to Talks On Mideast
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright will spend extra day in London for further talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders to restore momentum to peace talks; has been unable to win agreement from Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu to American proposal for Israeli withdrawal from 13 percent of West Bank over 12-week period, in conjunction with specific Palestinian moves to counter terrorism; photo (M)

headline: Unknown Authors Beat Their Books to the Stores
abstract: Penguin Putnam sends two unknown authors, Iain Pears (An Instance of the Fingerpost) and Janice Graham (Firebird), on tour of cities across the country five months before their books arrive so that they can meet with booksellers, journalists and book club leaders at the time retailers make their initial orders; visits are followed up with monthly mailings; usual practice is for authors to sign books in stores and be interviewed by media when their books are on the shelves; photo (M)

headline: CREDITORS OF BARNEY'S TERMINATE PURCHASE AGREEMENT
abstract: Creditors of Barney's Inc terminate Dickson Concepts International Ltd's $322 million agreement to buy the retailer; creditors now favor reorganization plan to be filed soon by retailer and its creditors, which would let Barney's emerge from Chapter 11 protection under control of creditors and investors (S)

headline: Allies Creating Press-Control Agency in Bosnia
abstract: US and its Western allies in Bosnia peacekeeping operation are creating tribunal that will have power to shut radio and television stations and punish newspapers that it decides are engaged in propaganda that is undermining peace (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCDONALD'S CORP., Oak Brook, Ill., said it planned to invest about $1.5 billion and open more than 2,000 restaurants in the Asia-Pacific region in the next three years despite economic downturns there.    CATERPILLAR INC., Peoria, Ill., a maker of construction and mining machinery, acquired Kato Engineering, Mankato, Minn., a maker of electric generators for power systems, from Rockwell International Corp. for an undisclosed price.

headline: Mitsubishi Trust in U.S. Options Deal
abstract: LEAD: Eager to give its corporate clients worldwide an opportunity to deal in futures and options, the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation of Japan said today that it would form a venture with the Chicago Research and Trading Group Ltd., one of this country's leading traders of options and futures.

headline: Iran's Ailing Economy Is Reeling From Quake
abstract: LEAD: Just when Iran's sickly economy seemed incapable of sustaining another blow, it was dealt a tremendous one by the earthquake in June.

headline: Haiti, as Expected, Calls End to State of Siege
abstract: LEAD: The military Government of Haiti said tonight that it had lifted a state of siege and restored parts of the Constitution that it suspended nine days ago before launching a major crackdown on political opponents.

headline: Cambodia Talks Quickly Collapse With Boycott by the Khmer Rouge
abstract: LEAD: A new round of talks on Cambodia lasted only 25 minutes today after the Khmer Rouge guerrillas complained about their representation here and boycotted the session.

headline: Barclays Cutbacks
abstract: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said it planned to streamline its domestic retail branch operations in the next five years by closing 110 offices and trimming 1,800 employees through attrition. The office cuts, mostly in urban centers, amount to slightly more than 4 percent of Barclays's network of 2,600 retail bank branches in Britain, while the staff cuts represent 1.5 percent of its total domestic work force of 87,000. Barclays said 1,300 of the jobs would be cut from clerical staff and the rest from management.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Richmond Playing Host To Tobacco Exhibition
abstract: LEAD: Richmond, once a capital of the American tobacco industry, is the site of an exhibition entitled ''Smoke Signals: Cigarettes, Advertising and the American Way of Life.''

headline: Taking the Heat at American Express
abstract: LEAD: Once again, the heat is on the American Express Company and its chairman, James D. Robinson 3d. Having been forced to rescue its brokerage subsidiary with a massive capital infusion, American Express is facing criticism for a series of missteps over the past decade.

headline: A Sugar Quota For Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: The United States said Tuesday that it planned to restore preferential treatment for Nicaraguan exports, including a quota for sugar exports to the United States.

headline: Fraud Alleged in Vote for Gorbachev Aide
abstract: Opposition members of the Congress of People's Deputies today produced what they called clear evidence of voting irregularities in the second-round election of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Vice President on Thursday.    Brandishing a smoking gun that consisted of two apparently excess ballots, the opposition legislators charged that the voting in the Congress had been falsified to insure the victory of Mr. Gorbachev's candidate, Gennadi I. Yanayev.

headline: Assessing Performance, Not Personality
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 6/  Ole! Authentic Mexican foods are flying off supermarket shelves, creating opportunities for investors. By Michael Parrish.    INVESTING IT /Page 7/  An equity mutual fund that doesn't invest in stocks? Smith Breeden Equity Market Plus is a strange bird that flies high. By Abby Schultz.

headline: Steady Growth Of Revenue Is Energizing Newspapers
abstract: Newspaper industry enjoys good health, with revenues from high-margin classified advertising surging, paper costs down and circulation expected to rise for first time since 1986; newspapers, in city after city, are replacing old nervousness about their outlook with new cockiness; profits come despite declining reader interest, especially among younger readers (M)

headline: Questions About Those Links Links
abstract: ''Duffers Need Not Apply'' (May 31), by Adam Bryant, examined a study comparing the golf handicaps of chief executives to their companies' stock market performance. The study found a pattern: that if a chief executive is a better-than-average golfer, his company is likely to deliver above-average returns to shareholders.    The article drew varied responses from readers. Many questioned the findings and methods of the study, saying that it did not include enough executives or that it incorrectly excluded seven chief executives whose data distorted the trend lines.

headline: Foote, Cone Gets Bristol-Myers Work
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co will expand its relationship with Foote, Cone & Belding by awarding agency's New York office responsibilities for Infusium 23 line of shampoo, conditioner and styling products sold by its Clairol division; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Clinton Meets Delegation From Kosovo Seeking Talks
abstract: Pres Clinton meets with ethnic Albanian leaders from Serbian province of Kosovo who favor negotiated solution to their conflict with Serbian Government; White House meeting is intended to display US interest and involvement in Kosovo, as well as support for Ibrahim Rugova, president of self-declared Republic of Kosovo (M)

headline: Shoe Manufacturer Cuts Work Force by 25%
abstract: KTP Holdings Ltd, athletic shoe manufacturer, says 30 percent decline in first-quarter sales prompts it to dismiss 6,000 employees in Indonesia and Chian, or about 25 percent of its work force, to reduce monthly labor costs by as much as $400,000 (US); KTP will stop producing Fila brand shoes and reduce its output of Adidas shoes to focus on making Reeboks; company also plans to raise $73 million (Hong Kong) by selling stock (S)

headline: A Free Personal Shopper For Internet News Hounds
abstract: Web site called Crayon lets users compile their own electronic newspaper on a personal Web site for free; photos (M)

headline: Spiders and Diamonds and Dogs, Oh My!
abstract: Individual investors are pouring billions of dollars into unit investment trusts--products that let them time market by actively trading in and out of broad indexes like Dow Jones industrial average or Standard & Poor's 500; unit investment trust is kind of hybrid between mutual fund and stock; it holds fixed portfolio of bonds or stocks for defined time; investors like unit trusts because they are easy to understand; stock brokers like them because they are even easier to sell, and because of fat commissions many offer, compared with similar mutual funds; while many investment professionals agree that unit trusts make sense for some people, there is good chance that many holders of unit trusts have mistaken uninterrupted bull market for their own investment brilliance; photos; chart (L)

headline: As Filipinos Vote, Movie Idol Has a Starring Role
abstract: Philippines Vice Pres Joseph P Estrada, former B-movie actor, is favorite to become next President in upcoming elections; polls show Estrada beating his chief rival, House Speaker Jose de Venecia, who is backed by Pres Fidel V Ramos; map; photo (M)5

headline: Productivity Grows at Slowest Pace Since '96
abstract: Labor Department says worker productivity grew at slowest pace in more than a year in first quarter, reflecting surge in hours employees spent on the job and acute shortages of job applicants; productivity rose at annualized rate of two-tenths of a percent; department reports first-time claims for state unemployment benefits unexpectedly declined by 11,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 308,000; Commerce Department says wholesale inventories and sales increased in March; Federal Reserve data on consumer borrowing for March show weakest increase in four months; borrowing rose $1 billion for month, far less than expectations of $4.1 billion; borrowing rose $1 billion, to $1.242 trillion, after rising revised $6.1 trillion during February; graph (M)

headline: Jakarta Takes Over Big Bank After Run
abstract: Indonesian Government takes control of Bank Central Asia, one of largest in country, after panicked customers withdraw large amounts, forcing bank to borrow heavily from Government; bank was run by Liem Sioe Lion, friend of ousted Pres Suharto (S)

headline: Oxford to Withhold Remainder of Ex-Chairman's Severance
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc, under pressure from Gov George E Pataki and New York State Insurance Department, agrees to withhold rest of $9 million severance package it had planned to pay its former chairman, Stephen F Wiggins; company has already paid Wiggins $3.6 milion cash from the package; insurance department, which has been sharply critical of Oxford's management, is reviewing company's finances (M)

headline: Predecessors' Woes Make Diet Drug a Tough Sell
abstract: Knoll Pharmaceutical Co faces tough time winning acceptance of prescription diet pill Meridia because of health concerns about predecessor drugs dexfenfluramine (Redux) and fenfluramine (Pondimin), part of drug cocktail known as fen-phen; Knoll holds Meridia is as effective, but safer, than predecessors; some diet centers that enlisted doctors to prescribe earlier drugs say they will not offer Meridia; consumer advocates and doctors groups are advising overweight people to carefully weigh possible side effects; graphs (M)

headline: Danish Banks Plan To Form Big Lender
abstract: BG Bank A/S and Realkredit Danmark A/S announce plans to form Denmark's largest lender by assets in merger worth at least 12.8 billion kroner ($1.9 billion); investors will swap each BG Bank share for one in Kapital Holding A/S, a new holding company with assets of 530 billion kroner; Realkredit Danmark will hold 55 percent of entity, while BG Bank will provide chief executive; graph (S)

headline: Body Shop Chief To Step Down
abstract: Body Shop International PLC says founder Anita Roddick will step aside as chief executive after 22 years as ailing cosmetics retailer seeks to cope with declining sales and falling stock price; company appoints Patrick Gourney as chief executive as Roddick takes on new role of co-chairwoman, joining her husband, T Gordon; company announces flat pretax profits of $62.1 million for last year; Body Shop says it plans to form joint venture with retail company Bellamy Retail Group LLC, in bid to resurrect its ailing business in US (S)

headline: Confusion Surrounds Mellon's Shares
abstract: Shares of Mellon Bank Corp spike higher in chaotic after-market trading after Pacific Exchange issues trading halt on stock and quotes price as $85.875, which would have represented jump of $12.625 from New York Stock Exchange closing price; Pacific Exchange later corrects itself; merger speculation surrounds Mellon's shares (S)

headline: Software and Hardball
abstract: Analysis of Justice Department's escalating antitrust battle with Microsoft Corp; companies in many fields fear competitive threat to them posed by Microsoft's near-monopoly over PC desktop, as main Windows screen is known; Justice Department is concerned that browser software that makes desktop portal to Internet gives Microsoft power to steer consumers to own Internet sites or those of companies that pay for desktop position; is expected to try to break Microsoft's grip on desktop by letting personal computer makers load Internet services chosen by customers before shipping machines; photo (M)

headline: Networks Turn to Affiliates To Defray Program Costs
abstract: Television networks are turning to station affiliates to help defray costs of specific programs; move is strongly opposed by local stations; network executives are contemplating selling affiliated stations commercial time now owned by networks during prime-time hours and ending program exclusivity arrangements with affiliated stations so that networks can sell more of their programs to secondary buyers like cable channels (L)

headline: SHRUGGING OFF DOOM: A special report.; Shops Closing, Japan Still Asks, 'What Crisis?'
abstract: Lack of crisis mentality is preventing Japan, which is enduring worst economic slump in quarter-century, from summoning political will to undertake far-reaching reforms to stimulate economy; life among Japanese still seems so secure that there is little public pressure on Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto to push for sweeping deregulation and huge stimulus measures being urged by US and other nations; unemployment, at all-time high, is just 3.6 percent; inflation is zero, interest rates are negligible and business bankruptcies per capita are still one third lower than in US; critics say that without deregulation, Japan will continue to stagnate as it has for last seven years, sapping strength from trading partners; photos; maps (M)

headline: LARGEST BURGER KING FRANCHISEE TO BUY POLLO TROPICAL
abstract: Carrols Corp, largest Burger King franchisee in US, will acquire Pollo Tropical Inc for $90 million in cash (S)

headline: Industry's big meeting hears pleas from marketers to look beyond traditional campaigns.
abstract: Panel composed of Robert L Wehling (Procter & Gamble), Dawn Hudson (Pepsico) and W Patrick McGinnis (Ralston Purina) addresses American Association of Advertising Agencies at its convention in Scottsdale, Ariz, urging agencies to elevate themselves and become strategic partners; executives say agencies should be looking beyond traditional ad campaigns and providing creative solutions to larger, long-term problems facing advertisers (M)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Taxicabs can be called by E-mail in Singapore; Compaq Computer discounts selected computers to reduce heavy stockpiles; Pioneer develops an audio CD changer that can hold 300 disks; several faculty members and doctoral candidates at Stanford Graduate School of Business lose irreplaceable research notes, databases, dissertationsand book manuscripts and other files when the school disconnects two powerful computers without verifying if data were backed up; Dell Computer begins selling Dimension XPS R400, its 400-megahertz Pentium II system (S)

headline: Blue-Chip Issues in Retreat, With Dow Declining 31.13
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 31.13 points, to close at 8,891.24; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.24, to 1,093.22; Nasdaq composite index climbs 14.97, to 1,761.79; chart; graph (M)

headline: HAIN IN ACCORD TO BUY NATURAL-FOOD BUSINESSES
abstract: Hain Food Group, leading natural-food company, says that it will buy four natural-food businesses from Shansby Group and others for about $80 million (S)

headline: Getting the Chance To Do It Himself; Out of the Shadows to Run Home Depot
abstract: Profile of Home Depot's co-founder Arthur M Blank; says in the year since co-founder Bernard Marcus handed over chief executive's reins and edged into background as chairman, Blank has quietly begun to make his mark; Blank comments on his strategy to steer toward new markets and expansion by acquisition; graph; photos (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark falls after Bundesbank leaves interest rates unchanged; graphs; table (S)

headline: REPUBLIC TO ACQUIRE 4 AUTO DEALERSHIP GROUPS
abstract: Republic Industries buys four groups of auto dealerships in Texas, Georgia, California and Ohio for undisclosed price, adding outlets with about $500 million in annual revenue to its nationwide sales network (S)

headline: FORTUNE BRANDS TO ACQUIRE ELECTROLUX CABINET UNIT
abstract: Fortune Brands Inc to buy Schrock Cabinet Co from Electrolux AB for $107.5 million in cash (S)

headline: Afghan Women Demanding End To Their Repression by Militants
abstract: Afghan women, who live as virtual prisoners in own homes, tell Unicef executive director Carol Bellamy they want end to their repression by militant Islamic Taliban Government, which they say is destroying already wounded country economically and socially; many who originally cast lot in civil war with Taliban as best hope for country's future now feel they are on front lines of battle for survival; say enforcement of purdah, custom in which women are secluded from men who are not members of their family, has caused extreme hardship; say Taliban has brushed aside their fears, and that even men who call themselves good Muslims also live in terror of seemingly unprovoked attacks by Islamic enforcers and are easily silenced; many families in country of 21 million have lost income not only of women but also of men who died in fighting, were thrown out of jobs in purges of government offices or left in flight of private businessmen and middle-class professionals; boys as well as girls are being denied education because many teachers were women who have not been replaced, and their male counterparts who remained in schools are often not paid and therefore do not show up; photos; map (M)

headline: Heineken Chooses Lowe & Partners
abstract: Heineken USA Inc names Lowe & Partners/SMS to handle advertising for its various beer brands, with combined billings estimated at $40 million; account had been handled by Wells BDDP (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Iran to make revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's works available on Internet, many of them in 16 languages; University of Washington offers cable television channel that broadcasts real-time, rush-hour traffic updates (S)

headline: 5 Women Gamers Rediscover Lost Loves
abstract: Regina Joseph article on a trip that she and four other women in field of digital media took to Harpers Ferry, W Va, to buy vintage video games at Home Amusement Co, largsst coin-operated machine retail business in US; photos (M)

headline: Treasuries Move Lower on Thin Volume as New Issues Arrive
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities are slightly lower in quiet trading; price of 30-year Treasury bond declines 9/32, to price of 104, and yield rises to 5.84 percent, from 5.82 percent on April 6; graph; chart (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE INC., Dallas, said its board had unanimously rejected an offer by the closely held Conquest partnership to acquire the restaurant chain for as much as $58 million in cash and debt.    GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its GE Capital Railcar Services unit had agreed to buy International Wagon Services Ltd., Bromley, England, a rail freight-car operator in Europe, for undisclosed terms.

headline: NEWS WATCH; Amazon Now Offering CD Music to Read By
abstract: Amazon.com, on-line bookstore, has expanded into audio CD business (S)

headline: Campbell Soup hopes a new campaign aimed at children will help bolster sagging sales.
abstract: Campbell Soup Co hopes new advertising campaign developed by J Brown/LMC Group aimed at children will help bolster sagging soup sales; new commercial exhorts children to save labels from Campbell products; their schools can redeem them for equipment from basketballs to computers to mini-vans; domestic soup sales have been flat or declining for years, and Campbell has been hurt by increase in sales of store-brand soups (L)

headline: Balkans Revisited
abstract: The last war in the Balkans lasted four years before President Clinton and NATO intervened. But now another part of the Balkans is aflame, and once again world powers are floundering in an effort to pressure Yugoslavia and contain the conflict.    News analysis, page A14.

headline: Annan Urges Formation of War Crimes Court
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Anna opens five-week conference in Rome to develop rules for permanent international tribunal that could prosecute individuals for crimes against humanity; urges establishment of global war crimes court as bulwark against evil and delegates from 156 countries to take firm stand; critical issue is how strong and independent court will be; US is seeking to limit its jurisdiction, arguing that American soldiers could face prosecution on politically motivated charges unless Security Council has say in what crimes are brought to trial (M)

headline: Underground Test Suggests India Seeks to Make a Variety of Nuclear Warheads
abstract: Underground nuclear tests suggest India seeks to develop variety of nuclear warheads, including hydrogen bombs, for various weapon systems; Western experts fear Pakistan will follow suit (S)

headline: Credit Suisse Buying Brazil Investment Bank
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston has acquired Brazil's leading investment bank, Garantia SA, for $675 million in cash and stock, making Swiss-American group largest underwriter and stock trader in that highly competitive emerging market (M)

headline: More Turmoil in Asia and Russia Lifts Blue-Chip Shares
abstract: Investors seeking to avoid the turmoil in Asian and Russian financial markets bought blue-chip stocks and Treasury bonds yesterday.    But technology issues -- led by Intel -- fell, pushing the Nasdaq composite index down almost 2 percent to its lowest level in almost three months.

headline: U.S. Pessimistic Before Middle East Talks
abstract: United States aides are pessimistic that meetings in London between State Sec Madeleine K Albright and Israeli and Palestinian leaders will lead to breakthrough; suggest Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu will not accept US call for roughly 13 percent withdrawal from West Bank (M)

headline: China Jobless Fuel a Growth Industry
abstract: Propaganda campaign in China urges former factory workers who cannot create their own work to swallow their pride and move into 'service' jobs; in practice, that usually means relatively menial positions that have often been filled by poor migrants from the countryside; Beijing and other large cities around the country have even issued new regulations banning rural migrants from all but most laborious occupations, hoping to force some of them to return home and increase opportunities for registered city residents; Yichang is in curious economic state: as nearest city to construction site of giant Three Gorges Dam, it is enjoying something of economic boom, with new banks and government offices and apartment blocks rising; boom appears to be thinly spread, overlaying rot of state-owned industries that used to dominate Yichang; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Treasury Yields Surge On Fear of Rising Rates  Investors fearful of a rise in interest rates sold bonds aggressively, pushing up the yield on the 30-year Treasury to 6.05 percent, from 5.94 percent on Friday, and contributing to a selloff in the stock market. It was the highest level in two months.    Bond market strategists attributed the selling to a report that the Federal Reserve was now leaning toward a rise in rates to suppress inflationary pressure. Even so, some said they saw little chance that the Fed would raise rates at the next meeting of its policy-making committee, on May 19. [Page D10.]

headline: Lounes Matoub, 42, Is Killed; Sang to Promote Berber Cause
abstract: Lounes Matoub, popular Algerian singer and Berber patriot who was kidnapped by Muslim militants in Algeria four years ago but was freed and lived mostly in France since, is killed in ambush near Algiers, apparently at hands of Islamic fundamentalists; demonstrations are held in Tizi-Ouzou, near his hometown; French Pres Jacques Chirac and others offer tributes; photo (M)

headline: Albania Calls In European Monitors to Watch Kosovo Border
abstract: Florian Raunig, Albanian-speaking Austrian, is head of four-member civilian monitoring group that has been posted by Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to assess conditions in lawless territory that runs along Albanian-Serbian border (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls for second day on growing market sentiment that production cutbacks by OPEC producers and others will not ease surplus; May contracts fall 23 cents, or 2 percent, to $15.22 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: OUTDOOR ADVERTISER BUYING DAME MEDIA, A BROADCASTER
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc agrees to acquire Dame Media Inc for $85 million in stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.43   5.72        3-month T-bills   4.94   4.92   5.22        6-month T-bills   5.11   5.05   5.45        10-yr. T-infl.   3.77   3.73   3.63        10-yr. T-note   5.78   5.65   6.90        30-yr. T-bond   6.05   5.94   7.11        Telephone bd.   7.18   7.12   8.16        Municipal bds.   5.42   5.34   5.98          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: I Say $70 Billion, and You Say $166 Billion
abstract: Article on proposed merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc focuses on reports of value of deal, which ranged from $70 billion to $166 billion; says after shares of Travelers fell on April 7, deal was worth $78 billion (M)

headline: Words of Warning in the NATO Battle: Senators Tilt at Europe's Future
abstract: Excerpts from Senate debate on expanding NATO to include Hungary, Poland and Czech Republic; photos (L)

headline: Republican Puts New Hurdle In Path of I.M.F. Financing
abstract: House majority leader, Dick Armey, urges fellow Republicans to reject Clinton Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for International Monetary Fund; says financing would encourage unchecked expansion of fund's lending that would cost US billions of dollars and weaken financial systems worldwide (M)

headline: VW Acts to Bolster Its Rolls-Royce Bid
abstract: Volkswagen AG, seeking to increase its chances of acquiring Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd, acquires engine supplier, Cosworth, from Rolls-Royce's parent, Vickers PLC, for $195 million (S)

headline: Computers: Hard to Use?
abstract: Howard A Karten letter on May 28 article disputes view that computers are hard for most people to use

headline: A Joining of Opposites Could Help Customers
abstract: Daimler-Benz-Chrysler Corp deal is essentially a merger of opposites; but after Chrysler's turn-on-a-dime managment is combined with German company's research and engineering bloodlines, customers should notice improvements in quality, performance, safety and perhaps price (L)

headline: HANDLEMAN TO ELIMINATE UP TO 1,000 JOBS AND SELL A UNIT
abstract: Handleman Co will cut 900 to 1,000 jobs, or 30 percent of its work force; company is selling its Sofsource educational-software unit to Learning Company Inc for $45 million; Handleman also says it will buy back up to $70 million of stock (S)

headline: Akzo Nobel to Acquire British Paint Maker
abstract: Akzo Nobel NV acquires Courtualds PLC for 1.83 billion pounds ($3.1 billion) in cash in deal that would make it world's largest producer of paints and coatings (S)

headline: BRADLEY REAL ESTATE BUYING MID-AMERICA REALTY
abstract: Bradley Real Estate Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Mid-America Realty Investments Inc. for around $87 million in securities and $66 million in assumed debt. Shareholders of Mid-America Realty, which is based in Omaha, will swap each of their 8.29 million shares for 0.42 share of Bradley convertible preferred stock with a par value of $25 each. The exchange ratio values Mid-America's shares at $10.50 each. The shares closed at $10.125 yesterday, down 43.75 cents, while shares of Bradley, based in Northbrook, Ill., slipped 6.25 cents, to $20.8125. Under the deal, Bradley will gain ownership of 25 shopping center properties, increasing its holdings to 88 properties.

headline: Coaxing From Clinton
abstract: President Clinton, whose 1994 overture to the leader of Sinn Fein helped bring the political wing of the I.R.A. to the peace table, was deeply involved as the Ulster talks concluded, urging both Catholics and Protestants to take risks for peace.    Article, page A4.

headline: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL AND BANCO FRANCES IN DEAL
abstract: American International Group Inc plans to buy 70 percent stake in Argentine consumer finance company, Compania Financiera Argentina SA, from Banco Frances SA for $49 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROYAL GROUP TECHNOLOGIES LTD., Woodbridge, Ontario, a maker of vinyl building products, agreed to buy Imperial Oil Ltd.'s Sarnia, Ontario, resin plant for the equivalent of $58 million.

headline: Coca-Cola Asks the Dismissal Of Federal Suit Filed by Pepsi
abstract: Lawyers for Coca-Cola Co file motion to dismiss lawsuit brought by Pepsico Inc earlier this month, in which Pepsi contended that Coke unfairly pressed food-service distributors to provide only Coke to restaurants, theater chains, stadiums and other places that serve what industry calls fountain soft drinks (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR NEARS 140 YEN.  The yen fell to its third consecutive seven-year low on steep drops in Asian stock markets and worsening economic problems in Japan. In New York, the dollar rose to 139.70 yen from 138.90.

headline: New-Home Sales Fell in March, As Months-Long Rise Is Ended
abstract: Commerce Department says sales of new single-family homes fell in March for first time in four months; sales fell 5 percent, to annual rate of 828,000 units; average price of new home climbed to record $183,500 in March from $179,600 in February, though median price fell to $153,900 from $155,000; graphs (M)

headline: OLD KENT FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE FIRST EVERGREEN
abstract: Old Kent Financial Corp signs definitive agreement to acquire First Evergreen Corp for about $488 million in stock (S)

headline: Dalai Lama Notes Shifts in China; Backs Clinton's Softer Line
abstract: Tibet's spiritual leader, Dalai Lama, distances himself from militant Tibetans and some international human rights organizations by saying that Clinton Adm is on right track in muting public criticism of China, interview (S)

headline: New Serb Assault On Albania Rebels
abstract: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has started a major campaign to wipe out a separatist rebel movement in the Serbian province of Kosovo, senior NATO officials and Western diplomats say.    The campaign involves several thousand heavily armed special police officers and soldiers backed by artillery batteries. It has escalated swiftly during the last three days and seems set to extinguish the faint hope of a negotiated settlement between Serbs and Kosovo's ethnic Albanian population.

headline: Unexpected Profit at Tele-Communications
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc reports profit in first quarter, its first in more than two years; says it had net income in quarter of $238 million, compared to loss of $84 million in quarter year ago; revenue rose 5.6 percent, to $1.50 billion (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH TO BEGIN OFFERING TV SERVICE TO ATLANTA
abstract: BellSouth Corp to announce it has begun to offer television service to Atlanta residents using digital wireless technology; company says it will offer service, which includes 160 channels, to more than 700,000 households; service's introduction is expected to be good news for Americast, television venture of BellSouth, Ameritech, GTE, Southern New England Telecommunications and Walt Disney Co; Americast is locked in legal battle with SBC Communications Inc, which has withdrawn from group, over whether SBC owes venture more money (S)

headline: U.S. Expresses Support for NATO Action to Halt Serb Attacks
abstract: United States says it will back British-sponsored United Nations resolution to authorize NATO military intervention in Kosovo, Serbia and press NATO to speed up planning for such action; says action is not imminent; joins European Union in imposing ban on new investment in Serbia and freeze on Yugoslav and Serbian government assets abroad because of crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo (M)

headline: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
abstract: Letter from Paul Henderson says April 2 article on declining ranks of Mac users was useless and served no purpose (S)

headline: ALLIED DIGITAL AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $68 MILLION
abstract: Allied Digital Technologies Corp agrees to be acquired by investor group for $5 a share, or $68 million; investor group consists of 399 Venture Partners Inc and members of Allied management (S)

headline: French Insurer's Profit Tops Estimate
abstract: Groupe des Assurances Nationales earns 170 million francs ($28.3 million), higher-than-expected profit in second half of last year, compared with 4.7-billion-franc loss in corresponding period last year (S)

headline: For Americans, an Indirect Route to the Party
abstract: A CASE can be made that one way for Americans to invest in Europe is to buy stock in American companies that do big chunks of business here.    The argument goes like this: As European nations go about marrying their national currencies, the wedding will be catered in large measure from the United States.

headline: U.S. Urges Indonesia To Reform
abstract: United States, in its first public insistence that Pres Suharto loosen his iron grip on Indonesia, says nation needs 'political reform' to regain stability; decides not to make reform condition for continuing economic aid, holding aid is overwhelmingly humanitarian; Sec Madeleine K Albright says Indonesia needs to break emerging cycle of violence; deplores deaths of students during demonstration (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MERCHANTS MUTUAL INSURANCE CO., Buffalo, held preliminary discussions about acquiring the shares of Merchants Group Inc., Buffalo, that it does not already own. Merchants Group is the parent of a property casualty insurer called Merchants Insurance Co. of New Hampshire Inc.

headline: Business Travel; Air fares between the United States and Japan are falling, partly because of an aviation accord.
