abstract: Air fares between US and Japan have dropped dramatically in last week, as most carriers have joined in sale begun by UAL's United Airlines; sale is partly result of aviation agreement reached earlier this year between two countries; study by J P Power & Associates finds Trans World Airlines ranked number 1 in customer satisfaction for long domestic flights and America West for short hauls; Royal Jordanian Airline has upgraded its business class, which it now calls Crown Class; Comair, a Delta regional partner, will begin jet service on June 1 between Islip, NY, and its home base of Cincinnati, with three nonstop flights daily; guests paying full published rate can get 24 hours for their money at Ritz-Carlton's seven hotels in Asia; program noted; company called Body Charge at Images of California is offering mini-massages at Los Angeles International Airport; cost is $20 for 15 minute massage (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: ADVANCED TISSUE SCIENCES' SHARES PLUMMET BY 44%
abstract: Shares of Advanced Tissue Sciences Inc fall 44 percent after Food and Drug Administration orders company to conduct new clinical trial before granting approval of its new Dermagraft skin-replacement product (S)

headline: In Support of Apartheid: Poison Whisky and Sterilization
abstract: Witnesses tell Truth and Reconciliation Commission about biological and chemical program that South African Government used to murder political opponents during apartheid era; photo of Dr Wouter Basson, leader of program who is facing array of criminal charges (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark and other major European currencies rise as dollar falls in reaction to heavy selloff of American stocks and bonds; dollar falls to 1.7876 marks in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: Broadcom First-Day Shares Jump 123%
abstract: Broadcom Corp's initial public offering is one of biggest ever; shares jump 123 percent from offering price, ending day at $53.625; Broadcom, small semiconductor company, was founded in 1991 by Henry T Nicholas 3d and Henry Samueli; they now own stakes in company worth $600 million each (M)

headline: In Mexico and the U.S., New Visas Produce Stress
abstract: US authorities, in sweeping new effort to control travel across Mexican border, have begun calling in border-crossing documents held for decades by millions of Mexicans to replace them with high-tech visas carrying digital fingerprint; documents being replaced allow over 100 million legal border crossings each year by business people, tourists and shoppers from Mexico; hope is that new cards, which State Dept calls laser visas, will help screen out criminals and illegal immigrants; replacement of old border-crossing cards has many Mexicans upset by $45 processing fee and nervous that their applications may be denied; map; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Agog at Clinton, a Hero (Like Nixon)
abstract: Pres Clinton is being lionized in China in advance of his visit as far-sighted statesman who shifted from initial attacks on China to current policy of close engagement; official media extol his courage in face of China-haters who are trying to derail emerging 'strategic partnership'; photos (M)

headline: Compliments of U.S. Investors; New Activism Shakes Europe's Markets
abstract: American brand of shareholder activism is spreading abroad; investors in Europe are beginning to organize against companies whose policies they feel are not in their best interests; European companies are under pressure from small investors, and from foreign investors; profiles of several European shareholder activists: Colette Neuville, founder of France's largest shareholder association, Adamo Gentile, head of Italian minority investor assn, and Sophie L'Helias, lawyer who led group of minority investors in battle against French Govt; photos (L)

headline: Peril of Politics in Japan
abstract: Sheryl WuDunn analysis contends that Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto is weak leader who cannot end Japan's economic slide; maintains that Hashimoto is governing with fragile coalition of parties and factions that seldom agree with each other, so Government finds it difficult to shift economic direction even as it becomes clear that Japanese ship of state is heading toward iceberg; says Japanese system is based on consensus, which has always made decision-making difficult in crisis (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls sharply after Group of Seven decides against helping Japan strengthen its currency; dollar costs 131.79 yen in New York, up nearly 2 percent from 129.36; graph; chart (S)

headline: Weight-Loss Drug Shows Some Success in Humans
abstract: Dr Andrew S Greenberg reports clinical trials found Amgen Inc's anti-obesity drug leptin causes weight loss in some people, American Diabetes Association meeting, Chicago; leptin is produced by fat cells in body and helps keep weight in check (M)

headline: Charles Schwab Ends Relationship With Lowe
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co and San Francisco office of Lowe & Partners/SMS say they ended their relationship after five and a half months (S)

headline: Microsoft Alternatives
abstract: Raymond W Townsend letter, commenting on Government suit against Microsoft Corp, says the only chance of real competition is for all preloaded software to be eliminated from computers

headline: Bouafle Journal; Age-Old Curse of Slavery Alive in the Ivory Coast
abstract: Wealth of Ivory Coast, West Africa's most prosperous country, rests to large extent on backs of poorly paid immigrants whose labor has helped make it agricultural giant; thousands of migrant laborers, most of them children from desperately poor hinterlands of neighboring Mali and Burkino Faso, end up working fields as slaves after being lured by unscrupulous businessmen; map; photo (M)

headline: Of Microsoft and Market Forces
abstract: ''Why Microsoft Should Be Left Alone'' (Viewpoint, May 24), by Bhaskar Chakravorti, drew varied responses from readers. Mr. Chakravorti, a senior member of the global consulting practice of the Monitor Company in Cambridge, Mass., argued that technology markets require no more regulatory intervention than other markets -- and that Microsoft has endured not by crushing competition but by finding ways to make challengers' products its own. Some readers essentially agreed; some saw other issues at work in Microsoft's fight with the Government.    To the Editor:

headline: U.S. AND 20 STATES FILE SUITS CLAIMING MICROSOFT BLOCKS COMPETITION OVER INTERNET
abstract: Justice Department and 20 state Attorneys General file two broad, aggressive antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corp, launching most concerted government attack on single company in generation; charge Microsoft uses its monopoly in personal computer operating systems to win control of Internet and software products, particularly Internet browsers; Justice Department suit charges Microsoft of having once approached then-infant rival Netscape Communications Corp with offer to divide Internet market; Atty Gen Janet Reno, announcing suits with three state Attorneys General, holds Microsoft's business practices restricted choices available to consumers around world; Microsoft chairman William H Gates scores suits; Asst Atty Gen Joel I Klein says suits do not try to block release of latest version of Windows operating system; Microsoft begins shipping product; photos (L)

headline: Adding Software Can Add Trouble
abstract: Adding new versions of computer software can create so-called 'bit rot,' in which the updating of one program creates problems throughout the system; bit rot is an issue in Microsoft's battle with the Justice Department over its inclusion of new version of Internet Explorer as part of Windows 95 operating system, which led to many complaints that program caused systemwide havoc (M)

headline: Dow Crosses 9,000 for the First Time, Then Backs Away
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average passes 9,000 points for first time before retreating and ending slightly lower as investors take profits; Dow, which rises as high as 9,030.49, closes down 3.23 points, at 8,983.41; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 2.69 points, to 1,122.70, and New York Stock Exchange composite gains 1.04, to 583.08; Nasdaq composite index edges up 2.44, to record 1,855.40; graph; chart (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MELLON BANK CORP., Pittsburgh, said it would buy Clair Odell Group, Plymouth Meeting, Pa., a private property and casualty insurance broker, for an undisclosed sum.    CROSSMANN COMMUNITIES INC., Indianapolis, a builder of single-family homes, has acquired the privately held Pinehurst Builders Inc., Myrtle Beach, S.C., for $29.1 million in cash and stock.

headline: U.N. Council Looks at Rise in Number of Children in Combat
abstract: UN Security Council debates rapid increase in number of child soldiers worldwide and what, if anything, can be done to keep children away from combat; experts say as many as 300,000 children in at least 50 countries are directly involved in conflict in violation of international treaties; photo (M)

headline: S.& P. Lowers Ratings Of 3 Japanese Airlines
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers ratings of Japanese airlines Japan Airlines Co, All Nippon Airways and Japan Air System Co (S)

headline: Administration Details Defense Of Controls on Satellite Exports
abstract: Clinton Adm mounts most detailed defense of its satellite export control policy; three top officials say that China's military has not benefited from transfers of sensitive American technology and that safeguards are in place to prevent any such leakage (M)

headline: The Life and Times Of the Father of Ma Bell
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews two books: Alexander Graham Bell: A Life, by James Mackay, and God Is My Broker: A Monk-Tycoon Reveals the 7 1/2 Laws of Spiritual and Financial Growth, by Christopher Buckley and John Tierney; photo (M)

headline: Britain's Yellow Pages blanketing London with humor and yellow in a new campaign.
abstract: British Telecommunications PLC's Yellow Pages unit has embarked on $10 million advertising campaign across London to show Yellow Pages brand is timely and hip referral guide rather than just a household staple; humorous campaign was designed by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO (Advertising column) (L)

headline: TBWA Executive To Join Petersen
abstract: Stacey Lippman, managing partner and corporate media director at TBWA Chiat/Day, says he will leave agency to join Petersen Companies in new position of president for Petersen brand and marketing; Annette Cerbone is promoted to assume Lippman's duties (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German currency falls in reaction to economic crisis in Russia, Germany's biggest borrower and trading partner; graphs (S)

headline: Israelis Ask Arafat's Help to Stop a Hamas Attack
abstract: Israel sends intelligence chief, Ami Ayalon, to Gaza to persuade Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat that Israel was not involved in assassination of Hamas bomb-maker Muhyiaddin al-Sharif and to block possible attack by Hamas to avenge his death (S)

headline: Thyssen Agrees to Sell German Phone Business
abstract: Thyssen AG says it will sell its Plusnet fixed-line telephone business to Esprit Telecom Group PLC for 315 million marks ($180 million) (S)

headline: Communities To Receive $115 Billion, Citigroup Says
abstract: Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc announce that they will give $115 billion in loans to low- and moderate-income people over 10 years as part of their proposed $70 billion merger; amount promised is less than what some community activists and others had expected (S)

headline: Akzo Nobel Makes Bid For Courtaulds of Britain
abstract: Akzo Nobel NV of Netherlands wants to buy Courtaulds PLC of Britain and will pay $3.03 billion (US) in cash to become world's largest maker of paints and coatings (S)

headline: Ex-General Leads in a Crucial Vote in Siberia, but Faces a Runoff
abstract: Aleksandr I Lebed enhances his presidential hopes by winning place in runoff election for governor of Krasnoyarsk, vast Russian region; partial tally shows he leads pack, with 43 percent of vote; Valery M Zubov, Kremlin-backed incumbent, is second, with 36 percent (M)

headline: Sir Ian MacGregor, 85, Bane Of Mine Workers in Britain
abstract: Sir Ian MacGregor, industrialist who forced Britain's coal miners to capitulate after their long and bitter strike in mid 1980's, dies at age 85; photo (L)

headline: Indonesian Currency Gains Against Dollar
abstract: Indonesian rupiah climbs to its highest level against US dollar in two months during Asian trading as market cautiously welcomes Indonesia's latest pact with International Monetary Fund; dollar sells at 7,550 rupiah, its lowest level since Feb 13; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Revoking Licenses to Export Firearms to Britain
abstract: Clinton Administration notifies British Government that it is revoking pending licenses for export of American firearms to British companies; says revocation is first step in plan to halt sale of firearms by American companies to all 15 members of European Union until they adopt laws to insure that weapons are not re-exported to terrorists and war zones (M)

headline: F.T.C. to Call for Laws to Protect Children on Line
abstract: Federal Trade Commission is expected to censure Internet industry in report to Congress for doing virtually nothing to insure adequate consumer privacy protection on line; agency, in departure from Clinton Administration's hands-off approach to Internet, will call for legislation that would require sites on World Wide Web to obtain parental consent before collecting personal information from children; Repr Edward J Markey praises reports; photo (M)

headline: Inside Intel, The Future Is Riding on A New Chip
abstract: Intel Corp, seeking to maintain its dominace of computer chip business, is developing new generation of chips that will attack market that has so far eluded Intel: very high end of mainframe computers, Internet Web servers, supercomputers and scientific work stations; is betting on future in which market for microprocessors is increasingly fragmented, planning distinct offerings for each fragment; hopes high profit margins on high-end chips can offset increasingly narrow margins on other chips; risks of strategy cited; table; photos (L)

headline: A Surprising Jump in Japanese Joblessness
abstract: Fastest rise in unemployment in Japan in 30 years has stunned even most pessimistic forecasters and reinforced fear that Government's economic stimulus plan announced last week could prove insufficient; unemployment reached record 3.9 percent in March, up from previous record of 3.6 percent in February (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: TUESDAY  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.  The Commerce Department reports on wholesale inventories for February.  The Federal Reserve reports on consumer credit for February. Analysts expect an increase of $3.1 billion.

headline: India Calls for Talks On a Treaty to Limit All Atomic Arsenals
abstract: India appeals for early negotiations on new global treaty limiting nuclear arsenals that would include all nuclear weapons states; similar proposals made over many years have been rejected by five established nuclear powers, including US; statement renews other proposals for limiting nuclear arsenals of India and Pakistan; includes suggestion for treaty binding both nations not to be first to use nuclear weapons against each other; says India is committed to joining in negotiations in Geneva on international treaty that would limit production of nuclear weapons fuel; reiterates pledge to observe voluntary moratorium on nuclear testing; reformulation of new offer and suggestions for early negotiations are seen by Western diplomats as further sign that India is moving toward defusing crisis that has gripped subcontinent for past three weeks since it carried out series of underground nuclear tests (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Unit's Woes Hurt Affiliates' Shares
abstract: Shares in several Mitsubishi group companies tumble in wake of severe financial troubles at one affiliate, Optec Dai-Ichi Denko Co; following tradition in Japan, several stronger companies within Mitsubishi conglomerate have pledged to help Optec restructure (S)

headline: New Reports Show Little Reason Not to Be Optimistic on Economy
abstract: Conference Board says its consumer confidence index fell to 134.3 points in March from 137.4 in February; National Association of Purchasing Management reports its monthly index of manufacturing activity in Chicago region, seen as bellwether for the economy, unexpectedly rose to 59.5 points in March from 57.8 in February; Federal Reserve's policy makers hold interest rates steady at meeting of Open Market Committee, which has not changed borrowing costs for more than a year (M)

headline: DuPont to Spin Off 20% of Conoco, the Rest to Be Sold Later
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours announces that it will divest itself of 20 percent of its $22 billion Conoco oil subsidiary in tax-free stock offering that could bring in as much as $5 billion; DuPont's chief executive Charles O Holliday Jr says he will dispose of the rest of Conoco as soon as practical (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.52   5.51        3-month T-bills   5.06   5.08   5.06        6-month T-bills   5.14   5.16   5.25        10-yr. T-infl.   3.76   3.76   3.57        10-yr. T-note   5.65   5.64   6.67        30-yr. headline: Game Boy's Toy Camera: Serious Business
abstract: J C Herz reviews digital camera available with Nintendo's handheld gaming device; discusses myriad ways to use images; photos (M)

headline: The Target Of Violence In a Time Of Wrath
abstract: Violence against Indonesia's ethnic Chinese residents, who make up about 5 percent of population but own 75 percent of nation's wealth, has been ugly sideshow in every Indonesian political upheaval since colonial days; Jakarta's Chinese are fleeing or cowering in shops in wake of looting and arson by angry mobs; fear trip to airport after attacks by mobs searching cars for Chinese passengers (M)

headline: Media Talk; Just Talking: Public Broadcasting
abstract: Rep W J (Billy) Tauzin to address Public Broadcasting Service annual meeting, Miami; will propose bill that could increase Federal funding for public broadcasting and would set up blue-ribbon commission to weigh future of such broadcasting, including possibility of trust fund to support it; photo (M)

headline: Lloyds TSB Expects Loss In Sale of Agency Group
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group PLC says sale of its Black Horse Agencies Group to Bradford & Bingley Building Society will result in net loss of 100 million pounds, or $167 million (S)

headline: CANADIAN COMPANY TO BUY REFRIGERATED STORAGE IN U.S.
abstract: Associated Freezers Ltd, Canadian operator of refrigerated warehouses, agrees to acquire assets of unidentified company in US for $42 million (S)

headline: Opportunity Beyond the Euro's Borders
abstract: EUROLAND may loom as the most visible temptation for those keen on new investment opportunities in Europe over the next few years. But strategists here are keeping their eyes on the periphery of the euro -- the economies and markets of nations that haven't yet joined the party and others on the edge of the new united Europe.    For starters, British traders don't have to look far from home. The City of London, after all, is Europe's prime financial center -- and is likely to remain so, whatever the outcome of Britain's flirtations with joining the European Monetary Union. Moreover, Britain's companies are seen as a decade or more ahead of many others in Europe in restructuring their way to competitiveness.

headline: In Preparing for Euro, the Laggards Are Likely to Lose Market Share : Corporate Europe Is Running Behind
abstract: FRANKFURT—  - Corporate Europe should be the first sector of society to learn what it means to have a shiny Trojan currency — a hopeful symbol of pan-European unity that many expect will sneak in with it a raft of painful economic and social changes.

headline: Rome Journal; A Delphic Oracle Has Seen the Future, and Likes It
abstract: Interview with Italian business tycoon Giovanni Agnelli, who says he welcomes change to single European currency and to more open markets; map; photo (M)

headline: Seek Reconciliation With Jews, Pope Tells Christians in Austria
abstract: Pope John Paul II says European Christians have moral obligation to fully reconcile with Jews, speech, Vienna; audience includes former Pres Kurt Waldheim, who has been closely linked to Nazis (S)

headline: A New Executive-Recruiting Service on the Web
abstract: Wall Street Journal and Korn/Ferry International will introduce service that seeks to recruit midlevel managers via Internet and match them with prospective employers; services automates recruitment process by using software designed to match person's skills and interests with job types (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.29   5.62        3-month T-bills   4.95   4.93   5.15        6-month T-bills   5.04   5.03   5.36        10-yr. T-infl.   3.73   3.74   3.64        10-yr. T-note   5.69   5.67   6.92        30-yr. T-bond   5.98   5.96   7.13        Telephone bd.   7.15   7.13   8.16        Municipal bds.   5.35   5.33   5.97          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: HONG KONG ELECTS NEW LEGISLATURE
abstract: Hong Kong voters turn out in record numbers to elect new legislature, defying torrential rains and returning to office pro-democracy politicians ousted by China; pro-democracy leader Martin Lee, whose party won at least 9 of 20 directly elected seats and about half of popular vote, urges China to take heed of results; exit poll shows three main pro-democracy parties won about 16 of directly elected seats; photo (M)

headline: A Little Border War Over Mexican-U.S. Phone Traffic
abstract: AT&T and MCI Communications, fiercely competing for business of Hispanic-Americans who make $2 billion worth of international phone calls a year to friends and family back home, are asking Federal Communications Commission to overturn its approval of long-distance service in United States by joint venture between Telefonos de Mexico and Sprint; MCI has also asked United States trade representative to bring its complaints against Telemex to World Trade Organization; AT&T and MCI say Telemex wants to charge them too much to complete calls from United States to Mexico (M)

headline: SYMBOL WITHDRAWS ITS SWEETENED OFFER FOR TELXON
abstract: Symbol Technologies Inc withdraws its sweetened bid to buy Telxon Corp after Telxon rejects offer as too low (S)

headline: Ban on Film Has Poland Debating Censorship
abstract: Documentary that takes caustic look at Polish operations of American direct-sales company Amway has set off debate in Warsaw about press freedom; Polish-made film Welcome to Life, which is dominated by hard-sell pep rallies that are hallmark of company, was stopped from being shown on television by court order sought by company; Amway argues that in seeking injunction it wants to protect its reputation; over 50 Polish editors and journalists have sent petition to Pres Aleksandr Kwasniewski, contending that successful court action is reminiscent of old Communist way of doing things (M)

headline: MOLSON BUYS OUT PARTNER IN CANADIAN VENTURE
abstract: Molson Companies buys 50 percent stake owned by Australian partner, Foster's Brewing Group Ltd, in Molson Breweries, beer makers' joint venture, for $1 billion (Canadian), or $680 million (US), giving it sole ownership of Canada's biggest brewer; Molson says it will buy Foster's 24.95 percent interest in Coors Canada partnership (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Indonesia in Debt Pact With Foreign Bankers  Indonesia and a group of foreign bankers agreed on a framework for rescheduling nearly $80 billion in corporate and bank debt that has become one of the biggest barriers to restarting the nation's economy.

headline: Sapporo Journal; Hokkaido Catches Cold: Will All of Japan Sneeze?
abstract: Japan's economic distress is particularly acute on Hokkaido, whichepitomizes traditional Japanese distaste for entrpreneurship and fondness for Government spending and regulation; island, among slowest Japanese areas to modernize and link up with rest of world, has depended heavily on Government public works projects; map; photo (M)

headline: With Few Layoffs Planned, a Collective Sigh of Relief
abstract: Employees at Citicorp and Travelers Group are happy about proposed merger; they say they do not fear losing their jobs because there is not much overlap between companies; two companies say there will be few layoffs; photo (L)

headline: Sudan Foes Resume Talks As Famine Stalks South
abstract: Round of peace talks between Islamic Government of Sudan and main rebel faction begins against backdrop of looming famine in south because of protracted civil war; Sudanese Government, in gesture to UN relief workers and rebels, gives permission for several extra cargo planes to fly food and other supplies to worst-hit Bahr el Ghazal region (M)

headline: A DOWNSIZED ARMY LEANS ON RESERVES FOR DUTY IN BOSNIA
abstract: NATO-led United States peacekeeping mission in Bosnia increasingly relies on reservists and National Guard members; peacekeeping missions tax active-duty Army and draw on many specialities, like civil affairs, now found predominantly in Reserve; use of reservists and National Guards to compensate for thinning active Army ranks raises questions of whether part-time soldiers are adequately trained and whether frequent mobilizations will discourage people from joining; some reservists in Bosnia say they have been assigned tours of over six months, far longer than average, upsetting their families and employers; map; photo (M)

headline: Sale of Russian Oil Company Gets No Bidders
abstract: Long-awaited auction of Rosneft, Russia's last big oil company, ends unceremoniously without any bids, in setback for country's economy and jittery financial markets; failure is embarrassment for new Prime Min Sergei Kiriyenko and young team who had pressed ahead with auction despite growing anxiety over economy; is likely to have big impact on Russia's financial markets--keeping stock market in downward course, prompting investors to unload Treasury bills, and making it much harder for Central Bank to prop up ruble (M)

headline: Jose Pena Gomez, 61, Rare Black Dominican Figure, Dies
abstract: Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, three-time candidate for President of Dominican Republic who rose from childhood of extreme poverty to become one of most prominent black political figures in Latin America, dies at age 61; photo (M)

headline: AMERICOLD LOGISTICS TO BUY CARMAR FOR $144 MILLION
abstract: Americold Logistics Inc agrees to buy Carmar Group for $144 million in cash and assumption of $14 million of debt, extending its position as nation's largest provider of cold storage warehouse space; Americold is 60 percent owned by Vornado Realty Trust and rest is owned by Crescent Real Estate Equities Co (S)

headline: Effie Awards Are Presented
abstract: M&M/Mars division of Mars Inc and its ad agency, BBDO New York, win top prize when New York chapter of American Marketing Association presents its annual Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness in advertising; other winners noted (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Palladium falls 2.8 percent, eradicating most of advance from previous day, on indications that Russia may resume exports sooner than expected; chart (S)

headline: Lucent Lists Charges For 2 Acquisitions
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc expects to take $668 million in charges this quarter for its acquisitions of networking equipment maker Yurie Systems Inc and German software maker Optimay GmbH (S)

headline: As Top Dissident Lands in U.S., China Is Hoping to Score Points
abstract: China frees Wang Dan, leader of abortive 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy movement, and sends him into exile in US; hopes release, repeatedly requested by US as tangible sign of progress on sticky issue of human rights, will score points with US prior to Pres Clinton's upcoming visit; says Wang, who was serving 11-year sentence on charges of conspiracy to subvert state, was freed on medical parole; rights advocates in China and elsewhere welcome release; are worried it could lead to reduction in international pressure for systematic change in China, where open opponents of Communist rule are readily imprisoned, often without trial or public attention; Wang arrives in Detroit, where he is hospitalized for medical evaluation; photo (M)

headline: On the Road to Talks: Israeli Pace Annoys U.S.
abstract: Steven Erlanger analysis notes that US negotiator Dennis B Ross made some headway during his recent meetings with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, but Sec of State Madeleine K Albright said that it was 'not nearly enough' for breakthrough in impasse; contends that stalemate is not only damaging Israel's position in Middle East but Washington's too; photo (M)

headline: TYCO INTERNATIONAL ADDS EUROPEAN SECURITY UNIT
abstract: Tyco International Ltd to buy CIPE France SA (S)

headline: WOOLWORTH TO SHUT 82 KINNEY STORES IN CANADA
abstract: Woolworth Corp plans to close 82 money-losing Kinney Shoe stores in Canada and dismiss 600 employees as it focuses on its profitable Foot Locker, Champs and other sporting-goods chains (S)

headline: Both Sides in the Kosovo Conflict Seem Determined to Ignore Reality
abstract: Rebels in Kosovo province and Serbian forces seeking to quash them seem oblivious to reality of their positions; rebels naively insist they can muster enough power to defend towns against mechanized assault by Yugoslav troops, even though their forces are made up of poorly trained volunteers with light weapons; Serbia seems intent on ignoring long-range impact of their fury, provoked by conterinsurgency sweeps that have left more than 300 dead and displaced 80,000; attitudes are evident in battle for Junik, one of villages held by Kosovo Liberation Army rebels; photo; map (M)

headline: For 47 Years, a Lobby Group With Muscle Has Tirelessly Tended U.S.-Israeli Ties
abstract: Article on American Israel Public Affairs Committee notes that after recent lobbying effort by Aipac, 81 Senators signed letter urging Pres Clinton not to go public with US proposal for Israeli withdrawal from West Bank that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyhau opposed (M)

headline: At the End of a Long Trek, Ulster's Apostle of Peace Is Still Trekking
abstract: John Hume, most influential mainstream Catholic leader in Northern Ireland, has for 30 years been principal champion of peace settlement; his indefatigable campaigning is credited with securing new peace agreement; Hume trudges through towns and villages urging voters to approve accord; photo (S)

headline: PARAGON IN $581 MILLION DEAL FOR MARINER
abstract: Paragon Health Network Inc will acquire Mariner Health Group Inc for about $581 million in stock, plus some assumed debt (S)

headline: 30-Year Treasury Is Off Sharply As Fears Re-emerge About Rates
abstract: Yield of 30-year Treasury bond drops 1 14/32, to price of 101 2/32, with yield rising to 6.05 percent, from 5.94 percent on April 24; yield reaches its highest level in two months after report in Wall Street Journal that Federal Reserve officials are pondering increase in interest rates; chart (M)

headline: Israelis Accused in Killing
abstract: Hamas and Palestinian officials accuse Israel of assassinating a suspected Hamas bomb maker, Muhyiaddin al-Sharif, on West Bank (S)

headline: Pol Pot's Body Is Shown to Reporters in Jungle Hideout
abstract: Five foreign journalists are escorted by Khmer Rouge guerrillas across Thai border into northern Cambodia to confirm death of Pol Pot, 73-year-old Khmer Rouge founder; Pol Pot's comrades say he died of heart attack; reporters say they saw no signs of violence, but questions remain about circumstances of his death; Khmer Rouge officers say Pol Pot's wife discovered his body when she went to tuck in mosquito net around small cot where he slept in sparsely furnished room; photo (M)

headline: Russian-Fueled Rally Lifts Price Of Palladium Past That of Gold
abstract: Price of palladium rises to 18-year-high; main cause of rally, which sent spot price in London up $36.50, to $332.50 an ounce, is potential turmoil in Russia, which has halted delivery of palladium from there all year; Russia is world's biggest producer of palladium; graph (M)

headline: 5 Attractions for Summer Joy Riding
abstract: Kirsty Sucato rates Batman & Robin: The Chiller, new roller coaster at Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson, NJ (S)

headline: NBC Ends Ban on 'Dirty Work' Ads
abstract: NBC president, Bob Wright, agrees to let the movie Dirty Work buy commercials on network; Don Ohlmeyer, president of NBC's West Coast division, banned such ads because of his dispute with film's star, Norm Macdonald; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Public Ambition of A Private Firm
abstract: Market Place column on future direction of Goldman, Sachs & Co as its partners debate whether to turn Wall Street's premier private investment bank into public company; says strategic plan drawn up by Goldman's co-chief executive Herny M Paulson Jr explores ways that Goldman, as public company, could rapidly expand in areas in which it considers itself small or weak; holds among most likely acquisitions targets: a major American or European asset managment company or a Japanese brokerage house; says some Goldman bankers say firm should also consider alliance with Daiwa Securities, Japan's second-largest broker and only leader there that has yet to find a partner; holds Goldman wants to add to mutual funds and other assets it manages so that it can rely more on recurring fees and less on volatile trading and underwriting revenues (M)

headline: Russia Isn't Likely to Receive More Funds Now, I.M.F. Says
abstract: International Monetary Fund warns Russia that it does not plan to provide $10 billion to $15 billion in additional assistance that Kremlin is seeking; no nations have announced any intention to provide extra help, although they might do so if fund agreed to provide more assistanceand Russia's economy continued to deteriorate (M)

headline: Japan Airlines Expects Net Profit for Year
abstract: Japan Airlines Co expects to report net profit of 14 billion yen for fiscal year ending March 1999 after switching to more lucrative routes in China, Europe and United States (S)

headline: Australian Far-Right Party May Have Impact on Economy
abstract: MELBOURNE—  Battered by changes they cannot control, including fears of being swamped by Asian migrants fleeing the region's economic crisis and Asian imports made irresistibly cheap by currency depreciation, Australians are turning to a far-right political party in such large numbers that it could upset the country's policy of further liberalizing its economy and moving closer to Asia, officials and analysts say.

headline: Frenchman Gets Big Stake In Christie's
abstract: Wealthy French takeover investor Francois Pinault has bought 29.1 percent of Christie's, raising prospect that ownership of famed London auction house could pass from British hands for first time in its 232 years; under agreement, Pinault paid undisclosed sum for 49.4-million-shares stake to Abe Inc, trust established by British financier Joseph Lewis; sale makes Pinault Christie's largest shareholder and gives him 27.2 percent of voting rights; Pinault's share is valued at $243.2 million; officials at Christie's are taken by surprise at the news and say it is premature to say whether Pinault will join the board; under British law, if Pinault were to increase his stake to 30 percent he would be required to declare his intentions to acquire Christie's; news of Pinault's purchase sends shock waves through art world; photo (L)

headline: Math Drills That Imitate Video Games
abstract: Alice Keim reviews educational mathematics software program from Learning Co; photo (M)

headline: T CELL SCIENCES IN $70 MILLION DEAL FOR VIRUS RESEARCH
abstract: T Cell Sciences Inc will acquire Virus Research Institute Inc for $70 milion in stock and warrants; combined company will be called Avant Immunotherapeutics Inc (S)

headline: FIRST-QUARTER FILM SALES IN U.S. DOWN BY 24%
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says first-quarter US film sales fell 24 percent, more than previously disclosed, because Kodak changed way it accounts for some promotional activities (S)

headline: It Takes a President To Overpay the I.R.S.
abstract: *Detailed examination of income tax returns filed by Pres and Mrs Clinton for both 1997 and 1996; over two years, they paid $291,755 in Federal income taxes, but they could have paid $167,532 less by having royalties from Mrs Clinton's book, It Takes a Village, sent directly from publisher to charitable fund instead of taking money as income, paying taxes and giving away difference; charities would have collected 22 percent more than $840,000 they received; if book royalties had not flowed through Clintons' accounts, they would have owed $41,865 in Federal income taxes, a savings of $50,099; photos (M)

headline: SEAGRAM AIMS TO RAISE $3.6 BILLION IN TROPICANA SALE
abstract: Seagram Co files with Securities and Exchange Commission to sell its entire Tropicana juice business to public, raising as much as $3.6 billion; Seagram unit will sell 95.1 percent of common stock in Tropicana Products Inc through initial public offering; unit will sell other 4.9 percent if underwriters need additional shares to meet excess orders (S)

headline: Favorable Government Data Spur a Treasury Securities Rally
abstract: Treasury securities surge for their biggest rally in six months, reacting to Government data showing surprisingly low inflation; price of 30-year bonds is up 1 24/32, to 102 16/32; charts (M)

headline: BANKBOSTON IN DEAL FOR BANKAMERICA UNIT
abstract: BankBoston Corp to pay $800 million for BankAmerica Corp's securities unit, Robertson Stephens; will pay $400 million in cash and put $400 million in pool to persuade firm's partners and key employees to remain; BankAmerica will keep firm's money-management and debt underwriting businesses (S)

headline: Computers Are Starting to Listen, and Understand
abstract: Dictation programs are so useful that they have changed way many people interact with computer chips; pushing trend toward conversational technology is new generation of speech-based products that are markedly improved from earlier programs; Dragon Systems and International Business Machines have programs priced under $200 for 'continuous dictation,' name for programs that will listen to and reproduce words spoken by someone talking at steady rate in phrases or sentences; one drawback is that systems are 'speaker dependent,' meaning new user must train program to recognize quirks in a voice, such as Southern or Boston accent; big leap in voice-recognition technology allows system to learn patterns of speaker quickly, in less than hour; photo; drawings; Sachin Shah, editor of speech and telecommunications industry newsletters, assesses Dragon and IBM digital stenographers (M)

headline: Ruffled, Japan Advises U.S.: Mind Your Own Business
abstract: Japanese have grown increasingly offended as parade of US officials all way up to Pres Clinton have told Japan how to fix its slumping economy; so specific have US economic prescriptions become that they leave political leaders in Tokyo with little room to save face; no matter what they do, they will appear to be caving in to 'gaiatsu,' or foreign pressure (M)

headline: Hopeful Words of Arrival, Contrite Words of Departure
abstract: Excerpts from inaugural address by new Indonesian Pres B J Habibie, and resignation speech by Pres Suharto; photos (S)

headline: Joys of Hanging Out On a Virtual Corner
abstract: User's Guide on popularity of free chat and messaging program called ICQ from Mirabilis, software company; says ICQ and similar software programs are more gimmick than utility; says it will not replace E-mail because its universe is limited to registered users (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Silver rises 1.5 percent after Warren E Buffett, billionaire investor who owns large amount of silver, repeats forecasts that prices are headed higher; July contracts rise 9.4 cents, to $6.247 an ounce; graph; chart (S)

headline: OIL AND GAS COMPANIES IN $565 MILLION MERGER
abstract: Devon Energy Corp to issue 15.4 million shares of stock to acquire Northstar Energy Corp in deal valued at about $565 million; will also assume Northstar debt of $312 million and other obligations (S)

headline: French-German Feud Dampens Euro Enthusiasm
abstract: France and Germany are still fighting over rival candidates to lead European central bank and over basic questions on how it should be run with only few days remaining before European leaders approve final preparations for single European currency, the euro; European central bank does not yet officially exist, but it already has staff of 400 economists and technical experts, who have been laying groundwork for pan-European monetary policy; if the euro is introduced on schedule on Jan 1, 1999, bank will become European equivalent of Federal Reserve in US; it would have supreme authority over new currency, which means it would control interest rates and, to some extent, growth rates of 11 European nations; feud between Germany and France threatens to sour celebration of hard-won unity in Brussels this weekend; if European leaders fail to announce bank president by May 2, they are likely to undermine new currency's credibility and raise questions about project's future; photo (L)

headline: Provident Chooses Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Provident Companies names Saatchi & Saatchi to handle its multimedia national advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million; account had been handled by Brouillard Communications (S)

headline: PRESIDENT OF EXCEL COMMUNICATIONS RESIGNS
abstract: John J McLaine resigns as president and chief executive operating officer of Excel Communications Inc; Kenny A Troutt, chairman and chief executive, will reassume president's position (S)

headline: Toughest Boards Are Biggest Stockholders
abstract: DIRECTORS with a lot of money tied up in the stock of the company they oversee are more likely to dismiss a poor-performing chief executive than directors who don't have much money at stake, according to a new study.    Many experts in corporate governance have long believed that directors with large ownership stakes provide more vigilant oversight, and the findings appear to confirm that view.

headline: Jousting in Iran
abstract: In a blow to Iran's reform-minded President, Mohammed Khatami, the Parliament voted to dismiss a close ally from the Cabinet. Page A9.

headline: METALS USA SAYS IT HAS ACQUIRED FOUR COMPANIES
abstract: Metals USA Inc acquires Fullerton Industries, Sierra Pacific Steels Inc, Industrial Metals Inc and Concord Metals Corp with combined annual revenues of about $151 million; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Iran Rejects Overtures By Albright
abstract: Iran today reiterated its rejection of a political dialogue with the United States, as a Deputy Foreign Minister praised the Clinton Administration for softening its hostile tone but sharply criticized Washington for not abandoning its punitive policies against his country.    In an interview, the minister, Mohammed Javad Zarif, offered the most detailed official Iranian reaction to a speech last week by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright calling on the Iranian Government to help formulate a ''road map'' to normal relations.

headline: Leadership Plan for Citigroup Tilts in Favor of Travelers
abstract: Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc designate management team to run merged companies, to be called Citigroup; John S Reed of Citicorp and Sanford I Weill of Travelers will be co-chief executives, but Travelers executives secure more of top leadership spots and are best positioned to stamp their company's identity on merged concern; Jamie Dimon of Travelers is named Citigroup president, making him clear heir apparent for top post; Weill has put together strong cadre of talented loyalists, while Reed has periodically reshuffled or ousted prominent senior executives (M)

headline: U.N. Panel May Approve Limit on Guns Despite N.R.A. Pleas
abstract: United Nations Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice proposal to curb illicit trade in firearms moves toward almost certain adoption, in wake of attack by National Rifle Association (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: British pound rallies against dollar after Bank of England surprises market and raises interest rates; pound eases to $1.6369, from $1.6399 on June 3, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: New Labour, Old Goal:Strong Workers' Unions
abstract: LONDON—  The government of Prime Minister Tony Blair undertook an ambitious attempt on Thursday to roll back the labor-market deregulation of the Thatcher era by unveiling a package of proposals to guarantee a worker's right to union representation and strengthen protection against unfair dismissals.

headline: CBS Affiliates To Share Costs For First Time
abstract: CBS announces agreement with its affiliated stations to share in cost of rights to National Football League games, first time network has received direct financial help from affiliates to pay for programming; agreement comes after five months of negotiations between CBS and its affiliate board, and involves complicated exchange of cash and commercial time; CBS executives say network expects to realize between $40 million and $50 million from arrangement; although value of concession to network is less than 10 percent of $500 million a year CBS has agreed to pay NFL, it represents significant shift in relationship between network and its more than 200 affiliated stations (M)

headline: Rancor Eases As the Koreas Open Talks After 4 Years
abstract: North and South Korean officials meet in Beijing in first face-to-face talks in more than four years; friendly discussion covers broad range of issues, ranging from large-scale economic investment to plans for reuniting families separated by division (M)

headline: Riksbank to Cut Repurchase Rate
abstract: Swedish central bank, the Riksbank, says it will cut its securities repurchase rate by 25 basis points, to 4.10 percent as it published its quarterly inflation report; inflation has been weaker than Riksbank and many other analysts expected (S)

headline: U.S. Mediators Get Support From 2 Israeli Ex-Officials
abstract: American mediators seeking formula to revive stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks get unexpected help from Israelis who started process; Uri Savir, chief Israeli negotiator under former Labor Government, says then Israeli Prime Min Yitzhak Rabin was secretly willing to cede half West Bank in three stages while negotiating final settlement; Israeli ex-Prime Min Shimon Peres, after meeting with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, backs creation of Palestinian state by May 1999; American mediators Dennis Ross and Asst Sec Martin Indyk meet with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and later with Arafat; photo (M)

headline: Two Big Nursing Home Operators Reach Agreement to Merge
abstract: Health Care & Retirement Corp and Manor Care Inc agree to merge in stock swap valued at about $2.45 billion, creating one of nation's largest operators of nursing homes; new company will be called HCR Manor Care and will be based in Toledo, Ohio, where Health Care and Retirement is based (M)

headline: Tripping Over Translations
abstract: Prof Lawrence Howe letter on Apr 30 article on shortcomings of computer translations (S)

headline: PURCHASE OF BALTIMORE GAS AND ELECTRIC UNIT PLANNED
abstract: Corporate Office Properties Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company's real estate unit for $203 million in cash and securities, increasing its office property holdings by about 59 percent. The unit, Constellation Real Estate Group Inc., owns eight buildings in the Baltimore and Washington, D.C., areas. Under the terms of the agreement, Corporate Office will pay $107 million in cash or assume the same amount of debt. It will also issue 6.88 million common shares valued at $96 million and $24 million of convertible preferred stock. After the transaction, Corporate Office will own 45 properties.

abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Blount Intl  Chemed  Guidant  Longs Drug Stores  Omnicare  Watkins Johnson

headline: Some Economic Interplay Comes Nearly Full Circle
abstract: World's economies are roughly as intertwined today as they were in 1913; two world wars and the Depression dismantled globalization that had been achieved over 40-year period staring in 1870's; by 1913, trade and foreign investment, two key measures of global integration, were roughly at levels that have been reached through gradual buildup since late 1950's (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Chicken Or Beef? Aim Higher
abstract: Article by Farrol Kahn, director of Aviation Health Institute, urges United States airlines to serve better food; offers ratings for food served on foreign carriers; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. V. MICROSOFT: THE REACTION -- A Goliath Needs the Little Guys; Microsoft Faces Challenge of Image Among Consumers
abstract: Crucial challenge for Microsoft Corp may lie in more traditional task of getting and keeping consumers on its side as world focuses on new legal battle between Microsoft and various governmental entities; as public sensitivity to Microsoft is heightened by intense coverage of the Government action, industry observers say company is at particularly vulnerable moment not just in courtroom but in the marketplace; some computer consumers comment on Microsoft's role in computer industry; charts; photos (L)

abstract: Carolina First Corp acquires First National Bank of Pickens County for $57 million in stock, expanding its business in South Carolina (S)

headline: In Search of Cybercafes

headline: Annan Given Cold Shoulder By Officials In Rwanda
abstract: Rwandan leaders give hostile reception to United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who visits Rwanda on what he calls 'healing mission,' and admits to Parliament that UN had done too little to stop 1994 massacres of Tutsi civilians; just before Annan's speech, Foreign Min Anastase Gasana embarrasses Annan with 10-point indictment of UN's role in country's history, culminating in killing of hundreds of thousands of people four years ago (M)

headline: GUINNESS TO ACCEPT MATTEL OFFER FOR BLUEBIRD SHARES
abstract: Guinness Peat Group PLC will accept offer of 116.5 pence a share in cash from toy maker Mattel Inc for shares in Bluebird Toys PLC, bringing to end four-month bidding war for British toy company; offer is worth about $78 million (S)

headline: Music on a Mac
abstract: Letter from David Battino, editor at Music and Computers magazine, appreciates May 14 article on how computers enable people to make music on a desktop (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: DaimlerChrysler A.G., A Global Challenger  Creating a formidable global company through the biggest industrial takeover ever, Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany agreed to acquire Chrysler, Detroit's No. 3 auto maker, for stock worth $39 billion. The merged company would have a market value of $92 billion and a vehicle lineup ranging from the little Plymouth Neon to the luxurious Mercedes-Benz S-Class, with Jeeps, mini-vans, pickups and less-expensive Mercedes sedans in between. ''Today, we are creating the world's leading automotive company for the 21st century,'' said Jurgen E. Schrempp, Daimler's chairman. Another German auto maker, Volkswagen, one-upped BMW, persuading Vickers P.L.C. of Britain to accept its $710 million bid for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars.    THE ECONOMY  Racking Up Sales  The auto industry's sales showed unexpected strength in April, rising 6.3 percent over April 1997 to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.5 million. Heavy mortgage refinancings have given buyers extra money to spend and hefty rebates have drawn them to showrooms. Other economic reports also showed continuing strength, with the unemployment rate falling to a 28-year low of 4.3 percent in April from 4.7 percent in March. Still, the Federal Reserve found inflation benign as economic growth continued in March and April. Factory orders rose a moderate 0.3 percent in March, while the Conference Board's index of leading indicators rose 0.2 percent. Retail sales rose 10.2 percent in April, the best monthly sales gains in four years. But worker productivity grew in the first quarter at the slowest pace in more than a year, rising at an annualized rate of 0.2 percent.    MARKETS  Nervous, Then Buoyant  With investors fearful that the Fed might push up interest rates, stock prices, buoyed just weeks ago by big bank mergers, were battered for the better part of the week. But Friday's strong jobs report erased the gloom, and market indexes resumed their winning ways. One of the most chaotic bouts of trading in memory came with Entremed, which may or may not find a cure for cancer. Investors bid its stock up $39.75, to $51.81, in chaotic trading on Monday, but by the end of the week it was down to $33.25. The Dow industrials ended the week down 91.92 points at 9,055.15, and the yield on the long bond rose to 5.97 percent.    THE BUDGET  A Growing Surplus  The nation's fiscal condition is improving at a startling pace. Tax collections surged in late April, with much of the money apparently coming from capital gains chalked up in last year's strong stock market. The Congressional Budget Office now sees a $43 billion to $63 billion surplus this year. After years of trying to reduce the deficit, Washington is now deeply divided over what to do with the surplus -- cut taxes, save Social Security or pay for other programs. Saying it could reduce borrowing, the Treasury will eliminate the three-year note.    PEOPLE  A Survivor's Victory  Estelle Sapir, 72, of Far Rockaway, Queens, whose health is failing, emerged as a rare victor in Holocaust survivors' battle with Swiss Banks. Credit Suisse, which her father had entrusted with his money before perishing in the Majdanek concentration camp in Poland, finally settled her claim for an estimated $500,000. For decades, the bank had demanded a death certificate -- something the Nazis had failed to provide. . . . Francois Pinault, a wealthy French investor, has bought 29.1 percent of Christie's, the London auction house. . . . Sidney Taurel, Eli Lilly's president and an expert in drug marketing, will become chief executive on July 1 and chairman on Dec. 31, succeeding Randall L. Tobias, who has decided to retire.    TECHNOLOGY  Fractious Growth  Microsoft, caught in a web of antitrust battles that threaten to delay the scheduled June introduction of its Windows 98 operating system, persuaded a number of computer industry leaders to back its case for no delay. . . . Compaq Computer will cut 15,000 jobs at Digital Equipment, or 28 percent of Digital's work force, after the companies complete their merger, an executive disclosed. . . . Whatever the industry's internal problems, users keep increasing. With new subscribers growing, America Online reported profits that sharply ecceeded analysts' expectations. . . . Steve Jobs, the interim chief executive who is nursing Apple Computer back to health, showed a new version of the company's G-3 computer with a shark on its screen in Cupertino, Calif, on Wednesday.    WALL STREET  Goodbye, Arbitration?  A proposed settlement of a discrimination suit filed by women brokers against Merrill Lynch could lead to the end of Wall Street's system for dealing with employee cases through mandatory arbitration, allowing cases to go into open court . . . Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced that Nationsbank, one of the country's largest financial institutions, had agreed to pay almost $7 million to settle charges that it misled customers who bought two bond funds in 1993-94. The announcement came as bankers and brokers lobbied for a sweeping overhaul of the laws separating their institutions. So far, Congress has not voted on the issue.    CHOCOLATE  A Bitter Forecast  Gold in short supply? Silver will do. Fine wines scarce? Plonk will do. But a shortage of chocolate? What's the world to do? With demand exceeding production of cocoa beans, the world's reserves could run out within 5 to 10 years. Consequently, an unusual alliance of manufacturers and environmental groups has formed to tackle the problem. Representatives of the Mars, Cadbury, Nestle and Hershey chocolate companies met with conservation groups last month at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama to discuss how to save farms under siege worldwide from insects and from fungal and viral diseases.    I.R.S.  Senate Votes for Overhaul  After hearing taxpayers' horror stories and complaints about the tax code's ever-increasing complexity, the Senate voted 97 to 0 to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service. Among other changes intended to make the I.R.S. more friendly to citizens, the bill would create an independent board to oversee the agency and establish an independent taxpayer advocate. To assure that collections are not unduly hampered, the White House said it would press for some changes when a joint committee reconciles the bill and a narrower version passed last year by the House. . . . Shirley Barron, who accused the I.R.S. in a $1 million lawsuit of driving her husband to suicide, said that the agency had agreed to a settlement that would eliminate her tax debt of more than $400,000 and let her keep her New Hampshire home.

headline: Kohl Paints Opponent As Far Leftist
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl opens re-election drive with harsh, personal attack on main challenger, accusing Gerhard Schroder of steering land toward 'leftist republic,' speech to special meeting of his Christian Democratic Union; scores him for allowing political accord with Communists in Saxony-Anhalt; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Resume Retreat, Nasdaq at Six-Week Low  A day after gains pushed blue-ship stocks sharply higher for no obvious reason, stock prices fell, and analysts saw various explanations: worries about corporate profit deceleration, worries about high prices, plus overall loss of stamina and momentum.

headline: Beijing Journal; At a Trying Time, China Revives Mao's Model Man
abstract: Faces of improbably perfect heroes are displayed in Beijing to inspire workers suffering hardships created by dismantling of Communist industries and cherished welfare programs; most heroic figure is that of Lei Feng, soldier of unsurpassed altruism who died in his early 20's and has been held up as ultimate 'model worker' every since; heaviest promotions of Lei Feng have come in waves, when Communist leaders worry about morale of people; photo (M)

headline: Scooby Doo, Where Are You?
abstract: Global Positioning System receivers, based on concept developed by Department of Defense in 1970's to use satellites to pinpoint position of soldiers, have expanded in use to include such activities as hiking, dog sled racing and long-distance running; receiver industry expects devices to become as pervasive and indispensable as other everyday items; predict market for all GPS-based products, now around $2 billion, will rise to $8.5 billion by 2005; cost of GPS receiver is about $249, down from $2000 six years ago; some pros and cons in using these devices discussed; certified amateurs on staff of The Times evaluate sampling of GPS receivers; charts tracing development of GPS, starting in 1973, and showing how system works; photos (L)

headline: U.S. and China Gain Rapport, Albright Says
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets with Chinese Foreign Min Tang Jiaxuan in Beijing; says US and China are building 'constructive, strategic partnership'; Albright has begun two days of high-level meetings; Pres Clinton will go to China for summit meeting in June (S)

headline: One Partnership, Starkly Different Career Goals

headline: MEDITRUST BUYING 12 GOLF COURSES FOR $130 MILLION
abstract: The Meditrust Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 12 golf courses for $130 million. The courses will be managed by Cobblestone Golf Group and are near courses that Cobblestone runs in Florida, Georgia, Texas and Virginia. The acquisition, expected to close next month, also includes courses in North Carolina and New Jersey. Meditrust, based in Needham Heights, Mass., is a real estate investment trust with investments in 474 health care facilities in 40 states. Meditrust acquired Cobblestone Holdings Inc., a Del Mar, Calif., operator of golf courses, earlier this year for $241 million.

headline: A Yacht, All Yours, Part Time
abstract: ''THE two best days with a yacht are the day you buy it and the day you sell it,'' lamented Steven Sands, the co-chairman of Sands Brothers, a New York investment bank.     Eugene Melnyk, the chairman of Biovail Pharmaceuticals in Toronto, shares Mr. Sands's ambivalence. ''Owning a big boat,'' he groused, ''is like owning a second business.''    But help for both, and for others who can  live neither with their yachts nor without them, may be on the way. And it is coming from an unlikely source: Irwin L. Jacobs, the 1980's corporate raider known as ''Irv the Liquidator'' for his habit of acquiring ailing companies and playing musical chairs with the assets.    Well, perhaps it is not so unlikely. When the game ended, Mr. Jacobs's portfolio included a dozen boat manufacturers, including Hatteras, the high-end yacht maker in New Bern, N.C. With fewer opportunities for slicing and dicing corporations, he put his restless mind to marketing their products -- notably, the million-dollar-plus behemoths turned out by Hatteras.    ''When I asked people at boat shows why they didn't own yachts,'' Mr. Jacobs explained, ''price was an issue, but so was the hassle factor.''    Never one to run with the crowd -- he once installed a delicatessen in a boat showroom in Minnesota to increase foot traffic -- Mr. Jacobs went looking for an unconventional solution to both problems.    Hardly anybody wants to spend more than a few months a year aboard a yacht, he reasoned. And hardly anybody with realistic aspirations of owning an ocean-going trophy has the time or inclination to tend to the details of keeping it provisioned and shipshape.    The solution, perhaps inspired by the latest fashion in sales of private jets: Yachtscape, a partial-ownership program in which access to a super-luxe, fully equipped Hatteras yacht is divided into thirds, while a management company handles everything from providing the crews to catering the cocktail parties to finding the perfect beach for sunbathing in the buff.     Indeed, the managers' job is part mundane maintenance, part European-style concierge service in which no client's wish is beyond reach. ''We're not just selling a boat; we're selling a life style,'' said Mr. Jacobs, testing his sales pitch.    Yachtscape's first two fiberglass beauties from Hatteras, the 74-foot Courageous with five bedrooms and the 65-foot Vigilant with four, are now on the block. Each of the three shares in the Courageous costs $1 million, or a third of what a single owner would pay for the boat. For this, plus an annual fee of $259,000, each part-owner is entitled to six 14-day cruises annually, which would keep the boat in use a total of 36 weeks a year.    The remaining 113 days are reserved for maintenance, weather-related down time and the scheduling convenience of the owners. With this many days of slack, potential conflicts over the use of the yacht at holidays should be minimized, Mr. Jacobs says.    Paying operating fees that are more than $3,000 a day, the owners of Courageous will presumably expect a lot, and Yachtscape aims to exceed their expectations. Everything needed to operate the boat -- a crew of two and back-up personnel, insurance, dockage fees and full maintenance -- is included. ''If a critical part breaks while the boat is cruising the coast of Siberia, we'll have a replacement there within 24 hours,'' Mr. Jacobs said.    A tour of Courageous, docked recently at Manhattan's Chelsea Piers, confirmed that clients needn't fear for their comfort, either. The yacht is exceptionally well appointed, with glitzy bathrooms attached to every bedroom, satellite TV's and telephones scattered about the living quarters like coasters.     The decor is Beverly Hills contemporary, with surfaces covered in natural fibers, mirrors, Hatteras's signature blonde-maple paneling -- or, in the case of the galley counters, granite. An inflatable outboard runabout and a Sea-Doo personal watercraft grace the rear deck.    ''In short, everything is included except food and fuel,'' said Ralph Vick, the managing director of Yachtscape, who earned his spurs indulging the whims of the well-heeled while working for the Ritz-Carlton hotel chain.     Of course, the three owners of Courageous will be masters of their domain only for discrete periods of the year. But management will swim the last lap to minimize the sense of sharing. Each owner will have separate sets of bed and bath linens. Each owner's clothes and accessories will be stored between cruises. Yachtscape is even prepared to juggle crews among boats if a particular owner finds that the chemistry with the help is wrong.    Kenneth Cancellara, the general counsel of Biovail, is ''98 percent sure'' he will buy a share of Courageous and expects to use the boat with friends and family. Mr. Melnyk, who is close to signing on for his own piece of the yacht, will probably mix business with pleasure.     But Mr. Sands, the investment banker,  sees the boat primarily as a capitalist tool. ''We're constantly entertaining, bringing together securities issuers and institutional buyers,'' he said.    Indeed, Mr. Jacobs envisions a big corporate market for share ownership, with buyers using cruises to reward star employees and stroke clients. ''A yacht cruise is the ultimate perk,'' he said.    And what if the partial ownership experience sours -- or if an owner decides to renounce his wealth and enter a monastery? Yachtscape stands ready to buy back shares for half the purchase price after 35 months. Probably more relevant, it will serve as a broker, finding buyers for orphaned shares for a predetermined commission.    Mr. Jacobs does not expect it to come to that very often. Indeed, he is projecting sales of an extra 50 yachts a year -- Hatteras now builds about 100 -- to satisfy the new market. Some may be specially equipped for fishing, while others may tap into the lavish fantasies of latter-day King Farouks.    What is the biggest boat he is prepared to sell in pieces? If the demand is there, Mr. Jacobs said, Hatteras can provide 130-footers. The tentative price is $3 million for each of three shares, plus $455,000 annual maintenance. The line forms to the right.

abstract: Dana Corp makes friendly $3.6 billion acquisition offer for its competitor Echlin Inc, topping hostile $3.1 billion bid from SPX Corp (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: ECONOMY  Up, Up and, for Some, Away  Sales of new single-family homes rose 5.2 percent in April to a record, and the Conference Board, a private research group, said its index of leading economic indicators rose 0.1 percent in April -- the fourth consecutive monthly increase. The index has not declined since April 1997. Separately, construction spending rose 0.8 percent in April, the fifth consecutive monthly gain. Factory orders rose 1.2 percent, the biggest increase in five months. On a less upbeat note, the productivity of workers continued to grow, but more slowly. And on a downright sour note, Americans filed nearly 342,000 personal bankruptcy petitions in the first quarter, up 6 percent from the period a year earlier, according to a lending industry group.

headline: Top General Strengthens His Grasp On Power
abstract: Gen Wiranto, Indonesia's most powerful military figure, consolidates his power under new Pres B J Habibie by removing son-in-law of ex-Pres Suharto from command post; Wiranto, who finally persuaded Suharto to step down, is now serving both as armed forces chief and Defense Minister; Suharto and several of his six unpopular children, grown vastly rich, are in seclusion in Jakarta; critics note Government still has same old faces; photo of student demonstrators (M)

headline: Taipei Is on Alert for Sign of Betrayal
abstract: Mood is Taipei, Taiwan, is sullen and profoundly nervous as festivities and pomp of Pres Clinton's state visit unfold in China; Foreign Ministry sets up 24-hour situation room to follow moment-by-moment developments of visit, and Government has impaneled interagency task force to monitor it; thousands of Taiwanese sign petitions or have taken to streets to warn US not to betray them (M)

headline: MARSULEX ACQUIRING 2 COMPANIES FROM TRELLEBORG
abstract: Marsulex Inc agrees to acquire two chemical waste-handling businesses from Swedish industrial conglomerate Trelleborg AB for $51 million; companies are Intertrade Holdings Inc and BCT Chemtrade Corp (S)

headline: Ruling Says Salinas Sister-in-Law Told of Bribes
abstract: Newly released Swiss court papers show that within weeks after police investigators found more than $130 million that Raul Salinas de Gortari, elder brother of former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas, had secreted away in Swiss banks, Raul Salinas's wife admitted to authorities that money had come from bribes; Switzerland's highest court, Federal Tribunal, in procedural ruling, indicates that US prosecutors suspected almost from start of their investigation that Raul Salinas had raised money by protecting major drug traffickers (M)

headline: A Bigger League Is Playing to the Players
abstract: Increasing number of banks, brokerage firms, money managers and mutual fund companies are wooing high-paid professional athletes; athletes and advisers face challenge of planning for lifetime of assets after brief playing period; photos (M)

headline: Reality Punctures Entremed's Bubble
abstract: Sharp runup of Entremed Inc stock on news report of cancer cure and subsequent price drop discussed as cautionary tale for investors; investors following stock were long aware of research promise, which was already reflected in pre-runup price; institutional ownership was unusually low (M)

headline: Earnings Higher At US West Unit
abstract: U S West Communications Group says that its first-quarter earnings rose 2.4 percent on strong sales of Internet services and demand for more phone lines; reports net income of $347 million, or 71 cents a diluted share (S)

headline: Omnicom Merges 2 of Its Units
abstract: Omnicom Group is forming TBWA Worldwide by merging its TBWA International unit with BDDP Worldwide (S)

headline: Justice Department Expected To Seek Contract Restraints
abstract: Justice Department is expected to sue Microsoft Corp to place limits on contracts company strikes with personal computer makers, Internet service providers and Web site operators; department will argue that contracts must be limited to prevent Microsoft from using a monopoly in operating systems, both to unfairly protect its Windows stronghold and to extend its monopolistic reach into new markets of Internet software and commerce (M)

headline: How Many Bill Gateses Does It Take to Change a Light Bulb?
abstract: Jokes spurred by Justice Department's antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp are spreading over Internet; examples cited; cartoon (M)

headline: With Euro Accord in Place, Next Question Is Credibility
abstract: Financial analysts predict that messy political compromise that marred agreement among European leaders to adopt new single currency will make world markets more suspicious than before about fledgling euro; few experts expect investors to react dramatically when markets reopen, but officials of new European central bank may feel pressure to err on side of toughness and higher interest rates to demonstrate credibility; one economist says machinations that led to compromise provided signal that political leaders are willing to twist and distort rules of bank to patch over their differences (M)

headline: Creating a Silicon Valley in the Washington Area
abstract: Mario Morino, software entrepreneur, is guiding light and financial patron of ambitious effort to make Washington, DC, and surrounding area model for entrepreneurial success in new media; his heady goals for region include 2,000 new start-up companies, 50,000 new jobs and $2.5 billion in new income; his Netpreneur program sponsors conferences, offers data base of business plans for companies looking for investors, and plans full-scale survey of Washington region's new-media economy; photo (M)

headline: VW and Porsche In Joint Venture
abstract: Volkswagen AG will jointly build off-road sport utility vehicle with Porsche AG; vehicles, which will bear car makers' individual trademarks, will be available beginning in 2002 (S)

headline: Shirkers Unite! Tomorrow Is Your Day
