headline: SUHARTO REVERSES HIKE IN FUEL PRICE DEMANDED BY I.M.F.
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto, responding to rioting, returns hurriedly from Cairo and rolls back new fuel-price rises imposed at International Monetary Fund insistence; confers with advisers and top generals as calls for his ouster grow on streets and from public figures; tanks guard suddenly quiet streets of Jakarta and Presidential Palace; young looters still roam streets; more rioting is reported in Jogjakarta, Solo and Ugung Pandang; Lt Gen Prabowo, Suharto's son-in-law, says there are no splits in military; ethnic Chinese citizens, whose homes and stores have come under attack, take refuge in hotels or gather at airports seeking to flee nation; foreigners also throng to airports after American Embassy advises United States citizens to leave; embassy plans charter flights to evacuate Americans; other nations also prepare to evacuate citizens; Pres Clinton says Indonesians must decide own political future; calls for reform; map; photo (M)

headline: On Pakistan's Side, Hopes of Ending 'a Perpetual State of Confrontation'
abstract: Pakistani army is dug in along 550-mile chain of sandbagged trenches and concrete bunkers in mountains of Chakothi, Kashmir; across Jhelum River valley are almost identical Indian fortifications; photo (M)

headline: Thompson Partner Joins Harry Winston
abstract: James Haag, head of De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd account at J Walter Thompson, is leaving agency to join Harry Winston Inc as global marketing director for retail operations (S)

headline: ACQUISITION TO BROADEN NETMANAGE'S SOFTWARE LINES
abstract: Netmanage Inc to acquire FTP Software Inc for about $77.4 million (S)

headline: Litton Gets Navy Contract
abstract: Litton Industries receives $138.6 million contract to modernize Navy's Triconderoga class of Aegis cruisers (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Head of Touchstone Pictures Expected to Quit, Executives Say
abstract: Donald DeLine, president of Touchstone Pictures, division of Walt Disney Co, is expected to resign his post within next few months (S)

headline: Rodale Sells Magazine
abstract: BET Holdings Inc acquires Heart & Soul magazine from Rodale Press Inc; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Council Chides Pakistanis and Indians, Too
abstract: Security Council strongly deplores Pakistan's nuclear tests, but also repeats its criticism of India and urges both nations to stop testing and take steps to reduce tensions between them; accuses both countries of being in violation of de facto moratorium on nuclear testing that has been observed world over for more than two years, when majority of nations agreed to Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (M)

headline: Defending the Safety Of Sport Utilities
abstract: American Automobile Manufacturers Assn aide Barry Felrice letter on Mar 15 article on safety issues involving sport utility vehicles (S)

headline: Hold the Applause, Indeed
abstract: Andreana L Doyle letter discusses March 22 article on mothers working at home (S)

headline: Value of Spin On Wall Street Is $15 Billion To 2 Companies
abstract: Market Place column explores divergent paths taken by shares of Hewlett-Packard and IBM, two of biggest technology companies, after their chairmen met with Wall Street analysts; notes that Hewlett-Packard shares fell 14 percent after company warned analysts that second-quarter results would be far weaker than expected; says investors piling out of Hewlett-Packard seemed to head straight for IBM, due largely to IBM chairman Louis V Gerstner Jr's ability to put rosy spin on news; says Hewlett-Packard's Lewis Platt does not share Gerstner's ease with analysts; says Gerstner did not actually forecast higher earnings, but he encouraged analysts to think that returning to double-digit revenue growth was a possibility; graph (M)

headline: A Response From Apple
abstract: Letter from Mitch Mandich, senior vice president at Apple Computer, says future of company's computer business if far brighter than April 2 article suggests (S)

headline: In Jakarta, Reports Of Numerous Rapes Of Chinese in Riots
abstract: Human rights and women's aid groups report organized campaign of assaults, gang rapes and killings of ethnic Chinese women during rioting in Jakarta and other Indonesian cities in May, when Chinese neighborhoods were targets of arson and looting; estimate over 100 women and girls may have been attacked and raped in Jakarta alone; say most of victims are too traumatized to talk about experiences and terrified of reprisals if they report ordeals to officals or even to unofficial rape centers; say some of women have committed suicide (M)

headline: For Want of Feed, Indonesia Is Losing Its Chickens
abstract: Indonesia's worst drought in 50 years has deepened prospects of severe food shortage in nation of 200 million people; with cost of imported feed more than doubling because of weakness of Indonesia currency, 90 percent of poultry farmers have gone out of business; Government is trying to keep some large producers in business by helping them pay for feed; map; photo (M)

headline: Boeing Wins U.S. Contract For Missile-Defense Testing
abstract: Pentagon awards three-year, $1.6 billion contract to Boeing Co to oversee design and testing of integrated nationwide system of satellites and land-based missiles to shoot down incoming ballistic missiles; award comes despite fact that there is still no proven technology capable of protecting nation from missile attack, and several independent studies have questioned whether one is feasible in light of repeated glitches; John Peller, Boeing vice president, is confident Boeing will overcome technological difficulites, citing years of research Pentagon conducted in so-far unsuccessful efforts to build missile defense; new program is far cry from system Pres Reagan proposed, and even from scaled-down versions advocated by Presidents Bush and Clinton (M)

headline: INTEGRATED CIRCUIT SAYS IT RECEIVED TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc says it received unsolicited takeover offer from undisclosed buyer (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Hey, Let's Put on a Fund! But Why 8,000 of Them?
abstract: Article discusses explosive growth of mutual funds; fund trackers at Lipper Analytical Services have added 163 growth funds to their data bases since end of 1996; Lipper now tracks 988 growth funds, almost double number just four years ago; drawing; graph (M)

headline: O.K., So Where Do You See Yourself In Five Years?
abstract: New York Times is requesting human resources workers to submit their favorite job interviews (S)

headline: Most Approve Of Microsoft, A Poll Shows
abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds antitrust battle has not tarnished Microsoft Corp's reputation as outstanding business that makes high-quality products; finds majority of Americans think Microsoft is monopoly and that Justice Department should continue its probe; respondents, in poll and follow-up interviews, laud Microsoft and co-founder William H Gates; graphs (M)

headline: Soros Is Said to Buy Caracas Bank Stake
abstract: Financier George Soros buys 5 percent stake in Banco Caracas, Venezuela (S)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Clearing the Air Over Clearing Firms
abstract: Article by Saul S Cohen, securities partner in law firm of Proskauer Rose LLP, discusses useful services provided by companies that provide underwriting to companies involved on various ventures (M)

headline: AT&T Says Failure Was Software Flaw
abstract: AT&T Corp says software problems with one of its switches caused April 13 failure of long-distance company's nationwide network for high-speed services; company says it changed procedure for upgrading switching software to prevent future breakdown on network; since failure, company has not been charging for service, which accounts for about $1 billion, or 2 percent, of AT&T's annual revenue and is increasing at rate of about 35 percent a year (S)

headline: ENVIROTEST HIRES INVESTMENT BANK TO EXPLORE OPTIONS
abstract: Envirotest Systems Corp hires investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd to explore possible sale or other alternatives (S)

headline: Royal Ahold Set to Acquire Giant Food
abstract: Royal Ahold NV extends its reach into American supermarket business with $2.6 billion deal to acquire Giant Food Inc supermarket chain; acquisition would strengthen Ahold's position as biggest foreign owner of American grocery store business and make it fourth-largest supermarket operator in US; it also reflects rapid consolidation of industry, where companies are trying to create dominant regional chains (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Drug Stock Joins List of Wall St.'s Wildest
abstract: Market Place column on wild fluctuations of stock of Entremed Inc, small biomedical company that might--or might not--have drugs that could lead to cure for cancer; says stock rose $39.75, to $51.81, with volume reported at level well above number of shares outstanding; says trading in stock was perhaps more chaotic than any in years, with highest prices--more than $80 a share--coming in first two minutes after market formally opened; chart (L)

headline: ENVIRODYNE AGREES TO SELL PLASTICS UNIT TO SOLO CUP
abstract: Envirodyne Industries to sell its Clear Shield National unit to Solo Cup Co for $140 million in cash as it seeks to reduce debt (S)

headline: No Sympathy for Gates in Parts of Silicon Valley
abstract: Microsoft Corp's many dependents offer muted reaction to suits by Justice Department and state Attorneys General, but software maker's outspoken adversaries call action major step toward dismantling its dominance; most forceful reaction comes from Lawrence J Ellison, chairman and chief executive of Oracle Corp, who ridicules Microsoft's chairman, William H Gates, for calling lawsuits harmful to American innovation; Mitchell Kertzman, chairman and chief executive of Sybase Inc, T R Reid, spokesman for Dell Computer Corp, Jim Finlaw, spokesman for Compaq Computer Corp, and Gordon Eubanks, president and chief executive of Symantec Corp, comment; diagram; photos (L)

headline: Corporate Push To Save Break On Foreign Tax
abstract: American multinational corporations are lobbying to preserve loophole inadvertently created two years ago by Clinton Administration that allows them to avoid paying foreign governments billions of dollars a year in taxes; all of Republicans and most of Democrats on House Ways and Means Committee, which sets tax policy, sign letter urging Treasury Department to withdraw regulations it issued in January aimed at closing loophole (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CV REIT INC., West Palm Beach, Fla., a real estate investment trust, will acquire three neighborhood shopping centers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for $33.4 million.    PRIMARK CORP., Waltham, Mass., said it would continue to review strategic alternatives for the company, which include possible mergers, acquisitions and share repurchases.

headline: Harm Found To the Image Of Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp's legal clash with Justice Department is beginning to hurt Microsoft brand reputation, according to Tectel, a research organization that tracks brand recognition of technology companies among business customers and consumers; Michael F Kelly, Tectel's president, says its survey data are often a useful harbinger of changes in a company's stock performance and return on equity (M)

headline: Short-Sellers Show Increasing Interest in Compaq
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports overall short interest rose to record 3.93 billion shares in period ending May 15, up from 3.87 billion a month earlier; American Stock Exchange says short interest rose to record 191.1 million shares, increase from 197 million a month earlier; charts (S)

headline: Emery I. Valyi, 86, an Inventor Known for Work With Plastics
abstract: Emery I Valyi, prolific inventor, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: Air France Pilots Not Budging : World Cup Is On, As Is Labor Unrest
abstract: PARIS—  The World Cup soccer tournament officially opened in France on Tuesday night amid a wave of labor unrest as specific groups of workers used the world's biggest sporting event as a lever to get higher pay, bonuses or improved conditions.

headline: People
abstract: Melissa Pordy is named senior vice president and print services director at Zenith Media Services, succeeding Amy Andrews, who left (S)

headline: British Dairy Company Ends Takeover Talks
abstract: Unigate PLC calls off talks to acquire Hillsdown Holdings PLC (S)

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions and appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Equitable Adopts Stock Buyback Plan
abstract: Equitable Companies adopts plan to buy up to eight million shares of its stock in what would be first such effort by company; Stanley B Tulin, chief financial officer, says move is meant to give Equitable flexibility in managing capital (S)

headline: NE RESTAURANT TO BUY REST OF BERTUCCI'S FOR $89 MILLION
abstract: NE Restaurant Co says it agreed to acquire 95.2 percent of Bertucci's Inc it does not already own for $10.50 a share, or $88.9 million (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.50   5.52   5.61        3-month T-bills   4.98   5.03   5.13        6-month T-bills   5.09   5.13   5.39        10-yr. headline: European Coke Concern Expects 10% Profit Gain
abstract: Coca-Cola Beverages PLC, Europe's newest Coca-Cola company, says it will increase sales and profit by at least 10 percent starting this year; Coca-Cola Beverages was created from spinoff of European operations of Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd of Australia, with addition of Coca-Cola Co interests in northern and central Italy (S)

headline: Paris Journal; If You Hear Mozart Arias, This Is a Metro Station
abstract: Paris Journal on new regulations for musicians who want to perform in Metro: they may do so in station corridors, but not on platforms or in cars, and must audition before Metro official to obtain badges; Antoine Naso, who runs badge program, says he tries to imagine what public would like to hear; photo of American singer-guitarist Morty Baumann auditioning; map; rules have led to decline in number of performers, and marked improvement in quality of music heard (M)

headline: The Pursuit of Diana: Book Tells of Frenzy at Crash
abstract: New book about car crash that took lives of Princess Diana and Dodi Fayed states there is little evidence to bolster initial police theories that photographers chasing car caused driver, Henri Paul, to lose control; says Paul, who was killed also, was far over legal driving limit for alcohol, and that remains biggest probable cause of tragedy; nevertheless, book paints devastating picture of behavior of some of photographers who had been chasing Diana and Fayed for 12 hours before crash; notes that only one of 10 photographers at scene of crash tried to call ambulance, and that most spent first minutes after crash snapping pictures of wrecked car and its dead or dying passengers; book is Investigation on the Death of Diana, written by Jean-Marie Pontaut and Jerome Dupuis, French reporters; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Arms Experts Brief Security Council on Iraqi Compliance
abstract: Two days of Security Council briefings on information that Iraq has been withholding from arms inspectors end with Special Commission exec chmn Richard Bulter preparing to go to Baghdad with list of steps Iraq must take if sanctions are to be lifted (M)

headline: Insignia to Buy Brokerage
abstract: Insignia Financial Group Inc agrees to acquire Hotel Partners, privately held brokerage firm that focuses on hospitality segment of real estate market; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Business Travel; The airlines may face some new regulations on how to calculate a flight's on-time performance.
abstract: Airlines may face some new regulations by US Transportation Department on how to calculate a flight's on-time performance; business and leisure travelers can benefit from recently published Eurail and Train Travel Guide to Europe and Eurail and Train Travel Guide to the World; both books are edited by Gena Holle and recently published by Houghton Mifflin (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: Compressed Data; Possible Purchase of Bay By Nortel Faces Hurdles
abstract: Northern Telecom's expected bid for Bay Networks Inc may be being delayed by dispute over price and by opposition from Nortel's institutional investors (S)

headline: With Drugs and Gangs Rife, Mexican Governor Resigns
abstract: Jorge Carrillo Olea resigns as governor of Morelos, Mex, in face of growing citizen protests over blatant local activities of kidnapping gangs and drug traffickers; is prominent member of Pres Ernesto Zedillo's governing party (M)

headline: Apartheid Inquiry Will Hear Widow of Mozambique's President
abstract: Graca Machel, widow of Pres Samora Machel of Mozambique and current companion of South African President Nelson Mandela, will testify before country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about circumstances surrounding husband's death in plane crash in 1986; crash has always been deemed suspicious by Mozambicans since Mozambique had regularly vexed former South African Government by giving refuge to its political opponents (M)

headline: Killer Was Bitter Over Reprimand, Vatican Says
abstract: Officials at Holy See move quickly to quell furor over violent deaths of disgruntled Swiss guard, his commanding officer and wife inside Vatican; say Vice Cpl Cedric Tornay, three-year veteran of Guards, used service revolver in fit of madness to kill commanding officer, Lieut Col Alois Estermann, and wife Gladys Meza Romano, before committing suicide; describe him as disturbed and embittered over formal reprimand by Estermann on February 12 for missing curfew, and say he felt he was not valued in corps; Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro-Valls says Tornay showed no early warning signs of psychological imbalance, while secretly harboring delusions about professional status; says he complained to peers that he had been unfairly denied medal of recognition given to many Swiss guards on April 30 at annual swearing-in ceremony, Guards' most revered tradition, that was attended by Pope John Paul II; says shortly before murders Tornay handed letter to fellow guard, apparently suicide note, to be relayed to family; photos; map (M)

headline: Bouncing Graphics and Light That Love Music and Dancing
abstract: Madeira Software Co releases Screen Dance 98, screen saver program including variety of dancing graphics; photo (S)

headline: Nine West Names Team for Easy Spirit
abstract: Nine West Group names Toth Advertising and Design and PGR Media to handle creative and media portions of its Easy Spirit women's footwear account; account had been handled by Lotas Minard Patton McIver and Media That Works (S)

headline: GTE Expects $174 Million Quarter Loss
abstract: GTE Corp says it will post loss for first quarter and sell billions in assets as big local telephone company continues to remake itself to compete in increasingly hectic telecommunications industry; company says it has formally withdrawn its offer to buy MCI Communications Corp; GTE says it will take after-tax charge of $802 million (L)

headline: Yeltsin Envoy To Chechnya Is Kidnapped Near Border
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin's personal envoy to Chechnya, Valentin Vlasov, is taken hostage by gunmen in broad daylight on well-traveled road near Chechen border, demonstrating once again how little control Russia has over region; map; kidnappings have become commonplace and brazen since end of 1996 war, but Vlasov abduction is believed political, not mercenary (S)

headline: The Salsa Is Hot, but What About the Stock?
abstract: Sales of grocery products tailored to Mexican-American tastes are booming, spurring interest in investing in stock of speciality food companies; Mexican-Americans stress favor fresh foods that stress spices like cilantro and coriander, and heat; graphs; photos (M)6

headline: VIAD INCREASES OFFER FOR MONEYGRAM PAYMENT SYSTEMS
abstract: Viad Corp sweetens its offer for Moneygram Payment Systems Inc by about 2 percent a share, to $17.35 from $17 (S)

headline: Stop Blaming Colonialism, U.N. Chief Tells Africa
abstract: Kofi Annan, first United Nations Secretary General from sub-Saharan Africa, asserts it is time for Africans to hold their political leaders--and not colonialism--responsible for civil wars and economic failures that ravage their lives, report to Security Council; an aide describes report as tougher on Africans that some of 'sunny' surveys surrounding Pres Clinton's recent trip to continent; Annan declares a winner-take-all attitude toward politics had led to inequities of patronage and wealth; Annan plans to travel to eight African countries on April 29; writes his report at request of Security Council (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.59   5.47        3-month T-bills   4.87   4.85   5.08        6-month T-bills   5.04   5.02   5.31        10-yr. T-infl.   3.76   3.76   3.58        10-yr. T-note   5.65   5.66   6.63        30-yr. T-bond   5.93   5.94   6.88        Telephone bd.   7.11   7.11   7.94        Municipal bds.   5.37   5.39   5.87          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones; Markets; The Bond Buyer)

headline: U.S. Envoy, Again in Israel, Sees Netanyahu and Arafat
abstract: Israeli and American officials acknowledge that Israeli-Palestinian summit meeting offered by Pres Clinton cannot be held on May 11, but they indicate that it will still be held, perhaps in late May; Dennis Ross, American mediator in Middle East, holds separate meetings with Yasir Arafat, Chairman of Palestinian Authority, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu; Ross, after meeting with Arafat, says differences that remain are not large (M)

headline: Aegon Is Selling Investment Banking Unit
abstract: Aegon NV, one of largest Dutch insurance companies, says it will sell Bank Labouchere NV, its investment banking arm, to Dutch broker Amsterdam Options Traders NV; Aegon says two companies will be merged to create Bank AOT Labouchere; Aegon expects to record profit of $550 million to $750 million on transaction (S)

headline: Belgium's Largest Bank Is to Be Acquired
abstract: Fortis, Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance group, announces agreement to acquire Generale de Banque, Belgium's largest, for $11.1 billion (US) (S)

headline: CNA FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE MARITIME INSURANCE OF BRITAIN
abstract: CNA Financial Corp to acquire Maritime Insurance Co, British-based marine insurer, from Norwich Union PLC for $93 million (US) (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bump in Road to Euro May Signal Trouble Ahead  A messy political compromise that marred an agreement among European leaders to adopt a new single currency is likely to leave world markets more suspicious than before about the fledgling euro, financial analysts predicted. But few expect that when markets reopen today investors will react dramatically to the squabble, which involved naming a chief for the new European central bank.

headline: Heavy Demand for Blue-Chip Issues Pushes Dow Up 116
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 116.83 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,171.48; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 9.54 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 1,119.06; Nasdaq composite index falls 14.12 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 1,831.75; graph; chart (M)

headline: Asian Crisis Lifts Bonds But Not Stocks
abstract: Stock prices tumble even as Government bond yields fall to their lowest level in more than 20 years; disjunction of two markets, which have normally moved in same direction in recent years, is result of disquieting impact of economic turmoil in Asia; Dow Jones industrial average drops 159.93 points, or 1.8 percent, to 8,811.77, off 4.3 percent since May high, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks falls 17.70 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,094.58, down 3.2 percent since its April high; Nasdaq index closes down 23.50, or 1.3 percent, at 1,749.75; price of 30-year bond rises 23/32, to 106 25/32, while yield, which moves in opposite direction, falls to 5.65 percent from 5.70 percent on May 10 and below previous closing low of 5.69 percent Jan 12; it is lowest yield on 30-year bond since it was first issued regularly in 1977; 30-year corporate bond yields are at their lowest levels in 30 years; Japan's inability to right its economy, combined with comments from US Treasury Secretary Robert E Rubin sends dollar close to eight-year high against Japanese yen; dollar jumps 1.7 percent against yen to 143.79, as traders take Rubin's comments as invitation to sell yen; graph; charts on US key interest rates and tax-exempt yields (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supporting Cast Figures In Microsoft Complaint  While Netscape, Microsoft's rival in producing Internet browser software, is mentioned scores of times in the Government's antitrust complaint against Microsoft, and the Justice Department's case focuses mainly on the browser market, another bitter Microsoft competitor, Sun Microsystems, makes a few cameo appearances in the court papers filed last Monday.

headline: MERCURY FINANCE SEEKING BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: The Mercury Finance Company, the troubled car-loan concern, said yesterday that it would file in 60 days for bankruptcy-law protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. The moves were announced as Mercury, based in Chicago, said it had reached agreement with its senior lenders and subordinated debt holders for a recapitalization that would reduce debt and enable the company to return to profitability.

headline: 2 Czech Cities to Wall Off Their 'Problematic' Gypsies
abstract: USTI NAD LABEM, Czech Republic—  Two Czech cities have decided to fence in what they call "problematic" public housing residents, creating what is virtually a ghetto for the residents, mainly Gypsies, who officials say ruin the calm, orderly life of their neighbors.

headline: All Nippon Airways Cancels 54 More Flights
abstract: All Nippon Airways Co, Japanese carrier, cancels 54 more flights as talks fail to resolve pilots' strike (S)

headline: SUHARTO, BESIEGED, STEPS DOWN AFTER 32-YEAR RULE IN INDONESIA
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto apologizes for mistakes and resigns after 32 years in power, handing over post to Vice Pres B J Habibie, televised ceremony; makes no further promise of elections and says Habibie will serve out remainder of his term, which ends in 2003; Habibie, Suharto's longtime adviser, has little independent political base; student protesters, who continue to occupy Parliament building, Jakarta, hail resignation; indicate they will not be satisfied with Habibie; Defense Min Wiranto, at ceremony, hails resignation; pledges to support Habibie and guarantee safety of Suharto's family; photos (M)

headline: Wealthy Nations Cut Aid to Pakistan Over Nuclear Tests
abstract: Japan, Germany, Canada and Australia join US cut off aid to Pakistan for its explosion of nuclear bomb; other Pakistani trading partners, such as France and Russia, offer much milder responses, as they did when India carried out nuclear tests (S)

headline: Raytheon Unit Gets NASA Job
abstract: Raytheon Co says its Raytheon Systems unit received five-year, $148 million contract to provide information processing services at National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Ames Research Center in Mountain View, Calif (S)

headline: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS AS EXPORTS TO JAPAN DECLINE
abstract: Commerce Department reports United States exports to Japan plummeted in Feb, helping to widen US deficit in trade of goods and services to $12.1 billion from revised $11.5 billion in Jan; drop in exports to Japan of nearly 15 percent from Feb 1997, to $4.64 billion, shows effects of Japan's economic slump are spreading; is likely to increase tension between US and Japan over Japan's slow response to severe economic problems; graph (M)

headline: Dow Closes Above 9,000 For First Time
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 49.82, to close at record 9,033.23; on New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumber advancers by 1,727 to 1,318; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 1.32 points, to 1,121.38; Nasdaq composite index falls 26.26 points, to 1,829.14; graphs; charts (L)

headline: German Analysts See Slight Rise in Rates
abstract: Germany's six leading economic research institutes say German interest rates will rise only slightly before introduction of European currency union next year, with three-month money market rates staying about four percent in 1999; institutes say currency union members with higher rates will have to bring their rates down to meet German levels (S)

headline: FIRST CHARTER TO BUY HFNC FINANCIAL FOR $241 MILLION
abstract: First Charter Corp agrees to acquire HFNC Financial Corp for $241 million in stock (S)

headline: At Afrikaner Schools, a Backlash Against Blacks
abstract: South Africa's efforts to integrate formerly white public high schools erupts into violence in towns that are bastions of white Afrikaner farmers, who cannot afford private tuition and who feel deeply threatened by arrival of black students; in school in Vryburg, site of racial flare-up, there are actually two schools operating in one building, one for whites and one for blacks; residents say tensions have spilled over from school, exacerbating other problems in town; photo; map (M)

headline: EMERITUS SELLING 6 ASSISTED-LIVING COMMUNITIES
abstract: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that it was selling six of its unprofitable assisted-living operations to an undisclosed buyer for $53.1 million, reducing the company's losses by about $4 million a year. The six communities for the elderly have a total of 750 units. Emeritus, a long-term-care provider based in Seattle, holds interests in about 126 centers in 27 states and Canada. Four of the centers being sold are in Florida, one is in Kansas and one is in Arizona. In April, Emeritus said its loss, before a charge, widened to $8.4 million, or 84 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier.

headline: House Again Delays Financial Services Bill
abstract: US House Republican leader, Repr Dick Armey, announces another delay on already troubled bill to revamp laws governing financial services industries; Armey says vote planned for May 7 will be pushed back until sometime next week; he attributes delay to scheduling conflict by Repr John D Dingell, Commerce Committee's ranking Democrat; analysts say Armey, Dingell and other proponents do not have votes to pass the bill and that measure might be all but dead (S)

headline: EXXON TO CREATE UNIT TO FOCUS ON DEEP-WATER PROJECTS
abstract: Exxon Corp is forming subsidiary, Exxon Upstream Development Co, to focus on developing deep-water oil and gas projects; Exxon Upstream will develop Hoover-Diana project in Gulf of Mexico and Girassol project off Angola; it will also take over development of offshore projects in West Africa; new unit will begin operation on July 1 (S)

headline: Japan Disciplines 112 Finance Officials
abstract: Japanese Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga says 112 ministry officials will be punished for accepting excessive entertainment from banks, brokerage firms and insurers under their supervision; Atsushi Nagano, director general of ministry's securities bureau, and Takashi Sugii, deputy director general of banking bureau, have resigned over matter (S)

headline: People
abstract: Victoria Melekson, advertising director at Interview magazine, is promoted to new position of associate publisher (S)

headline: Use of Work Visas by Technology Companies Is Under Fire
abstract: Critics say many Americans could easily be trained to perform jobs for which high-tech companies bring in foreign workers under special H1-B visa program for hard-to-fill jobs; figures given to Congress by Immigration and Naturalization Service show 10 companies using most H1-B visas in 1997 provide types of computer-related jobs that do not necessarily require college-level math and science degrees; company that imported most foreign labor last year under H1-B program, Mastech Systems Corp, brought in software programmers with only bachelor's degrees; Sen Spencer Abraham has proposed that number of H1-B visas be raised, but Rep Ron Klink and others contend that American industry is exaggerating dearth of qualified labor market to import foreign workers who take jobs from Americans by agreeing to work for lower pay; graph (M)

headline: Durable Goods Orders Retreated by 2.6% in May
abstract: Commerce Department reports total orders for durable goods fell by 2.6 percent, to $184.305 billion in May, largest decline in five months; May decline follows revised 1.6 percent rise in April, originally reported as 2.2 percent gain; graph (M)

headline: LEVEL 3 COMMUNICATIONS ADDING XCOM TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Level 3 Communications Inc acquires Xcom Technologies Inc for $165 million in stock (S)

headline: Indonesia's Telkom To Delay Collections
abstract: PT Telkom, Indonesia's domestic telephone monopoly, will allow group of joint-venture partners to delay $5 million in payments for up to three months to help them survive country's economic slowdown; payments are for leasing parts of company's domestic phone network; partners include Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp of Japan and Cable and Wireless PLC of Britain (S)

headline: Birds in the Bush and the Database
abstract: Bird-watching is becoming increasingly sophisticated in the 1990's with variety of gadgets replacing traditional binoculars and notebooks; today's serious bird-watcher may use palmtop computer with special software for record keeping, global positioning device to locate birds, parabolic microphone and professional audio recording device, nighttime scope, and telephoto camera lenses; listing of bird-watching websites; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Germany's mark falls for third day on news of benign inflation there, diminishing possibility that Bundesbank will soon raise interest rates; dollar rises to 1.7766 marks from 1.7701 in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: In an Old Orchard, Tastes the Supermarket Forgot
abstract: I FINALLY understood why Adam was so enticed by Eden's apples when we  walked for the first time through our orchard near the northern coast of Lake Michigan. More than 100 apple trees -- some gnarled and thick at the trunk like an old ash, others mere saplings -- stood scattered on a sandy ridge between the maple forest and a dun-colored meadow.     It was September 1991, weeks before the fruit fully matured. Still, the orchard's scent was sweet and inviting. A dry summer had produced unblemished apples that hung from the limbs in a wondrous display of variety and color. Big, red round apples almost as large as grapefruits were on one tree, and they had a light, candy taste. There were large green apples, a kind that had probably been stored during the winter in straw-lined pits to be eaten in spring. And there were smaller green apples with brown patches that might have originated from the old Roxbury Russet varieties popular in northwestern Michigan around the turn of the century.

headline: Blair Blocks Release of Rules for Parades in Northern Ireland
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair blocks publication of Government restrictions on Northern Ireland's flashpoint summer parades, saying that he wants to avoid destabilizing province at 'volatile time' (M)

headline: Hong Kong Confronts Democracy: How Soon?
abstract: Hong Kong's pro-democracy politicians, emboldened by their sweeping election victory, are calling for swifter transition to full democracy; Democratic Party head Martin Lee calls for direct election of all 60 members of legislature by 2000 and of chief executive by 2002 (M)

headline: Before Celebrating a Nation, Remember the 20,000 Soldiers Who Died Defending It
abstract: Israel's Indpendence Day, year's most joyous day, follows directly on Memorial Day, its most painful; since a day in Jewish calendar starts previous evening and ends at sundown, Israel's 50th birthday party--fireworks, street music, dancing--takes off at sundown after 24 hours of wrenching commemoration for the more than 20,000 soldiers who have fallen in battle (Reporter's Notebook column) (M)

headline: Arnold Receives Top Print Award
abstract: Arnold Communications wins top award in print portion of International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, known as Press and Poster Awards (S)

headline: A Flexible System That is Easy to USe
abstract: FAMILY HERITAGE DELUXE  (Mindscape; $19.99; Windows 95 and NT.)

headline: Campuses Are Turning To Laptops For Students
abstract: Laptop computers are becoming required equipment for more and more college and graduate school students; cost is frequently covered by tuition (M)

headline: In Borneo's Fading Jungles, a Grim Tale of Wildlife
abstract: BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia—  One by one, Gabriella Fredriksson tracked down the five little bears she had released into the forest.

headline: Seagram Expands Grey Assignment
abstract: Seagram Americas expands its relationship with Grey Advertising by naming agency to handle creative and media assignments for Seagram's VO Canadian whisky (S)

headline: If He Can't Tell What's Real, How Can You?
abstract: Market Watch column on Cendant Corp and its chief, Henry Silverman, who has lost reputation for erstwhile genius after admitting that he was taken in by inflated financial results during merger that created Cendant; says it is noteworthy that Silverman sold every Cendant share he ever bought, and currently owns not a single Cendant share; graph (M)

headline: New Partnership Of Cable Systems
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc forms cable partnership with New York concerns Bresnan Communications Inc and Blackstone Group; deal will allow Tele-Communications to shed $910 million in debt; new company will own and operate cable systems in Michigan, Minnesota, Nebraska and Wisconsin; Tele-Communications will own 50 percent of new company; Blackstone, 40 percent, and Bresnan, 10 percent (S)

headline: Rape and Murder Stalk Women in Northern Mexico
abstract: At least 70 women, many of them factory workers, have been raped and murdered in Ciudad Juarez, Mex, and their bodies dumped in desert over last five years; murders have shone spotlight on victimization of women workers and on growing influence of fledgling women's movement spurred by attacks; feminists and congresswomen say violence is fed by male backlash against independent social lives of women workers; score stumbling probe; map; photo (M)

headline: Shares of Ciena Fall on Outlook
abstract: Ciena Corp shares fall 5.4 percent after Ciena says it is unsure when orders for special equipment to bolster phone networks will come in from Worldcom Inc and AT&T Corp; Worldcom has cut off orders until it completes purchase of MCI Corp; AT&T continues to test Ciena equipment (S)

headline: The Information Superhighway and Its Back Roads
abstract: Chart depicts backbone metaphor as road in describing fiber-optic cable system that carries huges amount of computer data (M)

headline: Intuit Executive To Become Chief
abstract: Intuit Inc plans to promote William Harris to president and chief executive, succeeding William Campbell, who will become chairman; Scott Cook, who founded Intuit in 1983 and who is now chairman, will become chairman of board's executive committee (S)

headline: Lufthansa President Named Chief of Marketing at Delta
abstract: Lufthansa German Airlines president Frederick W Reid will join Delta Air Lines as marketing chief, latest in series of top personnel changes by Delta's chairman-chief executive Leo F Mullin (M)

headline: Sony Comes On Strong in Video-Game War
abstract: Computer-gaming industry convenes in Atlanta later this week for Electronic Entertainment Expo and annual battle of gaming titans; this year, that mainly means face-off between Nintendo, creator of Nintendo 64 and Mario, and Sony, creator of Playstation and Parappa; photos; chart (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Squatters: Land Claims on White Farms
abstract: Hundreds of subsistence farmers in Zimbabwe move onto three farms in Mardonera region as squatters in effort to reclaim ancestral lands seized by whites 120 years ago; say Government's land reform program, which would redistribute land to poor farmers, is going too slowly; whites, who number less than 2 percent of population, own 70 percent of land; map (M)

headline: Oran Henderson, 77, Dies; Acquitted in My Lai Case
abstract: Col Oran K Henderson, highest-ranking officer to be tried as consequence of killings of Vietnamese civilians in My Lai in 1968, dies at age 77; photo

headline: Ex-Vichy Aide Is Convicted And Reaction Ranges Wide
abstract: French court finds Maurice Papon guilty of complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity because as a Vichy official he turned Jews over to the Germans in World War II; imposes 10-year prison sentence, with deprivation of civil rights; finding both comforts and disconcerts country Papon served as high-ranking civil servant for 50 years; Papon remains free while he appeals, and both sentence and his continuing freedom draw criticism from those who expected more severe sentence; photo (M)

headline: COTT'S EFFORTS TO FIND A BUYER COME UP EMPTY
abstract: Coptt Corp, soft drink maker, says that efforts to find buyer failed (S)

headline: Some Japanese Banks Report Largest Losses Ever
abstract: Six of Japan's biggest banks report largest annual losses ever for year ended Mar 31 as they write off some of bad debts that could total at least $600 billion; predict modest profits for current fiscal year; economic fragility in Japan and financial crisis in Indonesia and rest of Asia threaten future earnings and could severely hamper banks' ability to grant new loans; Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi sets aside reserves and writes off loans worth over $10 billion, reporting net loss of about $6.7 billion (M)

headline: Poles Say, 'Thank You, America,' and Czechs and Hungarians Voice Delight
abstract: Polish Prime Min Jerzy Buzek breaks into rarely-used English to say 'Thank you, America' for US Senate's vote to approve NATO membership; Czechs and Hungarians voice similar delight (S)

headline: International Briefs; China's Bank Regulation Is Criticized by Moody's
abstract: Moody's Investors Service says arbitrary and unpredictable regulation by Chinese banking authorities poses great risk to outsiders (S)

headline: Complex Pressures, Dominated by Islam, Led to Testing
abstract: Pakistan's nuclear scientists are hailed as heroes in Islamabad on return from nuclear test site in Baluchistan desert; decision to proceed with recent tests to match those carried out by archrival India resulted from complex interplay of pressures inside Govt of Prime Min Nawaz Sharif, desires of military and scientists, political rivalries and potent fact that Pakistan is Islamic country forged from religious hatreds that ripped apart old British Raj and has left largely Hindu India dominant force on subcontinent; Gallup poll found 97 percent support for nuclear testing; photo (M)

headline: Shareholders Push for Tighter Rules Abroad
abstract: International panel makes recommendations to Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development on improving accountability of foreign companies to their shareholders; new interest in worldwide corporate governance issues is also reflected in internatinoal survey of institutional investors commissioned by Russell Reynolds Associates from Wirthlin Worldwide (M)

abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Templates With Humor And Beauty
abstract: Harold Goldberg reviews NetObjects' Web-site development program for intermediate and professional designers; photo (M)

abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Toxic Sludge Cleanup to Cost Spain 100 Million
abstract: Spanish Government says toxic sludge that burst from mine reservoir and flooded rivers and farms in southern Spain in April will take more than $100 million to clean up; map (M)

headline: Wrangler Jeans Venture
abstract: VF Corp forms joint venture to manufacture and market Wrangler jeans in Japan; VF says it owned majority rights in venture; other partners are Toyobo Co and Mitsubishi Corp (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CHARLES SCHWAB CORP., San Francisco, said its brokerage unit president and chief operating officer, Timothy McCarthy, had resigned, six months after being named to head the division, to seek work with buyout firms.    EMI RECORDED MUSIC, New York, named Roy Lott to the new position of deputy president of EMI Recorded Music North America.

headline: Big Board Posts 2.3% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Open positions of short sales on New York Stock Exchange increased 2.3 percent in last month, to 4.02 billion shares as of June 15, up from 3.93 billion a month earlier; short interest rose 3.7 percent on American Stock Exchange, to 196.5 million shares as of June 15 from 189.5 million shares; tables (M)

headline: AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL EXPANDS PROPERTY HOLDINGS
abstract: American Industrial Properties acquires six light-industrial and low-rise office properties and two parcels of land for about $43.5 million, expanding its holdings in US Southwest (S)

headline: Corestates Settles Bond Case With U.S. for $3.7 Million
abstract: Corestates Financial Corp says it agreed to pay $3.7 million to settle Federal allegations that its brokerage firm unit grossly overcharged investors and Federal and local governments in series of municipal bond deals in early 1990's; settlement is first time financial institution has agreed to pay fine for 'yield burning,' what Federal investigators call fraudulent marking up of bond prices (M)

headline: NEWELL IN STOCK SWAP WITH COOKWARE MAKER, CALPHALON
abstract: Newell Co acquires Calphalon Corp in stock swap; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Wireless Phone Will Operate Abroad
abstract: The Audiovox Corporation and the Bosch Telecom unit of Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany plan to announce today the availability of a wireless telephone that can operate on different continents without modification.    The new phone is based on a digital technology known as global system for mobile communications, or G.S.M. While other technologies are more popular than G.S.M. in the United States, G.S.M. is the dominant digital wireless technology overseas, especially in Europe.

headline: Turning the Tables: This Time, a Shareholder Is Being Sued
abstract: Emerging Germany fund has filed lawsuit against two activist shareholders, contending they violated Securities and Exchange Commission rules on proxy solicitation; suit accuses Phillip Goldstein and Ronald Olin of using Internet chat room to solicit shareholders to persuade management to convert fund's status and, in doing so, of violating SEC proxy solicitation rules; Goldstein says suit is meant to intimidate any challenge to management (M)

headline: $21 Billion Goes To Stock Funds
abstract: Trim Tabs Financial Services estimates United States stock mutual funds had net inflow of $21.1 billion, June, up from $18.7 billion in May; Investment Co Institute reports some $9.81 billion was invested in bond funds in May, up from $5.24 billion in Apr; almost $26.3 million was invested in money market funds in May, reversing Apr outflow of $12.7 billion (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls again after Pakistan tests five nuclear bombs, adding to uncertainty in Asia; dollar rises to 138.70 yen from 137.40 in New York, highest level since August 1991; graph; chart (S)

headline: Families Link Up
abstract: Candace A Hill letter lauds Mar 26 article on family communication via the Internet (S)

headline: DVD-Video Is Late to Bloom
abstract: Digital video disk (DVD) players, despite high-quality image, are slow in penetrating mass market, with consumers questioning whether they need another machine to play movies; disagreement in industry over competing plans for DVD players has also slowed consumer acceptance of format; photo (M)

headline: Laser Makers Agree To End Partnership
abstract: Visx Inc will pay Summit Technology Inc $35 million to end partnership and settle lawsuits between two laser companies; Visx and Summit make lasers to used to treat eye problems; each company grants the other royalty-free cross-license for their patented technologies involving removal of cornea tissue from the eye (S)

headline: Old-Line Retailers Resist On-Line Life
abstract: American retail stores find that Internet, touted as great electronic bazaar, is not successful venue for them; few if any are making money on Web; only 15 percent to 20 percent of sales figures for electronic commerce goes to on-line sites of conventional retailers; most retailers are still struggling to decide how to use medium--or whether they belong on line at all; Sheri Wilson-Gray, Saks Fifth Avenue's executive vice president of marketing, says Saks's brief exposure on Web convinced her that cyberspace is not conducive to selling high-priced, high-touch goods they specialize in; merchants finding most success at selling on line tend to be those that exist only on line; these companies have advantages of knowing quirks of electronic commerce, and being small and agile enough to adapt to shifting on-line technologies and demographics; photo (M)

headline: Dread Rules: An Unpopular Leader Leaves Nigerians Fearful and Divided
abstract: Death of Gen Sani Abacha, deeply unpopular military dictator, leaves Nigeria in state of dread; Abacha leaves behind demoralized army, political class whose leaders have been jailed or exiled and looted economy; army remains divided despite elevation of Gen Abdulsalam Abubakar; chronology of Abacha's reign; photos (M)

headline: Legislature Clears New Law On Day Before Its Dissolution; 'Just the Beginning,' Foes Say : Beijing Gains Wide Immunity In Hong Kong's Legal System
abstract: HONG KONG—  China's handpicked provisional legislature adopted a bill Tuesday that exempts some mainland Chinese agencies from Hong Kong law.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Briefly Exceeds 9,000 As Stocks End Strong Week  Stocks finished mostly higher yesterday, capping a strong week of gains that briefly pushed the Dow Jones industrial average past the 9,000 level for the first time.

headline: Stock Mutual Fund Purchases Reduced
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports investors reduced their stock mutual fund purchases by about 23 percent in May; estimated $20.5 billion went into mutual funds in May, down from $26.6 billion in April; trade group says it plans to stop publishing monthly estimates after release of June estimates because they have been inaccurately reported (S)

headline: BUS DEALS TO MAKE COACH USA THE LARGEST IN ITS FIELD
abstract: Coach USA Inc to buy 10 bus and ground-transportation companies with total annual revenue of about $125 million; terms undisclosed; acquisitions include Gray Line New York, Shortline, Airport Connection, Tippett Travel, Valen Transportation and Mini Coach of Boston Inc (S)

headline: I.B.M. Begins Making Fast, Cheaper Chip
abstract: International Business Machines Corp begins industry's first large-scale production of of type of chip that may cut prices and improve performance and portability for cellular phones and other wireless communications devices; use of germanium, efficient electricity conductor, allows combination of wireless communications components and silicon digital transistors on single chip; analysts expect silicon germanium chips to play key role in future network-switching equipment for routing all sorts of Internet traffic (M)

headline: 'Fun Stuff' in '48: British Gentile in Israel Air Force
abstract: Article on Gordon Levett, British pilot and non-Jew, who volunteered to fight against Arabs who threatened new Israeli state in 1948; Levett recalls being only English gentile pilot in Israeli Air Force during recent visit to Israel; photo (M)

headline: A Buffett Effect on Sequoia
abstract: Stock in Sequoia mutual fund has been adversely affected by Berkshire Hathaway's announced acquisition of General Re; 26.4 percent of Sequoia portfolio is in Berkshire; photo; graph (M)

headline: Mixed Day for Share Prices as Inflation Worries Still Nag
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is down 18.68 points at 8,898.96; Nasdaq composite index rises 11.46 , to 1,831.77; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 1.43 points; Japan's benchmark Nikkei index falls 254.52 points, or 1.63 percent, after losing 361.29 points, or 2.26 percent, on April 27; graph; chart (L)

headline: Q & A / Edmund Jensen, President of Visa : Large Retailers May Spur Revolution in Chip Cards
abstract: Edmund Jensen, president and chief executive of Visa International Inc., is retiring in December after a four-year tenure that saw Visa expand into chip-card technology. He recently discussed the future of smart cards with Gina Rarick of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Invitation To Dispute a Settlement
abstract: Lawyers who won $1 billion class-action settlement from brokerage firms that allegedly unfairly priced Nasdaq securities, May 1989-July 1996, are offering investors chance to exclude selves from settlement and initiate separate suits; few individuals are likely to do so, even though they will not learn much about settlement details before July 14 deadline (M)

headline: Job Growth Surges
abstract: Despite Asian tremors, stock market jitters and fears that America is running out of workers, the economy is still booming. In May, the Labor Department reported yesterday, employers added nearly 300,000 new jobs, unemployment held steady at an almost unbelievably low 4.3 percent -- the lowest rate in 28 years -- and pay continued to rise.   Business Day, page D1.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MCN ENERGY GROUP INC., Detroit, an energy holding company, said the Internal Revenue Service had ruled the company qualified for tax credits on a coal-refining project. The company's stock rose $2.75, to $39.3125.    TRANSCEND THERAPEUTICS INC., Cambridge, Mass., a biotechnology company, ended a test of an intravenous form of its lead drug, intended to treat respiratory infection, after suspending the study in March as more patients getting the drug died than those on a placebo.

headline: Indians Risk Invoking U.S. Law Imposing Big Economic Penalties
abstract: India risks invoking US law that could block billions of dollars in aid by recently carrying out three underground nuclear tests; national security adviser Samuel R Berger says officials are scrutinizing never-used 1994 Nuclear Proliferation Prevention Act--Federal law which orders President Clinton to impose severe penalties on nations conducting nuclear tests or selling nuclear weapons; law covers nations developing nuclear weapons but excludes declared nuclear powers; action by India prompts US officials to plead with Pakistan not to intensify regional arms race by conducting its own atomic tests (M)

headline: Risking Labor Trouble and Clash Of Cultures, 2 Makers Opt for Size
abstract: Plannned merger of Daimler-Benz AG and Chrysler Corp will turn two medium-sized auto makers with limited vehicle lineups into single, nearly global manufacturer selling everything from economy cars to luxury sedans to sport utility vehicles and minivans; short-term advantages of merger are clear; Daimler's automotive unit, Mercedes-Benz, will no longer be so dependent on European sales and on luxury-car market; Chrysler will no longer earn almost all its profit from sales in US; auto executives say several obstacles remain to any long-term success from merger; one lies in avoiding ponderous decision-making that has plagued General Motors, partly because of its enormous size; another danger comes from combining two giant corporations with very different business cultures; third pitfall may lurk in auto makers sometimes contentious labor relations (M)

headline: U.S. and Microsoft to Talk Before Possible Showdown
abstract: Justice Department's top antitrust official Joel I Klein is scheduled to meet with Microsoft Corp general counsel William H Neukom in Washington, DC, in what both sides are portraying as effort to find common ground instead of going to court again (L)

headline: KTI IN STOCK AND CASH DEAL FOR FCR, A WASTE HANDLER
abstract: KTI Inc agrees to buy FCR Inc for $63.9 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GREAT LAKES INC., Oak Brook, Ill., a real estate investment trust, agreed to acquire the 28-story, 370,000-square-foot Milwaukee Center Office Tower in Milwaukee for about $46.7 million.    PPG INDUSTRIES, Pittsburgh, a chemical, coatings and glass company, will repurchase up to 10 million of its shares and increase its quarterly dividend to 36 cents a share from 34 cents.

headline: As Prices Sink, Hong Kong Curbs Land Sales
abstract: Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee-hwa says government, seeking to stop frightening downward spiral in property market, is halting sale of land until March; ; action is starkest sign yet of how deeply Asian crisis is hurting Hong Kong's normally resilient economy; property prices drive broader stock market in Hong Kong, and government is biggest single landowner, selling about half of Hong Kong's new residential property at public auctions; by halting land sales, officials are trying to stop plunge in prices; Tung announces series of measures to restore consumer confidence and ease deepening credit shortage; these include lowering of import and export duties, tax rebates and freeze on government salaries; photo (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Charter One Financial Inc, holding company of Charter One Bank, and CS Financial Corp, holding company of Cuyahoga Savings Assn, announce definitive agreement to merge in stock-for-stock exchange (S)

headline: Kaplan Thaler Group Wins Aussie Campaign
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb names Kaplan Thaler Group to handle advertising for its newly acquired Aussie hair care products (S)

headline: Brief Books for Busy Readers
abstract: Two publishers are investing in two series of short books by prominent authors; hope is that busy people will be attracted to books that can be read in couple of hours; short-book idea was tried unsuccessfully 9 years ago by Christopher Whittle; in latest effort, Viking Penguin unit of Pearson PLC's Penguin Putnam Inc is entering into joint venture with Kenneth Lipper, whose Lipper & Co is providing 50 percent of equity for project and taking editorial role in series; second publisher trying out short books will be Ballantine unit of Random House Inc; photo (M)
