headline: $1.6 Billion in Deals Can't Mask U.S. Disappointment
abstract: Commerce Sec William M Daley and Zeng Peiyan, chairman of China State Planning Commission, gather with American and Chinese officials in Great Hall of the People in Beijing to announce $1.6 billion worth of new trade and investment deals between two countries; while both sides tried to put best face on occasion, US disappointment was obvious since American companies received far less than expected; many deals were given inflated values or were same ones announced earlier; poor showing attributed to faltering Asian economy and White House sensitivity to allegations that it helped American aerospace companies conduct business in China in exchange for campaign contributions; photo (M)

headline: MEDIQ IN $50 MILLION CASH DEAL FOR CH INDUSTRIES UNIT
abstract: Mediq Inc agrees to acquire CH Industries' CH Medical unit for $50 million in cash (S)

headline: CITIZENS BANCSHARES TO BUY MID AM FOR $681 MILLION
abstract: Citizens Bancshares Inc to acquire Mid Am Inc, rival Ohio bank holding company, for $681 million in stock (S)

headline: Sumitomo Likely To Pay Big Fine
abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission is expected to announce that Sumitomo Corp will pay record fine totaling $150 million to settle charges of illegal trading by its former chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka (S)

headline: In a Process That's 'Going to Be Years': World Bank's Estimate For Jakarta:$3 Billion
abstract: SINGAPORE—  The World Bank is warning that $3 billion in emergency food and medical aid will be needed over the next year to help Indonesia provide essential supplies to millions of people affected by drought and the economic crisis.

headline: 2 Big Clients Consolidate Accounts
abstract: First Brands Corp consolidates advertising account, naming McCann-Erickson to handle its Glad plastic products, STP automotive products and four cat litter brands; parts of account had been handled by Young & Rubicam Advertising, Bozell Worldwide, J Walter Thompson and Leo Burnett Co; Kaiser Permanente consoidates its national direct response advertising at Rapp Collins Worldwide; account had been split among nine agencies (S)

headline: West Wayne Names Chief Creative Officer
abstract: West Wayne Inc. in Atlanta has named Luke Sullivan to oversee its creative output as chief creative officer. Mr. Sullivan, 43, a copywriter at Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis for almost a decade, assumes responsibilities from Martin Macdonald, vice chairman and executive creative director, who left in February.

headline: Satellite Network Is Planned To Keep Car Radios Tuned In
abstract: Lucent Technologies to develop and supply communications chips for planned satellite-to-car radio network that will beam programming coast to coast; CD Radio is building 50-channel subscription radio system using Lucent chips; photo (M)8

headline: Treasury Will Offer Both Bills and Notes In This Week's Sales
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.92 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.05 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.57 percent, and the five-year note to yield 5.62 percent.

headline: Prizes Created As Memorial To a Writer
abstract: Series of awards have been established in honor of late writer J Anthony Lukas, including annual prize for book on important aspect of American social or political life and grant for work in progress on similar subject; awards were conceived by Lukas's widow, Linda Healey, and Arthur Gelb; will be administered by Harvard University's Nieman Foundation and Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and financed by family of late Mark Lynton (S)

headline: U.S. Eyes Curbs on Belgrade As Albanian Deaths Mount
abstract: US will seek freeze on Yugoslav assets held overseas, in response to warnings that heavy fighting in Kosovo Province is on verge of spilling into Albania; map; State Departments has reports of 'myriad deaths' in Kosovo, where 90 percent of population is ethnic Albanian (S)

headline: Top man on TBWA Chiat/Day's Nissan account takes a leave. Other agency changes afoot.
abstract: Personnel and organizational changes are underway at several leading advertising agencies and agency companies; Tom Patty, top executive on TBWA Chiat/Day's largest account, Nissan Motor Corp, unexpectedly steps down for sabbatical of undetermined length; agency president Bob Kuperman will assume his duties while successor is sought; move comes as agency is under pressure to help spur slumping Nissan sales; J Walter Thompson is reorganizing worldwide direct marketing operations, which had been handled by 21 offices and affiliates, under single identity, Thompson Connect Worldwide; names Michael Graham to added post of chief executive of Thompson Connect; True North Communications gathers its promotional marketing companies into unit, Promotion Services Group; Wes Bray will head unit as president; TLP unit of Omnicom Group, formerly known as TL Partnership, forms TL Planet, network of promotional marketing agencies; TLP president David J Marchi will temporarily oversee TL Planet (M)

headline: Christian Group Feels Net Filter's Wrath
abstract: Cyber Patrol, popular Internet filter designed to cordon off nastier corners of Internet from users, particularly children, is blocking Web site of American Family Association, conservative Christian group that is vocal supporter of such filter software; classifies group as 'intolerant' because of its support for discrimination based on sexual orientation; association holds it does not preach hatred of homosexuals; Cyber Patrol oversight committee rejects group's bid to remove block; agrees to review site again and other pro- and anti-gay Web sites (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for Auction Today
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.87 percent and a six-month bill was 5.10 percent.    The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: Cramer-Krasselt Wins Birds Eye
abstract: Dean Foods Vegetable Co says it named Cramer-Krasselt to handle advertising for its Birds Eye frozen vegetables line; billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million (S)

headline: COLTEC INDUSTRIES COMPLETES ITS MOVE OUT OF AUTO PARTS
abstract: Coltec Industries agrees to sell its Holley Performance Products carburetor and ignition systems business to management-led group backed by Kohlberg & Co for $100 million, completing Coltec's move out of auto parts business (S)

headline: British and Japanese Win Singapore Pact
abstract: Group led by British Telecommunications PLC and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp of Japan wins license to sell fixed and mobile phone services in Singapore and pledges to invest as much as $1.7 billion there; group will give Singapore Telecommunications Ltd its first head-on competition (S)

headline: ULTRAMAR TO CUT 466 JOBS AND SELL OR SHUT 14% OF STORES
abstract: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corp plans to eliminate 466 jobs and sell or close 14 percent of its stores in move to cut costs and increase profitability (S)

headline: Yugoslav Leader Curbs TV and Radio
abstract: Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic uses licensing powers to clamp down on independent radio and television stations, as part of drive to consolidate power lost after huge street protests last year (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department issues its weekly report on planting progress for seven crops.    TUESDAY  The Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee meets. Most economists expect no change in interest rates for now.  The Commerce Department reports on April housing starts. The average forecast is for 1.599 million, an increase of 0.6 percent from March.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.

headline: Holding the Reins of Reality
abstract: Article evaluates computer game Unreal, an application for 3-D accelerator cards; game is published by GT Interactive; photos (M)

headline: Vehicle Sales Are Highest Since 1986
abstract: Nation's auto industry reports that May was best month for car and truck sales since September 1986, with sales totaling 1,511,661 cars and trucks, a 12.1 percent increase from year-earlier period; seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for light vehicles reached 16.3 million cars and trucks, highest level since October 1987; car sales totaled 793,066 units, up 6.9 percent; light-truck sales topped 718,575 units, up 18.4 percent; General Motors says it sold 484,168 cars and trucks, increase of 12.4 percent over May 1997; truck sales increased 19.2 percent, to 226,114 vehicles; Ford reports it sold 353,270 cars and trucks in May, up 1.2 percent from May 1997; car sales totaled 141,558, down 5.5 percent; truck sales were 211,712, up 6.2 percent from last year; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Gazprom Cites Pressure to Buy Oil Company
abstract: Gazprom, Russia's natural gas monopoly, says Government is pressing it to buy oil company Rosneft as other potential bidders appear short of cash and unable to pay $2.5 billion asking price; Gazprom plans to make final decision on May 26, when bidding for Rosneft closes (S)

headline: City of Angels Is the City of Death for Magazines
abstract: Demise of Buzz, which originally competed against seven other Los Angeles magazines, leaves nation's second-largest city served by only one general-interest city magazine; survivor, Walt Disney Co's money-losing Los Angeles, will pay $5.3 million for Buzz's subscription list and trademarks; photo (M)

headline: His Critics Say President's Words Ring Hollow
abstract: Clinton Administration officials praise President for his performance in Beijing, where he spoke out on human rights in televised news conference with Chinese Pres Jian Zemin, while his critics say he did only minimum that was required and that his words were largely empty (M)

headline: Shares Post Modest Gains, With Dow Climbing by 17.44
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs 17.44 points, to 9,012.30; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slip 0.98 point, to 1,109.69; Nasdaq index finishes 4.71 points higher at 1,824.95; graph; chart (L)

headline: COMMERCIAL UNION PLANS TO ACQUIRE FARMERS UNION
abstract: Commercial Union PLC says its US unit agrees to buy Farmers Union Insurance Acquisition Corp for about $118 million (S)

headline: Especially in India/Fair Color as a Cultural Virtue : Creams for a Lighter Skin Capture the Asian Market
abstract: NEW DELHI—  When Abha Bhatnagar was growing up, her mother forbade her to go outdoors. She was not trying to keep her daughter out of trouble. "She was trying to keep my skin from getting dark," said Mrs. Bhatnagar, who disobeyed the order. Now she regrets that her olive skin is not lighter. But she believes there is a solution: fairness cream, which she recently started using on her face.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merrill Lynch Settles Suit Brought by Orange County  Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $400 million to Orange County, Calif., to settle claims that the firm helped push the county into bankruptcy in 1994 with reckless investment advice.    With the settlement, the county will have recovered more than $621 million, and may end up recovering more than $800 million over all, out of $1.6 billion lost. [Page A1.]

headline: In the End, Voters Found, a Real Chance at Peace Was Irresistible
abstract: Supporters of Northern Ireland peace accord, approved by 71 percent of voters in North, succeeded in building coalition that includes majority of Catholic nationalists and large share of Protestant Unionists; convinced more than half of wavering Unionists that treaty offers chance for peace; photo (M)

headline: Billion here, billion there, and soon your estimate on 1998 U.S. ad spending reaches $200.3 billion.
abstract: Robert J Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson USA unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, says he will again raise his estimate of ad spending for 1998; Coen predicts marketers will spend record $200.3 billion in US, up 6.8 percent from revised figure of $187.5 billion for 1997 (M)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Plans Rescue of Unit
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG will set aside as much as 4.5 billion marks ($2.5 billion) this year to cover cost of its money-losing cable TV operation after regulator rejects its attempt to raise fees; company is 74 percent owned by German Government (S)

headline: How Conversions Can Take a Toll
abstract: Shareholders who sell their closed-end shares at wrong time may end up with lagging returns, high tax bills or both; unlike open-end funds, whose potentially unlimited number of shares are bought and sold at net asset value, closed-end funds have set number of shares bought and sold on stock markets (M)

headline: Small Company Builds on Edge Of Microsoft's Real Estate
abstract: Pixel Co is set to offer computer software innovation that could loosen Microsoft Corp's grip on computer desktop, which Microsoft controls through its dominant Windows operating system; Pixel program adds control bar at unused bottom edge of computer screen that can link user to World Wide Web site, control hardware like CD player or start software programs; Packard Bell NEC plans to begin installing software in its computers for home market; on-line information and commerce sites have signed accords with Pixel to place their icons on control bar (M)

headline: Shares of EMI Rise as It Says Talks May Lead to Merger
abstract: Shares of EMI Group PLC soar after company confirms speculation that it is in talks that might lead to acquisition offer; unnamed suitor is said to be Seagram Co; person close to Seagram says that because of potential cost of acquiring EMI, Seagram has approached several other companies to join with it in possible purchase; EMI's market capitalization is about $8 billion following surge in company's shares (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Russia at risk, and the I.M.F.'s prescription raises concerns.
abstract: Economic Scene column on erosion of Russian economy and whether International Monetary Fund is applying flawed priorities and policies in Russia; says drumbeat is growing from critics of IMF, which places enormous premium on stabilizing currency exchange rates, sometimes at very high costs; holds genuine reforms, ranging from changes in tax system to application of rule of law, are necessary to get Russian economy moving; says as long as Russia depends on good opinion of international capital markets, those reforms may not be sufficient; drawing (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark strengthens as Russia, major trading partner of Germany, averts default on debts by raising more than $2 billion in bond sales; dollar falls to 1.7710 marks from 1.7806 marks in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: For Most in Belfast, an Easter of Joy and Hope
abstract: People of Northern Ireland go to their churches to celebrate Easter and to pray for permanent peace promised by historic agreement signed by leaders of Protestant majority and Roman Catholic minority; many of them barely remember when there was no sectarian violence; forgiveness and hope for peace are themes at most Catholic and Protestant churches, but not at breakaway church founded by Rev Ian Paisley, who kept his Democratic Unionist Party out of peace negotiations; Paisley, publicly described by opponents as xenophobe and fascist, attacks peace agreement and urges his congregation of 300 mostly older people to vote against it in May 22 referendum; one of his congregants voices fear about terrorists being released, theme Paisley has been stressing; under peace accord, many Catholic and Protestant paramilitary prisoners would be eligible for early release within two years; photo (M)

headline: Diplomat Rules Bosnia With a Strong Hand
abstract: Carlos Westendorp, Spanish diplomat responsible for carrying out Bosnian peace agreement, says he is determined to shatter monolithic grip on power by Serbian, Croatian and Muslim nationalist parties that waged war and control three partitioned entities; Westerndorp rules Bosnia by fiat with blessing of US; photo (M)

headline: British Concern Drops MCI Suit
abstract: Cable and Wireless PLC drops breach-of-contract lawsuit that it filed against MCI Communications Corp to secure its bid to buy all of long-distance company's Internet business (S)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are Off Slightly on Nasdaq
abstract: Nasdaq stock market reports that open positions of short sales on market slipped six-hundredths of 1 percent, to 1.97 billion, in month through May 15 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Average Near 9,000 As Stocks Surge Again  The Dow Jones industrial average flirted with the 9,000-point level as stocks roared higher on waning fears of inflation. The Dow closed at 8,986.64, up 118.32 points, or 1.33 percent.

headline: Dalai Lama Is All Smiles Over Debate
abstract: Interview with Dalai Lama, who says Pres Clinton's debate with Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin over Tibet during televised news conference in Beijing is one of best things ever to happen for Tibetan cause; says debate sent signals not only to watching world, but importantly, across China, that Tibet is issue whose time has come; photo (M)

headline: A Top Female Executive Leaves Disney/ABC
abstract: Geraldine B Laybourne, most prominent female executive in television industry, says she has resigned as president of cable television operations for Walt Disney Co and ABC Inc in order to form her own company, devoted to creating programming for both television and the Internet (M)

headline: Even as Stocks Plunge, Treasuries Soar to 30-Year High
abstract: Long-term US Treasury rates fall to their lowest level in 30 years while other Government bond yields drop sharply; price of 30-year bond rises 1 6/32, to 107 26/32; yield drops from 5.61 percent to 5.58 percent, down from 5.66 percent on May 12; graph shows fluctuations in 3-month Teasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Qwest Marketing Deal With Ameritech
abstract: Qwest Communications International announces reaching agreement with Ameritech Corp to market their long-distance and local telephone services jointly; AT&T, MCI Communications and five other long-distance rivals of Qwest file suit to challenge deal; marketing agreement with Ameritech is second for Qwest in week (M)

headline: Fateful Crash In Africa: Link to U.S. Is Denied
abstract: Bernard Debre, former French Government minister, says missiles from American stockpiles were used to shoot down plane carrying Presidents of Rwanda and Burundi in 1994--act that led to massacre in Rwanda that took at least 500,000 lives; US denies it knows origin of missiles used in attack (S)

headline: Murdoch Sets TV Guide Sale For $2 Billion
abstract: News Corp agrees to sell TV Guide to United Video Satellite Group Inc for $2 billion in cash and stock; TV Guide combination with United Video's Prevue Networks, which scrolls schedules of broadcast and cable programming on cable television, promises new avenue of growth; Prevue Networks is in 50 million cable households in the United States and 3 million homes overseas; United Video is owned by two companies that in turn are in turn controlled by Tele-Communications; charts; photos (M)

headline: Relief for Tired Eyes
abstract: Peter Mark Prince letter comments on eye problems attributed to computer use (June 11 article); suggests replacing monitor with projection screen

headline: The New Math Of Big Mergers Has a Number Of Solutions
abstract: Deal between Chrylser Corp and Daimler-Benz AG is worth $39 billion, based on official terms disclosed on April 7 and on stock prices of April 6, before terms were announced; but in announcing their pact to combine, two companies called deal 'a merger of equals' worth $92 billion, a figure arrived at by combining stock market valuations of two companies; most news organizations reported that deal was worth significantly less, reflecting opinion that Daimler is, in fact, acquiring Chrysler; details support that view (M)

headline: Merck's Zocor Approved Against Stroke
abstract: Merck & Co wins Food and Drug Administration approval of new use of its cholesterol-lowering drug, Zocor; FDA approves drug for reducing risk of stroke (S)

headline: WPP and Rouse Form Joint Venture
abstract: WPP Group PLC and Rouse Co form joint venture that will focus on advertising, marketing and research projects involving regional shopping centers; terms undisclosed; joint venture will enable clients of WPP-owned agencies to expand ways they reach, sell and communicate with consumers at 50 regional malls operated by Rouse in US (S)

headline: New Orange Soda With Familiar Name
abstract: Pepsi-Cola, aiming at teen-age America, will introduce reformulated version of its orange-flavored Slice soft drink; reformulation is less sweet and contains caffeine (S)

headline: Daimler Says Mercedes Aids Its Sales Increase
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG says sales rose 22 percent in first quarter, fueled by Mercedes-Benz AG, whose new line of sports utility and small cars is seen helping annual brand sales 28 percent by year 2000; Daimler says first-quarter sales rose to 31.58 billion marks (17.1 billion) from 25.906 billion marks a year earlier (S)

headline: A Consortium Seeks to Create In-Home Computer Networks
abstract: Eleven high technology companies, including IBM, Lucent Technologies Inc and Compaq Computer Corp plan to announce formation of Home Phoneline Networking Alliance, which will develop standards for systems that transmit data at high speeds over copper phone wires; seek to make computer networks as common in homes as they are in offices (M)

headline: For Better Earnings, Try Bigger Write-Offs
abstract: While the stock market ended last week on a high note, pleased with the mix of economic reports, one little-noted piece of data had ominous implications for investors.    Corporate write-offs, as a percentage of the reported earnings per share of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, surged in the first quarter to 14 percent. Of the $10.25 a share that the S.& P. 500 companies reported in earnings for the quarter, write-offs totaled $1.44 a share.

headline: Screen Grab; See the Spiral Spin, See Your Skin Crawl
abstract: Optical and auditory illusions abound on World Wide Web; photo (M)

headline: Asia Feels Strain Most at Society's Margins
abstract: First of two articles, The Human Crisis, discusses effect of Asian financial crisis on poor people in Ban Wan Yai and other Thai villages; most prominent victims of crisis have been humbled tycoons in big cities, but they are neither most common victims nor most desperate; worst off are people who are already at margins of society--those who had almost nothing before and who have even less now; experts predict that crisis will result in increases in malnutrition and death rates; say legacy of crisis will be felt long after region's economies improve; map; photos (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department reports on 1998 crop conditions for wheat, corn, soybeans and cotton.    TUESDAY  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.

headline: U.S. Talks With Israel On Mideast Move Slowly
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel end second round of talks in Washington without achieving breakthrough on reviving stalled Middle East peace negotiations; but senior American and Israeli officials say that lower-level aides from each side will continue working on issues on Friday and over weekend (M)

headline: NATO JETS PATROL SKIES NEAR SERBIA IN SHOW OF FORCE
abstract: NATO warplanes from 15 European bases carry out exercises over Adriatic Sea, Albania and Macedonia to reinforce demand that Serbia to halt use of military force against civilians in Kosovo Province; exercise, aimed primarily as warning to Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, takes place day before he meets with Pres Boris Yeltsin in Moscow; Pres Clinton speaks with Yeltsin, who assures him he will express very strong sentiments in favor diplomatic rather than military solution during meeting with Milosevic; about 400 refugees from Kosovo enter Albania after being flushed out of mountains by Serbian forces; say hundreds more remain in mountains after Serbs sealed off trails leading out of country; photo; map (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.56   5.62   5.52        3-month T-bills   4.94   5.02   4.98        6-month T-bills   5.13   5.16   5.23        10-yr. T-infl.   3.73   3.75   3.61        10-yr. T-note   5.57   5.56   6.79        30-yr. T-bond   5.84   5.83   7.02        Telephone bd.   7.06   7.06   8.09        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.23   5.77          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Officials Are Uncertain as to How Punishing India Is Likely to Affect U.S. Businesses
abstract: United States and corporate officials say sanctions Pres Clinton imposes against India are likely to hurt wide swath of American industry, but that impact will be small for most companies because India is currently small market for American companies; biggest impact could be postponement or cancellation of some contracts (M)

headline: Goldman Expected to Name Co-Chief Today
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co is expected to name Henry M Paulson co-chairman and co-chief executive working alongside Jon S Corzine; appointment comes as company's 190 partners discuss how best to structure firm and whether to vote on making Goldman public company (S)

headline: Empty Suits In the Board Room; Under Fire, Mutual Fund Directors Seem Increasingly Hamstrung
abstract: WHAT'S a mutual fund director to do? Lately, when independent directors have stood up to fund managers, they've gotten their ears boxed. And when, to some eyes, the directors have let fund managers go their own way, they've gotten their ears boxed again.    Consider events of the last two years, a period in which the fund industry has experienced some of its most rapid growth:

headline: News Brings Rush of Buyers to Wrong TCI
abstract: News that AT&T Corp agreed to buy Tele-Communications Inc causes heaviest trading in TCI stock in more than four years; one problem: that is the wrong stock; TCI is New York Stock Exchange symbol for shares of Transcontinental Realty Investors Ltd; it has no connection with proposed communications deal; ticker for Tele-Communications is TCOMA (S)

headline: Investors Snap Up Korea Bonds in a Big Vote of Confidence
abstract: South Korea, financially destitute just four months ago, wins enormous vote of confidence from foreign investors with successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds; it is first time South Korea has attempted to sell bonds to foreign investors since worst of its economic crisis in December, when Government's largest state-owned bank had to scrap bond sale because of investor resistance; South Korea's stock market jumps 3.69 percent; Government says it will sell further $1 billion in bonds next month; successful bond sale also shows investors are increasingly confident that Asia's economic malaise has eased, diminishing risk of contagion; chart (L)

headline: Yeltsin Choice as Prime Minister Finally Approved by Parliament
abstract: Sergei Kiriyenko, Pres Boris Yeltsin's choice as Prime Minister, is finally approved by fractious legislature, after weeks of strident threats and sullen rebellion; photos; 251-to-25 vote for 35-year-old Kiriyenko is clear victory for Yeltsin, at expense of Communists; Yeltsin also turns aside demands from business tycoons that he dismiss reform-minded aides or form new coalition Government; vote keeps Russia on economic course toward building free stock market, but hard work remains on daunting issues like tax reform, land reform and privatization (S)

headline: Macklowe Properties Plans Stock Offer
abstract: Harry Macklowe will seek to sell 26 million shares of his Macklowe Properties Inc at $20 each; company will use money to repay debt (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Central Vt Pub Svs  Zurn    TUESDAY  Brush Wellman  Overseas Shiphold  Spartech

headline: Oil Prices Up 2% After 3 Producers Agree to Cut Output
abstract: Oil prices rise by 2 percent in futures markets after Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico, world's largest oil producers, agree to cut production by 450,000 barrels a day; crude oil for July delivery closes up 31 cents, to $15.12 a barrel, on New York Mercantile Exchange; in London, benchmark Brent crude for July delivery rises 44 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $14.48; some analysts predict that when cut is put into effect on July 1 it will only help to keep prices from falling and will not lead to any significant increase; graph (M)

headline: Improvement Seen For German Labor
abstract: Germany's central bank says there are signs of stabilization in German labor market but that improvement is largely confined to western part of country; German unemployment dropped by 2,000 in March, to 4.41 million, or 11.5 percent of labor force (S)

headline: Excite to Acquire Advertising Site
abstract: Excite, the Internet search service, agrees to buy Classifieds2000, a World Wide Web site that posts classified advertising, for $48 million in Excite stock (S)

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Set to Be Offered This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of sugar falls 3.9 percent to weakest level since April 1991 on fear that record harvest and weakened demand in Asia will create global glut; July contracts fall 0.31 cents, to 7.55 cents a a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Ernst & Young Initiates a Review
abstract: Ernst & Young places in review its domestic advertising account, which may lead to its worldwide account (S)

headline: Dutch Company to Take A Charge for Revamping
abstract: Royal PTT Nederland NV says it expects to take reorganization charge this year of $245 million to $390 million and that profit before charge will be slightly higher than in 1997 (S)

headline: Fidelity Follows a Crowd It Shunned
abstract: Fidelity Investments, reversing strategy of not investing in stock market's most popular and expensive stocks, has seen its holdings rise sharply since 1996 with purchases of such stocks as Microsoft Corp, Coca-Cola Co, Walt Disney Co and Gillette Co; chart (M)0

headline: Panel Set Up to Settle Insurance Claims of Holocaust Victims
abstract: Panel Set Up to Settle Insurance Claims of Holocaust Victims**Agreement to create commission to settle insurance and annuity claims by Holocaust victims or their heirs is reached in New York City by four major European life insurance companies, state insurance regulators and representatives of World Jewish Congress and World Jewish Restitution Organization (M)

headline: Suharto & Company: Out, Yes, but Still Hugely Rich
abstract: Former Pres Suharto remains wealthiest man in Indonesia, and impoverished country may take years to recover any of billions of dollars he and his powerful children siphoned off; Suharto cronies also grew hugely rich in one of world's most corrupt economies; photo (S)

headline: OFFER FOR BELL SPORTS IS LOWERED BY 25 CENTS A SHARE
abstract: Bell Sports Corp, sports helmet maker, says that HB Acquisition Corp has reduced its offer for company to $10.25 a share from $10.50 a share in wake of product liability verdict against Bell Sports; amended deal is valued at about $163.75 million (S)

headline: Ford-Mazda Deal For Kia Is Reported
abstract: Kia Motors Corp chairman Yoo Chong Yul says Ford Motor Co and its Japanese affiliate, Mazda Motor Corp, want to form international consortium to bid for between 49 percent and 51 percent of Kia Motors; Yoo Chong Yul says continued unrest could cause deal to unwind; 2,000 striking Kia workers are demanding payment of back wages and halt to layoffs (S)

headline: Files Focus on Salvador Colonel in U.S. Women's Deaths
abstract: Newly released State Department documents show Gen Jose Guillermo Garcia, who was El Salvador's Defense Minister when four American Roman Catholic church women were abducted by military unit, raped and killed in Dec 1980, confided to then American Amb Thomas R Pickering in 1985 that he suspected member of his high command ordered killings; State Sec Madeleine K Albright ordered release of documents in response to requests from members of Congress and Lawyers Committee for Human Rights; four National Guard members sentenced for crime recently broke 17-year silence and told Lawyers Committee that acted on orders from above (M)

headline: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
abstract: Letter from Charles Barthold, prompted by April 2 article on declining use of Apple computers, says he found his Mac as difficult to use as PC's (S)

headline: Japan, Sensing a U.S. Slight, Is Soothed a Bit by Albright
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, visiting Japan, stresses firm United States-Japanese ties, tones down American criticism of Japan's economic recovery efforts and lauds Japan's boldness and courage; seeks to sooth Japanese concerns that Pres Clinton will not stop in Japan on his June trip to China (M)

headline: Pain Under Attack; Explosion in Biotechnology Drugs Focuses on Arthritis
abstract: Next generation of treatments for rheumatoid arthritis--often developed in biotechnology labs--is carrying promise of fewer side effects and greater effectiveness; new drugs are causing excitement on Wall Street as well as in the clinic because the potential market for them is estimated to be in billions of dollars each year; specific new drugs coming to market detailed; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: TCI's Adviser Could Receive $40 Million
abstract: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette reportedly stands to make $40 million for advising Tele-Communications Inc in its sale to AT&T Corp; AT&T will spend about $25 million in investment banking fees to be split between advisers Goldman, Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston (S)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Backs Off Fee Plan
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG modifies its plans to impose fee on customers who switch to competing services after German regulators say that former monopoly wanted to charge too much; regulatory agency says it will rule on new proposal as soon as possible (S)

headline: Stake in Jones Intercable Being Sold To Comcast
abstract: Comcast Corp agrees to buy 37 percent stake in Jones Intercable Inc, a cable television operator, in transaction with BCE Inc valued at more than $500 million, as it seeks to bolster its cable television system in mid-Atlantic region; agreements also end soured partnership between Bell Canada, which is part of BCE, and Jones; in February, BCE sued Jones Intercable to stop company from using Internet service run by chairman of Jones Intercable; transactions give Comcast, which has cable systems in Baltimore area, an option to control Jones (S)

headline: INTUIT TO PRODUCE QUICKEN FOR MACINTOSH AFTER ALL
abstract: Intuit Inc will produce its popular Quicken personal-finance software for Apple Computer Inc's Macintosh next year, reversing earlier decision (S)

headline: Net for Rebel Leaders
abstract: Since Pol Pot's death, the Clinton Administration has intensified its effort to bring the leaders of the Khmer Rouge to trial, asking experts to prepare indictments of several figures for gross rights abuses, American officials said.

headline: Managers Hedge. Customers Don't.
abstract: Market Watch column notes odd dichotomy developing in American financial markets, whereby money managers are keeping their clients' money fully invested but selling their own investments; prevailing wisdom is that it would be wrong for managers to impose their caution on the public, and to raise cash in funds they manage (M)

headline: After Years Of Being Off Track, VH1 Hits Its Groove Cable; Channel Pursues Adults and Leaves MTV To Chase After Children
abstract: MTV Networks VH1 cable channel has succeeded since 1994, when John Sykes took over as president, in establishing separate identity as channel offering pure music and music-related programs for adults; shift has increased ratings and driven up profits, offering advertisers highest concentration of viewers between ages 18 and 49; photos (M)

headline: Sogen Shops for a Suitor, But Manager Must Say 'I Do'
abstract: Mutual fund news roundup; Societe Generale seeks buyer for its American mutual fund unit; funds' manager, Jean-Marie Eveillard, owns some 20 percent of unit and has veto power over any sale; Euclid Advisors offers new 'market-neutral' fund that will invest in stocks managers see as undervalued and offset holdings by selling short stocks seen as overvalued; David Brady to run new Stein Roe Large Company Focus fund, which will invest in stock of 15 to 25 large companies; Putnam Investments, which has long sold its funds through brokers, quietly joins Charles Schwab & Co's fund supermarket, offering eight of its funds to investors with no transaction fees or loads; graph of rise in assets in Schwab fund program (M)

headline: Air France Pilots Settle Strike, Accepting 7-Year Pay Freeze
abstract: Air France pilots accept seven-year pay freeze, ending strike that had grounded most flights since beginning of June; strike, on eve of World Cup soccer championships, has embarrassed airline, official carrier for games, and French Government (M)

headline: 3 Who Urged Clinton to Meet With Democracy Groups Are Detained; U.S. Protests
abstract: United States officials expressed concern to the Government today over reports that several dissidents had been detained and others harassed in connection with President Clinton's visit.    ''We're very concerned that some dissidents may have been detained or otherwise disrupted,'' the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, told reporters soon after Mr. Clinton's arrival in Xian this evening. He said the United States Ambassador, James R. Sasser, had conveyed this to Chinese officials.

headline: National Semiconductor Reports $212.4 Million 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reports loss of $212.4 million in fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31, compared with loss of $19 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 24 percent, to $510 million, from $670.5 million in fourth quarter of 1997 fiscal year (S)

headline: Beatrice Snyder, 74, Generic-Drug Official
abstract: Beatrice Snyder, co-founder and former executive of Biocraft Laboratories, maker of generic pharmaceuticals, dies at age 74 (S)

headline: Cycling the World the Easy Way
abstract: Computrainer, frame with rollers and electronic sensors, links bicycle, television and computer to give indoor athletes feel of hills and pacing of dozens of bike race courses around world; Computrainer is manufactured by Racermate; photo (M)

headline: Risk of Hong Kong Recession Sparks a Sell-Off : Major Stock Markets Fall Amid Anxiety Over Asia
abstract: NEW YORK—  Warnings that Hong Kong is headed for recession and that Japan's banking system may be in trouble sent the world's stock markets into a fresh tailspin Wednesday.

headline: INDIA CARRIES OUT 2 MORE ATOM TESTS DESPITE SANCTIONS
abstract: India, ignoring appeal from Pres Clinton, carries out two more underground nuclear tests; Government of Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee approved tests in face of threatened economic sanctions; Clinton announces wide-ranging sanctions, including end to most United States aid and threat to use US vote to deny India International Monetary Fund and World Bank loans, news conference, Berlin; Japan and number of other nations halt, cut or defer aid; map; photo (L)

headline: My Own Personal Antitrust Action
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on trying to use computer program designed to bypass Microsoft Corp start-up screen that is part of Windows operating system; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; With Astra billions, rumors of a huge-scale Merck merger.
abstract: Market Place column on Astra AB's expected announcement that Astra is buying Merck & Co's share of Astra-Merck, joint venture formed by two companies in 1994; Astra's acquisition could give Merck & Co about $4 billion windfall (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CACI INTERNATIONAL INC., Arlington, Va., a provider of information technology services, said it planned to buy Questech Inc., Falls Church, Va., another information technology company, for $35 million in cash and $7 million in assumed debt.    TRAMMELL CROW Dallas, a commercial real estate services company, agreed to acquire the closely held Fallon Hines & O'Connor, Boston, a real estate brokerage firm, for around $33 million.    INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., the maker of microprocessors, bought an equity stake in Hot Office Technologies Inc., Boca Raton, Fla., a privately held software company. Terms were not disclosed.    MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL INC., Washington, said it had increased its quarterly dividend to 5 cents a common share from 4.5 cents.

headline: LIBRARY/TEST PREPARATION; Sugarcoated Practice for the SAT and ACT
abstract: Computer software to help prepare students for SAT and ACT Assessment tests discussed; photo (M)9

headline: Rubin Postaer Wins VH1 Assignment
abstract: VH1 cable television network says it has awarded Rubin Postaer & Associates a new assignment, to handle creative and media duties for television and print image campaign with budget of $10 million (S)

headline: Now, there's a familiar face. And his Madison Avenue comeback reflects a change in attitudes.
abstract: Earvin (Magic) Johnson is returning to national advertising campaigns after virtually disappearing from ranks of celebrity endorsements; Madison Avenue began assessing its relationships with Johnson after he disclosed in late 1991 that he tested positive for virus that causes AIDS; Johnson's advertising comeback relects evolution in attitudes about AIDS and HIV, particularly as new drugs have made disease manageable condition for many patients; photo (L)

headline: U.S. Fears That Calm Talk Is Masking Harsher Reality
abstract: US intelligence reports indicate that Pakistan may be preparing for more tests of nuclear weapons and missiles, acts likely to provoke Indian reaction; Clinton Administration officials are skeptical of conciliatory statements by both nations because they believe that calmer rhetoric does not reflect calmer reality in region; map; photo (M)

headline: ABN Amro Bids for Generale de Banque
abstract: ABN Amro Holding NV offers more than $12 billion for Generale de Banque SA, exceeding takeover proposal from Fortis (S)

headline: PGS to Expand Oilfield Services
abstract: Petroleum GeoServices ASA, Norwegian oil services company, agrees to pay combined $139 million for British offshore drilling business and US seismic data provider to expand its range of oilfield services; PGS to pay $35 million, including $20 million in assumed debt, for Acadian Geophysical Services Inc, provider of seismic data for oil exploration in Gulf of Mexico; PGS will pay $104 million in stock for Atlantic Power Group (S)

headline: Pressure From Clinton
abstract: At the meeting of major industrial democracies, President Clinton urged President Yeltsin of Russia to press for the ratification of a pending nuclear weapons treaty.     Article, page A8.

headline: Ameritech to Cut 5,000 Jobs In an Effort to Save $3 Billion
abstract: Ameritech Corp will eliminate 5,000 jobs, or nearly 7 percent of company's work force; takes $64 million charge against first-quarter earnings; reports earning $590 million in quarter; revenue increase 7.1 percent, to $4.13 billion (M)

headline: Weather Advisories In Your Pocket
abstract: Accu Weather, commercial weather forecasting service, offers farmers, city dwellers, sailors and others array of National Weather Service warnings, watches and advisories by pager; photo (S)

headline: Armed Gang Raids Perfume Scion's Home : Robbers Shoot Guerlain
abstract: PARIS—  Jean-Paul Guerlain, one of the most celebrated "noses" in the French perfume industry and a scion of the famous fragrance family, was wounded during a robbery early Friday after an armed invasion of his home.

headline: Anti-Drug Effort Criticized As More Harm Than Help
abstract: Lindesmith Center, drug reform institute financed by billionaire George Soros, has amassed signatures of hundreds of prominent people around world on letter to United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan holding global war on drugs causes more harm than drug abuse; signers include Soros, former UN Sec Gen Javier Perez de Cuellar, ex-Sec George P Shultz, Nobel Peace Laureate Oscar Arias, Walter Cronkite, ex-Sens Alan Cranston and Claiborne Pell and South African human rights activist Helen Suzman; letter, which also ran as advertisement in New York Times, is timed to UN General Assembly special session on combating drug abuse; Soros comments, phone interview (M)

headline: Biggest One-Day Setback For Treasuries in 2 Months
abstract: US Treasury market posts one of its biggest one-day losses in nearly two months; 30-year bond drops full point to 106 26/32, sending yield up to 5.65 percent, from 5.58 percent on May 15; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Bill Sale Is Only Auction by U.S. This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.96 percent and a six-month bill was 5.11 percent.    The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

headline: Gloom Over Asia Economies Spreads as Yen Drops Again
abstract: Asian economies, which started into tailspin with Thai devaluation last year, may be heading into even worse decline; Hong Kong, Malaysia and Indonesia confirm that economies shrank in first quarter of 1998 and will likely continue to do so this year; Japan, South Korea and Thailand are also in retreat and even economies that have managed to keep growing, in Taiwan, Philippines, Singapore and China, are slowing dramatically as Asian financial crisis turns into most serious region-wide recession since World War II; country-by-country table charts decline; culprit in latest bout of contraction and gloom is Japanese yen, which has plummeted against US dollar and put enormous pressure on other Asian currencies; yen falls again, to eight-year low; Bangkok stock market closes at ten-year low; plunge has so far been mildly positive for US, keeping import prices and interest rates down, but troubling symptoms are emerging; Asian-related US companies report anemic earnings, and US exports declined at $9 billion annual rate in first quarter (M)

headline: CSX GETTING $850 MILLION TO START JOINT BARGE VENTURE
abstract: CSX Corp will receive $850 million in cash and stock to set up barge transportation joint venture with Vectura Group Inc; CSX will combine its American Commercial Lines Inc unit with Vectura's National Marine Inc unit (S)

headline: NATIONAL-OILWELL IN DEAL FOR PHOENIX ENERGY PRODUCTS
abstract: National-Oilwell Inc says it agreed to buy Phoenix Energy Products Inc for $115 million plus $35 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Microsoft and Sega Creating Windows-Based Game System
abstract: Microsoft Corp to collaborate with Sega Enterprises Ltd on home video game system based on slimmed-down version of its Windows computer operating system (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.68   5.64   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.87   4.85   5.08        6-month T-bills   5.08   5.07   5.13        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.73   3.67        10-yr. T-note   5.44   5.50   6.17        30-yr. headline: South Korea's Kohap To Sell Tape Unit
abstract: DG Bank says Kohap Ltd plans to sell its German tape unit, Emtec Magnetics GmbH, to group whose members include Legal and General Ventures Ltd, funds advised by German company Apax Partners & Co and DG Bank unit, BmU (S)

headline: Dow Retreats by 16.45 As Asia Optimism Shrinks
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 16.45 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,813.01; Standard & Poor's 500 index falls 0.74 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 1,106.37; Nasdaq composite index falls 3.70, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,772.70; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Ever Polite, Always Convenient, Superbly Efficient: The A.T.M.
abstract: Bank automated teller machines employ several tests during each transaction to make sure they dispense correct amount of cash; diagrams on how machines work (M)

headline: Tension? What Tension? Not on a Smiley Day for Netanyahu.
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu gets warm, bipartisan reception on his visit to Washington, in hallways and lunchrooms of Congress; through day of courtesy calls, fresh fruit and speechmaking, Netanyahu is welcomed with kind of full-throated, bipartisan heartiness that he rarely receives at home (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: SAMSONITE CORP.,  Denver, said it had laid off 149 more employees at its Denver factory because of mounting inventory in a year of slackening suitcase sales.

headline: Switzerland Said to Have Backed Nazi Trade in Looted Gold
abstract: Declassified US documents suggest that Swiss Government itself endorsed wartime trade in looted Nazi gold and that, in at least one case, Swiss bankers deliberately sought out gold they knew to be looted; World Jewish Congress releases information as Swiss panel prepares to rule on extent of official connivance; papers reveal secret financial dealings during closing stages of World War II, and important economic ties between Nazi Germany and Switzerland; Swiss National Bank was single biggest recipient of gold sold by German central bank to help finance Hitler's war effort; quotes from papers suggesting Government officials, not just bankers, were privy to trade in looted gold (M)

headline: Audits Spread Unevenly Across U.S.
abstract: Newly release data obtained by Syracuse University researchers finds there are such wide disparities nationwide in who gets audited by Internal Revenue Service, that residents of New York City and suburbs continue to be treated with kid gloves by agency while those in California have been hit comparatively hard; difference attributed to fact that agency has looked harder at California for people who do not file tax returns, and relies on decade-old study of taxpayer behavior that critics call obsolete; charts (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises to six-week high against dollar after Bundesbank official suggests higher interest rates will be needed by summer; in New York, dollar costs 1.8123 marks, down from 1.8356; graph; chart (S)

headline: Case Creates a New Unit
abstract: Case Corp creates new unit, Case Capital Corp, to expand focus of its financial-services unit (S)

headline: The New Monster Of The Midway; Premier Parks Thrives by Not Being Disney
abstract: Article on success of Premier Parks, amusement park company whose stock performance rivals Disney's; Premier recently agreed to purchase dozen Six Flags parks from Time Warner Entertainment and has purchased stake in six European parks; photos; chart; drawings (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; An accounting method favored in mergers may get a new name
abstract: Market Place column on accounting method known as pooling of interest that is used in large and small corporate mergers and prospects for another accounting option, one with all benefits of pooling and then some; says members of Financial Accounting Standards Board are considering moving closer to practices in other countries where pooling is allowed only if merging companies are of equal size; holds Wall Street has long worried about such a move and the way it would crimp its deal machine (L)

headline: NPC TO SELL TONY ROMA'S UNIT AND REORGANIZE PIZZA HUTS
abstract: NPC International Inc will sell unit that operates Tony Roma's restaurants to Sentinel Capital Partners and unit's executives for $121.5 million, and will reorganize its Pizza Hut business; NPC will receive $118 million in cash and $3.5 million in stock for Romacorp Inc; company also plans to close 31 money-losing Pizza Hut restaurants, move 53 others to better sites and combine another 11 with current Pizza Huts (S)

headline: Wong Doody Wins Top Andy Award
abstract: Wong Doody in Seattle wins grand prize, known as Grandy Award, at annual International Andy Awards for creativity, sponsored by Advertising Club of New York; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners wins most Andys, 14 (S)

headline: London Journal; Dig These Digs! Digs Galore for Lord Chancellor
abstract: British newspapers criticize renovated apartment of Lord Irvine of Lairg, who as Lord Chancellor is nation's most senior judge as well as Speaker of House of Lords; renovation of apartment in Westminster Palace cost $1.1 million and is paid by taxpayers; photos (M)

headline: I.R.A. Says It Won't Yield on Weapons; Backs Accord
abstract: Irish Republican Army rejects calls contained in Northern Ireland peace agreement for disarming its guerrillas and dismantling its underground arsenal, but expresses guarded support for overall accord; photo (M)

headline: WOOLWORTH IN STOCK DEAL FOR SPORTS AUTHORITY
abstract: Woolworth Corp to buy Sports Authority Inc in stock swap valued at about $570 million, plus assumption of $179 million in debt (S)

headline: Black U.S. Marine Assaulted In Wave of Racism in Moscow
abstract: Black US marine is severely beaten by band of Russian skinheads in busy area of Moscow in daylight in new wave of assaults against foreigners of African and Asian descent; US and other embassies issue warnings to citizens; foreign student groups accuse police of routinely failing to protect them; strong current of racism that runs through Russian society despite portrayal of itself as defender of third world against colonialist West noted (S)

headline: Miller Brewing Sues 2 Former Agencies
abstract: Miller Brewing Co sues two former ad agencies, Bates USA and Zenith Media Services; lawsuit accuses agencies of failing to seek television commercial time to compensate for spots that ran on local stations in 1995 and 1996 and fell short of reaching ratings goals; lawsuit is seeking $6.9 million, reflecting estimated value of free spots to make up for shortfalls, known as make-goods (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 5/  Outperforming the money market by fractions of a cent matters when you're investing billions. Just ask Afsaneh Beschloss of the World Bank. By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EQUITY OFFICE PROPERTIES TRUST, Chicago, a real estate investment trust run by the financier Sam Zell, acquired two downtown San Francisco buildings that were jointly owned by Rolaco Services Inc. and its Paladin U.S.A. Inc. subsidiary for $90 million.    CAMPBELL SOUP CO., Camden, N.J., agreed to sell its European confectionery and distribution unit, Continental Sweets, to Gilde Buy-Out Fund and AXA Private Equity Fund, for undisclosed terms.    HOLIDAY INN CO. changed its corporate name to Bass Hotels and Resorts.

headline: News Corp. Role In Bidding Seen
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp reportedly joins in bid by Michael R Milken and others for Simon & Schuster publishing house (S)

headline: Sometimes, Casual Just Won't Do
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about office attire for casual days; drawing

headline: LICKING RURAL TO PURCHASE NATIONAL GAS AND OIL
abstract: Licking Rural Electrification Inc acquires National Gas and Oil Co for $93 million (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH; Offerings of Y2K Fixes Grow, But It's Time to Tread Carefully
abstract: Computer millennium glitch, despite dire warnings of some consultants, poses little threat to personal computers; problem mainly affects mainframe computers programmed in 1960's and 1970's to recognize two digits for dates instead of four; most newer personal computers will accept date change and those that have problem can be fixed easily by resetting date (S)

headline: New cable services are everywhere, but they all seem to be owned by the same big companies.
abstract: Most of dozens of new services being offered by cable television industry as it expands channel capacity are owned, wholly or in part, by handful of companies, all of which are already in cable business; only giant companies with cable services already have money and muscle to develop new concepts; photos (M)

headline: Commerce Secretary Seeks Compromise on Encryption
abstract: Commerce Sec William M Daley says Clinton Administration's attempts to control encyption technology have been a failure and are forcing American software makers to concede ground to foreign competitors, speech to high-technology industry, Washington; Daley's remarks are strongest indication yet that Administration is seriously considering parting ways with FBI Dir Louis Freeh and other law enforcement and spy agencies over issue of how data should be scrambled; Daley blames both industry and law enforcement officials for failed policy, saying that two sides failed to find reasonable compromise between need to monitor activities of criminals and need to offer consumers strong security for on-line transactions (M)

headline: Pilots Set Back A Delta-United Alliance Plan
abstract: Delta Air Lines pilots surprise company executives by informing them that union wants seat on 12-member Delta board; move comes just as United Airlines and Delta thought that they had agreement to form marketing alliance; Delta management refuses union request and several hours later talks are suspended; both Delta executives and union say they still expect to forge alliance eventually with UAL Corp (M)

headline: A Study Finds Few Roses Among the Market Thorns
abstract: IT'S part of the momentum stock-picking game. What goes up sharply can plummet on bad news. When it does, many investors bail out, but bargain hunters jump in, betting that the beaten-down stock will rise quickly again.    Claudia E. Mott, director of small-cap research for Prudential Securities in New York, calls this strategy ''trolling the momentum trash,'' and it is based on the yard-sale adage that one person's trash is another's treasure. Specifically, the thinking goes, such stocks are punished more severely than the day's bad news warrants, and therefore a hammered stock is a good value.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Wins Reprieve From Big Antitrust Action     Less than an hour before state and Federal Governments were set to file sweeping antitrust suits against the Microsoft Corporation, the company postponed the release of its new Windows 98 operating system so it could hold settlement talks that were likely to last through the weekend.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japanese Pledge on Banks Raises Hopes for Overhaul  Japan's Prime Minister has again pledged to resolve the more than $600 billion in bad bank loans that have been hampering that country's economic recovery.

headline: Irish Aircraft Lessor Trims Ties to G.E. Unit
abstract: GPA Group PLC will seek outside investor to take 'significant minority stake' as it severs number of ties with GE Capital Corp; GE Capital, which rescued GPA from bankruptcy with capital infusion in 1993, will drop option to buy GPA for $65 million and instead will take options to buy as much as 24.9 percent of company at any time until Oct 29, 2001 (S)

headline: INVESTING IT; More, Bigger Slaps In Redeeming Shares
abstract: INVESTORS who skip blithely from fund to fund, beware. More funds are imposing redemption fees to trip up those who are fleet of foot, fund experts say, and the fees are carrying nastier stings.   Unlike back-end loads, or deferred sales charges -- typically used to pay brokers -- redemption fees are returned to the fund's asset base. They average 1 percent of the assets being redeemed and are intended to discourage short-term players, like market timers or those who simply change their minds a lot.

headline: ESSAY; Finding Liberation in Cyberspace
abstract: Article by Ella Veres, Romanian freelance writer living in Budapest, on joys of surfing World Wide Web; hails data glut; photo (M)

headline: SmithKline Head Sees No Further Glaxo Talks
abstract: SmithKline Beecham PLC chief executive Jan Leschly tells British legislators that there is no chance company will revive merger talks with Glaxo Wellcome PLC (S)

headline: Japan, Asia's Giant Economy, Struggles to Rescue Itself First
abstract: Bad economic news in Japan helps send many of region's markets lower as Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto arrives in London to discuss how to solve Asian financial troubles; Hashimoto is expected to pledge to Europe and other Asian leaders that Japan will try to help others in Asia recover by bolstering its own economy first; many economists say that Japan is verging on recession, if not already in one, and that any real recovery will be elusive unless radical steps are taken; closely watched survey of Japanese business sentiment, the Tankan report, reflects some of most disappointing trends in more than two decades; Norio Ohga, chairman of Sony Corp, tells journalists that without dramatic action by Government policy makers 'Japan's economy is on the verge of collapse'; photo of Hashimoto with Britain's Prime Minister Tony Blair (L)

headline: Mysterious Virus at Source Drives Up the Price of Pearls
abstract: Pearl prices are rising sharply in response to mysterious virus and disruptive weather patterns that have killed over half of Akoya oysters in Japan's coastal waters in last several years; Japanese Akoya oysters provide half of cultural pearls sold in United States; problem has been building for decade, but became acute in 1996 and 1997; exporters have been reducing shipments to other countries to meet strong US demand and shipping more pearls to US from China; graphs; photos (M)4

headline: S.& P. Assails State of Indonesian Banks
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp says Indonesia is not moving fast enough to close or seize control of weak banks in a 'dramatically undercapitalized' banking system; holds Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency is not being aggressive enough in taking banks under its wing, and either forcing them to merge with rivals or putting them out of business (S)

headline: WITH CABLE DEAL, AT&T MAKES MOVE TO REGAIN EMPIRE
abstract: AT&T announcement that it will acquire Tele-Communications Inc, nation's second largest cable television company, for $31.8 billion in stock and total cost of $48.3 billion draws initially favorable response from regulators but concerned response from investors; two companies say they want to begin selling digital phone and data service over cable system by end of 1999; say they will begin to bundle and jointly market each other's existing services before deal closes; Federal Communications Commission Chmn William E Kennard suggests deal could enhance competition and force down prices for long distance and high-speed Internet access; AT&T shares fall; AT&T chairman C Michael Armstrong stresses deal's potential to increase competition, interview; regional Bell phone companies use deal as chance to press regulators to allow them into long-distance market; TCI chairman John C Malone will join AT&T's board and remain chairman of Liberty Media, TCI's programming unit; AT&T will fold TCI's cable assets into its consumer business and spin off unit as new subsidiary; AT&T president John D Zeglis will be chairman of unit and TCI president Leo J Hindery Jr unit's chief operating officer; map of TCI's largest markets; photos; drawings (M)

headline: Microsoft and ICL of Britain In 'Enterprise Computing' Pact
abstract: Microsoft Corp announces European alliance with British information systems developer ICL PLC that will make Microsoft formidable contender in network operating systems that connect many types of computers throughout entire an company; ICL will promote and market Microsoft's products throughout Europe; agreement represents major inroad by Microsoft's Windows NT operating system into 'enterprise computing,' large institutional networks that connect all computers throughout an enterprise (M)

headline: I.B.M. Leads Dow Higher As Most Indexes Set Records
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 43.1 points, to close at record 9,184.94; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 3.02 points, to record 1,126.67; Nasdaq composite index gains 16.73 points, to close at record 1,903.87; graph; chart (L)

headline: Hill & Knowlton and Sunbeam to Split
abstract: Hill & Knowlton, public relations firm for Sunbeam Corp, notifies company that it will no longer represent it; Sunbeam confirms that it hired new public relations firm but characterizes split with Hill & Knowlton as a mutual agreement; Sunbeam's new public relations firm will be Sard Verbinnen & Co (S)

headline: Latin America Fears Stagnation in Trade Talks With U.S.
abstract: Pres Clinton and 33 other leaders from Western Hemisphere open talks in Santiago, Chile, aimed at making good on their commitment four years ago to create free-trade zone stretching from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego; many Latin American governments, disappointed that Clinton failed to gain fast-track negotiating authority from Congress in 1997, express serious doubts that hemispheric agreement on trade will ever by signed; photo (M)

headline: Fed, at March Meeting, Saw Manageable Inflation Risk
abstract: Minutes of Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee meeting in March show Federal Reserve saw increased risk of resurgent inflation, but decided to hold interest rates steady in belief that Asian financial problems would help cool down domestic economy and keep price increases in check; committee also decided that risks of inflation were great enough for it to signal that it expected its next move on monetary policy would be to raise interest rates (M)

headline: Kicking Some Sand Into Powerful Faces
abstract: HERE'S some excellent beach reading: a pair of business books that are light enough to tote (83 and 102 pages, respectively) yet anything but scrawny.    ''Team Rodent: How Disney Devours the World,'' by Carl Hiaasen, and ''News Is a Verb: Journalism at the End of the Twentieth Century,'' by Pete Hamill ($8.95 each), are part of a new series by Ballantine's Library of Contemporary Thought -- short paperbacks by high-profile writers on everything from sports to the Supreme Court.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Cooper Tire & Rubr  Jefferson-Pilot  Motorola  Piccadilly Cafe  Source Cap

headline: Wall St. Is Bolstered by Strengthened Overseas Trading
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 52.82 points, to 8,997.36; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 5.29 points, to 1,138.49; Nasdaq composite index gains 21.55 points, to 1,891.08; graph of Dow Jones industrial average; table (M)

headline: Gold Industry Tries to Dig Itself Out
abstract: Gold prices are at levels too low for many mining and exploration companies to make money, and there is no relief in sight; companies are closing mines, putting new projects on hold, laying off employees and cutting costs to try to ride out hard times; big losses are eroding cash reserves and share prices are in doldrums; industry depression is worldwide and companies in gold-mining countries like Australia and South Africa are in worse shape than those in United States because their costs are higher; gold's heyday seems long past; major investors and central banks of many countries no longer want to stockpile gold; photo; graphs (L)

headline: STRANGLED LIFELINE: A special report.; Shortage of Plasma Drug Creates Health Care Crisis
abstract: Kurt Eichenwald special report, Strangled Lifeline, discusses growing health crisis caused by shortage of intravenous immune globulin, drug made from human plasma; notes that shortage began with decisions to recall plasma products that carried theoretical but unproven risk of transmitting fatal Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; discusses plight of Nick Valestrino and tens of thousands of other Americans who suffer from chronic deficiency in their immune system and need drug to remain healthy; photos (M)

headline: Some Will Miss Out on Big Payday at Goldman, Sachs
abstract: Announcement that Goldman, Sachs & Co will go public was ultimate missed opportunity for retired, resigned and might-have-been partners of private firm; even most junior of Goldman's 190 general partners are likely to have stake in company valued at $50 million or more after Goldman issues stock (M)

headline: Audi Pretax Profit Grew in First Half
abstract: Audi AG says pretax profit rose significantly in first half of year and sales jumped 26.6 percent (S)

headline: Where Fine Lines Blur
abstract: Analysis of Justice Department's carefully honed antitrust suit against Microsoft Corp, which is likely to be watershed in setting ground rules of competition in digital age and guidelines for Government intervention in high-technology economy; Government sees case as key test of how antitrust enforcement can be applied swiftly and 'surgically' to protect innovation and competition in computer software business; Microsoft holds Government misunderstands economic facts of life in industry and that its business practices result in improved products that benefit consumers; photos (M)

headline: Some Newspapers Try A No-News Front Page
abstract: Growing number of newspapers are following example set by Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, printing some papers with no front-page articles, only teasers to features in rest of paper; photo (S)

headline: Iran's Leader Asks for Unity After Release of His Moderate Ally
abstract: Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, calls for unity in renewed effort to head off political rupture over legal case involving Mayor of Teheran, Gholamhossein Karabaschi, who was freed from prison on April 15 (M)

headline: Cardinal Health in Surprise $2.2 Billion Deal
abstract: Cardinal Health Inc, one of nation's largest drug wholesalers, says it will buy R P Scherer Corp for $2.2 billion in stock; analyst says acquisition will make Cardinal more of player in pharmaceutical business; Cardinal was unsuccessful last August in its effort to buy rival drug wholesaler, Bergen Brunswig Corp, in deal that would have made Cardinal nation's largest drug wholesaler (M)

headline: Lucent Technologies to Acquire Yurie Systems for $1 Billion
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc acquires Yurie Systems Inc in cash transaction valued at $1 billion (M)

headline: A Web Archive Stretches From Air Travel to 'War and Peace'
abstract: Pilot Zone is one of the larger and more elaborate of the numerous Web sites spawned by Palm Pilot's increasing popularity; photo (S)

headline: 11 Foreigners Are Detained In Mexico Raid
abstract: Mexican police raid farming cooperative in Chiapas state after Indian supporters of Zapatista rebels declared independence from state government; arrest 20 people, including 11 foreigners, some of whom were human rights observers (S)

headline: Horse and Blender, Car and Crockpot
abstract: Americans with disposable income and overabundance of choices are confronting disadvantages and benefits of modern technologies; Kevin Kelly, executive editor of Wired magazine, says individual consumers set up their own belief systems for accepting some technologies and rejecting others; says these choices are often motivated by reasoned yet idiosyncratic personal rules; Paul Saffo of Institute for the Future says Amish are most conspicuous example of process of negotiation between humans and their hardware, but while Amish make their decisions as entire community, based on their religious beliefs, mainstream Americans make theirs as individuals or single families, based on which technologies support their lives and which interfere with them; Saffo says it is important that people be aware that choices can be made; says common fear that technology is inexorable tide that cannot be stemmed can lead to apathy or radical rejection of all technologies; photos; chart showing percentages of Americans who own TV's, computers, telephones, answering machines, fax machines and other such gadgets (L)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE TO CLOSE A PLANT IN NORTH CAROLINA
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co to close plant in Greenville, NC, that produces adult diapers and sanitary napkins, affecting 585 workers; company will move production of its Always sanitary napkins to its plant in Belleville, Ontario (S)

headline: 2 Agencies In Seattle Merge
abstract: Seattle-based advertising agency Hammerquist & Saffel and Matthaeus Halverson Advertising have merged to form Hammerquist Saffel & Halverson; Fred Hammerquist and Hugh Saffel, principals and co-creative directors at Hammerquist & Saffel, retain those positions at merged agency, as does Linda Halverson, principal and director for client services at Matthaeus Halverson; Paul Mattaeus, principal and creative director at Matthaeus Halverson, will not join merged agency (S)

headline: Mitsubishi Chemical To Buy Out 3 Ventures
abstract: Mitsubishi Chemical Corp will acquire Hoechst AG's stake in three joint ventures; deal is valued at 750 million marks ($414 million) to 940 million marks; Hoechst will sell its 33.3 percent stake in Diafoil Hoechst in Japan, its 66.7 percent of Hoechst Diafoil in Germany and its 66.7 percent stake in Hoechst Diafoil in US (S)

headline: As G.M. Idles Plants, Talks Make Progress
abstract: Strikes at two General Motors parts factories in Flint, Mich, force auto maker to close some of its most profitable assembly plants, increasing number of temporarily laid-off workers to 50,900; but tensions start to ease in dispute as negotiators begin making slow progress (M)

headline: The Richer Rich, and Where They Live
abstract: May issue of Smart Money magazine takes sobering look at income gap between rich ad poor in United States; they find that income of top 1 percent of Americans, or about 2.6 million people, now equals that of bottom one-third of population--or 88 million people; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Makes Strategic Move In Ending Suit
abstract: Article on some reasons Merrill Lynch & Co agreed to pay Orange County, Calif, $400 million to settle litigation for its role in county's bankruptcy three years ago while maintaining its innocence; says Merrill was finding itself shut out of much municipal business in California and its reputation as municipal bond underwriter and financial adviser was tarnished; holds at a time when financial services industry is being reshaped by mergers Merrill would find it easier to be a player in this merger game, either as a buyer or seller, with no major lawsuits still outstanding (M)

headline: China Lifts Year's Ban On 3 Brokerage Firms
abstract: Chinese stock brokerage firms Shenyin and Wanguo Securities Co, Haitong Securities Co and Guangfa Securities Co resume trading after one-year ban imposed for market manipulation (S)

headline: Kodak and AOL Plan To Offer Photos on Web
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co, hoping to revive its digital photography operations, says it will permit America Online's 12 million subscribers to drop off rolls of film at any of 30,000 photo-processing shops in United States; once film is developed, images can be digitized and sent to their owners over Internet as E-mail (S)

headline: Chateau Communities Deal
abstract: Chateau Communities Inc buys 12 manufactured-home communities in Michigan and North Carolina for $79 million (S)

headline: Israel Offers Pullout if Lebanon Bars Raids
abstract: Israel formally accepts 20-year-old United Nations Security Council resolution calling on it to withdraw from Lebanese territory; says any pullback will be made only on condition that Lebanon assumes control over region and prevents its use for attacks on Israel; map (M)

headline: Dissident Says Students Bore Some Blame In Tiananmen
abstract: Wang Dan, dissident freed by China, expresses feelings of guilt about his role in Tiananmen Square protests, in which hundreds of people were killed by the Chinese Army; tells audience of rights activists and supporters at City University of New York that he stands by his political views and support for democracy (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; Like the Geisha, the Good-Time Bar Is Endangered
abstract: Japan's economic pinch and wave of scandals are hurting business at high-priced bars and restaurants in Tokyo and other major cities favored for business entertaining; it is uncertain whether Japanese, used to highly formal, ritualized behavior, can do business without entertaining; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Delays World Bank Loans For India in Response to A-Tests
abstract: Clinton Administration makes good on threat to impose economic sanctions on India for conducting five underground nuclear tests by blocking $865 million World Bank loan for electric power grid and other projects; has also cut off bilateral aid, including trade credits, private American bank loans to Indian Government and loan guarantees to American companies doing business there; move is clearly intended to send signal to Pakistan about how it would suffer if it carries out test of its own; CIA reports Pakistan has completed preparations for test, but Foreign Ministry in Islamabad denies any test is imminent; widening gap between US and allies over using World Bank loans and other international assistance to punish New Delhi discussed; most European nations view sanctions as unwise and unlikely to deter India from turning its nuclear capacity into weapons (M)

headline: Families Link Up
abstract: Amy Lemberger letter, commenting on Mar 26 article about older Americans going on-line, discusses her father's experiences with the Internet (S)

headline: CompUSA: Revising Computer Retailing
abstract: CompUSA, having agreed to buy Computer City from Tandy Corp, seeks to prove that computer superstores remain viable, while diversifying into corporate sales and services; competes against direct marketers, which are growing faster than retail outlets; graphs of personal computer sales by types of outlets and of computer prices; photo (M)

headline: GEC Alsthom to Offer Shares in Public Offering
