abstract: GEC Alsthom will offer between 52 percent and 57 percent of its shares in initial public offering on June 22, which could raise as much as 26.6 billion francs ($4.45 billion) (S)

headline: Getting Biotechnology Set to Hatch; As Science Gathers Speed, Monsanto Leads Pack
abstract: Profile of Monsanto Co, front-runner in fast-growing biotechnology field; company is raking in profits from having placed heavy biotechnology bets early in agricultural sector and is now moving into other sectors; table; graph; photos (L)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Agriculture Department reports on May farm prices and on crop conditions for wheat, corn, soybeans and cotton.

headline: Gingrich Clarifies G.O.P. Stands on Trade
abstract: As President Clinton arrived in China, Representative Newt Gingrich suddenly stepped forward today to polish Republican credentials on an array of international issues, from trade relations with China to long-stalled financing for the International Monetary Fund.    The House Speaker, a Georgia Republican, promised that Congress would try again this September to give President Clinton expanded fast-track trade-negotiating authority -- an issue that sharply divides Democrats.

headline: MELLON BANK IS SELLING ITS COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE UNIT
abstract: The Mellon Bank Corporation plans to sell its commercial mortgage servicing business, including $17 billion of servicing rights, and focus its energies on the residential mortgage business. Mellon is seeking buyers for the Income Property division of the Cleveland-based Mellon Mortgage Company. The commercial business includes 200 employees, 12 branches and the fourth-largest servicing business in the United States. Michael Kula, chief operating officer of Mellon Mortgage, said the company had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to seek buyers. The plan, first reported in Commercial Mortgage Alert, follows less than a year after Mellon Mortgage acquired a $7.9 billion servicing portfolio from the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

headline: Businesses Explore Cyberauctions
abstract: Number of Web sites offering auctions of industrial and scientific equipment, and of electronic parts, is growing exponentially; Michael Brader-Araje, chief executive of Open Site Technologies, which sells auction software, predicts that auctioneers without Internet auctions will be out of business in five years; aficionados of cyberauctions see many advantages, but there are disadvantages as well; photo (M)

headline: LIBRARY/WEB SITES FOR GIRLS: WWW.PURPLE-MOON.COM; Fun, but Based on Products
abstract: Review of Web sites for young girls, including Purple Moon site (S)

headline: Times Names Chief For Labor Relations
abstract: New York Times announces that Marc Z Kramer has been named vice president for labor relations; he will be responsible for directing labor relations with unions at The Times;, and will head labor relations department; photo (S)

headline: SHAW COMMUNICATIONS BUYS WIC WESTERN INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Shaw Communications Inc to buy WIC Western International Communications Ltd for $975 million (Canadian) (US$682.5 million), topping hostile offer by CanWest Global Communications Ltd (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark rises on speculation that International Monetary Fund, which has lent Russia $670 million to pay urgent debts, will grant further aid to Germany's biggest trading partner; dollar falls to 1.8056 marks from 1.8087; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Ann Taylor has big plans and investors have high hopes. But more housekeeping seems in order.
abstract: Market Place column on Ann Taylor Stores Corp in light of recent runup in price of company's stock; says investors, long enamored of Ann Taylor name, are betting that new stores will bolster sales and earnings; holds given company's recent experience, one has to wonder why Ann Taylor does not focus first on steadily increasing its sales; says it has been down expansion road during hard times before, and results were not good (L)

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Issues Statement on Its Status
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi PLC states its preference for independence in wake of reports of a possible takeover attempt by Havas Advertising (S)

headline: Generale des Eaux Holders Approve Bid
abstract: The shareholders of Compagnie Generale des Eaux S.A. backed the purchase for 34.2 billion francs ($5.7 billion) of the media company Havas S.A. yesterday, culminating the 144-year-old utility's rebirth as a faster-growing communications company. Symbolic of the renaissance, shareholders also approved changing the company's name to Vivendi.

headline: TORONTO-DOMINION IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR JACK WHITE
abstract: Toronto-Dominion Bank, moving to expand its discount brokerage operations in US, says its Waterhouse Investor Services Inc unit agreed to acquire Jack White & Co for about $100 million (S)

headline: Why Poppers can be found in the freezer aisle, and does New York have an official uniform?
abstract: Advertising column asks 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media (M)

headline: INDIA DETONATED A HYDROGEN BOMB, EXPERTS CONFIRM
abstract: Indian scientists, in disclosure almost certain to accelerate nuclear arms race with Pakistan, confirm that largest of five recent underground nuclear tests involved hydrogen bomb, device with potentially enormous power known as 'city buster' in American military circles; say bomb had explosive force equivalent to 43,000 tons of TNT, and was two-stage device involving fission trigger; say it was deliberately kept small to avoid damage to populated areas near test site in northwestern desert; emphasize they developed weapons on their own, without any foreign help; Dr Rajagopal Chindambaram, chairman of Indian Atomic Energy Commission, says bomb design gives India ability to increase its explosive power virtually at will; Dr A P J Abdul Kalam, regarded as 'father' of Indian bomb, says India will build bigger bombs if need arises; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Accounting Rule Hurts Software Companies' Revenues
abstract: New accounting rule could soon affect bottom lines of high-technology companies across nation; new rule requires companies to postpone revenues on certain software sales if all promised components and services have not yet been provided; in some cases, companies will not record those revenues for months, if not years; rule applies for fiscal years beginning after Dec 15, 1997; companies operating on calendar year had to comply in first quarter of 1998; how rule has hurt revenues of Creative Computer Applications Inc, Ovid Technologies Inc, Intervoice Inc discussed (Market Place column) (L)

headline: Lagos Journal; Nigeria Hangs Out a Banner: Ici On Parle Francais
abstract: lagos journal: nigeria hangs out a banner: ici on parle francais**Nigeria has begun crash program to make English-speaking nation bilingual in French virtually overnight; schools are scrambling to find qualified teachers and many in nation's political elite have been rushing to comply with Pres Sani Abacha's decree to learn French; Africans from neighboring French-speaking nations and Western business people are skeptical; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: British pound drops on London Business School forecast that Britain's economy will slow considerably this year; pound falls to $1.6393 from $1.6491 in New York, lowest since March 8; graph; chart (S)

headline: Fighting Back on Fees
abstract: Frank Bredell letter on April 19 article on high fees New Yorkers pay at banks suggests using a credit union, which usually charge no fees (S)

headline: CITRIX SYSTEMS IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE ALL APM SHARES
abstract: Citrix Systems Inc to acquire all outstanding shares of APM Ltd in cash transaction valued at about $40 million (S)0

headline: NETSCAPE AGREES TO LICENSE ITS SOFTWARE TO CITIBANK
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp to license its electronic commerce software to Citibank, which will expand its on-line sales and customer banking services by using Netscape software; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: France's 'Foreign Legion' Hopes Hour of Glory Has Arrived
abstract: PARIS—  Wines and designs are not the only French products in demand as the 20th century draws to a close. French soccer talent is a popular export as well.

headline: German Central Bank Leaves Rates Unchanged
abstract: Bundesbank leaves its full set of interest rates unchanged, confirming expectations that German central bank is not ready yet to help short-term interest rates converge across Europe (S)'

headline: Rebels in Kosovo Striking Back Against Yugoslav Forces
abstract: Western diplomats say that separatist rebels in Kosovo Province, after taking losses in their fight with Yugoslav military and bolstered by huge infusion of weapons and fighters from Albania, have begun to hit back in recent days; say that guerrillas of Kosovo Liberation Army have set up roadblocks on key roads in province, leading to frequent clashes with Serb forces; photo; map (M)

headline: Case Study Shows Why Bosnians Shun Banks
abstract: Officers of SAB bank in Sarajevo, Bosnia, say large cash accounts of embassies, World Bank, European Commission and other international organizations are frozen and perhaps lost; dispute over bank's ownership caused a run, and depositors can no longer withdraw their money; some foreign banking experts say they expect trouble to be cleared up soon, but many Bosnians say they believe foreigners do not know Bosnia (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Rise, Aided by Continued Strength in the Dollar
abstract: Treasury prices rose yesterday, helped by continued strength in the dollar and a weak manufacturing survey     The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32, to 104 30/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.77 percent, from 5.80 percent on Friday.

headline: Both Sides of Spam
abstract: Brian Santo letter, responding to May 7 article, says there is no way for the average consumer to refuse spammer messages and demand that spammers take them off their lists (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls against dollar on news of strong US job growth with little inflation; table; graphs (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BOSTON CHICKEN INC., Golden, Colo., named Lawrence White chief financial officer, filling the post vacated by Mark Stephens earlier this month during sweeping management resignations.    FORT JAMES CORP., Deerfield, Ill., named Daniel McCarty president of its Dixie paper products business, which last week became a separate operating group from the company's paper towel and tissue businesses.

headline: AES TO ACQUIRE 90% STAKE IN ARGENTINE ELECTRIC CONCERN
abstract: AES Corp to acquire 90 percent of Empresa Distribuidora La Plata SA, or Edelap, an Argentine electric distribution company, for $350 million; AES purchases stake from joint venture of Houston Industries Energy Inc and unit of Technit SA (S)

headline: The Welfare State Is Alive, if Besieged, in Uruguay
abstract: Economic change sweeping Latin America has largely bypassed Uruguay, where welfare state faces biggest test in years, union-sponsored plebiscite opposing new law to let private companies compete with Government's electric monopoly; unions seek to make Pres Julio Maria Sanguinetti, centrist who pushed law through Congress, into lame duck and propel socialist to presidency next year; map; photo (M)

headline: South Korea Banks Criticized Over List
abstract: South Korean banks propose that about 20 companies repay loans or face immediate liquidation, a list country's financial regulator Lee Hun Jai rejects as too narrow; not single affiliate of Hyundai Group, Samsung Group or other three largest industrial groups is included on so-called black list; omissions reflect dilemma facing Korea's banks, which aim much of their lending to affiliates of Hyundai, Samsung, Daewoo, LG and SK; by including companies owned by these groups on lists, banks will be forced to write off more bad loans (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HERTZ CORP., Park Ridge, N.J., the car and industrial-equipment rental company, agreed to buy Big 4 Rents Inc., San Francisco, an equipment-rental company, for an undisclosed amount.    UNILEVER, the British-Dutch consumer products company, acquired Americlean Systems Inc., Southfield, Mich., a provider of cleaning and hygiene products, for an undisclosed sum.

headline: Oxford Health Gets Financing Pledges
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc secures commitments to sell $350 million in debt, completing part of company's $700 million financing plan; plan clears the way for $350 million equity investment from Texas Pacific Group (S)

headline: Business Travel; Airlines Coddle High Fliers At Expense of Coach Class
abstract: Airlines are investing millions of dollars to pamper customers who pay highest fares; they are enticing these passengers with everything from more leg room to extra frequent-flier miles to fancier VIP lounges; focus on elite, who represent fewer than a tenth of all passengers, often translates into decline in service for everyone else; few airlines are adding new workers to staff their new premium services, so budget travelers may have to make do with longer check-in lines and longer waits for baggage (M)

headline: EATON TO CUT 200 JOBS BECAUSE OF DOWNTURN IN SALES
abstract: Eaton Corp will cut 200 jobs as part of effort to save $60 million a year because of poor sales in its semiconductor-equipment making business (S)

headline: Media Edge Gets Tricon Assignment
abstract: Tricon Global Restaurants, which owns and operates Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC restaurant chains, has consolidated duties for buying $260 million to $300 million worth of television commercial time annually at Media Edge division of Young & Rubicam Inc (S)

headline: IRAQ IS SMUGGLING OIL TO THE TURKS UNDER GAZE OF U.S.
abstract: United States and Turkish Govt officials say that Iraq is smuggling large volumes of oil into Turkey in violation of United Nations sanctions; say Clinton Administration has chosen to look the other way, aware that smuggling benefits Turkey, a crucial ally in American policy toward Iraq, and Kurds who deny Iraqi Govt of Pres Saddam Hussein control over northern Iraq; smuggling is enriching Pres Hussein's Govt and family, at time when Iraqi leader is chafing under United Nations' restrictions on official oil exports, which have been in place since Persian Gulf war eight years ago (M)

headline: Officer Tied to '91 Killings Gets Post in Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian Pres B J Habibie appoints as a senior military adviser a retired army general, Lieut Gen Sintong Panjaitan, who was ordered by United States court to pay millions of dollars in damages for his involvement in 1991 massacre in which 270 people are estimated to have been killed (S)

headline: Opium Puts Myanmar In Crisis Over AIDS
abstract: Heroin addiction is spreading in Myanmar, world's top opium exporter, where sharing of syringes has led to world's highest rate of infection with AIDS virus; foreign medical researchers put total number of addicts at some 500,000 and estimate several hundred thousand have become HIV-positive (M)

headline: Israel Mural Reveals The Fault Lines at 50
abstract: An effort to have an Israeli Jew, an Israeli Arab and a Palestinian work together to produce a mural depicting a future without fear proved far more tortured than any of them imagined -- a microcosm of mistrust and betrayal that mirrored the hostilities they had set out to overcome.    On a personal level, in private, the men forged a bond and shared a deep mutual respect. But burdened by history and communal expectations, their mural became a battleground of symbols.

headline: GEC Alsthom to Produce $1.3 Billion Dividend
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom SA and General Electric Co PLC of Britain will get special dividend of about $1.3 billion from their GEC Alsthom venture before its initial public offering in June; dividend will compensate for investments made since GEC Alsthom was formed in 1989; two companies plan to sell 52 percent of GEC Alsthom, valued at about $6.7 billion (S)

headline: Putting Africa On Coke's Map; Pushing Soft Drinks on a Continent That Has Seen Hard, Hard Times
abstract: Coca-Cola Co is heating up its efforts in Africa; soft drink has been available in South Africa for 60 years and West Africa for 30, but company has long tended to ignore Africa's underdeveloped markets and only recently has continent acquired priority status--decision made largely by new chairman-chief executive M Douglas Ivester; Ivester's strategy has several parts: strengthening bottler network, increasing number of outlets and intensifying marketing to consumers; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Joystick's Short, Bumpy Life
abstract: Descriptions of joysticks used with computer and video games since their introduction in 1976; photos (M)

headline: CSX Sells a Rail Line
abstract: CSX Corp sells its 51-mile rail line in Michigan to Saginaw Valley Railway Co unit of RailAmerica Inc; terms not disclosed; Saginaw Valley will immediately start rail service on line, which runs from Saginaw to Brown City, Mich (S)

headline: Parts of Africa Showing H.I.V. In 1 in 4 Adults
abstract: United Nations reports that 30 million people carry HIV, virus that causes AIDS, including 21 million in Africa; says one in four adults are infected in Botswana and Zimbabwe and at least 10 percent in 13 subSaharan nations; report is UN's first country-by-country analysis on AIDS and is released ahead of international AIDS conference set for Geneva; shows AIDS now rivals greatest epidemics of history; UN officials say slow deaths from untreated AIDS make for quieter epidemic that national leaders have too easily ignored; report shows infection rates have slowed in nations that adopted strong prevention programs; maps; photo (M)

headline: Investors Push Dow Near 9,000 as Inflation Fears Wane
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at record 8,986.64, up 118.32 points, or 1.33 percent; Standard & Poor's 500 index also hits new high, rising 11.86 points, or 1.07 percent, to 1,120.01; Nasdaq composite gains 5.30 points, to record 1,852.96, a 0.29 percent gain; graph; chart (L)

headline: In the Mainstream: Dead Deer, Not Demons
abstract: J C Herz article on computer game Deer Hunter, designed for outdoor sporting enthusiasts by Wizard Works for Wal-Mart; cites success of low-cost software, which runs on inexpensive computers, as sign that audience for games is changing in kind and size; photo (M)

headline: Student Revolt in Paris Lasted Barely a Month, and a Lifetime
abstract: Suddenly, the world focused on Paris. In modern French history, May '68 is probably the best-known dateperhaps the only one that is recognized around the world. The monthlong student revolt on the Left Bank in Paris during that time fired imaginations everywhere and still does. Its slogans, stenciled on the city's walls, laminated themselves onto minds in a new utopian capital whose rules would be: "It is forbidden to forbid," "Under the paving stones, the beach" and, perhaps most prophetic of all, "Run, comrade, the old world is catching up with you." Those heady spring days and nights of student power in the streets created an icon in the French specialty of revolution.

headline: Business Travel; American Express's planned bulk purchase of airline seats may be only the beginning.
abstract: Planned bulk purchase of airline seats between US and London may be only first in series of such deals by American Express; company is buying seats on Virgin Group's Virgin Atlantic Airways flights from Continental Airlines, Virgin's partner, on certain routes; Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, is getting new international airport, scheduled to begin operating June 30; it is situated near Sepang, about 35-miles south of the city (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Asian Markets Cheer Suharto Resignation
abstract: HONG KONG—  Asian stock and currency markets struggled with and then welcomed the news of President Suharto's resignation Thursday. But analysts said the gains could easily vanish if Indonesia's political future remained muddy, or if the newly sworn-in president, B.J. Habibie, lived up to his reputation as a profligate spender.

headline: Key Personnel Moves Made at Two Agencies
abstract: GCI Group expands into management consulting services with hiring of Keith Burton as executive vice president and managing director of new GCI Consulting unit; Young & Rubicam Inc names Etienne Boisrond to new post of chairman for Asia/Pacific region; he will assume duties from Tim Pollack, vice chairman, who resigns (S)

headline: Five Nations Join in Plea To Pakistan And India
abstract: US, Russia, China, Britain and France call on India and Pakistan to freeze their nuclear weapons development and agree not to test nuclear missiles or arm them with warheads; five permanent members of United Nations Security Council, all nuclear powers themselves, offer to help India and Pakistan reduce tensions over disputed territory of Kashmir (M)

headline: Ending Silence, Suharto Insists On Staying Put Until Elections
abstract: Indonesian Pres Suharto, rejecting intensifying calls for his resignation, says he will stay in office to oversee broad-ranging reforms that will lead to new presidential elections in which he will not take part, televised speech; says he will name respected public figures to 'reform council' to draft new laws on Constitution, general elections and political parties, as well as anti-monopoly and anti-corruption laws; says after election, National Assembly will elect new President and Vice President; warns any sudden leadership shift could tear nation apart, possibly causing violence; speaks after meeting with prominent figures, including some Muslim leaders who have called for his resignation; House Speaker Harmoko has called for Suharto's resignation, stand later opposed by Defense Min Wiranto; Wiranto also takes hard line against protesters, holding demonstrations have led to destructive riots (M)

headline: Pol Pot Is Dead, Thai Army Says; Made Cambodia a 'Killing Field'
abstract: Pol Pot, who turned Cambodia into slaughterhouse in 1970's, reportedly died of heart attack in his jungle hideout, at age of 73; news of his death comes from Thai military and Khmer Rouge sources, but some foreign diplomats remain skeptical of his death and others suspect he did not die of natural causes; Nuon Nou, who was assigned to guard Pol Pot after he lost power in deadly internal struggle last year, denies any suggestion of foul play; some Cambodian officials had predicted that Pol Pot's comrades would kill him, rather than allow him to be tried before foreign tribunal where he could testify about their own atrocities; during Pol Pot's time in power, his Khmer Rouge caused deaths of more than million Cambodians; photo; map (M)

headline: In Bulgaria, Students Bone Up on Pax Americana
abstract: BLAGOEVGRAD, Bulgaria—  They waited through the valedictorian's oration, through the honorary degree for a minor poet, through an address by a distinguished foreign ambassador, until finally the moment came when the provost pronounced them "Bachelors of Arts." Tasseled mortarboards were tossed into the air, only to be carefully retrieved for family photographs.

headline: Housing Starts Fell in March, But Not Much
abstract: Commerce Department says housing starts declined 2.8 percent in March, to 1.59 million units at seasonally adjusted annual rate; Labor Department says number of people on unemployment benefit rolls decreased by 55,000 in week ended April 4, to 2.12 million; also says first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 22,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 289,000; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Is Urged to Offer More Data on Line
abstract: Carl Malamud, president of Internet Multicasting Service, challenges Federal Government to make nation's patent and trademark data base freely available, and threatens to undertake project himself as guerrilla effort; Malamud's crusade throws new light on continuing dispute between those who advocate widely distributing Government data bases that are created at taxpayer expense and thriving private information industry that remarkets and resells information to business customers and libraries (M)

headline: A Plan to End Bankruptcy At Barneys Is Nearly Ready
abstract: Barney's Inc will attempt to emerge from bankruptcy court proceedings as independent concern; creditors' committee is close to signing agreement in principle among its members that would give creditors and other investors control of company (M)

headline: Computer and Drug Shares Pull Lethargic Market Down
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 17.93 points, to 9,114.44, in very light trading; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 4.17 points, to 1,110.47; Nasdaq composite index drops 15.99 points, to 1,805; tables; graph (M)

headline: If a Pay Phone Rings, Who Will Answer?
abstract: Mark Thomas sets up Web site called Payphone Project (www.sorabji.com/livewire/payphones) that lists pay phone numbers around the world; says his page is intended to provide site to dial into and hope for excitement that random response can provide; Godrey Daniels, in his own home page, describes how he got number of phone booth in Mojave Desert and what happened day someone answered; photo (M)

headline: 2 Web Ventures End Merger Plan
abstract: Citysearch and Zip2 Corp, two of leading developers of local World Wide Web sites known as city guides, call off merger plans, citing incompatibilities in cultures and technology (S)

headline: Even without 'Seinfeld,' NBC is the network that others build their fall schedules around.
abstract: Four major networks and two would-be networks prepare to announce their fall programming plans to advertising industry in series of elaborate stage presentations in atmospheric show business locales; process, known as upfront, will take 4 days, rather than usual 10 days; whole industry is on edge awaiting NBC's decision about Thursday minus Seinfeld; photo (M)

headline: Aging Hackers
abstract: Letter from Rhoda Ferber says computers are synonymous with young, but in Florida, with so many retirees, computer is fast becoming tool of connection, to keep minds alert as bodies slow down (S)

headline: The Law That Spells Out Sanctions
abstract: Excerpts from Nuclear Proliferation Act of 1994, which US could invoke in imposing sanctions against India for carrying out three underground nuclear tests (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ARTERIAL VASCULAR ENGINEERING INC., -- Santa Rosa, Calif., agreed to acquire the closely held World Medical Manufacturing Corp., Sunrise, Fla., another medical device concern, for $62 million in stock.    FIRST DEFIANCE FINANCIAL CORP., -- Defiance, Ohio, a savings and loan company, agreed to buy Leader Mortgage Co., Cleveland, for $39.55 million.

headline: It Was Child's Play to Seize and Barricade the Latin Quarter
abstract: THE FIRST surprise was how easy it was for the students to take charge without adult approval: buildings, then streets, finally the Latin Quarter, together with schools and factories across the country. Paris street skirmishing erupted May 3, a Friday and two days after the trade unions' traditional May Day parade. The flash point occurred the following Friday, May 10, the night of the barricades. Students fought riot police for 12 hours in the Rue Gay Lussac and nearly 1,500 people were hurt, a third of themseriously. Of these, 250 were policemen. When the police retreated, the barricades were still there.

headline: The Interview: Adding Insult to Indignity
abstract: Readers share their memories of job interviews they would rather forget about; drawing (M)

headline: Nasdaq Index Leads Rivals After Quarter
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gained 16.90 percent in first quarter of 1998; Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.27 percent, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.53 percent; Russell 2000 gained 9.99 percent in the quarter; Dow Jones industrial average gains 17.69 points, to close at 8,799.81; Standard & Poor's 500 rises 8.20, to 1,101.75; charts (L)

headline: Prince of the Citi; Reed Runs Citicorp With Brains and Pragmatic Skills
abstract: Profile of John S Reed, chief executive of Citicorp, who will be co-chief executive when his company merges with Travelers Group Inc to become Citigroup; Reed has always shown fascination with consumer banking and strong international bent; by merging with Travelers, Reed is recommitting Citicorp to corporate banking and hitching merged company's fortunes to unproved virtues of cross-selling financial products; Reed has been criticized for not trusting, and frequently discarding, his lieutenants, but Reed himself is sanguine about how effectively he and Sanford I Weill, Travelers' chairman and co-chief executive of new company, could operate behemoth like Citigroup, which would have $700 billion in assets, $50 billion in revenue, 162,000 employeees and more than 100 milion customers; photo (M)

headline: In About-Face, NBC Is Marketing Its Wares With Toll-Free Number
abstract: NBC, adopting practice that networks have long disdained, takes first steps toward establishing a regular business in direct marketing to television viewers through toll-free numbers, segment of industry previously relegated mainly to cable channels and public television; in a little-publicized move connected to its hit mini-series Merlin this week, NBC withheld two 30-second commercials from sale to advertisers and instead used them to market sale of videocassettes of film to home viewers; experiment was so successful--100,000 cassettes were sold--that senior NBC exec says that network will begin aggressively seeking similar opportunities in other programs (M)

headline: Thistle Hotels Reports Takeover Approaches
abstract: Britain's Thistle Hotels PLC says it has received several takeover offers in recent weeks (S)

headline: 11th-Hour Wrinkle Became Basis for the Intel Case
abstract: Intergraph Corp's claim of antitrust violation against Intel Corp may end up playing central role in broad antitrust suit that Federal Trade Commission plans to file against Intel; Federal Judge Edwin L Nelson concluded last month there was 'substantial likelihood' that Intergraph would succeed in proving its claim, thus paving way for FTC action; although other competitors have accused Intel of violating antitrust laws, Intergraph is first to take public stand against Intel (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group hold their annual spring meeting in Washington.

headline: South Africa Relents a Bit on Ousting Reporter
abstract: South African Government, after months of refusing to let award-winning journalist Newton Kanhema return to fight deportation order, abruptly reverses itself; Kanhema is Zimbabwean citizen who has been living and working in South Africa but is visiting US on journalism fellowship; free press advocates say South Africa appears to be trying to chill freedom of press by deporting journalist who has angered Deputy Pres Thabo Mbeki; Jimmy Carter has raised Kanhema's case with Pres Nelson Mandela (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.54   5.39        3-month T-bills   5.02   5.03   4.93        6-month T-bills   5.09   5.12   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.70   3.70   3.62        10-yr. T-note   5.46   5.49   6.37        30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.70   6.66        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.13   7.44        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.21   5.58          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: MidAmerican to Buy Real Estate Group
abstract: Iowa-based MidAmerican Energy Holdings Co, in unusual move to market electricity and natural gas to homeowners, says it will buy large real estate brokerage group, Amerus Home Services Inc, for undisclosed price (S)

headline: CMG INFORMATION STOCK HITS HIGH ON PLANS FOR SPLIT
abstract: CMG Information Services says it will split its common stock 2 for 1 as its shares reach 52-week high of $100 (S)

headline: Economic Slump in Asia Spurs Sharp Drop in Dow
abstract: US stocks fall on concern that Asia's economic slump is causing companies that do business there to report disappointing earnings; Dow Jones industrial average declines 78.22 percent, to 8,971.70; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 6.13, to 1,112.28; Nasdaq composite index drops 27.51, to 1,773.25; graph; chart (M)

headline: Apple Profits Are Double Expectations
abstract: Apple Computer Inc reports quarterly earnings that are more than twice consensus forecast of Wall Street analysts and are largely result of improved profit margins and sharp cost-cutting; revenues fall 12 percent in company's second fiscal quarter ended March 27 from comparable quarter a year earlier and 11 percent from fiscal first quarter; Apple reports earnings of $55 million compared with loss of $708 million in year-earlier period; sales for quarter are $1.41 billion, down from $1.60 billion; chart (M)

headline: Old Idea, New Tools
abstract: Howard J Adler letter, in response to June 11 article, recommends www.steves-digicams.com Web site for information on digital photography

headline: Japan Denies It Intends to Rescue Two Banks
abstract: News reports appear that Japanese Government might rescue two major banks by merging them as high-level US delegation presses Japanese leaders to strengthen economy and tackle bad loan problems; report by Kyodo News Service says authorities are considering merger of Long-Term Credit Bank and Nippon Credit Bank; both banks deny reports and Government says it will refrain from supporting feeble banks (M)

headline: Underground History Surfaces Again in Berlin
abstract: Berlin city planner Dietmar Arnold investigates extensive network of tunnels, sewers and bunkers bneath city, latest discovery being personal bunker of Nazi leader Josef Goebbels; photo; site is embarrassingly close to projected site of city's memorial to Jews killed by Nazis; Arnold calls for mapping and preservation of underground networks; reports that portable toilet now stands on exact spot of ventilation tower for Hitler's personal concrete lair (S)

headline: Forget the Facilitating. Just Vent!
abstract: A COLLEAGUE and I were recently lamenting the lack of honest, direct communication in companies. There is no way, we decided, to vent anymore in the workplace -- to state one's mind, expect the same from the other person and get on with the task at hand.    We've all taken so many training classes and seminars on effective communication and been exposed to so much psychobabble that many times we talk around the problem we need to solve. Too often, it's not who has the best solution, but rather who has the better skills to turn the situation to his or her advantage.

headline: As India Adds Up Costs of Its A-Tests, Dissent Grows Louder
abstract: India's Hindu Government, only two weeks after it detonated five underground nuclear tests to popular acclaim, runs into storm of protest in Parliament that reflects growing disquiet about risks and costs of acquiring nuclear weapons (M)

headline: Getting Ready for Windows 98, Microsoft Adds Tech Support
abstract: Microsoft Corp increases its technical support staff by 400, to more than 1,000, in anticipation of arrival of Windows 98 operating system on retailers' shelves next week (S)

headline: At Brauerei Beck: Prosit, Saatchi!
abstract: Brauereri Beck & Co in Bremen, Germany, expands its relationship with Saatchi & Saatchi PLC by naming that agency's New York office to handle Beck's beer account in US; billings on account, which had been handled by Rapp Collins Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, are estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: MEDPARTNERS SAYS IT WILL DISMISS 900 WORKERS
abstract: Medpartners Inc says it will dismiss about 900 of its 9,500 employees in Southern California and impose temporary 7 percent pay cut on physicians not losing their jobs as company struggles to return to profitability under new chief executive, Marc Crawford (S)

headline: Alioune Blondin Beye, 59, Envoy for U.N.
abstract: Alioune Blondin Beye, United Nations envoy on diplomatic mission aimed at averting renewed bloodshed in Angola, is apparently killed in crash of light plane near Abidjan, capital of Ivory Coast; he was 59 (N)

headline: Economic Scene; The Fed is trapped between expectations and reality.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's dilemma, trapped between public's expectation of perpetual economic bliss and evidence that even current economy is not immune to ailments of inflation and recession; by conventional measures, American economy is overheating; Fed has not made pre-emptive strike on inflation for variety of reasons, but it will doubtless act sometime this year, barring evidence that economy is cooling on its own; predominant view is that delay will compound both pain of taming inflation and risk of overshooting; drawing (M)

headline: Market Place; Amid muted earnings, a siren song from technology stocks.
abstract: Rush to buy technology stocks and mutual funds after a stunning first-quarter runup in the Nasdaq market puzzles some analysts, who cite warnings of disappointing earnings issued by sector's bellwether companies; others, however, say that technology sector is simply due for a rebound after sitting out the bull market in 1997 and that its fundamentals remain strong despite problems at some companies; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Cotelligent Group Inc., San Francisco, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the provider of information technology and system support services. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

headline: CALPINE IN $110 MILLION DEAL FOR TEXAS POWER COMPANY
abstract: Calpine Corp, power company based in San Jose, Calif, buys remaining half-interest in Texas Cogeneration Co for $110 million from unit of Dominion Resources Inc; says it paid $52.75 million at closing on March 31 and also agreed to make royalty payments to Dominion valued at $56.75 million beginning in 2000 (S)

headline: CORSAIR COMMUNICATIONS ADDING SUBSCRIBER COMPUTING
abstract: Corsair Communications Inc agrees to acquire Subscriber Computing Inc for about $71.25 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Elf Aquitaine Signs An Accord in Russia
abstract: Elf Aquitaine SA signs agreement with Yuksi Oil Co, largest oil company in Russia, to pay $528 million for five percent stake to diversify its sources of crude oil reserves (S)

headline: Host Marriott to Become REIT and Buy 13 Hotels
abstract: Host Marriott Corp, hoping to become more competitive in acquiring upscale hotels, says it will convert into real estate investment trust and buy 13 luxury hotels from Blackstone Group for about $835 million in cash and $945 million in assumed debt; will spin off 31 retirement communities, valued at about $700 million, to shareholders (M)

headline: WATSCO TO BUY AIR-CONDITIONING PRODUCTS DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: Watsco Inc to acquire Kaufman Supply for undisclosed price (S)

headline: NTL TO BUY COMTEL FOR $898 MILLION IN STOCK AND CASH
abstract: NTL Inc to buy Comtel, British cable unit of KPN Koninklyke PTT Nederland NV, dominant Dutch phone and post company, for $898 million (US) in stock and cash (S)

headline: Sony and Lowe End Relationship
abstract: Sony Electronics unit of Sony Corp of American and ad agency Lowe & Partners/SMS say they will part company after more than three years; billings estimated at $35 million to $50 million (S)

headline: Military Group Finds Doors Closed for a Fair in Europe
abstract: Belgian Foreign Ministry official Reginald Moreels asks Czech Republic Pres Vaclav Havel not to permit Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association, private, military-oriented American organization, to holds its fair in Brno; association holds exhibitions and conferences around world so that military officers and leaders of industry can view latest developments in military communications, electronics and intelligence systems (M)

headline: Roger Murray 2d, 86, Economist Who Was an Adviser to Congress
abstract: Roger F Murray 2d, economist whose financial acumen made him frequent adviser to members of Congress and business leaders during 1950's and 60's, dies at age 86 (M)

headline: Milosevic Agrees to Let Diplomatic Observers Into Kosovo
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic has agreed to allow diplomatic observers to enter and move through Kosovo, where Serbian troops and policemen have been attacking ethnic Albanian majority; photo of rebels marching toward Kosovo from northern Albania (M)

headline: U.S. Reportedly Backed British Mercenary Group in Africa
abstract: Sandline International, British mercenary force, and Clinton Administration aide say private army that helped restore Pres Ahmed Kabbah to power in Sierra Leone after his ouster by army officers kept United States informed of its activities and had tacit US support; Sandline, which was paid $10 million on Kabbah's behalf to arm and train force, brought in over 100 tons of weapons in violation of United Nations arms embargo; disclosures about Sandline are creating political stir in Britain, where Foreign Sec Robin Cook has said he will resign if embargo was knowingly violated; Prime Min Tony Blair dismisses charges and lauds Amb Peter Penfold, who reportedly coordinated Sandline operation; photo (M)

headline: Efamol Unit Selects Kirshenbaum Bond
abstract: Efamol Neutraceuticals, unit of Efamol Ltd, names Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners as first advertising agency to introduce its nutritional supplement programs in US; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: A Video Middleman as Shopkeeper, Too
abstract: Ingram Entertainment, largest wholesale distributor of recorded videocassettes, buys controlling interest in Speedserve, which sells videos and books over Internet; Ingram hopes to offer drop-shipping services to other on-line video companies and to Speedserve; Ingram's plan to be both friend and foe to video stores may be difficult; Hollywood Entertainment, Ingram's largest customer, says it will not buy videocassettes from Ingram for its own Internet store because of its Speedserve investment (M)

headline: Clinton Defends Trip to China and Policy of 'Engagement'
abstract: Pres Clinton, pushed by critics to defend his summit meeting in China, describes his policy of cooperation as 'principled and pragmatic'; says it is in US interest to engage China on commercial and security issues, while not turning blind eye to human rights concerns; speech at National Geographic Society fails to quiet critics who urge cancellation of trip; Clinton defends allowing American aerospace companies to export sophisticated satellites for launching aboard Chinese rockets; says moderate policies have led to release of dissidents, Chinese pledge to end sale of nuclear technology to Iran and Chinese help on halting India-Pakistan nuclear arms race; Clinton also says he cannot violate protocol and tell Chinese leaders not to hold official ceremonies in Tiananmen Square, where pro-democracy protesters were killed in 1989 (S)

headline: CORE LABORATORIES IN DEAL FOR OWEN OIL TOOLS
abstract: Core Laboratories NV acquires Owen Oil Tools Inc for $55 million in stock plus $7 million of assumed debt (S)

headline: ABB Quarterly Net Rises as Orders Dip
abstract: Asea Brown Boveri says its first-quarter net income rose 9 percent, to $258 million, from year earlier (S)

headline: What I Really, Really Want Is to Quit
abstract: When Geri Halliwell, better known as Ginger Spice, announced a week ago that she had had enough of Spice Girl-dom, holders of EMI shares worried about the impact on their record company's stock price.    In the event, all it did was wiggle a bit, dropping and then recovering to close in London Friday at $8.69, up 2.9 percent since the bombshell dropped her bombshell.

headline: IN LARGEST DEAL EVER, CITICORP PLANS MERGER WITH TRAVELERS GROUP
abstract: Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc agree to $70 billion merger, largest in history, that would create world's biggest financial-services company and corral many different financial businesses under one roof for first time since pre-Depression era; merger is remarkable not only for size but for brashness, since Federal laws still restrict how actively banks can sell products like insurance; challenges lawmakers to either end restrictions imposed by 1933 Glass-Steagall Act, scuttle deal or force merged company to cut back on what it offers customer; promises to ignite intense legislative battle in Congress over shape and future of financial services in America, and to speed pace of merger activity across financial landscape; will have to negotiate maze of regulations governing banking industry put in place precisely to prevent type of company both hope to put together; companies are betting that profits and competitiveness will be enhanced by offering one-stop shopping for broad range of services; Citicorp's chief executive John S Reed and Travelers chief executive Sanford I Weill will run new entity, to be called Citigroup Inc; new company will vault ahead of other financial giants in Japan and Europe that already offer large menu of financial services to customers; Reed and Weill comment; photos; charts; graph (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- A Vivid-Livid Divide; Madison Ave.'s New Explicitness Is Open to Debate
abstract: Sales pitches or wide variety of products are being infused with increasingly explicit images and language, which until recently had been considered too daring for conventional advertising; trend to be rude, crude and sometimes lewd is bringing American advertising sensibility somewhat closer to attitudes that have long prevailed in Europe, where consumers are routinely exposed to naked bodies, swearing and obvious sexual situations in brand campaigns; some ad executives comment on new advertising trends; drawings; photos (M)

headline: PLAYBOY INCREASES ITS BID FOR SPICE ENTERTAINMENT
abstract: Playboy Enterprises Inc raises its offer for Spice Entertainment Companies, adult television entertainment company, to about $100 million in cash, stock and assumed debt from $95 million (S)

headline: Road to Riches Starts In the Golden Triangle
abstract: Interview with Lo Hsing-han, former opium warlord of Golden Triangle of 1960's who currently has reputation as one of Myanmar's most influential businessmen; US views has prosperity as evidence that Myanmar's economy is awash in laundered drug money and that it military leaders have encouraged those who trade in drugs to invest in its development projects; photo (M)

headline: FIRSTMERIT IN $256 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR SECURITY FIRST
abstract: Firstmerit Corp agrees to buy Security First Corp for $256 million in stock (S)

headline: MITCHELL ENERGY AGREES TO BUY 3 PROPERTIES IN TEXAS
abstract: Mitchell Energy and Development Corp agrees to buy three oil- and gas-producing properties in Texas in separate transactions totaling $50 million; Mitchell is buying 67 percent interest in Columbus field unit in southeastern Texas from Occidental Petroleum Corp; other acquisitions noted (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises in anticipation of dollar sales by Japan's central bank on April 24 when Government releases details of its economic stimulus plan; in New York, dollar falls to 130.28 yen from 131.35; graph; chart (S)

headline: David Walsh, 52, Promoter Caught Up in Gold Mine Scandal
abstract: David G Walsh, Canadian stock promoter whose gold mining company, Bre-X Minerals, was at center of fraud case, dies in Bahamas at age 52; photo (S)

headline: Kingfisher Takes Stake In French Retailer
abstract: British retailer Kingfisher PLC to acquire controlling interest in French retailer BUT SA for $172.3 million (US) (S)

headline: In Investment Sector: Rumor And Hot Denial
abstract: Frank Quattrone, head of DMG Technology Group, technology arm of Deutsche Bank AG, denies rumors that he is shopping around his group to Goldman, Sachs, Union Bank of Switzerland and Credit Suisse First Boston; Quattrone squelches another rumor that Deutsche Bank has forced him to renegotiate his lucrative contract; Quattrone, who left Morgan Stanley Dean Witter two years ago, promised then that with his considerable talents and German bank's capital, DMG Technology would become pre-eminent technology bank, knocking Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs, & Co out of their top spots; while DMG Technology ranked fifth in technology mergers and acquisitions last year, it has not supplanted either of two most powerful contenders (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Average Surges 116, But Nasdaq Declines 14  With investors funneling money into blue-chip issues, the Dow Jones industrial average snapped a weeklong slump and surged 116.83 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,171.48. The bond market also rallied, with the price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbing 19/32 to 1039/32, sending its yield down to 5.89 percent.    But technology stocks remained under pressure, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 14.12 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 1,831.75. [Page D8.]

headline: NEW LEADER VOWS EARLY ELECTIONS FOR INDONESIANS
abstract: Pres B J Habibie bows to internal and external pressure and promises to hold election in Indonesia before term as transitional figure expires in 2003; calls for widespread reforms of economic, political and judicial systems in long and detailed televised speech, in which he repeatedly cites need to end corruption, collusion and nepotism; frees Muchtar Pakpahan, labor leader, Sri Bintang Pamungkas, former legislator, from prison in apparent gesture of conciliation; political analysts say it is not clear how far current electoral system can be opened to allow for real opposition or whether Habibie possesses power or will to steer country along such course; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Beats Earnings Expectations, but Revenue Growth Slows
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports earnings for fiscal third quarter ended March 31 were $1.34 billion, up 28 percent from $1.04 billion in year-earlier quarter; says sales rose 18 percent, to $3.77 billion from $3.21 billion; sales growth is slowest in five quarters; Microsoft's chief financial officer, Greg Maffei, says Microsoft is feeling both slowing of personal computer sales that affected other companies, as well as aging of many products, like Windows 95 and Office 97; chart (L)

headline: Peru's Leader Rejects Call to Release American
abstract: Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru stands firm against pardoning Lori Helene Berenson, American serving life sentence for helping guerrillas plan assault on Congress; Prime Min Javier Valle Riestra has called for clemency or new trial for Berenson (M)

headline: First Choice Holidays To Acquire Unijet
abstract: First Choice Holidays PLC to acquire Unijet, British travel and airline company, for 110 million pounds ($183.7 million) in cash and stock; as part of deal, First Choice also agrees to acquire British long-haul tour operator Hayes & Jarvis for 24 million pounds in cash, making it leading long-haul tour operator in Britain (S)

headline: Not Just 'Larry King Live'
abstract: CNN Newsstand, series of 10 PM news magazine shows, makes debut; will mix expertise of some Time Inc print magazines with CNN's television resources; photos (M)

headline: CHASE TO BUY CUSTODY UNIT FROM MORGAN STANLEY
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp agrees to buy custody unit of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co to help increase Chase's profits in low-margin business of processing trades and keeping track of investors' holdings; Chase pays about $600 million for unit (S)

headline: HUGHES IS RAISING STAKE IN PANAMSAT TO 81%
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp to buy 14.1 million shares of Panamsat Corp, including 11.2 million shares from Grupo Televisa SA and 2.9 million from group of Panamsat's founding shareholders, for $846 million, raising its stake in company to 81 percent from 71.5 percent (S)

headline: Big 3 Copy One Another Except in Labor Relations
abstract: Analysis of labor-management relations of United Auto Workers and Big Three auto manufacturers in light of strike at General Motors Corp; says GM, in its 16th strike in last five years, has publicly lashed out at union; by contrast, Ford Motor Co has not had strike in 12 years and its executives play golf with UAW leaders; Chrysler Corp's approach lies somewhere in between, with prolonged periods of calm interrupted by occasional strikes that are usually settled behind closed doors with little public acrimony (M)

headline: Advertisers Shift Compensation Method
abstract: Study conducted by Association of National Advertisers shows majority of American advertisers have shifted from compensating their agencies based on traditional billings method; finds use of billings-based commissions, both fixed rate and sliding scale, declined from 61 percent in 1994 to 35 percent in 1997; paying agencies by what is known as labor-based compensation grew by 35 percent in 1994 to 53 percent in 1997 (S)

headline: Foreigners to Be Allowed Stake in Korea Telecom
abstract: South Korea says it will sell as much as a third of Korea Telecom Co, its biggest telephone company, to foreign investors in share sale that could raise $2.4 billion to help finance country's economic recovery (S)

headline: 2 Drug Companies Report Big Quarterly Profit Gains
abstract: Pfizer Inc and Johnson & Johnson report double-digit percentage gains in first-quarter earnings; Pfizer says earnings totaled $692 million, up 15 percent from $602 million a year earlier; revenue totaled $3.34 billion, up 11 percent from $3 billion; Johnson & Johnson says earnings totaled $1.01 billion, up 11 percent from $909 million a year earlier; revenue totaled $5.78 billion, up 1.2 percent from $5.72 billion (M)

headline: DuPont to Buy Merck's Share of Venture
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co will pay Merck & Co $2.6 billion for drug company's half of DuPont Merck Pharmaceutical Co, joint venture they formed in 1991 (M)

headline: WARNACO TO MAKE CALVIN KLEIN CHILDREN'S CLOTHING
abstract: Apparel maker Warnaco Group Inc acquires license to make Calvin Klein children's jeans and related clothing for $41 million from Commerce Clothing (S)

headline: International Briefs; Lithuania Telecom Stake Sold for $510 Million
abstract: Telia A.B. of Sweden and the Sonera Corporation of Finland said yesterday that they would buy 60 percent of the Lithuanian state-owned telecommunications operator Lietuvos Telekomas for $510 million. Telia and Sonera, both state-owned telecommunications companies, will each pay $255 million for the stake.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Mellon Sues Its Suitor But May Encounter Hurdle  Seeking to halt an unwanted takeover bid, Mellon Bank sued Bank of New York, contending that it used confidential information from previous merger talks when it offered to buy Mellon.

headline: Long-Term Interest Rates Fall to 5.7%
abstract: Long-term interest rates fall sharply, as Asian financial crisis and continuing problems in Russia apparently send more foreigners to haven of American bond market; Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan helps rally when he indicates, in upbeat assessment of economy, that interest rate increase to slow economic growth is not imminent; price of 30-year bond rises 1 7/32, to 106 2/32, as yield falls to 5.70 percent; Greenspan says Asian crisis could lead to cut in earnings expectations, key element in outlook for stock market, speech to Joint Economic Committee of Congress; Greenspan says Asian crisis should lead to further dampening of American export sales and reduction in profit margins because of rising price pressures from cheaper imports; both developments would cut into earnings; graph; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: $253 Million Offer In Swedish Real Estate
abstract: Wihlborgs Fastigheter AB will bid 1.98 billion kronor ($253 million) in stock to acquire Storheden AB (S)

headline: S.& L. Expands Pledge on Loans
abstract: Washington Mutual Inc says it designates $120 billion for loans to lower-income consumers and communities over 10 years, beginning in 1999, if its acquisition of H F Ahmanson & Co is completed; plan expands $75 billion program it announced last year (S)

headline: Economy Brisk, But Data Offer Some Cautions
abstract: Commerce Department reports gross domestic product rose in first quarter at annual rate of 4.8 percent; corporate profits fell 2.2 percent, after taxes; it is second quarterly decline after more than three years of steadily rising profits; new orders for durable goods rose 2.6 percent, to $191.2 billion in April, after slight increase in March; graph (M)

headline: American Topics : A School in California Starts Suspending the Parents, Too
abstract: Teachers and administrators in San Juan Capistrano, California, are fed up with rudeness and foul language. So under a new school policy, cursing a teacher can lead to suspension. The rule, however, aims not at students but at their parents.

headline: EQUITY INNS TO PURCHASE RFS HOTEL FOR $660 MILLION
abstract: Equity Inns Inc agrees to acquire RFS Hotel Investors Inc for $660 million in stock and $330 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: DAOU SYSTEMS ADDING INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY CONCERN
abstract: Daou Systems wukk buy Resources in Healthcare Innovations for $54 million (S)

headline: Where You Can Turn If the Bottom Drops Out
abstract: Article offers advice to employees with 401(k) plans in light of survey by William M Mercer Inc that 52 percent of companies have no plans to communicate with workers in event of major market selloff (M)

headline: Sweet Slips Of the Ear: Mondegreens
abstract: Several Web pages collect 'mondegreens,' often hilarious examples of misheard song lyrics; one site, called The Ants Are My Friends, is named for common mishearing of 'the answer my friends' from Bob Dylan's Blowin' in the Wind; survey finds 77 percent of those who submit mondegreens believe their versions are better than the originals; drawings (M)

headline: Iran Arms Smugglers Take the Canadian Route
abstract: A shadowy Iranian effort to smuggle American-made jets and sophisticated military equipment across Canada and into Iran was recently exposed by a United States undercover agent. But this attempted violation of the American embargo of Iran was not an isolated case, according to a joint investigation by The New York Times and CBS News. A significant portion of the American-made weapons and parts that Iran buys illicitly move through Canada, taking advantage of regulatory loopholes and the Canadian Government's decision not to support the American embargo.     Article, page A3.

headline: FIRST HAWAIIAN TO BUY BANCWEST IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: First Hawaiian Inc to acquire BancWest Corp in stock swap valued at $971 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities column; palladium falls after Russian Parliament approves new Prime Minister, raising hopes that exports will resume after four-month delay; graph (S)

headline: SLH TO PAY $535 MILLION FOR ALL OF SYNTROLEUM
abstract: SLH Corp agrees to pay $535 million in stock to acquire shares it does not already own of Syntroleum Corp (S)

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES ORDERS 25 MORE BOEING AIRCRAFT
abstract: American Airlines said yesterday that it had ordered 25 more 737-800 aircraft from the Boeing Company, adding to a $7 billion purchase of more than 100 planes announced in November 1996. The 737, one of the most widely used jetliners in commercial aviation, will replace 727-200's, the oldest planes in American's fleet. The 25 new planes, worth $1.29 billion before discounts, are scheduled to be delivered between January 2000 and January 2002. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, now has 100 737's on order. The carrier expects to replace all its 727's by 2004. American originally ordered 103 planes from Boeing in 1996.

headline: Companies Are Investigated For Aid to China on Rockets
abstract: Federal grand jury is investigating whether Loral Space and Communications and Hughes Electronics illegally gave China space expertise that significantly advanced Beijing's ballistic missile program; officials say criminal inquiry was dealt serious blow when Pres Clinton recently approved export to China of similar technology from Loral; decision was opposed by Justice Department, which argued that it would be difficult to prosecute companies if Government gave blessings to deal; companies have denied wrongdoing (M)

headline: The Year 2000 Problem: Offering Second Thoughts
abstract: Norman Kurland letter on Apr 23 article on year 2000 computer software problem (S)

headline: PRIMESTAR IN DEAL TO BUY UNITED VIDEO SATELLITE UNIT
abstract: Primestar Partners Inc agrees to buy large-dish satellite television business of United Video Satellite Group for $430 million in securities, aiming to switch 1.2 million subscribers to Primestar's direct broadcast TV service (S)

headline: Kia Group Vows To Stay Independent
abstract: Kia Group will continue its fight to remain independent; says cost-cutting drive is paying dividends, enabling Kia Motors Corp to turn its first profit since 1993 (S)

headline: THOMAS H. LEE BUYOUT FIRM IS ADDING 30% OF COTT
abstract: Buyout firm Thomas H Lee Co agrees to acquire 30 percent interest in Cott Corp, a Canadian soft-drink maker, for $110 million (S)

headline: HEICO ADDING FRENCH AERONAUTICAL PRODUCTS CONCERN
abstract: The Heico Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Teleflex Lionel-Dupont of Paris for about $64 million in class A stock. Heico, an aerospace, aviation and military products company based in Hollywood, Fla., will also assume debt of $53 million to buy the larger Teleflex Lionel-Dupont, a maker of aeronautical products and ground-support equipment. Heico said the purchase, along with the ground-support business it acquired when it bought Trilectron Industries in 1996, would give it the largest share of the highly fragmented industry of providing equipment to service aircraft while on the ground. Teleflex Lionel-Dupont had revenue of $146 million last year, while Heico had $64 million. Heico's class A shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $28.

headline: In Sex-Role Tangle, A Woman's Search
abstract: Looksmart is attracting a higher percentage of women than other top web search sites, perhaps indicating that women are well disposed to its unique categorized approach to searching; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SERVICEMASTER CO., Downers Grove, Ill., a provider of consumer and management services, agreed to acquire Quantum Resources Corp., of Richmond, a temporary staffing company. Terms were not disclosed.    LIFE USA HOLDING INC., Minneapolis, a financial services holding company, agreed to purchase a minority stake in Windsor Financial Group L.L.C., a Minneapolis-based investment management firm. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Kosovo: Yet Another Act In the Balkan Tragedy
abstract: European and US diplomats are arguing over what to do about crisis in Kosovo, Serbia; they say Kosovo, where 90 percent of two million people are ethnic Albanians, is looking more and more like Bosnia; map; photo (M)

headline: Help Along the Campaign Trail From Kohl's Friend 'Dear Bill'
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl warmly greets Pres Clinton, Potsdam; visit by Clinton, who is very popular in Germany, boosts Kohl, who faces tough election; two will take part in blur of campaign-style events (M)

headline: Turkish Commandos Capture a Kurdish Leader in Raid Into Iraq
abstract: Turkish commandos stage raid into northern Iraq and capture Kurdish rebel commander, Semdin Sakik, who recently defected from guerrilla leadership (S)

headline: Goldman Partners Meet on Firm's Future
abstract: Partners of Goldman, Sachs & Co meet at suburban conference center to consider proposal to turn firm into public company (S)9

headline: Prices Up on Signs of Sound Economy and Scant Price Pressure
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities turn higher; 30-year bond rises 18/32, to 102 22/32; yield drops to 5.93 percent, from 5.98 percent on March 30; charts (L)

headline: Rebel Ranks Expand In Serbian Province
abstract: In Kosovo, once-elusive guerrilla bands fighting for independence from Serbia suddenly seem to be everywhere. Their numbers are being swelled by an infusion of troops and weapons smuggled in from Albania.     The startling growth of the insurgency is prompting fears that the unrest could explode into a new Balkan war.

headline: A Bilingual Way to Attract Viewers
abstract: Spanish-language television, seeking to reach younger, more culturally attuned niche of nation's eight million Hispanic households, is broadcasing handful of programs that use varying degrees of both English and Spanish; Maria Conchita Alonso hosts new bilingual program for Telemundo Group Inc; photo (M)

headline: Mack-Cali Property Deal
abstract: Mack-Cali Realty Corp buys two Washington, DC, office buildings and has entered into contract to acquire property in Maryland for combined purchase price of $104.5 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. Is Challenging MCI On Accounting Procedures
abstract: MCI Communications Corp delays release of its full financial report for last year because of dispute with Securities and Exchange Commission over some of company's accounting practices; if SEC does not back down, MCI could be forced to retract financial results it announced for final quarter of 1997 and take unexpected charges against its earnings for first half of this year; dispute is not expected to affect outcome or terms of MCI's planned $37 billion acquisition by Worldcom Inc (M)

headline: Wary Mood in Ulster After Vote: Trials Still Ahead
abstract: Ronnie Kane, proprietor of R. J. Kane Confectionery, Newsagent, Tobacconist, had just handed the morning papers to a customer when he checked to see that no one was listening and stepped from behind the counter.    ''I'm really excited,'' he confided, giving the air a barely visible jab. ''But I know we've still got a painful process ahead of us.''

headline: Iraq Insists It's Being Candid With U.N. Arms Inspectors
abstract: Iraqi Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz disputes report by United Nations chief arms inspector Richard Butler charging Iraq still hides details about its program to develop weapons of mass destruction, letter to Security Council; Sen Trent Lott and three other Republicans send Pres Clinton letter citing new reports that Iraq deployed weapons carrying VX nerve gas before Persian Gulf War; demand full United States support for UN inspection team and score Clinton's policy toward Iraq (M)

headline: Experts Say Indonesia Can Boom, Long-Term
abstract: Economists are strikingly optimistic about long-term prospects for Indonesia, despite current economic and political upheaval; say country must turn away from crony capitalism that led to wasteful investments, and go back to using cheap, abundant labor to power fresh export boom (S)

headline: Four Big Drug Makers' Nets Are Higher on Strong Sales
abstract: Pharmaceutical companies Bristol-Myers Squibb, American Home Products, Schering-Plough and SmithKline Beecham report higher quarterly earnings; Bristol-Myers's profit rose 14 percent, American Home's rose 13 percent, Schering-Plough's earnings rose 20 percent and Smithkline Beecham rose 8 percent; Bristol-Myers Squibb says it earned $927 million, up from $810 million a year earlier; revenues rose 9.9 percent, to $4.45 billion; American Home Products Corp earned $982 million, up from $576 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 1.8 percent, to $3.67 billion from $3.60 billion; Schering-Plough earned $450 million from $375 million in quarter a year earlier; revenue rose 22 percent, to $1.91 billion; Smithkline Beecham reports earnings of $475 million compared with $438 million in year-earlier quarter; chart (L)

headline: VALHI PURCHASES A 43.8% STAKE IN TREMONT
abstract: Valhi Inc., a holding company with stakes in chemical, waste management and metal parts companies, said yesterday that it had bought 43.8 percent of the Tremont Corporation from the parent of both companies for about $165 million, raising its ownership in the fourth-largest maker of white pigments. Valhi paid $56 a share for 2.9 million Tremont shares from the closely held Contran Corporation, which owns 93 percent of the Dallas-based Valhi. The purchase increases Valhi's stake in NL Industries, the fourth-largest maker of titanium dioxide, from 57 percent to 75 percent because of the Denver-based Tremont's stake in NL. The Texas billionaire Harold C. Simmons owns controlling stakes in Contran, Valhi, NL Industries and Tremont.

headline: Persistence Pays Off for a Janus Manager
abstract: Article on success of Janus Special Situations fund, started in December 1996 by David C Decker; says from fund's inception through May 8, Decker has turned out 49.6 percent annualized return; chart; photo (M)

headline: Pennzoil and Quaker State Plan a Two-Stage Merger
abstract: Pennzoil and Quaker State plan to combine into new, dominant force in sale and manufacture of automotive lubricants, waxes and additives; companies, already first and second in nation's motor oil market, would together have 36 percent share; Pennzoil would spin its motor oil operations, Jiffy-Lube chain and related businesses into new public company, which would then merge with Quaker State Corp in stock swap, but their brand names would remain distinct; deal could help compensate Pennzoil shareholders dismayed by its rejection last year of hostile, $4.2 billion takeover bid from Union Pacific Resources; Pennzoil would remain independent petroleum exploration and production company; chart (L)

headline: Live Debate On Television Is a Rarity For Chinese
abstract: Live television coverage of important political events is relatively new development in China; in past, all events were taped and difficult discussions, or possibly embarrassing scenes, were edited out; live coverage of exchange between Pres Clinton and Pres Jiang, covering some very sensitive topics, was not announced in advance; hours later, it was replaced by edited version for evening news; photo (M)

headline: Offshore Oil Rig Is Sold
abstract: Pride International Inc agrees to buy MSV Amethyst semisubmersible drilling rig for $85 million (S)

headline: Offerings Scheduled in Equity This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: An On-Line Critic Tackles the Big Papers
abstract: Scott Shuger does daily analysis of articles in nation's major daily newspapers, and analysis, called Today's Papers, is sent to 20,000 subscribers of electronic magazine Slate; Michael Kinsley, editor of Slate, says Shuger hopes to educate people about how to read newspaper; photo (M)

headline: Dell Wants to Lead Way In Move to Pentium II's
abstract: Dell Computer Co leads computer industry switch from Intel's older processors to its Pentium II line, offering only new chip it Dimension personal computers (S)

headline: Chief of S.E.C. Chides Funds On Information
abstract: Mutual fund investors, blinded by stunning investment returns the last several years, are not getting enough information about how much they are paying for a fund company's services, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today.     In an address to the annual meeting of the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, Mr. Levitt called on fund companies to temper their promotion of investment performance by explaining ''clearly and unequivocally'' how fees and expenses affect small investors and what risks they face if the financial markets decline.

headline: Licensing of Names Adds to Image and Profit
abstract: Corporate brand licensing has grown rapidly in last five years; last year, corporate brands accounted for 22 percent of all licensing in US, or $16.06 billion in sales; companies see licensing as low-risk way to build brand awareness, which can also bring in additional revenue; in some cases, licensing a name to be used on certain products can help focus it on different audience or increase its appeal to specific consumer groups; specific licensing deals discussed; graph; photos (M)

headline: CD-ROM Maps: Flexible (but Hard to Fold)
abstract: CD-ROM trip planners, atlases and street finders and their related Web sites are useful enhancements to travel planning; several products evaluated; photo (M)

headline: Oranjemund Journal; Find a Diamond in the Sand? Just Don't Pick It Up
abstract: De Beers Corp maintains tight security in Sperrgebeiet, rich diamond bed along Namibia's southern coast; expects diamonds will be depleted in another 25 years and weighs moves to open ecologically fragile desert area to public; map; photo (M)

headline: ESSAY; In a Life's Digital Flotsam, a Bittersweet Balm for Death's Sting
abstract: Lou Grinzo article on his feelings about sorting computer files of friend and business associate who died unexpectedly; photo (M)0

headline: Fuji 2d-Half Net Off On Weak Asia Demand
abstract: Net earnings of Fuji Photo Film Co fall 4.1 percent in second half of year that ended on Mar 31, to 38.61 billion yen ($294 million); sales grew 8.26 percent, to 704.781 billion yen (S)

headline: For the Long Final Hours, Clinton Coaxed
abstract: Pres Clinton, whose 1994 overture to Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams helped bring political wing of Irish Republican Army to peace table, was deeply involved as Ulster talks successfully concluded; he cajoled and prodded both Republicans and Unionists to step out of parochial interests and take historic risks for peace (M)

headline: An On-Line Rush Is On
abstract: Study by Forrester Research predicts mutual fund assets in on-line accounts will grow from estimated $47 billion now to $241 billion by 2002, at a pace five times expected growth rate for overall household assets; retail investors will benefit from trend; Internet represents growth, variety and low-cost means of distribution which could lead to lower fund expenses; added variety of funds can be useful to investors; research shows newer, smaller funds tend to outperform older peers that have greater assets, expecially in certain asset classes like small-capitalization stocks; graph (M)

headline: Sony Profit Increases, But Problems Are Seen
abstract: Sony Corp president Nobuyuki Idei says Sony earned record profit on record sales for second year running in 12 months just ended, yet year ahead will be 'very severe'; profit was at least 210 billion yen ($1.6 billion), up at least 51 percent, on sales of at least 6.6 trillion yen, up 17 percent (S)

headline: Executive Succession Timetable Is Moved Up by Bell Atlantic
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp says president Ivan G Seidenberg will become chief executive June 1, over two months earlier than planned; he succeeds Raymond W Smith and is set to succeed him as chairman; Smith hints he may step down before end of year (S)5

headline: Taking the Plunge on Casual Day
abstract: Workers are invited to submit anecdotes about casual dress days; photo9

headline: Can-Do American's Patience Paid Off With an Ulster Pact
abstract: George J Mitchell gave up comforts of retirement from United States Senate to spend three years trying to wring peace agreement out of feuding political leaders of Northern Ireland; all sides are praising him for his stewardship during 22 months of talks it took to produce peace accord; there is general agreement that without his guidance and forbearance no accord would have emergered; Mitchell says he was motivated by belief that children of Northern Ireland deserve same peace and political stability that his children enjoy; photo (M)

headline: Japan Credit Bank To Review Some Lending
abstract: Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd starts to review its lending to 2,500 companies, one-third of its total client base, with possibility that loans may be eliminated; review will be finished by March 2000 (S)

headline: Europe's No. 2 Insurer Bids for Royale Belge
abstract: AXA SA, Europe's second-biggest insurer, offers about $3.4 billion in cash and shares to buy 52.2 percent of Royale Belge SA it does not own (S)

headline: Market Place; While the deal for TCI may be good for most shareholders, it will make the company's chairman very rich.
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc chairman John C Malone struck rich deal for himself in agreeing to sell company to AT&T Corp; owns some 30 million of 50 billion class B shares outstanding; AT&T has agreed to pay 9.7 percent more per share for these shares than for class A shares, in which Malone has far smaller stake; table; photo (M)

headline: Bonds Turn Downward as Dollar Continues to Weaken
abstract: US Government bonds close mostly lower; Treasury's 30-year issue rises 7/32, to price of 103 15/32, while its yield declines to 5.88 percent, from 5.89 percent on April 8; chart (L)

headline: U.S. Says It Told Russia 2 Days Before Balkan Aerial Maneuvers
abstract: Western officials deny charge by Russian Defense Minister, Igor Sergeyev, that Russia was not given advance word of NATO's aerial military exercises in Balkans; say Russia was notified Russia two days in advance; say NATO Sec Gen Javier Solana informed Amb Sergei I Kislyak and Gen Klaus Naumann informed Lt Gen Victor M Zavarzin, Russia's chief military representative to NATO (M)

headline: Mexicans Belittle Drug-Money Sting
abstract: Mexican officials seek to belittle results of huge United States undercover operation that exposed laundering of drug money in 12 Mexican banks after Federal grand jury in Los Angeles unsealed three indictments against Mexican bankers and their clients in drug organizations based in Ciudad Juarez and in Cali, Colombia; more than $72 million in drug proceeds was seized during three-year undercover operation (M)

headline: 3 Radio Free Asia Journalists Are Barred : Clinton Assails China Over Rescinded Visas
abstract: WASHINGTON—  President Bill Clinton, seeking to fend off pressure from congressional critics of his China visit, denounced Beijing on Tuesday for denying visas to three journalists who had planned to cover the trip for Radio Free Asia, which is funded by the U.S. government. He said the move was "highly objectionable."

headline: New Freedoms Feed Ethnic Frictions
abstract: Indonesians, exultant and volatile after Pres Suharto's downfall, now face critical questions about their political and economic future; photo; map; converations with dozens of people suggest that democracy may prove less tolerant and compassionate than Suharto's dictatorship, and may also allow outlet for hatreds lurking among poor workers and peasants; ethnic Chinese are especially resented for their economic success and Christian faith in Muslim country (M)

headline: Xian Turns Out, and It Wasn't Even Compulsory
