abstract: On this steamy summer night, the people of Xian took to the streets to welcome President Clinton on the first stop of his state visit, in what many here said was one of the largest spontaneous gatherings they could remember.    ''There's never been another event like this here -- I don't think I've ever seen this many people come out for anything,'' said Sun Qinqi, an engineer, who said he had decided to pass up the World Cup soccer game to cram onto the sidewalk just inside the Old City's South Gate to catch a glimpse of the Presidential motorcade's arrival.

headline: Treasuries Flat Ahead of Greenspan Talk
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities end little changed; price of benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rises 2/32, to 104 29/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 5.78 percent; chart on US key interest rates (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization               May 8   May 1   May 9   1998   1998   1997       Gasoline production, daily   7.9   8.0   8.1       Distillate production, daily   3.3   3.5   3.5       Gasoline stocks   214.5   211.1   197.1       Distillate stocks   124.0   122.4   96.5       Crude imports, daily   8.7   8.8   7.6       Product imports, daily   2.1   1.7   1.9       Crude stocks   343.1   342.3   321.7       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   95.9   98.6   96.9          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Money and Other Hardening Positions in Strikes at G.M.
abstract: Analysis of United Auto Workers strike against two General Motors parts plants; soaring losses on both sides make it harder for either side to paint eventual settlement as victory; both sides are beginning to see strike as showdown over future course of labor-management relations, making it much harder to settle; photo (M)

headline: FIFTH THIRD GETTING 4 BANC ONE BRANCHES
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp of Cincinnati to buy four Banc One branches in southeastern Ohio for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Advanced Micro Devices' Deficit Larger Than Analysts Expected
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc reports substantially larger loss than Wall Street analysts had expected; for quarter ended March 29, company reports loss of $55.8 million compared to profit of $13 million in year-earlier period; sales fell 2 percent, to $540.86 million, from $551.99 million in first quarter of 1997 (M)

headline: Network Helps Children Cope With Serious Illness
abstract: Starbright Foundation runs computer network that enables seriously ill hospitalized children to communicate with each other; network is being tested in 16 hospitals across nation and expanded version is planned; table of on-line projects to help sick children communicate with one another; photo (M)

headline: Union Pacific Chief Faults Plans to Restore Competition
abstract: Union Pacific Railroad chairman-chief executive Richard K Davidson says railroad will resist plans by Federal regulators meant to restore competition because results would only further erode service; Davidson makes remarks during interview while on inspection tour from Fort Worth to Dallas, Tex; Davidson speaks three days after Surface Transportation Board ordered broadest review of rules governing railroads since they were deregulated in early 1980's; Davidson, attributing clogged tracks and yards to too much traffic and too little capacity, rather than too few carriers, says that even giving rivals temporary access to its tracks in Texas has only compounded tie-ups; photo (L)

headline: With 2 Takes on One Tale, Sinn Fein Chief Bargains
abstract: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams, in week since announcement of Northern Ireland peace agreement, has taken different approaches with different Roman Catholic political groups in order to win their support for agreement in May referendum (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: German mark surges on jump in Germany's money supply, increasing possibility of higher interest rates there; in New York, dollar falls to 1.7884 marks from 1.8012, its lowest level since Jan 26; graph; chart (S)

headline: Intel's Antitrust Alternative: Avoid Public Confrontation
abstract: Intel Corp's response to Federal Trade Commission's antitrust suit differs markedly from Microsoft Corp's aggressive drive against Justice Department's antitrust suit; Intel is keeping low profile, not lobbying Congress and Clinton Administration; apparently believes Microsoft's public-relations blitz backfired (M)

headline: Business Groups Press For $18 Billion for I.M.F.
abstract: American business is lobbying Congress to approve $18 billion in new financing for cash-strapped International Monetary Fund, which has been instrumental in Asian financial bailout; campaign has scored one major victory; Senate approved financing and attached it to must-pass disaster-relief bill; House is balking, setting up showdown when Congressional negotiators return from their spring recess (M)

headline: Volkswagen Expected to Set Off a Bidding War for Rolls-Royce
abstract: Nearly one month after BMW AG reached agreement to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars from Vickers PLC, Volkswagen AG is expected to ignite new bidding war by offering more money and lavish promises to invest billions of dollars in future expansion (M)

headline: Consolidations by Frito-Lay and Pepsico move a host of choice assignments to BBDO Worldwide.
abstract: Advertising column on decision by Frito-Lay and its parent, Pepsico Inc, to consolidate global accounts at BBDO Worldwide; says this follows trend among large marketers to consolidate (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.63   5.47   5.56        3-month T-bills   4.93   4.98   5.13        6-month T-bills   5.06   5.09   5.38        10-yr. headline: German Agency Sells Apartments
abstract: The German Transport Ministry has sold 112,600 apartments used by Deutsche Bahn A.G. rail workers to a group including WCM Beteiligungs-und Grundbesitz A.G. for 7.1 billion marks, or $3.94 billion.    Money from the sale of the apartments, grouped in 18 housing associations, will help reduce the German Government's budget deficit this year and in 1999, the ministry said.

headline: Mourning the End of a Printing Era
abstract: Once-complicated craft of setting type has been made obsolete over last 15 years by personal computer and inexpensive software packages; membership in Typographers Assn of New York has dwindled from 180 typesetting shops to just 14 companies; about 70 people attend farewell party for trade group; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.69   5.63   5.58        3-month T-bills   4.87   4.90   4.81        6-month T-bills   5.10   5.11   5.18        10-yr. T-infl.   3.73   3.74   3.57        10-yr. T-note   5.55   5.56   6.65        30-yr. T-bond   5.80   5.82   6.91        Telephone bd.   7.03   7.06   7.97        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.23   5.74          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: SOME PRICES JUMP DESPITE A PATTERN OF LOW INFLATION
abstract: US inflation rate stays persistently low, but prices are rising noticeably for variety of everyday items, sharply enough in some cases to catch attention and provoke annoyance; prices of commodities and manufactured goods remain steady--partly from pressures of global competition--but prices are rising smartly for growing number of items in service sector, including fast-food hamburgers, auto maintenance and dental care; increases are seen as reflection of robust economy, in which people become more ambitious in purchases and more tolerant of costs, as incomes rise and unemployment falls; Consumer Price Index has risen only 1.7 percent in past year; chart (M)

headline: Lilly Forms Research and Development Pact
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co forms marketing and development collaboration in genitourinary drug field with Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc, which will get worldwide licenses to Lilly drugs to treat conditions like bladder and sexual dysfunction (S)

headline: FRANCHISE BUYS AND SELLS HOTEL SITES FOR $84 MILLION
abstract: US Franchise Systems Inc buys franchise rights to Best Inns and Suites hotels and 17 of its properties for $84 million; US Franchise immediately sells 17 properties to investment fund Alpine Capital Group for $84 million; seller is America's Best Inns (S)

headline: Unexpected Profit Reported In Viacom's First Quarter
abstract: Viacom Inc reports unexpected profit for first quarter; net income was $1.4 million compared with net loss of $18.7 million a year earlier (M)

headline: 4 in the Running For Sony Project
abstract: Sony Electronics is seeking advertising agency to handle fall introduction of HiFD, computer data storage product, with billings of about $20 million; four agencies in the running for the account noted (S)

headline: After 6 Months, Harry Evans Still 'Invisible Man'
abstract: Harold M Evans has not become much of visible presence at any of Mortimer B Zuckerman's publications, including New York Daily News, US News & World Report, Atlantic Monthly and Fast Company, where he has been editorial director and vice chairman for six months; is in charge of hiring and firing and has apparently been interviewing candidates for some jobs; photo (M)

headline: FELCOR TO ACQUIRE 8 ALL-SUITE HOTELS FROM STARWOOD
abstract: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc agrees to buy eight all-suite hotels for $245 million from Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust; six of the hotels are to be run by Promus Hotel Corp; other hotels will be managed by ITT Sheraton, now operated by Starwood, as Sheraton Suites Hotels (S)

headline: Legislation on On-Line Copyrights Advances
abstract: Congress is completing legislation that would expand copyright protections to on-line material; legislation is meant to put into force international treaty on digital copyrights; it seeks to protect intellectual property holders while limiting liability of Internet access providers that unwittingly store, transmit or link Web surfers to illegally copied material (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Keep a Strong Patent System
abstract: MUCH has been written about how the explosion of patent litigation in the last decade in the high-technology industry threatens to cripple America's most innovative companies. Critics of the patent system are quick to point out how patent infringement judgments have escalated into the hundred-million-dollar range, not to mention the lawyers' fees.   In addition, the critics say, the less tangible effects of patent litigation, including the distractions to management and engineers, can stifle the development of new products.

headline: Durango Sales Send Chrysler Net Up 2.9%
abstract: Chrysler Corp earned $1.05 billion in first quarter, up 2.9 percent from $1.03 billion in year-earlier period; revenue climbed 4.3 percent, to $16.8 billion from $16.1 billion a year ago; earnings were helped by sales of new Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle; chart (L)

headline: Microsoft Fires First Salvo In Antitrust Fight With U.S.
abstract: Microsoft Corp asks Federal judge to give it seven months to prepare for hearing in Government's antitrust case; Government and 20 states will ask court to move more quickly, probably within four to six weeks; they say Microsoft's request is merely effort to stall case, allowing rapid pace of change in software business to render legal issues obsolete (M)

headline: Italian Leader Will Visit Iran This Week
abstract: Prime Min Romano Prodi of Italy will make official visit to Iran, first by head of Government from European Union country since 1979 revolution (S)

headline: Spanish Ex-Premier Denies Role in Terror
abstract: Former Spanish Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, testifies at trial of 12 political aides and police officers who served under him, saying he never ordered his Socialist Government to conduct illegal counter-terrorism against armed Basque separatists in 1980's; prosecution seeks to prove his Government sponsored 'dirty war' that killed 27 suspected Basque rebels (S)

headline: 3 MacArthur Fellows Are Adding Value to the World of Money
abstract: EVERY year since 1981, it has been a cross between a Pulitzer and a lottery: the fellowship program of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which awards sizable, no-strings-attached grants to a diverse group of creative thinkers.    To choose recipients, the foundation uses a confidential group of nominators and a selection committee. Earlier this month, the foundation announced 29 such fellows -- distributing grants, to be paid over five years, that ranged from $220,000 to $375,000, depending on the recipient's age.

headline: Auschwitz Synagogue to Reopen, Bringing 'Hopes of the Future'
abstract: Auschwitz Jewish Center Foundation reclaims title to former Lomdei Mishnayot Synagogue in Oswiecim, Poland, which was converted into carpet warehouse by Communists after World War II; is first property to be returned to Polish Jewish community under Government restitution program; Fred Schwartz, foundation founder, says building and adjoining house will be transformed into Jewish religious and cultural center (M)

headline: Ruling Party in Paraguay Maintains Its Long Grip on Presidency
abstract: Paraguay's governing Colorado Party sweeps presidential elections, defeating coalition of opposition parties to maintain its half-century-long hold on power (M)

headline: Media Talk; A PBS Look at Press Behavior
abstract: Terence Smith to join PBS to head special unit that will examine performance of news media; will report on press-related issues regularly for News Hour With Jim Lehrer; Pew Charitable Trusts funds effort (S)

headline: Japanese Offer No New Measures, Just Pledges, to Bolster the Yen
abstract: Japan pledges to revive its economy and repair banking system, Group of Seven deputy finance ministers' meeting, Tokyo; fails to spell out any new or specific moves; Deputy Treasury Sec Lawrence Summers say Japanese officials are aware of situation's urgency (M)

headline: Do You Have Bad Cyberkarma?
abstract: Many people believe some sort of machine-to-mind connection causes them to bomb their computers with alarming regularity; people who service computers and receive trouble calls from crash-prone users offer other explanations, including hyperactive (therefore error-prone) typing or machines with poor surge protection; science has almost as many explanations for crashing talent as there are crash-prone people, including stress factor; experts have yet to document any psychic connection between human and computer, but some people are convinced it exists; computer mystique is not surprising, since its inner workings are beyond most people's understanding and far more complex than earlier technological advances; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Exports to Japan Fall, And Trade Gap Widens  American exports to Japan plummeted in February and helped send the United States trade deficit to its widest gap in a decade.

headline: If Sentiment Fails, Cold Cash Will Do
abstract: Interviews with event planners, etiquette experts and sampling of households in New York City, Los Angeles, De Kalb, Ill, Seattle and Memphis underscore that 'proper' amount of cash that person should give as gift for various events varies according to region, culture and relationship between giver and recipient; photo (S)

headline: CLINTON TO IMPOSE PENALTIES ON INDIA OVER ATOMIC TESTS
abstract: Pres Clinton decides to impose raft of economic sanctions on India for its underground nuclear testing; decides after India refuses to disavow future testing or deployment of nuclear arms; will invoke for first time 1994 nuclear sanctions law, which will cut off nearly all aid to India, bar American banks from making loans to its Government and curb exports of computers and other equipment with possible military uses; law requires United States to oppose World Bank and International Monetary Fund loans to India; Clinton, at earlier news conference, calls on India to halt testing; photo; table (M)

headline: Kinko's Parts Ways With Its Agencies
abstract: Kinko's Inc parts ways with domestic advertising agencies, Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland and CPM Media Management, and seeks new agency with worldwide capabilities (S)

headline: International Briefs; Iberia Order With Airbus Gives Boeing a Setback
abstract: Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana SA, Spanish national airline, signs contract to buy up to 76 aircraft from Airbus Industrie for as much as $2.63 billion; order represents setback for Boeing Co (S)

headline: Many Internet Shares Rally, but Major Indexes Are Mixed
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 19.68 points, to close at 9,049.92; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 2.69 points, to 1,118.41; Nasdaq composite index gains 12.99 points, to 1,800.76 graph on intraday Dow fluctuations; charts on US key interest rates and stocks with large price percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: Boston Properties in Deal for Embarcadero
abstract: Boston Properties Inc acquies San Francisco's Embarcadero Center from Prudential Insurance Co of America and partnership including David Rockefeller for $1.22 billion; Boston Properties also agees to acquire Prudential Center in Boston for $519 million (S)

headline: Europeans Drop Lawsuit Contesting Cuba Trade Act
abstract: European Union drops legal challenge to Helms-Burton Act, under which US can impose penalties on companies that use American properties in Cuba that were seized by Castro Government three decades ago; decision is major step toward defusing dispute over sanctions that has riled trans-Atlantic relations for more than three years; both sides caution they are still far from final settlement of dispute, and that if talks break down, European Union could file new action with World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Acquirer Likes Financial Arena
abstract: Thomas H Lee, who runs buyout firm by same name, says he is interested in buying stakes in financial services companies; Lee says he is looking at such deals since his company sold its holding in two such companies, Freedom Securities Corp and Homeside Inc, recently (S)

headline: NATO Is Inching Closer, But Russians Don't Blink
abstract: US Senate's vote to approve NATO membership for Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic draws little notice in Moscow, although Russians continue to view expansion of alliance as US attempt to take advantage of Russia's current weakness (S)

headline: J. Gordon Lippincott, 89, Dies; Pioneer Design Consultant
abstract: J Gordon Lippincott, product designer, dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: Nomura Gets Stake in Hardage Hotels
abstract: Nomura Asset Capital Corp says it will acquire 35 percent interest in Hardage Suite Hotels LLC for $81.5 million (S)

headline: Broadway gets its own platinum card as theaters try a unified approach to mass marketing.
abstract: League of American Theaters and Producers begins promoting next week 'Live Broadway' platinum Visa credit card in effort to stimulate demand nationwide for live theater and, essentially, establish 'Broadway' as highly visible brand; card will be offered jointly by league and First USA Bank, subsidiary of Banc One Corp (M)

headline: Bringing Asia on Line; Hong Kong Tycoon Seeks Internet Success
abstract: Richard Li, second son of Hong Kong's most prominent tycoon, Li Ka-shing, plans to start digital media company to provide Internet access and other information services to television sets and personal computers throughout Asia; map; chart; photo (M)

headline: FONOROLA ADVISES HOLDERS TO ACCEPT NEW OFFER
abstract: Fonorola Inc, reversing stand, advises shareholders to accept Call-Net Enterprises Inc's sweetened $1.97 billion (Canadian) takeover offer after failing to attract superior bids from abroad (S)

headline: High Technology, High Rewards
abstract: A new Morgan Stanley Dean Witter index that goes by the ungainly name of Deep UV Photolithography Food Chain tracks the performance of five companies that make equipment used for etching tiny wires into the surface of microchips. The demand for this equipment has made these companies investor favorites.

headline: Qwest Expected to Announce New Senior Management Team
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc plans to announce its new senior management team after merger with LCI International Inc is completed; most of LCI's top executives will remain with Qwest; H Brian Thompson, LCI's chairman and chief executive, will become Qwest's vice chairman; Joseph P Nacchio will remain Qwest's president and chief executive; Philip F Anschutz will remain chairman (M)

headline: Pirelli Stops Talks For Cable Maker Stake
abstract: Pirelli SpA aborts talks to buy Telecom Italia SpA's 39 percent stake in Sirti SpA, Italian cable maker, as part of $740 million (US) transaction, because two companies could not agree on company's value (S)

headline: U.N., Stymied by Congo Leader, Halts Inquiry on Rwanda Killings
abstract: United Nations suspends its investigation into allegations of massacres of Rwandan refugees in Congo, after weeks of harassment and detention of Canadian member of team, Christopher Harland; United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights Mary Robinson says there is no longer any excuse for behavior of Pres Laurent Kabila's Government in Congo (M)

headline: Bogota Halts Unit Faulted Over Rights
abstract: Colombian army intelligence brigade suspected of links to political killings will be disbanded (S)

headline: Vivendi Sells Its Stake In Electrafina of Belgium
abstract: Vivendi SA sells 24.6 percent stake in Electrafina SA to Groupe Bruxelles Lambert for $1.2 billion (S)

headline: House Acts to Ease 30's Banking Curbs By One-Vote Margin
abstract: House, 214-213, approves banking bill that would overturn Depression-era curbs on financial services industries; bill allows for merging of banks, securities firms and insurance companies into huge financial conglomerates able to operate globally with far fewer regulatory restrictions; Speaker Newt Gingrich worked floor and kept Republican votes in line amid intensive lobbying by competitng groups; passage in Senate is not certain, although Senate approved similar bills in previous years, when House balked; Clinton Administration says it favors modernization of financial industry, but opposes bill provision to shift regulatory authority from Treasury to Federal Reserve; table (M)

headline: House Is Set To Revisit Bill On Bank Rules
abstract: US House of Representatives is expected to revisit on May 13 legislation that would rewrite nation's banking laws and allow for new combinations of financial services companies (S)

headline: Newest Data Ease Concerns About Rate Increase by Fed
abstract: Commerce Dept reports retail sales rose for fifth time in six months in April, while producer prices hardly changed for everyone except smokers; Labor Dept says producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in April, first increase in seven months; core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, also rose two-tenths of percent; higher tobacco costs accounted for about half of that increase; Federal Reserve's policy committee to meet May 19 to decide whether economy's strength means interest rate increase is needed to prevent inflation from accelerating; analysts say latest reports offer little reason for concern; graphs (M)

headline: PC Makers Cool to Microsoft's Push for WebTV
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in effort to bundle its WebTV for Windows software with Windows 98, is offering manufacturers sigificant discounts on Windows 98 software if they agree to install television-tuner cards as standard equipment on their new computers; cards, which cost about $50 to $130, enable computer users to watch television on their monitors; few. if any, manufacturers say they intend to take advantage of Microsoft's offer, noting experience has shown that consumers are not interested in watching television on their computers (M)

headline: Decisions Reached In Account Reviews
abstract: AMF Bowling Inc chooses Richards Group for its advertising account, with billings of about $10 million to $15 million; account had been handled by Mumford Marketing, which will continue to handle promotional projects; Wyndham Resorts, part of Wyndham Hotels and Resorts, selects Harris Drury Cohen as first agency to handle its account; billings estimated at $10 million; Andrew Jergens Co, unit of Kao Corp, decides to keep Bozell Worldwide as creative agency for Curel moisturizing lotion (S)

headline: U.S. Argues Against Strongly Independent War Crimes Prosecutor
abstract: Bill Richardson, US representative at United Nations, says efforts to create fully independent war crimes prosecutor are unrealistic and unwise, UN conference in Rome on establishing international criminal court; angers human rights groups by warning against turning court into 'human rights ombudsman' that must respond to any and all complaints from any source (M)

headline: Judge Tries To Find Cause Of Car Crash Fatal to Diana
abstract: Judge Herve Stephan begins closed-door hearings in Paris on whether responsibility for car crash that killed Diana, Princess of Wales, and Emad Mohamed al-Fayed lies with any of the photographers and motorcyclists who were following the couple that night (M)

headline: Lois/USA Forms Health Care Unit
abstract: Lois/USA Inc forms Lois/Health Care, which will operate as part of Lois/EJL New York agency and specialize in health-related accounts; Ray Hilton will be executive vice president and managing director at Lois/Health Care (S)

headline: Deciphering Those Growls
abstract: Q. When my computer is idling, without screen-saver or antivirus programs running, I still hear occasional hard-disk action. What is it doing?

headline: Gore, in Mideast, Prods Sides Before Talks
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore meets with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv and Yasir Arafat in West Bank city of Ramallah to press for breakthrough at impeding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks; meets with Pres Hosni Mubarak and other Egyptian officials in Cairo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Toymax Inc ad account to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, which had been handled in-house; billings estimated at $13 million; Foundation Health Systems Inc ad account to Cadwell Davis Partners, which had been handled by various agencies; DeGeorge Home Alliance Inc to Friedland Jacobs Communications as first agency to handle advertising for company; billings estimated at $5 million to $7 million; T G Madison is awarded ad accounts for American Cancer Society, Atlanta, for its national office, and Double-Cola Co-USA; billings for two accounts estimated at $10 million; Wilmington Trust Corp ad account to Korey Kay & Partners, which had been handled by Barasch, Galterio & Partners; billings estimated at $7 million (S)

headline: Southland to Buy Stores
abstract: Southland Corp agrees to buy 132 Christy's Market Inc stores, enhancing its presence in New England; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Russian Premier Sees No Need For More Crisis Loans 'So Far'
abstract: Russian Prime Min Sergei V Kiriyenko says, in Moscow television interview, that country so far does not need emergency international loans to pull it out of financial crisis (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: A WORLD OF ARMS: A Deal Under Suspicion; For U.S., Gun Sales Are Good Business
abstract: A World of Arms, series on spread of arms around the world, focuses on soaring legal US exports of small arms; notes that worries inside US Government that such sales might supply terrorists and guerrillas or strengthen governments with poor human rights records are routinely submerged by business interests; private trade in small arms has soared from annual sales of $2 billion to $3 billion during cold war to over $25 billion in 1996; $3.4 million sale of small arms to Solomon Islands illustrates problem (M)

headline: Man in the News: Andres Pastrana; 'Stoolpigeon' to President
abstract: Profile of Colombian Pres-elect Andres Pastrana; Pastrana, hounded in 1994 for releasing recordings of Pres Ernesto Samper's campaign officials soliciting contributions from drug lords, defeated Horacio Serpa by firm margin amid record voter turnout; calls for peace talks with leftist rebels and invites United States to play role in talks; photo (M)

headline: ARMY OUT IN FORCE TO HALT PROTESTS AIMED AT SUHARTO
abstract: Thousands of anti-Government protestors gather outside Parliament building in Jakarta, Indonesia, chanting for removal of Pres Suharto, despite massive show of military force aimed at preventing demonstration; relations between protestors and troops appear friendly; cheering students escort two truckloads of soldiers onto grounds; Parliament, which has been occupied by students for three days, has become focal point of nation's defiance of Pres Suharto, who has rejected widespread calls for resignation while still promising new national elections; photos (M)

headline: Korean Air, Bucking a Trend, Will Buy 27 Boeing 737 Jets
abstract: Korean Air Lines, bucking trend that has seen many Asian airlines delay orders for new airplanes as result of region's economic crisis, plans to announce next week that it is buying 27 new Boeing 737 passenger jets valued at $1.35 bilion (M)

headline: As World Cup Looms, Paris Seeks End to Airline Strike
abstract: Prime Min Lionel Jospin says that French Govt is ready to step in and push Air France pilots and management to settle a strike that has grounded most of airline's flights just as hundreds of thousands of soccer fans begin to pour in for World's Cup soccer tournament; with Air France the official carrier of games, which start on June 10, strike over management demand that its highly compensated pilots take $26,000 pay cut in exchange for company stock has embarrassed country; photo (M)

headline: Some Cross-Border Deals May Be Star-Crossed
abstract: Merger of Daimler-Benz AG and Chrysler Corp is latest example of companies choosing to enter new market by merging or acquiring company already there; Security Data Co says cross-border deals--in which a company in one country acquires a company in another--completed last year totaled $320.5 billion, or more than double their value of $132.3 billion in 1994; huge problems that often occur in cross-border deals discussed; chart (L)

headline: MEDICARE CHANGES PROMPT JOB CUTS AT VENCOR
abstract: Vencor Inc, second-largest nursing home operator in US, will cut as many as 1,100 jobs to save more than $100 million a year as it gets ready for change in Medicare payments (S)

headline: Peruvian Premier Offers to Quit in Dispute Over Jailed American
abstract: Peruvian Prime Min Javier Valle Riestra says he offered to resign after Pres Alberto K Fujimori rejected his idea to pardon American Lori Helene Bereson, jailed for life on terrorism charges, radio interview; stand that her trial was legally flawed sparked storm of protest in Peru's Congress; Fujimori declined resignation (M)

headline: After Lots of Late Nights, Baby Bonds With Computer
abstract: Letter from Kenn Fong on Apr 16 article on staying up late to use Internet (S)

headline: Clinton Predicts a Safer and Richer Europe
abstract: Pres Clinton hails Senate approval of NATO membership for Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic, saying it will make Europe safer for its citizens and a more prosperous trading partner for US; comments to workers at Therma Inc in Palo Alto, supplier to high-tech industry; Clinton is in California to visit daughter at Stamford, and to raise money for Democratic candidates in Silicon Valley and Los Angeles (S)

headline: Bermuda, facing a host of competitors, rolls out a campaign to revive its tourism industry.
abstract: Bermuda, hoping to rejuvenate its slumping tourist industry, is trying yet another advertising campaign, its third in recent years; Radio Bermuda, which began March 30 and runs through June 30, will consist of 540 different one-minute commercials during morning and evening drive time on three radio stations each in five US cities; new campaign is by DDB Needham New York; budget of almost $12 million includes about $8 million, for advertising, split almost evenly between radio and print (L)

headline: Rubin Could Find China The Easiest Part of His Trip
abstract: Interview with US Treas Sec Robert Rubin, whose visit to China may be easiest part of trip to Far East; has been subject to fresh volley of criticism from Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, who accuses US Government of plotting with Wall Street to take over Asian economies (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stocks Surge On Run-Up in Microsoft  Technology stocks extended their rally on a correct bet by investors that Microsoft would report better-than-expected earnings after the market closed. Microsoft shares rose 4.2 percent, to a record high, and the Nasdaq index rose 13.74 points, to 1,917.61, its fourth straight record.     Bank shares also strengthened on further speculation about takeovers after the Bank of New York announced an unsolicited offer for Mellon. But the broader market was mixed, and the Dow Jones average fell 8.22 points, to 9,176.72. [Page D8.]

headline: New Plan for Junk E-Mail Is Dividing Internet Camps
abstract: Legislation to control spam, junk E-mail flooding the Internet, has driven wedge between two camps of Internet activists: free-speech advocates who favor wording of bill and anti-spam crusaders who seek outright ban; bill passed by Senate would require that all unsolicited commercial E-mail contain actual name, postal address, E-mail address and phone number of sender; would also obligate senders of junk E-mail to honor recipients' requests to be removed from mailing lists; would grant authority to Federal Trade Commission to investigate complaints and impose civil fines of up to $15,000 (M)

headline: U.N. INVESTIGATORS OF CONGO KILLINGS TO BE WITHDRAWN
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan expected to announce that he will pull team of United Nations human rights investigators out of Congo after months of harassment and obstruction of their work; team of 26 foreign experts and at least as many Congolese is investigating reports that tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees were massacred in 1996 and 1997 by troops loyal to Laurent Kabila, now President of Congo, formerly Zaire; human rights groups say UN team's expertise in forensic examination of exhumed bodies became threat to Congolese officials who do not want full accounting of deaths; rights groups claim Congo is sliding back into repression since overthrow of Mobutu Sese Seko last May; UN officials reportedly seek help of governments with influence in region to assure safe withdrawal of UN team and evidence they have collected (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen reverses four-day slide on speculation that leading industrialized nations will discuss support for yen at meeting next week; dollar falls to 138.83 yen from 139.70 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Georgia Bank Purchase
abstract: The Regions Financial Corporation agreed today to buy the VB&T Bancshares Corporation for about $18.1 million in stock, expanding its banking operations in Georgia. Regions, which is based in Birmingham, said that the purchase of VB&T, which is based in Valdosta, Ga., would give Regions an additional $75 million in assets. Shares of Regions fell 68.75 cents, to $42.50, in Nasdaq trading today.

headline: A Dictator's Rise and Fall
abstract: Chronology of key events in life of Pol Pot, leader of Cambodia's Khmer Rouge (S)

headline: Role of Military: A Potential Unifier Split by Conflicting Goals
abstract: Key to Indonesia's future lies increasingly in hands of its powerful military, as nation suffers its worst crisis in 30 years, its capital seething with rage and Pres Suharto struggling to keep control; the one institution with an efficient nationwide orgn, and one institution that enjoys broad support among most Indonesians, may ultimately decide whether it is time for Suharto to heed widespread calls to step aside afer 32 years in power; Suharto has worked hard to insure loyalty of military, appointing his supporters to all top positions (News analysis) (M)

headline: In the Wings: Euro as Potential Rival to the Dollar
abstract: Single European currency could be new rival to US dollar, which has reigned supreme in global finance; 11 nations of European Union that have chosen to participate in first stage of monetary union will take big step this weekend toward making long-planned single currency a reality: they will lock their exchange rates together in preparation for program's formal start on Jan 1, 1999; international influence of new currency, the euro, will depend on economic strength of European partners; given high unemployment rates and other problems afflicting Continent, the new system's success cannot be taken for granted; graphs (L)

headline: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICATIONS IN 2 RADIO STATION DEALS
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc will buy six radio stations in West Palm Beach, Fla, for $85 million in cash from Fairbanks Communications Inc and then swap three of the stations as well as another one in Florida for WTPX-FM of Palm Beach, and $47 million in cash from James Crystal Broadcasting (S)

headline: Worries About Prices and Profits Send Dow 39.11 Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 39.11 points, closing at 9,132.37, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 4.42 points, to 1,114.64; Nasdaq composite index falls 10.76 points, to 1,820.99; graph; chart (M)

headline: Luxury Rentals Adding T-1 To Drmn and Hdwd Flrs
abstract: Luxury apartment buildings in Manhattan are drawing tenants who spend much time on line with lure of T-1 connectivity; the high-speed data line carries information up to 50 times as fast as a conventional modem; photos; chart (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Invest in Workers for Best Child Care
abstract: Article by Rosemary Jordano and Marie Oates focuses on recent foray of big business into child care industry; drawing (M)

headline: Clinton Urges Latin America to 'Be Patient' on Free Trade
abstract: Pres Clinton pleads with leaders of Latin America to be patient with United States as it conducts a painful internal political debate over merits of free trade throughout hemisphere, speech, Santiago, Chile; Clinton is in Chile for Latin American summit meeting dedicated to creating hemispheric duty-free shop from Yukon to Tierra del Fuego; Clinton photo with Chilean Pres Eduardo Frei (M)

headline: Free Fall Not Seen for the Pound Despite Soros Rumblings
abstract: George Soros, the man who broke the Bank of England six years ago, is said to be betting against the pound sterling once again; experts say sterling is not going to collapse because economic conditions are different and structure of foreign exchange is different than six years ago; graph; chart (L)

headline: Samsung in Talks to Sell Units and Consolidate
abstract: Samsung Group says it is in talks to sell some of its units to General Electric and Hewlett-Packard as part of move to raise $13 billion to repay debt and reduce sprawling organization to five main businesses; Samsung's announcement is latest response to criticism from Pres Kim Dae Jung of South Korea that corporate debt and inefficiency helped cause Korean debt crisis (M)

headline: Richard L. Rosenthal, a Utilities Entrepreneur, Is Dead at 82
abstract: Richard L Rosenthal, former Citizens Utilities head, dies at age 82; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.39   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.99   4.96   4.94        6-month T-bills   5.16   5.11   5.20        10-yr. headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of oil jumps for second day on optimism that reductions promise by some OPEC members will shrink a surplus; July contracts rise 62 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $12.50 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: With 'No More Pol Pot,' the 'New' Khmer Rouge Hopes the World Will Forgive and Forget
abstract: Khmer Rouge spokesman is optimistic that world will forgive and forget atrocities it committed between 1975 and 1979 now that Pol Pot is dead and Khmer has regrouped into National Solidarity Party; Pol Pot's death seems to have strengthened resolve of international community to capture and try remaining Khmer leaders (M)

headline: MSNBC Leads for the Month As the Top Web News Site
abstract: Media Metric reports that MSNBC drew 4.8 percent of Internet users in Mar, highest of any World Wide Web general news cite; MSNBC has won top rating in 14 out of last 21 months (S)

headline: Despite Furor Over China, Clinton Defends Trade Status
abstract: Pres Clinton says he will renew China's trading privileges despite rising Congressional clamor over whether Chinese Government illegally contributed to his campaign and used protected American technology to improve its missiles (M)

headline: Into the Island Lair of a Currency-Trading Tiger
abstract: Interview with Joseph C Lewis, little-known currency trader who has amassed huge fortune by winning bets that have shaken number of currencies; his role as speculator highlights increasing economic impact of currency trading in world of computerized, global finance; graphs; photos (L)9

headline: Rolling Stone Magazine Receives a Top Award
abstract: Wenner Media wins three Ellie awards at National Magazine Awards, including one for Rolling Stone in category of general excellence for magazines with circulation of more than a million; awards are sponsored by American Society of Magazine Editors and administered by Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism; Gloria Steinem, who founded Ms magazine, Hugh Hefner of Playboy and Byron Dobell, former editor of Life, New York, Esquire and American Heritage, are inducted into society's hall of fame; list of other winners (M)

headline: U.S. Indicts 26 Mexican Bankers in Laundering of Drug Funds
abstract: Federal grand jury, after three-year undercover sting, charges three Mexican banks and 26 Mexican bankers with laundering millions of dollars in drug profits; Treas Sec Robert E Rubin and Atty Gen Janet Reno, announcing indictment, say case is first to directly link Mexican banks and bank officials to laundering of United States drug proceeds for Colombia's Cali cartel and Mexico's Juarez cartel; banks are Bancomer and Banca Serfin, Mexico's second- and third-largest banks, and Banca Confia, recently acquired by Citibank; Federal Reserve gets temporary cease-and-desist orders against Bancomer and Banca Serfin and three other banks with US branches, Banco Nacional de Mexico, Banco Internacional and Banco Santander of Spain; number of Mexican bankers, lured to US through various ruses, have been arrested (M)

headline: Filling Power Vacuum: Will Army Rule?
abstract: Resignation of Pres Suharto raises question of who will hold reins of power in Indonesia; Suharto may intend to retain control through his protege and successor, B J Habibie; role of armed forces, dominant and most cohesive power in nation, is unclear (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/  A shareholder frustrated by persistently weak performance wants to shake up the John Nuveen Company. By Edward Wyatt.

headline: World News Briefs; Volkswagen Faces Suit Over Jewish Slave Labor
abstract: Klaus von Munchhausen, lecturer at Bremen University, says he is suing Volkswagen, seeking payment of wages to 30 Jewish slave laborers who were forced to work for the company during Nazi era; action is a blunt reminder of Volkswagen's roots not only as Hitler's favored car company--the idea of a Volkswagen, or 'people's car' was a pet prewar project--but also as a key player in the Nazi armaments industry (M)

headline: Disney's Quarterly Earnings Rise 21.5%
abstract: Walt Disney Co says earnings rose 21.5 percent in second quarter; company earned $384 million compared with $316 million in year-earlier period; revenue edged up to $5.24 billion, from $5.22 billion; Disney announces 3-for-1 stock split and plans to increase its buyback stock plan (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; News Corp. To Sell Shares In New Unit
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp plans to sell to public up to 20 percent of new company, Fox Group, which will own its American film, television and sports businesses, including 20th Century Fox, Fox Television and Los Angeles Dodgers; analysts note News Corp has not yet disclosed how much debt Fox Group will carry; News Corp stock rises sharply on announcement; table; stock price graph (M)

headline: M.S. Gilman, 76, Builder
abstract: Marvin S Gilman, builder and developer for nearly 50 years in New York, Maryland and Delaware, died on April 8 at age 76 (S)

headline: Film Spins Off a Small Galaxy of Screen Toys
abstract: Screen Gab column on New Line Cinema's innovative Web site promoting movie Lost in Space; drawing (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: Gateway offers new computer purchasing program that includes customized PC, software, unlimited Internet access and right to trade in computer for newer model every two to four years (S)

headline: Increased Production Compounds Problems for Gold
abstract: Main problems for gold prices have been selling and lending of gold by world's central banks, increased hedging by producers in attempt to lock in higher gold prices, and continued downward pressure from investors and hedge funds that have sold gold short, betting that its price will decline; graphs (M)

headline: Jobs Surged By 300,000 Last Month
abstract: Labor Department reports US employers added nearly 300,000 new jobs in May, and unemployment held steady at almost unbelievably low 4.3 percent, lowest in 28 years; economic remains robust despite Asian woes, with spending soaring in areas from cars to business equipmentness equipment; graphs (M)

headline: Cirrus Logic and Lucent To Use ARM Processor
abstract: ARM Holdings PLC shares jump after Cirrus Logic Inc and Lucent Technologies Inc say they will work with semiconductor maker on chips to improve disk drive performance; graph (S)

headline: Uproar Over Jailing of Teheran Mayor Reveals Political Divisions in Iran
abstract: Outcry in Iran over detention of Teheran's powerful mayor, Gholamhossein Karbaschi, in corruption probe exposes deep schisms between moderates who won last year's elections, and conservatives who have dominated since Islamic Revolution; Karbaschi is close ally of Pres Mohammed Khatami, moderate cleric who swept to power last May, but supporters have been powerless to reverse arrest by judiciary leaders who report to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei; more than four dozen municipal officials have been charged with corruption, although mayor is being held without charge; Karbaschi has been mayor since 1989, giving priority to beautification efforts that have added many parks and roads, while also heading powerful political machine that aided Khatami; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Rally After Moves To Bolster Yen
abstract: US stock market stages powerful rally after US and Japan buy yen to bolster sagging economy, which has threatened to plunge Asia into deeper economic crisis; Dow Jones industrial average soars 164.17 points, or 1.89 percent, to close at 8,829.46; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 19.52, or 1.79 percent, to 1,107.11, and Nasdaq composite gains 1.33 percent, to 1,776,40; at midday break on June 18, Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 4.4 percent, or 647.11 points, to 15,362.49; graph; charts (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls 1.5 percent after Japan fails to propose dramatic new economic stimulants during weekend meeting of Group of Seven, richest industrialized nations; dollar rises to 138.16 yen in New York from 136.10; graph; chart (S)

headline: American Airlines' Chief To Step Down
abstract: Robert L Crandall will retire as chairman and chief executive of American Airlines in mid-May; will be succeeded by Donald J Carty, who is airline's president (M)

headline: Washington Memo; The Horror Of Bosnia Draws Only a Few
abstract: Rep Christopher H Smith convenes Congressional hearing exploring West's inaction while thousands of Muslims were massacred by Bosnian Serb soldiers at United Nations 'safe haven' of Srebrenica in July 1995; says US and UN should make public what they knew at time about possibility of mass killing and why they did not or could not stop it; only three members of Congress attend hearing; map; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy
abstract: Pres Clinton will nominate Asst State Sec Jeffrey Davidow as Ambassador to Mexico, post vacant for almost 10 months because of wrangling with Senate over Clinton's first choice, William F Weld; photo (M)

headline: Piano Suite, New on Market, Uses Variety to Fan Interest
abstract: Bruce Headlam reviews piano playing instructional computer software from Adventus; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls on indications Bank of Japan might cut interest rates to boost economy; graphs; tables (S)

headline: LIBRARY/WEB-SITE SOFTWARE; Home Page: Pared Down But Versatile
abstract: Harold Goldberg reviews Web-site development package for beginners from Filemaker; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo's First-Quarter Earnings Exceed Expectations of Analysts
abstract: Yahoo Inc reports first-quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street analysts' expectations; company earned $4.3 million, compared with loss of $740,000 in quarter a year earlier; revenue tripled, to $30.2 million (S)

headline: Moody's Plans to Review Its Ratings for Malaysia
abstract: Moody's may cut Malaysia's credit rating because of economic contraction (S)

headline: PAKISTAN SETS OFF ATOM TEST AGAIN, BUT URGES 'PEACE'
abstract: Pakistan explodes another nuclear test device, spurning worldwide criticism and calls for restraint after its nuclear tests two days ago; Shamshad Ahmad Khan, senior official in Foreign Ministry, indicates nuclear weapons can now be swiftly made ready for use; says test concludes the series; holds Pakistan is ready to 'talk peace' with India and that it is not Pakistan's purpose to enter into arms race; Pakistani tests come two weeks after India exploded what it said were five nuclear devices; US, which has imposed economic sanctions on Pakistan and India, condemns latest Pakistani test; test is conducted in remote Baluchistan region of desert and mountains near Iranian border where previous tests by Pakistan were conducted; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Auto Giants Detail Deal, But Challenges Remain  Officials of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler made their $39 billion wedding official. They plan to form a global auto giant making luxury Mercedes-Benz cars as well as Cherokee Jeeps and Voyager mini-vans.

headline: Two-Day Rally in Treasury Market Ends
abstract: Treasury market ends its two-day rally; 30-year bond falls 1/32, to price of 102 22/32, to yield 5.93 percent, unchanged from end of last week (S)

headline: North Korea Says It Will Unseal Reactor
abstract: North Korea suspends implementation of 1994 accord to dismantle its nuclear program, saying United States has not honored pledge to send fuel oil; plans to unseal closed nuclear reactor at Yong Byon; has barred technicians from packing last of reactor's spent fuel rods for shipment out of nation; rods contain plutonium that can be used in nuclear arms (M)

headline: China Cancels 3 Visas Issued To Radio Free Asia Reporters
abstract: China cancels visas for three Radio Free Asia journalists who planned to cover Pres Clinton's visit; Clinton scores move; Radio Free Asia scores Clinton's failure to challenge move by letting journalists board jet chartered by White House for news organizations covering trip (S)

headline: Airbus Profits Hurt By a Price War
abstract: Airbus Industrie posts 61 percent drop in its profit for 1997 as European plane maker is squeezed by price war with its archrival Boeing Co; profit was 268 million marks ($147 million) (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Finds Economy Is Extraordinarily Sound  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, declared the economy to be in extraordinarily good shape and signaled that he saw no immediate need to strike against inflation by raising interest rates.    His testimony before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress was sprinkled with caveats about how the combination of low unemployment and strong growth could eventually force the Fed to raise rates. But for now price pressures are subdued and Asia's crisis is taking some of the steam out of the American economy. [Page A1.]

headline: INDONESIAN LEADER PICKS NEW CABINET AND VOWS REFORMS
abstract: Indonesia's new President, B J Habibie, names compromise Cabinet that sweeps out daughter and best friend of resigned leader Suharto and brings in members of other parties, but also keeps half of previous lineup; Gen Wiranto, most powerful military figure, keeps Defense post; key economics officials also remain, even as Habibie promises to push forward with reforms demanded by IMF; supporters of opposition leaders, Megawati Sukarnoputri and Muslim Amien Rais, decline to join Cabinet; demonstrators occupying Parliament grounds reject Cabinet and continue to call for special electoral assembly to create new government; Habibie, addressing nation for first time, outlines plans for reform, clean government and economic responsibility; says he is impressed by pro-democracy movement that brought down Suharto; 67-year-old protege of Suharto has never held important administrative post and does not have strong political or military base, suggesting he may be only transitional figure; Gen Wiranto reportedly persuaded Suharto to leave rather than face impeachment (M)

headline: Insurer Buys Unit of Aetna For $1 Billion
abstract: Lincoln National Corp agrees to pay Aetna Inc $1 billion for its US individual life insurance business; Lincoln National, nation's 10th-largest United States life insurer, plans to merge Aetna unit with its Hartford, Conn-based life insurance business, and reduce its payrolls by attrition (S)

headline: Deals Lift Lycos Stock
abstract: Shares of Lycos Inc rise almost 16 percent after Internet-search directory company says it has received contracts worth $30 million over several years, more than all revenue it had last year (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.38   5.36   5.45        3-month T-bills   4.99   5.02   4.94        6-month T-bills   5.12   5.09   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.71   3.70   3.64        10-yr. T-note   5.46   5.46   6.41        30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.66   6.70        Telephone bd.   7.10   7.10   7.77        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.22   5.62          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems; The Bond Buyer

headline: Power Broker Ousted by Disney Challenges Ex-Boss on Broadway
abstract: Michael Ovitz, former Hollywood power broker forced out as Walt Disney president 16 months ago, returns to entertainment business by taking effective control of Livent Inc, financially ailing theater company; will buy 2.5 million shares of Livent, or 12 percent of outstanding shares, for $20 million and will take seat on company's board and become chairman of executive committee; hand-picked management team will take over day-to-day financial control of company from Garth Drabinsky, impresario who built company from single production in single theater in Toronto into roster of shows and network of five theaters, including new Ford Center for the Performing Arts in Times Square; announcement follows company report of 1997 losses of $30 million, compared with profit of $7.4 million in 1996 (M)

headline: Yeltsin to Ask Western Help for Ruble as Markets Steady
abstract: Pres Boris Yeltsin will ask Western leaders to help defend Russian rubble, even as Russian financial markets steady slightly after record plunge; Yeltsin will ask Pres Clinton and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl to support Russia as it plans new round of spending cuts and more vigorous tax collecting; tells foreign investors there will be no collapse, that central bank and finance ministry have enough reserve funds to stay afloat; IMF envoy John Odling-Smee arrives to confirm $700-million installment of $10 billion loan; Anatoly B Chubais will talk with officials in Washington; deputy minister Oleg Vyugin says Russia needs psychological boost of more foreign credits, even if they are not needed; photo; Russian RTS stock index gains 6.2 percent, winning back most of previous day's losses; key test will be auction of Government-backed bonds at interest rate of 150 percent; Yeltsin warns that 'heads will roll' unless tax collectors improve dismal collection rates (M)

headline: Deal Will Save Tax Money, Lockheed and Northrop Say
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp and Northrop Grumman Corp, responding to Justice Department antitrust suit, hold their proposed merger would spur competition, save taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars a year and make military industry more efficient, Federal court (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00        Federal funds   5.44   5.35   5.56        3-month T-bills   5.05   5.06   4.97        6-month T-bills   5.13   5.14   5.22        10-yr. T-infl.   3.75   3.76   3.59        10-yr. T-note   5.60   5.65   6.72        30-yr. T-bond   5.89   5.93   6.95        Telephone bd.   7.11   7.14   7.96        Municipal bds.   5.24   5.26   5.76          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Dow Jones  Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Windows 98: $90 Worth Of Duct Tape
abstract: Article evaluates Windows 98 software as being a minimal renovation of Windows 95 that patches some holes but leaves many problems unsolved; recommends upgrading to the new program only if it offers some especially needed feature; photos (M)

headline: HERTZ AGREES TO BUY FRENCH EQUIPMENT RENTAL COMPANY
abstract: Hertz Corp will acquire Boireau Group, French equipment rental concern (S)

headline: Argentina to Seek Extradition Of 2 Executives From U.S.
abstract: Argentina will seek extradition from US of two current and two former IBM executives, amid allegations that company gave Government officials up to $21 million in bribes in exchange for lucrative bank contract (M)

headline: Wake-Up Call: Truisms Of U.S. Policy Totter
abstract: R W Apple Jr analysis contends that several of hopes and assumptions of post-cold-war era have been shaken by momentous events in Asia; maintains that collapse of Pres Suharto's rule in Indonesia and detonation of nuclear devices by India and Pakistan have forced rethinking in Washington and other Western capitals of ideas that had come to be policy truisms; holds that widely acknowledged ascendancy of US commercial and economic interests over strategic and other goals, which led to subordination of human-rights considerations in region, is likely to be questioned much more sharply then previously (M)

headline: Insider Traders In White Coats; Drug Researchers in Rare Position to Exploit Stocks
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission has brought spate of insider-trading cases involving clinical drug trials; charges some researchers and their friends trade drug stocks on results of trials before results are made public; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Economic Scene; Few see bank consolidation as a harbinger of doomsday.
abstract: Peter Passell column on wave of gigantic bank mergers says most economists believe industry consolidation threatens neither competitiveness nor stability of banking; Bert Ely, banking consultant, Prof George Bentson of Emory University, Prof Alan S Blinder of Princeton and Prof Lawrence White of NYU comment; drawing (L)

headline: Magazines Revise Their Mastheads
abstract: Reader's Digest Association Inc names Bernadette Harrison Haley, vice president and publisher of US edition of The Reader's Digest; Haley succeeds Dick Porter, who resigned; Haley had been associate publisher of Good Housekeeping magazine; she will be succeeded there by Sean K Sullivan; at Teen People magazine, Anne Zehren is named publisher, assuming duties from Nora McAniff, who continues as publisher of People magazine; Zehren had been associate publisher at Glamour magazine; at Glamour, Vanessa Reed is named to succeed Zehren as associate publisher; Reed had been associate publisher at People for almost six years; at The Advocate magazine, owned by Liberation Publications Inc, Joe Landry, associate publisher, is promoted to publisher, succeeding Sam Watters, who continues as president at Liberation Publications; at Money magazine, Geoffrey Dodge, publisher, is adding additional responsibilities, including consumer marketing and new-business development; he assumes those duties from Michael Pepe, who continues as president of Business Information Group at Time Inc (S)

headline: John Wesley Jones, 90, a Retired Diplomat
abstract: John Wesley Jones, retired Foreign Service officer, Ambassador to Libya and Peru and former deputy commandant of National War College, died on May 20 at age 90/

headline: Road Races Are a Challenge But Graphics Don't Keep Up
abstract: Joseph Siano, editor at The Times who covered auto racing for the paper from 1989 to 1997, evaluates CD-ROM game Cart Precision Racing, from Microsoft; photo (M)

headline: AT&T Results Get a Tepid Reception
abstract: AT&T Corp releases quarterly earnings that modestly exceed analysts' expectations; company's revenues grew by less than 1 percent, disappointing investors, who shave more than $3 billion from company's market value; AT&T reports earnings of $1.326 billion compared with profits of $1.126 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue was $12.631 billion or about seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than company's $12.548 billion in revenue during first quarter of last year; chairman C Michael Armstrong comments; chart (L)

headline: At CBS News, Win a Few and Lose a Few
abstract: CBS News president Andrew Heyward's focus on earning attention, ratings and profits without compromising CBS News's prestige discussed in light of his recent failures and successes; CBS Corp president Mel Karmazin comments, phone interview; photos (M)

headline: Man in the News -- Richard C. Holbrooke; A Tough Man (Some Say Brutal) for a Tough Job
abstract: Man in the News profile of Richard Charles Albert Holbrooke, named by Pres Clinton as chief American representative at United Nations; photo (M)

headline: A campaign for Forbes raises some internal hackles.
abstract: Forbes is running what it intends as humorous new ad campaign; but some editors and writers at magazine are not laughing; campaign, designed by Merkley Newman Harty, features tag line 'Fearless writers. Tireless editors. Business reporting as tough as business itself.' campaign is meant to point up notorious comments often scribled in margins of Forbes's articles in progress, some of most scathing of which have been known to come from James W Michaels, magazine's top editor; photo (L)

headline: 2 MAJOR MERGERS EXPECTED TODAY IN BANK INDUSTRY
abstract: Two huge new banking mergers are expected to accelerate wave of consolidations in financial-services industry and likely leave just few giant powerhouses; expected merger of Nationsbank Corp and BankAmerica Corp will create nation's first coast-to-coast bank, largest in terms of total branches and deposits and nation's second-largest bank holding company in terms of total assets; second expected merger, of Banc One Corp and First Chicago NBD Corp, will create fifth-largest banking company by assets; resulting bank would dominate Midwest; Nationsbank-BankAmerica deal is expected to involve stock-for-stock transaction valued at about $60 billion; Nationsbank's chief executive, Hugh L McColl Jr, is expected to be named chairman of combined company, and David A Coulter, BankAmerica's chairman, is expected to be named president; deal between First Chicago and Banc One has estimated value of $30 billion in stock, with Fist Chicago shareholders receiving 1.62 shares in new company for every share they own and Banc One shareholders getting one share of new company for each share they own; Verne G Istock, First Chicago chairman, will be chairman of new company and John B McCoy, Banc One's chairman, will become president and chief executive (L)

headline: A practical guidebook to technology for the reluctant business executive.
abstract: Book by Larry Downes and Chunka Mui proposes radical strategies for companies to use digital technology to gain market dominance; drawing (M)

headline: For the Weary Rebels of Kosovo, A Brutal Lesson From the Serbs
abstract: Weary ethnic Albanian rebels fighting to set up separate state in Serbian province of Kosovo seem to have embraced disastrous strategy, holding ground against superior Serbian forces for days until retreating with heavy losses; Serbs apparently seek to empty border villages and towns of ethnic Albanians, creating free-fire zone along Albanian border to deny rebels succor and support; tons of weapons and hundreds of rebels have crossed into Kosovo from Albania since fighting intensified in Mar; map; photo (M)

headline: Customer fears and risks have yet to be worked out with airline electronic tickets.
abstract: Commercial airlines are increasingly using electronic tickets in place of paper tickets, but customers, particularly business travelers, remain wary; key problems are traveler's inability to exchange E-ticket from one airline for ticket on another airline and inadequate notification of travelers about tickets outstanding in computer system; drawing (M)

headline: Roland Wolseley, 94, Syracuse Professor
abstract: Roland E Wolseley, journalism teacher who wrote one of first surveys of black press, dies at age 94 (S)

headline: Concerns Over First-Quarter Profits Send Markets Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 76.73 points to close at 8,956.50; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 11.83 points, or 1.05 percent, to 1,109.55; Nasdaq composite inded shows 1.7 percent loss, closing at 1,798.71, down 30.43 points; graph; chart (L)

headline: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.92 percent and on the six-month bill, 5 percent.

headline: Heady Days Return For Textbook Sales
abstract: Despite dire predictions of the death of the printed word, makers of textbooks and instructional materials are having banner years. Last year, purchases of elementary school books increased by 13 percent, to $3 billion, and college texts rose by 7.4 percent, to $2.7 billion.    ''It's a good time for all of us -- all tides are rising,'' said Roby Harrington, the director of the college department for W. W. Norton & Company, who noted that this year 79 of the 123 titles in the Norton Critical Editions series showed higher sales.

headline: What's a good word for updating one's competitive position? At Burnett, it's Vigilante.
abstract: Advertising column on Vigilante, specialty shop opened in New York by Leo Burnett Co, to create advertising campaigns, promotional events and other marketing programs aimed at fledgling niche known as urban consumers: younger trend-setters who have turned aspects of their distinctive culture into mainstream mainstays; principals at Vigilante are Marc Stephenson Strachan, executive vice president and chief marketing and operations officer, and Danny Robinson, executive vice president and creative director; photo (M)

headline: Military Says It Will Allow Civil Protests In Indonesia
abstract: Indonesian military affirms backing for reform movement that is spreading new freedoms through country, but warns of crackdown if protests are destabilizing; armed forces chief, Gen Wiranto, also voices support for Pres B J Habibie, urging people to be patient and allow new Government to pursue reforms; soldiers stand by but do not intervene as 4,000 students demonstrate outside locked gates of Parliament (S)

headline: Panel Weighs Testimony On Insurers Of Nazi Era
abstract: New York State Senate committee reviews evidence of widespread Nazi theft of insurance assets of European Jews in collusion with German and other European insurance companies, hearing, Manhattan; weighs bill to curb ability of European insurers to do business in NY if they failed to pay outstanding claims; Allianz AG, German insurer that would be affected by law, lauds its intent but questions whether it is right way to handle issue; favors voluntary efforts by insurance companies (M)

headline: Museum for the Wyeths to Open in Maine
abstract: ROCKLAND, Maine—  The rocky coastline, rugged landscape and people of Maine have long inspired American artists. Among them have been three generations of one of America's most prominent artistic families — the late N.C. Wyeth, his son Andrew Wyeth and his grandson Jamie Wyeth. The three are now the focus of a new museum and study center that will open on June 21 in the scenic coastal town of Rockland.

headline: U.S. JOINS JAPAN IN SURPRISE MOVE TO SHORE UP YEN
abstract: United States, in surprise move, joins Japan in coordinated effort to halt sharp drop in yen, together buying estimated $4 billion of Japanese currency in foreign-exchange markets; yen rises more than 5 percent within hours; Pres Clinton says he hopes move will stem worsening Asian economic crisis; says he approved move after speaking by phone with Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto, who he says pledged added economic changes; list of actions released later by Japan seem to restate and go only modestly beyond Japan's past agreements; United States apparently also responds to China's threat that it might be forced to devaluate if yen continued to slide, move that would sharply worsen Asian crisis; Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin, who shifted stand to recommend move, insists he his not backing away from strong-dollar policy; graph of yen's changing value over week (M)

headline: ORACLE TO BUY ACTIVA SOFTWARE FROM PRICE WATERHOUSE
abstract: Oracle Corp buys Activa software from Price Waterhouse LLP; terms undisclosed; Price Waterhouse, which developed software, will continue to use it with clients and will receive royalties from license sales (S)

headline: Trade Deficit Rose in March To New High
abstract: Commerce Department reports nation's monthly trade deficit rose to new high of $13 billion in March, providing clearest evidence yet of how Asia's mounting economic problems are restraining American growth; deficit in February was $12.2 billion; deficit in merchandise trade with Pacific Rim nations grew to $12.1 billion in March from $10.5 billion in February and from $6.8 billion in March 1997; for first three months of year, deficit with Pacific Rim was $34.3 billion, $10 billion higher than for period a year earlier; trade deficit with Japan expanded to $5.8 billion in March from $5.3 billion a month earlier; graph (L)

headline: CREDITORS OF BARNEY'S FREE TO FILE RIVAL PLAN
abstract: Creditors of Barney's Inc will be allowed to file rival reorganization plan for retailer under agreement worked out in Federal Bankruptcy Court; Barney's has until June 15 to file its own plan to exit Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; creditors for first time are free to file rival plan in effort to recoup their $350 million in claims; impetus for agreement comes from Barney's biggest unsecured creditors, Bay Harbour Management and Whippoorwill Associates Inc, which together are owed $150 million (S)

headline: Shakers on the Net
abstract: Letter from Joel Cohen in response to Stuart Semmell's letter about Shakers (S)

headline: Levitt Approved Again at S.E.C.
abstract: Nomination of Arthur Levitt Jr to second term as chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission is approved by US Senate (S)

headline: Media Talk; WBAI Makes a Home on Wall Street
abstract: WBAI-FM, left-oriented New York City radio station, moves to new offices on Wall Street, capitalist citadel (S)

headline: EX-PREMIER ADMITS HE LED MASSACRES IN RWANDA IN 1994
abstract: Former Rwandan Prime Min Jean Kambanda pleads guilty to genocide charges before UN tribunal in Tanzania, and promises to testify against former associates concerning deaths of half million people in 1994; Kambanda faces maximum sentence of life in prison and cannot be tried in Rwanda, where some of his formerassociates have been publicly executed; guilty plea is first time prosecutors have cracked wall of silence and denial among Hutu who orchestrated slaughters, and first such guilty plea ever entered before any international tribunal, including Nuremburg; Kambanda was economist and banker and leading figure in radical Hutu party tht came to power after death of president in plane crash in April 1994; he led Government during blood bath, presided at meetings when massacres were planned and personally ordered roadblocks to catch and murder Tutsi (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: International Mobile Communications Inc's ad account to McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising and Weber/Ryan McGinn, both owned by McCann-Erickson World Group; account was previously handled by Rainmaker LLC; billings estimated at $1 million to $3 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. and Japan Buy Yen To Bolster Falling Currency  The United States and Japan bought yen to stop the precipitous fall of the Japanese currency.    The action, which took currency markets by surprise, marks the first time in six years that the United States has sold dollars and purchased yen. President Clinton said he approved the move after speaking by telephone with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, who committed to specific economic reforms that go beyond earlier pledges. [Page A1.]

headline: Hackers' Bazaar; On-Line Auction Services Put Haggling Back Into Sales
abstract: New Web site caled Priceline will allow consumers to bid on airline tickets from some major airlines; it joins more than 150 other sites already running auctions of various sorts on line; other Web sites discussed include Onsale, Ebay, Haggle and Auction Sales; photos (L)

headline: After 300 Years of Auctions, This Tea Break Is Final
abstract: LONDON—  From the rise of the East India Co. in the 17th century through the glory days of the British empire to the country's subsequent decline, tea growers from what is now the Indian province of Assam and the plantations of Kenya and Zimbabwe have come to London to sell their tea at auction.

headline: New Yorker Merger Will Begin Next Month
abstract: Merging of New Yorker magazine into rest of Conde Nast Publications's operations will begin in June; merger was not scheduled to take place until 1999, when Conde Nast moves into new building in Times Square; Conde Nast president-chief executive Steven T Florio comments (S)

headline: Students in Jakarta March Into Parliament
abstract: Hundreds of Indonesian university students demanding reform march peacefully into Parliament in Jakarta for unprecedented meeting with Government officials; are escorted by troops in officially sanctioned protest; call for end to 32-year rule of Pres Suharto; include high-ranking university alumni, retired military generals, poets and actors; photo (M)

headline: Inquiry to Ask if Nazi Loot May Also Be in U.S.
abstract: Clinton Administration and Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, who has led investigations into wealth looted by Nazi Germany, say they will set up commission to determine if any Holocaust-era assets are still in American banks (M)

headline: CBS TO SELL UNIT TO EMERSON ELECTRIC FOR $265 MILLION
abstract: CBS Corp agrees to sell its Westinghouse process-control unit to Emerson Electric Co for $265 million (S)

headline: Can the Internet Be Addictive, Or Is the Problem Elsewhere?
abstract: University of Cincinnati researchers report small study found people who seem unable to curtail number of hours they spend on Internet may suffer from raft of other psychiatric disorders (S)

headline: Free Trade Victory Is Sea Turtles' Loss
abstract: The World Trade Organization ruled yesterday that the United States was wrong to prohibit shrimp imports from countries that fail to protect sea turtles from deadly entrapment in shrimp-boat trawl nets.    The decision by a three-member panel in Geneva was the latest sign that when free trade conflicts with environmental protection, the international trade body is unlikely to swerve from its central mission.

headline: In Search of Cybercafes
abstract: Letter from Jodi Bornstein comments on Apr 16 article on cybercafes (S)

headline: Agreement Draws Scorn From Range Of Europeans
abstract: FRANKFURT—  — Critics across Europe's political spectrum poured scorn Sunday on a compromise over the leadership of the new EuropeanCentral Bank, charging that the weekend's overt deal-making violated the Maastrichttreaty and "deforms" the European Union's single currency at its birth.
